headline: 22-Year Sentence for Man Guilty in Hate-Crime Killing of Asian Immigrant
abstract: Jarrod Powell pleaded guilty to attacking Yao Pan Ma on an East Harlem street because the victim was of Asian descent.
lead_paragraph: A man who admitted to brutally, and fatally, attacking a 61-year-old immigrant in East Harlem two years ago because the victim was Asian was sentenced to 22 years in prison on Friday.

headline: L.S.U. Rallies Against Virginia Tech to Make N.C.A.A. Championship Game
abstract: Angel Reese had 24 points and 12 rebounds as the Tigers took control of the game in the last period.
lead_paragraph: Louisiana State is heading to its first championship game in program history after a rousing fourth quarter rally against top-seeded Virginia Tech, 79-72.

headline: Israeli Police Fatally Shoot Arab in Scuffle at Holy Site in Jerusalem
abstract: The man was shot dead early Saturday at the edge of the Aqsa Mosque compound, known to Jews as the Temple Mount. The circumstances of the killing were disputed and risked raising tensions during Ramadan.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli police shot dead an Arab man early Saturday in disputed circumstances in front of an entrance to the most prominent holy site in Jerusalem, in an episode that risked escalating tensions in the city at an already volatile time.

headline: How Alvin Bragg Resurrected the Case Against Donald Trump
abstract: A year ago, the investigation into the former president appeared from the outside to be over. But a series of crucial turning points led to this week’s indictment.
lead_paragraph: One year ago this week, the Manhattan district attorney’s investigation into Donald J. Trump appeared to be dead in the water.

headline: Cry Heard on April Fools’ Day
abstract: This Saturday collaboration between Wyna Liu and Joel Fagliano looks hard, but it really just looks hard.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — If a puzzle like this one makes you wonder who makes the rules around here, well, Wyna Liu and Joel Fagliano make up at least 20 percent of The New York Times’s crossword nerve center. Individually, they’re constructors of wide repute, but this is their first collaboration; they had tried before, apparently, but their schedules never lined up. To work around that, they agreed to split things up in an interesting way: Ms. Liu composed an entire clue set, Mr. Fagliano constructed a grid full of peppy entries, and then a neutral party reconciled the two halves.

headline: Read the judge’s order
abstract: Judge Thomas L. Parker agreed to delay the implementation of a law limiting drag performance in Tennessee for at least 14 days.
lead_paragraph: Judge Thomas L. Parker agreed to delay the implementation of a law limiting drag performance in Tennessee for at least 14 days.

headline: Judge Temporarily Blocks Tennessee Law That Restricts Drag Performances
abstract: A federal judge put a hold on the law hours before it was to take effect, saying there were legitimate questions about whether it violated the First Amendment.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — A federal judge on Friday temporarily blocked the implementation of a Tennessee law aimed at restricting public drag performances, hours before it was set to go into effect.

headline: Quotation of the Day: The 5-Nation Odyssey of Ukrainian Criminals
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 1, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “There was a war going on. Who had time for inmates?”

headline: Caitlin Clark and Iowa Deliver Toppling Upset of South Carolina in Final Four
abstract: The Gamecocks were considered a heavy favorite to repeat as champions. But Clark and the Hawkeyes delivered, all the way to the championship game against Louisiana State.
lead_paragraph: Many thought that South Carolina winning the national championship this year was a forgone conclusion. Louisiana State’s coach Kim Mulkey told reporters after L.S.U.’s round-of-8 win that South Carolina was “going to be there” in the championship game.

headline: The Beach Boys Making a Final Four Run
abstract: Florida Atlantic has seemingly come out of nowhere to make a deep run in the men’s N.C.A.A. tournament. The university’s ambitions are relatively young, too.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — David Vanterpool has played professional basketball in Italy, China, and Russia and coached in the N.B.A., yet even he was surprised on his first visit to Florida Atlantic University.

headline: A Once Lowly Program Gets a Second Shot at the Top
abstract: San Diego State was poised for a top seed in the 2020 N.C.A.A. tournament before the pandemic led to its cancellation. This year’s team, with three key holdovers, has made a run to the Final Four.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — What once appeared to be the apex of the history of the San Diego State men’s basketball program occurred just over three years ago.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Trump’s G.O.P. Rivals, Shielding Him, Reveal Their 2024 Predicament
abstract: Many of Donald Trump’s potential opponents snapped into line behind him, showing just how hard it may be to persuade Republican voters to choose an alternative.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida took a measured dig at Donald J. Trump by publicly mocking the circumstances that led New York investigators to the former president.

headline: Gift of a Stethoscope to a Refugee Child Inspired a Career of Caring
abstract: Waheed Arian fled the war in Afghanistan when he was a teenager. Now an emergency room doctor in Britain, he has made it his mission to bring hope and healing to others.
lead_paragraph: CHESTER, England — When Waheed Arian was 5, his father knelt by his side and handed him a big, colorful kite. That small moment, in Afghanistan, seared itself into the son’s memory.

headline: Inside Saudi Arabia’s Global Push for Nuclear Power
abstract: Despite qualms in Washington, Saudi officials have pressed the United States to help them develop nuclear power. But they are also exploring other options, including China.
lead_paragraph: For years, Saudi Arabia has pressed the United States to help it develop a nuclear energy program, as Saudi leaders look beyond oil to power their country.

headline: Pope Francis Quips He’s ‘Still Alive’ After Hospital Stay
abstract: The 86-year-old pontiff spent three days undergoing treatment for bronchitis at a hospital in Rome.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis returned to the Vatican on Saturday morning after a three-day hospital stay during which he was treated for bronchitis, raising new concerns about the health of the aging pontiff, who had major surgery in 2021 and now often uses a cane or a wheelchair because of knee problems and sciatica.

headline: The Things They Left Behind: How the U.S. Laid Waste to Southeast Asia
abstract: George Black’s new book, “The Long Reckoning,” describes the environmental devastation of the Vietnam War.
lead_paragraph: The lore of American military logistics celebrates triumphs of sustainment. Take the Civil War “Cracker Line,” a network of wagon roads and pontoon bridges opened in October 1863, which supplied the besieged federal forces at Chattanooga, Tenn.; the Red Ball Express, a truck convoy system established in France in 1944, which moved approximately 12,000 tons of matériel a day for 82 days to supply the Allied advance during World War II; or the monumental staging of the 1991 gulf war, which the general in charge deemed “the largest logistical move in history.”

headline: How Small Businesses Can Find Safety Before the Next Bank Crisis
abstract: Financial advisers recommend that business owners examine their accounts now to ensure they are protected in case of a future bank failure.
lead_paragraph: The collapse of two regional lenders, Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank, last month caused a ripple of panic among small businesses across the country as owners watched the news unfold and wondered whether their assets were safe — even if their deposits were not in one of the failed institutions.

headline: ‘Yellowjackets’ Shows Us the Teenage Girlhood We Were Hungry For
abstract: On set with the hit mystery series, which, amid all the gore, presents one of the most sensitive portraits of women on TV.
lead_paragraph: In a cabin in the wilderness, a group of starving teenage girls, a teenage boy and one adult man wake to an unfamiliar smell. Their noses twitching in the air, they leave their thin blankets and head out into the snowy wild in socks and insufficient clothes. Outside, their friend, whose body they tried to cremate last night, has turned into smoked meat. They surround her corpse, girl-shaped but foodlike, like a pig from the barbecue pit. One of the girls stands near the charred flesh, knife in hand. “She wants us to,” she says. A few moments later, the feast begins.

headline: 10 Places to See Wildflowers in the West
abstract: A ‘super bloom’ may be in the eye of the beholder, but the winter’s rain and snow promises a bumper crop of spring blooms in Southern California and Arizona.
lead_paragraph: With the arrival of spring, there’s a silver, or really, a multicolored lining to the extreme weather that has battered the west all winter: the promise of wildflower-filled weeks and months ahead, particularly in Southern and Central California and Arizona’s Sonoran Desert.

headline: Pablo Picasso, the Pariah of Paris
abstract: As Annie Cohen-Solal shows in “Picasso the Foreigner,” the Spanish master was always under suspicion in France, simply for being not-French.
lead_paragraph: This month’s half-century anniversary of Pablo Picasso’s death (on April 8, 1973) will bring tributes large and small. And a substantial one has already arrived in Annie Cohen-Solal’s “Picasso the Foreigner: An Artist in France, 1900-1973,” an outsize but propulsive read (600 pages in snack-size chapters) with a peppery twofold brief. It’s both a portrait of Picasso, that Zeus of 20th-century modernism, as a cultural outcast, a pariah, and an indictment of the culture — French — that made him one.

headline: April Space Events: Artemis Astronauts, a Journey to Jupiter and More
abstract: Here’s what to expect during the coming month in space and astronomy.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of NASA’s Artemis II moon mission announcement.If you’re looking for space news in April, you won’t have to wait long.

headline: Go Play in the Street, Kids. Really.
abstract: Street Lab is bringing pop-up reading rooms and playgrounds to New York City’s open streets and plazas.
lead_paragraph: Jacqueline Kook and her 5-year-old daughter, Francesca Cabrera, were making their way to the playground when they came upon a reading cart and an obstacle course in the middle of Amsterdam Avenue on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

headline: Security Force or Anti-Arab Militia? Israelis Feud Over Far-Right Plan
abstract: The far-right security minister, Itamar Ben-Gvir, wants to create a national guard that he would control, saying it is needed to guarantee Israel’s security.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — When Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu suspended his contentious plan to overhaul Israel’s judiciary this past week, easing weeks of unrest, he won the support of one of the most right-wing ministers in his coalition by promising to take the first steps toward forming a new national guard that the minister could control.

headline: In ‘Transatlantic,’ Stories of Rescue and Resistance From World War II
abstract: A Netflix series dramatizes the efforts of Varian Fry, an American who helped save some 2,000 people from the Nazis without his government’s support.
lead_paragraph: When Anna Winger, the co-creator of the new Netflix series “Transatlantic,” relocated to the vibrant French port city of Marseille last year, she found a dilapidated villa awaiting her. The “relic,” as she called it, was ideal for her purpose: the recreation of the Villa Air-Bel where, early in World War II, a dapper American named Varian Fry oversaw an extraordinary rescue operation for artists and writers, most of them Jews, hounded by the Nazis and the Vichy government of occupied France.

headline: Indicted and Running for Office? It Didn’t Begin With Trump.
abstract: American politics has a long history of candidates who were indicted or convicted of crimes but sought office again.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump may be the first former president in history to be indicted on criminal charges. But he is hardly the first political candidate — or even the first presidential one — to run for office after being charged with or convicted of crimes.

headline: China Draws Lessons From Russia’s Losses in Ukraine, and Its Gains
abstract: With an eye on a possible conflict over Taiwan, analysts have scrutinized the war for insights ranging from the importance of supply lines to the power of nuclear threats.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of miles from the cities that Russia is bombing in Ukraine, China has been studying the war.

headline: The Last Days of Beckett’s, a Smoky New York Literary Salon
abstract: They came. They drank. They staged plays and argued about Shakespeare. For dozens of up-and-coming writers, actors and artists, it was nice while it lasted.
lead_paragraph: About a year ago, a literary salon sprang to life in a run-down townhouse in the West Village of Manhattan. Dozens of young writers, critics, artists, theater actors and filmmakers started going there almost nightly to drink, smoke, talk, dance and argue, much like their bohemian predecessors in the days before sky-high rents priced poets out of the neighborhood.

headline: The Finnish Secret to Happiness? Knowing When You Have Enough.
abstract: The Nordic nation has been ranked the happiest country on earth for six consecutive years. But when you talk to individual Finns, the reality is a bit more complicated.
lead_paragraph: On March 20, the United Nations Sustainable Development Solutions Network released its annual World Happiness Report, which rates well-being in countries around the world. For the sixth year in a row, Finland was ranked at the very top.

headline: The Lesbian Bar Isn’t Dead. It’s Pouring Orange Wine in Los Angeles.
abstract: Two recent openings testify to the power, and joy, of queer spaces.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — One pleasingly bitter, gently botanical, sort-of purple nonalcoholic cocktail in, and I was just happy to be caught in the gravitational pull of the Ruby Fruit.

headline: Thailand’s Unemployed Elephants Are Back Home, Huge and Hungry
abstract: When the tourists who rode them disappeared from resort destinations, Thailand’s captive elephants, and their owners, went back to their birth villages, where finding enough food has been a struggle.
lead_paragraph: BAAN TA KLANG, Thailand — Lucky was busy munching on some freshly cut grass when she spotted a special treat a tourist was holding out. She dropped her next mouthful of greens and extended her trunk, asking for the banana.

headline: Venice Is Saved! Woe Is Venice.
abstract: Produced by Mona Boshnaq
lead_paragraph: In the middle of the night, as the tide rose, winds whipped and waves grew, an engineer in a command center on an artificial island on the rim of the Venice lagoon clicked an arrow on his screen reading, “Lift.”

headline: Tornadoes Rip Wide Trail of Destruction
abstract: Storms have killed at least 32 people and injured dozens of others this weekend across numerous states, as another round of severe weather threatened the East.
lead_paragraph: BELVIDERE, Ill. — The room went dark. The roof crashed down. And as debris blew across the old theater packed with concertgoers, a powerful blow landed on the back of Gabriel Salas, leaving a gash that would need to be repaired with stitches.

headline: Ukraine Charges a Leading Ukrainian Vicar, as Russia Pounds Eastern Ukraine
abstract: The charge against the religious leader, Pavlo Lebid, came as Russian forces hit the town of Avdiivka, among 70 other targets, along the front line.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukraine’s security service charged a senior Orthodox Christian leader on Saturday with supporting Russia’s war effort and placed him under house arrest, in a sharp escalation of a dispute over loyalty to the state that has deeply divided the country’s dominant religion.

headline: Far-Left Canadians Susceptible to Russian Influence Too
abstract: Researchers found that on Twitter, members of Canada’s far left joined those on the far right in embracing pro-Russian messages created by a two-year Russian influence campaign.
lead_paragraph: While the torrent of leaks about possible interference by China in Canadian politics seems to have ebbed, the uproar over them continues and the federal government presented a budget this week containing some measures it hopes will deal with such meddling.

headline: Bring the Kids Along
abstract: We take our children on vacation to expose them to history, novelty and beauty.
lead_paragraph: When I was a child, we rarely went on big family trips.

headline: Word of the Day: synswer
abstract: The teenage winner of our Invent a Word challenge suggests a word for distinguishing between human- and machine-generated responses in the era of chatbots.
lead_paragraph: Note: This April Fools’ Day, we’ve turned our vocabulary column over to the winner of our Invent a Word challenge, which invited students to fill a gap they saw in the English language.

headline: In ‘Beef,’ Road Rage Is Only the Beginning
abstract: Steven Yeun and Ali Wong star in this comedy about a traffic incident that triggers a bitter feud. “It really is about how hard it is to be alive,” said Lee Sung Jin, the creator.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the Netflix series “Beef,” Steven Yeun plays Danny Cho, a struggling handyman in Los Angeles who becomes embroiled in a road rage incident with Amy Lau, a wealthy entrepreneur played by Ali Wong. Over 10 episodes, their simmering hatred fuels an escalating series of poor decisions, setting off a bizarre chain of retribution including but not limited to robbery, vandalism, catfishing and bad Yelp reviews.

headline: The N.B.A. and Its Players’ Union Reach a Tentative Labor Deal
abstract: The collective bargaining agreement, which is said to create a new in-season tournament, must be ratified by the players and team governors.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. and the N.B.A. players’ union have agreed to a new collective bargaining agreement that will ensure labor peace, the league announced Saturday morning. The new deal must be ratified by N.B.A. players and the league’s board of governors before it becomes official.

headline: What We Had to Lose
abstract: An artist reflects on what was lost during Russia’s war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: An artist reflects on what was lost during Russia’s war in Ukraine.

headline: I Am Not 80 Yet, but Among These 80-Year-Olds Is Where I Like to Be
abstract: In this locker room, the arc of fitness is long.
lead_paragraph: At my community pool, the locker room is a tableau on aging.

headline: What Decades of Providing Trans Health Care Have Taught Me
abstract: The field of transgender medicine is every bit as objective- and outcome-driven as any other specialty in medicine.
lead_paragraph: This year more than 350 anti-transgender bills have been introduced in state legislatures, pushing discussion about treatment for trans and gender-diverse patients further into the national spotlight. It isn’t hard to surmise that politically convenient doubts about the validity of trans identities have come to take the form of prohibitions against trans health care.

headline: In the Utah Ski Trial, We Are All Gwynnocent
abstract: This case has reminded us that the justice system is easily exploited in ways that are wasteful and stupid.
lead_paragraph: In what was the second highest profile legal deliberation this week, jurors determined on Thursday that Gwyneth Paltrow was not liable for damages in a ski crash between her and a retired optometrist, Terry Sanderson, causing him, he alleged, a traumatic brain injury. Mr. Sanderson was denied the $300,000 he sued for, and Ms. Paltrow, whose net worth is reportedly north of $200 million, was awarded the amount she requested in a countersuit: $1.

headline: The Fight for Israel’s Democracy Continues
abstract: Protesters who took to the streets understand that the written and unwritten checks and balances of Israeli government are still vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: In a triumph for democracy, a remarkable popular uprising has compelled Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to suspend his far-right coalition’s assault on the country’s judiciary. Over the past few months, Israelis from across the social and political spectrum — labor unions, Army reservists, diplomats, health workers and students — have filled the streets to deliver a full-throated rejection of Mr. Netanyahu’s plan to remove almost all legal restraints on his government.

headline: Trump’s Prosecution Has Set a Dangerous Precedent
abstract: Biden could soon find himself in the cross hairs of politically motivated suits from local prosecutors eager to make names for themselves.
lead_paragraph: You were probably not alone if the news of Donald Trump’s indictment seemed slightly strange: How could something so big — the first criminal indictment of an American president — seem so small?

headline: Are Abortion Pills Safe? Here’s the Evidence.
abstract: The Times reviewed 101 studies of medication abortion, spanning continents and decades. All concluded that the pills are a safe method for terminating a pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: The Times reviewed 101 studies of medication abortion, spanning continents and decades. All concluded that the pills are a safe method for terminating a pregnancy.

headline: The Value of Regional Banks
abstract: As midsized lenders have come under pressure in the wake of Silicon Valley Bank’s collapse, experts say their role in the economy must be preserved.
lead_paragraph: Walk around any city in America, and you can hardly miss the many branches of the Big Four banks — JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America, Wells Fargo and Citigroup. They’re almost as ubiquitous as gas stations. With their $1 trillion-plus in assets and national reach, the Big Four have dominated the banking landscape for the last quarter century.

headline: Let’s Really Try to Abolish Poverty
abstract: Readers respond to a guest essay about the excessive level of poverty in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: When the Landlord Sells the Building, What Are Your Rights?
abstract: For starters, don’t send any rent checks until you know exactly who you’re sending them to.
lead_paragraph: Q: I didn’t know that the rent-stabilized building where I live had been sold until I received a text message from an unknown number telling me to pay my rent via Venmo or Zelle. Moments later, a stranger knocked at my door and introduced himself as a representative of the new owner. He refused to disclose the owner’s identity and told me I could mail my check to a post office box if I didn’t want to pay rent digitally. I was left feeling stunned, vulnerable and betrayed by the previous landlord. Was there no obligation to inform tenants that the building had been sold, and to verify the new landlord’s identity on our behalf? Shouldn’t we have received notice?

headline: Finding Peace in the City That Never Quiets Down
abstract: A New York City illustrator reflects on the unlikely serenity she has discovered in one particular part of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Is It Too Late for Ron DeSantis?
abstract: Republican voters don’t want a manager, they want a performer.
lead_paragraph: The Republican establishment thought it could have Donald Trump’s political appeal without Donald Trump himself.

headline: As the Final Four Finishes, a Parallel Transfer Season Plays Out, Too
abstract: Call it the consolation bracket, as teams jockey for position for next season.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — It wasn’t long before Kansas and North Carolina tipped off for the men’s college basketball championship in New Orleans last April that Darrion Trammell called San Diego State Coach Brian Dutcher with some news. He wanted to join the Aztecs.

headline: How Trump’s Playboy Persona Came Back to Haunt Him
abstract: A salacious indictment against the 45th president is the latest chapter in a life made for the tabloids.
lead_paragraph: The particulars of the indictment against former President Donald J. Trump have yet to be revealed, but the salient details are heaven-made for headlines and screen crawls:

headline: Margot Stern Strom, Anti-Bigotry Educator, Dies at 81
abstract: She started an organization whose curriculums challenge teenagers to understand the roots of the Holocaust, racism, apartheid and other human injustices.
lead_paragraph: Margot Stern Strom, a former schoolteacher who in the mid-1970s turned her dismay over her lack of knowledge about the Holocaust into a nonprofit educational organization that develops anti-hate curriculums for teenagers, died on Tuesday at her home in Brookline, Mass. She was 81.

headline: Green Savior or Deadly Menace? Paris Votes on E-Scooter Ban
abstract: For five years, the French capital has permitted the renting of electric scooters, which have proven both popular and perilous. On Sunday, voters will decide whether to end the experiment.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Manil Hadjoudj was handing out fliers at the entrance to Sorbonne University, tirelessly repeating, “Do you care about electric scooters?” to passing students, most of whom seemed indifferent to his plea.

headline: Concertgoer Dead After Roof Collapses at Illinois Theater
abstract: More than two dozen others were hospitalized after dangerous weather caused the roof of the Apollo Theater in Belvidere, Ill., to cave in.
lead_paragraph: More than two dozen others were hospitalized after dangerous weather caused the roof of the Apollo Theater in Belvidere, Ill., to cave in.

headline: Inside the F.B.I.’s Jan. 6 Investigation of the Proud Boys
abstract: A log of messages shows how agents scrambled after evidence and sought to recruit members of the group all while trying to squeeze in workouts and cope with the bureau’s obsolete technology.
lead_paragraph: In March 2021, two months after the F.B.I. arrested Dominic Pezzola, a New York Proud Boy, on charges stemming from the Capitol attack, one of the lead agents on the case made an unusual confession. On Lync, the bureau’s internal chat system, she said she felt sorry for the man she had helped take into custody.

headline: What the Trump Indictment Means for Ron DeSantis and the G.O.P.
abstract: The Florida governor hasn’t yet swung back hard at Trump.
lead_paragraph: There is a presumption among a certain kind of analyst — rooted, I presume, in a deeply buried belief in the vengeance of Almighty God — that because Republicans morally deserve Donald Trump they will be stuck with him no matter what. That having refused so many opportunities to take a righteous stand against him, they will be condemned to halt at the edge of a post-Trump promised land, gazing pathetically across the Jordan even as they cast in their lots with the False Orange Messiah once again.

headline: Donald Trump’s Time-Tested Legal Strategy: Attack and Delay
abstract: Across many court cases over the decades, Mr. Trump has regularly leaned on those tactics. Now facing criminal charges in Manhattan, he has already lashed out at the judge.
lead_paragraph: Attack. Attack. Attack.

headline: How Iowa Ended South Carolina’s Storied Perfect Season
abstract: South Carolina had fielded the nation’s toughest defense, but couldn’t stop the offensive fireworks of Iowa’s Caitlin Clark.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — As the victories mounted, 42 in a row across two seasons, Coach Dawn Staley acknowledged that while South Carolina did not feel pressure, exactly, it did sense the weight of expectation as it sought a second consecutive women’s N.C.A.A. basketball championship.

headline: Trump and Fox News, Twin Titans of Politics, Hit With Back-to-Back Rebukes
abstract: Donald Trump’s criminal indictment and Fox News’s civil trial have nothing in common, but, combined, they delivered a rare reckoning for two forces that have transformed politics.
lead_paragraph: For the better part of a decade, Donald J. Trump and his allies at Fox News have beguiled some Americans and enraged others as they spun up an alternative world where elections turned on fraud, one political party oppressed another, and one man stood against his detractors to carry his version of truth to an adoring electorate.

headline: Pope Francis Returns to the Vatican After a 3-Day Hospital Stay
abstract: Pope Francis was discharged from a hospital in Rome after undergoing treatment for bronchitis. The Vatican said he would take part in all of the Holy Week celebrations.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis was discharged from a hospital in Rome after undergoing treatment for bronchitis. The Vatican said he would take part in all of the Holy Week celebrations.

headline: Artistic Differences
abstract: Jeremy Newton and Tracy Gray harmonize on a Sunday crossword masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Lamont Butler Hits Buzzer-Beater to Send San Diego State to N.C.A.A. Title Game
abstract: “You cant even dream about what just happened,” his father, Lamont Butler Sr., said moments after the shot went in.
lead_paragraph: Lamont Butler practiced moments like these when he was a young child, shooting on the hoop at his house, counting down to the buzzer of the imaginary shot clock in his mind.

headline: Max Verstappen Cruises Away From the Chaos in Melbourne
abstract: Red Bull makes it three wins in three races, reviving talk that it might be unbeatable this year.
lead_paragraph: One car ended its day in a spray of gravel on the first lap. A second sent its driver scrambling to safety after it caught fire. A third team lost both its entries when they collided only minutes from the finish. Red Bull? Its top driver cruised into his usual position, first place, and stayed there all day.

headline: Iowa’s Win Over South Carolina Was a Hit for ESPN, With 5.5 Million Viewers
abstract: The highly anticipated matchup delivered more viewers than any non-championship game in women’s college basketball. And the Iowa-Louisiana State final on Sunday is on network TV.
lead_paragraph: The nail-biting victory for Caitlin Clark and Iowa over South Carolina on Friday night in the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament semifinal was watched by an average of 5.5 million viewers, ESPN said on Saturday, citing early data from Nielsen. That is the third-largest audience ever on ESPN for a women’s college basketball game, and the largest audience ever for a semifinal.

headline: Heidi Gardner Celebrates Easter … Candy
abstract: When she isn’t making audiences laugh on “Saturday Night Live,” she’s hanging out with girlfriends, admiring the flowers at 30 Rock and cheering for the Kansas City Chiefs.
lead_paragraph: Heidi Gardner has developed a knack for portraying women in troubled relationships, dialing up the melodrama until she gets a laugh. On “Saturday Night Live,” where she has been a cast member since 2017, she sometimes plays Angel, “every boxer’s girlfriend from every movie about boxing ever,” according to the show’s Weekend Update anchors, who is perpetually threatening to take the kids to her sister’s.

headline: UConn Will Meet San Diego State in the Final After Romping Past Miami
abstract: The Huskies could claim their fifth championship in 25 years — something no men’s program other than U.C.L.A. and Duke has accomplished.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, when Connecticut flamed out of the N.C.A.A. tournament, upset by 12th-seeded New Mexico State in the opening round, Coach Dan Hurley was back in his office the next Monday at 7 a.m. to meet with his staff and his players.

headline: Journalist Detained by Russia Was Reporting Stories That ‘Needed to Be Told’
abstract: Evan Gershkovich, who works for The Wall Street Journal, knew the risks of reporting in Russia but felt a deep connection to the country, his friends said.
lead_paragraph: The reporting job in Moscow had everything Evan Gershkovich was looking for, his friends said: experience in a far-flung location with the chance to connect with his Russian roots.

headline: For Leaders Abroad, the Prospect of a Trump Revival Is Ever-Present
abstract: The indictment last week of Donald J. Trump has not changed the calculations of many world leaders who view his political resilience as inevitable.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Whether foreign leaders view the potential return of Donald J. Trump to the White House with hope or horror, the prospect of a Trump restoration is so deeply ingrained overseas that leaders in several countries have hedged their bets in diplomacy, security and even where they invest their fortunes.

headline: The Endorsement Deals Shaping the N.C.A.A. Tournaments
abstract: Both Miami’s men’s and women’s teams made deep runs in March. Their athletes also had significant backing in the form of name, image and likeness deals.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Last spring, Isaiah Wong led the University of Miami’s men’s basketball team to its best season to that point, a run to the round of 8 in the N.C.A.A. tournament, where it lost to Kansas, the eventual champion.

headline: Quotation of the Day: As Sea Levels Rise, the Savior of Venice May Also Be Its Curse
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 2, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Without the walls, it would be a disaster.”

headline: Corrections: April 2, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, April 2, 2023.
lead_paragraph: The Calculator column last Sunday, about the cost of building a house from scratch or buying a newly built existing one, transposed the costs of the two in New York State. Building from scratch in New York State would cost $524,000 and buying $535,000.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Tackles the Trump Indictment
abstract: The episode, hosted by Quinta Brunson, envisioned the former president going to unusual lengths to pay for his legal defense.
lead_paragraph: Two days after Donald J. Trump was indicted in New York, marking the first time that a U.S. president, sitting or former, has faced criminal charges, “Saturday Night Live” envisioned Trump going to unusual lengths to pay for his legal defense by selling his own album of musical covers.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: ‘A Cabdriver With Four Young Male Passengers Cut Across a Lane’
abstract: An exchange on Fifth Avenue, sketching on the C and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: An Unlikely Champion
abstract: The publisher of The New York Times received a Red Sox World Series ring after Boston’s historic triumph in 2004.
lead_paragraph: Even today, Boston Red Sox fans would recognize the names inscribed on the bejeweled 2004 World Series rings: Damon. Francona. Martínez. Ortiz. Ramirez. Schilling. Sulzberger. Varitek.

headline: A Chicago Mayoral Hopeful Who Took on Hard-to-Fix Schools Faces a Political Shift
abstract: Paul Vallas has long been a supporter of charter schools. He is running against Brandon Johnson, an ex-teacher with a different approach.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2023 Chicago mayoral runoff election.

headline: No More Blank Checks: Saudi Arabia Clamps Down on Regional Aid
abstract: The kingdom used to send money to poorer countries like Egypt with few strings attached. But it is increasingly leveraging its economic power for influence in the Middle East and beyond.
lead_paragraph: For much of the past decade, Saudi Arabia sent billions of dollars in aid to Egypt, bolstering a poorer regional ally seen as too strategically important to neglect.

headline: Chicagoans Are Picking a Mayor. Here’s What Matters From 4 Key Wards.
abstract: Voters will go to the polls on Tuesday in the nation’s third-largest city, a place where neighborhoods often stand apart.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2023 Chicago mayoral runoff election.

headline: Angel Reese, Caitlin Clark and the W.N.B.A.’s Talent Conundrum
abstract: Women’s college basketball has never seen the scale of talent it has today. But with only 144 spots in the W.N.B.A., some very bright college stars will have to play elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Caitlin Clark and Angel Reese will likely be playing against each other for a very long time.

headline: Russian Shelling Kills 6 as Assault Stalls in Ukraine’s East
abstract: The attack came after President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said that permitting Moscow its monthlong presidency of the Security Council showed “the complete bankruptcy of such institutions.”
lead_paragraph: Russian shelling blasted apartment blocks, homes and a preschool in eastern Ukraine on Sunday, killing six civilians, even as evidence mounted that Moscow has failed to make much progress in its campaign to seize the whole of the region.

headline: Forest Fire Breaks Out on a Mountain in Central Seoul
abstract: Dozens of nearby homes were evacuated as firefighters hurried to contain the blaze on one of Seoul’s most popular hiking sites.
lead_paragraph: A forest fire broke out around noon on Sunday on Inwangsan, a mountain in central Seoul that is a popular outdoor destination, prompting the evacuation of dozens of nearby households as firefighters hurried to contain the blaze.

headline: Refusing to Evacuate, Ukrainian Residents Go Underground
abstract: Huddled in basements just over a mile away from the front lines of Avdiivka, over 1,800 residents are refusing to be rescued from one of the most active battlegrounds in eastern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Huddled in basements just over a mile away from the front lines of Avdiivka, over 1,800 residents are refusing to be rescued from one of the most active battlegrounds in eastern Ukraine.

headline: Inside the Ukrainian Frontline City Residents Are Refusing to Leave
abstract: Huddled in basements just over a mile away from the front lines of Avdiivka, over 1,800 residents are refusing to be rescued from one of the most active battlegrounds in eastern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: It’s been described by Ukrainian officials as “post-apocalyptic.”

headline: A Daughter of Veracruz Takes Up Its Perils and Ghosts
abstract: In a new collection, Fernanda Melchor considers not just violence but how people cope in a troubled region.
lead_paragraph: Fernanda Melchor advises us early on in her new collection, “This Is Not Miami,” that “I do not write about tears, armed men or wounded children where they never actually existed.” Tears and hurt children abound, of course, in the city and state of Veracruz, Mexico, and the region has long been rich in armed men: Here comes another pickup full of soldiers in black masks and green vests; they rest their machine guns on the truck bed, their passing presence as quotidian as the open-air market’s heaps of fruit, eggs, chickens, metal parts; they dwindle away on the waterfront avenue named after Comodoro Manuel Azueta.

headline: It’s Work, Not Junior High
abstract: Sometimes it’s necessary to remind yourself that earning a living shouldn’t be a popularity contest.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: The Children’s Rights Advocate Accused of Russian War Crimes
abstract: Maria Lvova-Belova says she is running a humanitarian evacuation of abandoned Ukrainian children. The International Criminal Court accuses her of abducting them wholesale.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — As children gathered at a holiday camp outside Moscow, they were greeted by a female performer in a kokoshnik, a traditional tiara, who extended the customary Russian greeting of a loaf of bread and salt.

headline: SPAC Tied to Trump Media Rushes to Complete Deal
abstract: The merger of Digital World and Trump Media has been held up by investigations, but executives are rushing to complete the deal by a Sept. 8 deadline.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 18 months ago, an obscure investment banker unveiled a blockbuster deal: His so-called blank-check company would bankroll a social media outfit that former President Donald J. Trump planned to start with hundreds of millions of dollars.

headline: The Rise and Fall of a Grand Dragon of the Ku Klux Klan
abstract: In a new book, Timothy Egan traces the Klan’s expansion in the 1920s across American political and civic life. Then its leader, David C. Stephenson, committed murder.
lead_paragraph: The scene, in some ways, could not have been more commonplace. On July 4, 1923, in a creekside park in Kokomo, Ind., families celebrated Independence Day with flags and bunting, watermelon and pie, patriotic songs, a parade. Commonplace — except that these families, many thousands in number, wore the white hoods and robes of the Ku Klux Klan. Banners insisted that “America is for Americans”; floats portrayed Klansmen defending women from Black people and Catholics. As the day’s featured speaker — David C. Stephenson, Grand Dragon of the Realm of Indiana — stepped out of the rear cockpit of a Klan-branded biplane, members of the crowd dropped to their knees and, in rapture, reached out their arms. “My worthy subjects,” Stephenson exulted.

headline: It Takes More Than the Kindness of Strangers
abstract: Playing Blanche DuBois is shattering, say the actresses featured in Nancy Schoenberger’s “Blanche.” But Tennessee Williams’s most indelible character is now a figure of sympathy.
lead_paragraph: Last we saw of Blanche DuBois, the brittle antiheroine of Tennessee Williams’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play “A Streetcar Named Desire,” she was being carted off to a state  loony bin, uttering her famous line about relying on “the kindness of strangers” that can hardly be improved upon.

headline: These Ukrainians Arrived Under a Biden Program. They Ended Up Homeless.
abstract: More than 280,000 Ukrainians have escaped the war through a program meant to resettle them into the homes of Americans. But not everyone has found a safe or welcoming place to stay.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, Stanislav Holotiuk had been searching for someone to help him flee the war in Ukraine and sponsor his resettlement in the United States.

headline: Fight Over Corruption and Congo’s Mining Riches Takes a Turn in Washington
abstract: Dan Gertler, an Israeli billionaire, is pressing President Biden to remove sanctions that were imposed on him for bribe-fueled transactions in the impoverished African country.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Five years ago, the United States accused a wealthy Israeli diamond dealer of more than $1 billion worth of corrupt mining and oil deals in the Democratic Republic of Congo, saying they undermined economic growth and “the rule of law” in the impoverished African nation.

headline: How a Milliner Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Linda Pagan, who runs a popular hat shop in SoHo, likes to stroll and visit neighborhood spots like Fanelli Cafe and Film Forum.
lead_paragraph: “The right hat is an expression of your personality,” said Linda Pagan, who owns The Hat Shop NYC. “You are never alone when you wear a hat — wearing one is like walking a dog but without all the work; people will always stop and talk to you.”

headline: Norfolk Southern’s Push for Profits Compromised Safety, Workers Say
abstract: Federal officials are investigating the railroad’s safety practices and culture after the derailment in East Palestine, Ohio, and worker deaths.
lead_paragraph: Norfolk Southern once had so few accidents and injuries that it won the rail industry’s prestigious E.H. Harriman safety award for 23 years in a row until it was retired in 2012. But in the last decade, the company has gone from an industry leader to a laggard.

headline: Democrats Run on Abortion, Even for Offices With Little Say on the Issue
abstract: Seizing on a powerful motivator for their party, Democratic candidates for municipal offices have put Republicans on their heels. “I’m running for mayor, I’m not debating abortion,” one said.
lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY, Wis. — Eric Genrich is running a full-throated campaign in support of abortion rights, reminding voters of his position at every turn and hammering his anti-abortion opponent in television ads. At a recent event, he featured an obstetrician who now commutes to a state where abortion is legal to treat patients and a local woman who traveled to Colorado to terminate a nonviable pregnancy.

headline: ‘On a Tightrope’: How Taiwan’s President Navigated the U.S. and China
abstract: Known for her quiet pragmatism, Tsai Ing-wen has ushered in a new era of American cooperation as worries about Chinese aggression rise.
lead_paragraph: In an island renowned for boisterous politics, Taiwan’s president, Tsai Ing-wen, is an improbable leader.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘A Sandwich Shop, a Tent City and an American Crisis’
abstract: As homelessness overwhelms downtown Phoenix, a small business wonders how long it can hang on.
lead_paragraph: Joe Faillace, 69, has been running the sandwich shop Old Station Subs alongside his wife, Debbie, for the last four decades. But as an epidemic of unsheltered homelessness began to overwhelm Phoenix, and many other major American downtowns, the Faillaces have been met with hundreds of people sleeping within a few blocks of Old Station. Many of them were suffering from mental illness or substance abuse, resulting in incidents such as pilfered goods and public masturbation.

headline: Ending Your Pet’s Life Was the Right Decision. So Why Do You Feel So Guilty?
abstract: As a veterinarian, I counseled many people through the end of a beloved pet’s life. But when my cat got sick, it started a whole new journey.
lead_paragraph: Marula was an orange kitty, a purr machine with multiple birth defects, so he was the perfect cat to be a veterinarian’s companion. He purred against my belly when I was pregnant and, years later, he never missed story time, seeming to read the book from one side of me while my son sat on the other. “Did you know your cat is limping?” new visitors to my home often asked with alarm. I’d point out the cat’s shortened leg and funky paw and reassure them that, despite his awkward gait, he got around just fine.

headline: Colleges Should Be More Than Just Vocational Schools
abstract: Elected officials have pushed vocational programs at the expense of the liberal arts. That’s hurting America.
lead_paragraph: Is a university a university without the liberal arts? Marymount University seems to think so. The institution’s trustees voted unanimously in February to eliminate majors in mathematics, art, English, history and philosophy, among other fields.

headline: The Problem With Everything-Bagel Liberalism
abstract: Trouble comes when Democrats try to do everything everywhere all at once.
lead_paragraph: In February, I visited Tahanan, a building that might be the answer to San Francisco’s homelessness crisis. I left wishing that the answer had been other than what it was.

headline: The Week in Business: A Bank Takeover
abstract: Regulators faced questions about their oversight in the wake of bank failures. The jobs numbers for March come out. And Donald Trump is expected to be arraigned.
lead_paragraph: First Citizens BancShares, a family-run bank in North Carolina, announced last Sunday that it was acquiring Silicon Valley Bank, capping off a tumultuous month for the California lender whose collapse touched off a wider banking crisis. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation seized control of SVB and its assets on March 10, after a run on deposits left it insolvent, and SVB filed for bankruptcy a week later. First Citizens’ deal with the F.D.I.C. to take over the bank involved the purchase of about $72 billion in loans at a $16.5 billion discount. First Citizens also took control of all of the bank’s roughly $56 billion in deposits. But an additional $90 billion in SVB’s securities remain under the purview of the F.D.I.C. The collapse of SVB was followed in short succession by two other bank failures. Credit Suisse, which was bought by its rival UBS, Switzerland’s largest bank, and Signature Bank. New York Community Bancorp later acquired substantially all of the remaining deposits at Signature Bank.

headline: Maggie Haberman on Donald Trump
abstract: We talk with a Trump reporter to prepare you for the week when he will likely be arrested.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is expected to fly to New York this week from his home in Florida to be arrested. For now, the specific charges are unknown because the indictment is under seal, but they involve his role in the payment of hush money during the 2016 presidential campaign to cover up an extramarital affair.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | April 3, 2023
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: Pope Francis, Back From the Hospital, Thanks Crowds for Their Prayers
abstract: Francis arrived in St. Peter’s Square in an open-topped jeep on Palm Sunday, the beginning of a week of major ceremonies before Easter.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis, who was discharged from a three-day hospital stay on Saturday, seemed on the mend on Sunday as he addressed tens of thousands of faithful gathered in St. Peter’s Square for Palm Sunday Mass, allaying concerns about his health.

headline: He’s Not Jesus, but He Plays Him on TV
abstract: For Jonathan Roumie, the star of “The Chosen,” playing the son of God is an act of faith.
lead_paragraph: I typically don’t like religious movies and TV shows. I find them corny or mawkish, the kind of thing that certain believers feel they are supposed to watch but that lack any real artistic merit or appeal. I truly hated Mel Gibson’s “The Passion of the Christ.” But about a year ago, a friend of mine, whose taste in art and culture I respect, recommended that I watch “The Chosen,” a multiseason television series about the life of Jesus and those around him. I watched it with my family. A couple of episodes in, we were hooked.

headline: ‘The Last of Us’ Is Right. Our Warming Planet Is a Petri Dish.
abstract: Fungi are a public health blind spot.
lead_paragraph: “The Last of Us,” a postapocalyptic television thriller, recently concluded its first season with a stunning finale. However, as a physician and horror superfan, I found the show’s beginning more striking: A 1960s talk-show host asks two epidemiologists what keeps them up at night. “Fungus,” one replies.

headline: ‘I Felt Like I Was at Warp Speed’: Baseball Adapts to a New Era
abstract: A sport that wanted more action got its wish, but a series of major rule changes has some major leaguers struggling to keep up.
lead_paragraph: In the first inning of his major league career, 58 years ago at Fenway Park in Boston, Jim Palmer struck out Tony Conigliaro on a high fastball. On Thursday, from the Baltimore Orioles’ broadcast booth, Palmer looked down at the same mound and saw a pitcher get a third strike without even throwing a pitch.

headline: Interpreting the Science of Masking
abstract: Readers respond to a column by Zeynep Tufekci about the efficacy of masks. Also: Dealing with artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Apple’s New App Aims to Make Classical Music More Accessible
abstract: The company says it has a fix for the unwieldy world of classical streaming. But it’s unclear how much traction a stand-alone app can get.
lead_paragraph: In the streaming era, fans of classical music have had reason to grumble.

headline: Asa Hutchinson Announces Presidential Bid
abstract: The former governor of Arkansas, a prominent Trump critic within the Republican Party, has been testing the waters in Iowa.
lead_paragraph: Asa Hutchinson, the former governor of Arkansas, joined the race for the Republican nomination for president on Sunday, banking that in a crowded field, enough G.O.P. voters will be searching for an outspoken critic of Donald J. Trump to lift his dark-horse candidacy.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Sticky honey-ginger drumsticks, blackened cauliflower and nori rice.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. The cherry blossoms were pinking the side streets on Staten Island the other morning as I drove the family down from Joe and Pat’s pizzeria to the beach at Great Kills, for a walk out to Crooke’s Point.

headline: Ryuichi Sakamoto, Oscar-Winning Composer, Dies at 71
abstract: Mr. Sakamoto, whose work with Yellow Magic Orchestra influenced electronic music, composed scores for “The Last Emperor” and “The Revenant.”
lead_paragraph: Ryuichi Sakamoto, one of Japan’s most prominent composers, who scored the films “The Last Emperor,” “The Sheltering Sky” and “The Revenant” and was a founder of the influential Yellow Magic Orchestra techno-pop band, died on Tuesday. He was 71.

headline: In Rare Call With Lavrov, Blinken Demands Release of Imprisoned American Journalist
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken spoke with his Russian counterpart after the American basketball star Brittney Griner, who was detained for almost 10 months by Russia, urged the U.S. government to use “every tool possible” to secure Evan Gershkovich’s release.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said Sunday that he had spoken with his Russian counterpart, Sergey V. Lavrov, to demand the release of Evan Gershkovich, the Wall Street Journal reporter who has been imprisoned in Russia on what the United States and the newspaper called a bogus espionage charge.

headline: Tesla Sales Rose in the First Quarter
abstract: The electric car company’s decision to slash prices appears to have offset the effect of higher interest rates.
lead_paragraph: Tesla sales rose 5 percent in the first three months of the year after it cut prices on its electric cars, helping to compensate for slowing economic growth and rising interest rates.

headline: 2 Pro-Impeachment Senators Question Motives Behind Trump Indictment
abstract: Joe Manchin, a Democrat, and Bill Cassidy, a Republican, both voted to convict Donald Trump after Jan. 6. They expressed concern on Sunday that the criminal case against him is political.
lead_paragraph: Two senators who voted to convict former President Donald J. Trump for inciting the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol — one a Republican and one a Democrat — have raised concerns that Mr. Trump has been improperly targeted by the Manhattan district attorney, Alvin Bragg, even before they have learned the details of the indictment.

headline: Review: Doleful ‘Vespers’ Pray for an Earth in Crisis
abstract: John Luther Adams’s latest premiere, “Vespers of the Blessed Earth,” is a tear-splattered departure from his usual style.
lead_paragraph: Lately, the composer John Luther Adams has been thinking about art — and artists — in times of crisis.

headline: In Surprise, OPEC Plus Announces Cut in Oil Production
abstract: Oil prices soared 7 percent on Sunday night after the group’s move to cut 1.2 million barrels a day.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia, Russia and their oil-producing allies announced on Sunday that they would cut production by more than 1.2 million barrels of crude a day, or more than 1 percent of world supplies, in an apparent effort to increase prices.

headline: Influential Russian Military Blogger Is Killed in St. Petersburg Bombing
abstract: Vladlen Tatarsky represented a radical wing of pro-invasion bloggers and activists who backed Moscow’s war but also criticized what they saw as the flaws in the Russian Army.
lead_paragraph: An influential Russian military blogger who called for an escalation of the war in Ukraine was killed when a bomb exploded in a cafe in St. Petersburg, Russia, on Sunday, in what appeared to be one of the most high-profile attacks on a supporter of Moscow’s invasion.

headline: Another Round of Severe Storms Is Expected From Texas to Illinois
abstract: After a storm system tore through parts of at least seven states on Friday and Saturday, forecasters said tornadoes, hail and strong winds were possible on Tuesday in the South and Midwest.
lead_paragraph: Communities across the country face another round of severe weather this week as regions in seven states recover from a powerful storm system that killed at least 32 people over the weekend.

headline: As Trump Arraignment Looms, New York City Braces for a Day of Tumult
abstract: Donald J. Trump is expected to fly in on Monday night, then he is expected to spend the night in Trump Tower. The police will monitor every movement.
lead_paragraph: Even for a city accustomed to celebrity appearances, the two-day visit during which Donald J. Trump is expected be arraigned in Manhattan is likely to be a striking spectacle: There will be protests and celebrations, an all-hands-on-deck police presence and a crush of media attention on the moment in which the first American president is charged with a crime.

headline: Trump Flourishes in the Glare of His Indictment
abstract: The former president’s appetite for attention has been fundamental to his identity for decades. Where others may focus on the hazards of a criminal case, he raises money, promotes his campaign and works to reduce the case to a cliffhanging spectacle.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since long before he entered the White House, former President Donald J. Trump has been an any-publicity-is-good-publicity kind of guy. In fact, he once told advisers, “There’s no bad press unless you’re a pedophile.” Hush money for a porn star? Evidently not an exception to that rule.

headline: Anxious Times Descend on New York. Enter Springsteen.
abstract: There was tension in the city as New Yorkers waited for Donald J. Trump to appear, but in the meantime, Bruce kept playing at the Garden.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t wanna go home,” Bruce Springsteen told some 20,000 cheering fans on Saturday night in Madison Square Garden. “New York, wanna go home?”

headline: Israel Moves Forward With Far-Right Plan for National Guard
abstract: Itamar Ben-Gvir, one of the most extreme voices in the Israeli government, had long sought to create a national guard. Ministers agreed on Sunday to set up a committee to discuss next steps.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli government agreed in principle on Sunday to establish a national guard, handing a political victory to the far-right minister Itamar Ben-Gvir, who had long demanded the militia as a condition for supporting Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

headline: Body of a Missing 2-Year-Old Boy Is Found in an Alligator’s Jaws, Police Say
abstract: The discovery was a tragic end to the search for the Florida toddler, who had been missing since Thursday after his mother was found stabbed to death, officials said.
lead_paragraph: The body of a 2-year-old boy was discovered on Friday in the jaws of an alligator in a tragic end to a search for the toddler after his mother was found stabbed to death, according to the authorities in St. Petersburg, Fla.

headline: Review: ‘Fragments’ Proposes a New Kind of Cello Recital
abstract: Alisa Weilerstein brought her new project, a mix tape of new works and movements from Bach’s cello suites, to Zankel Hall.
lead_paragraph: Alisa Weilerstein, a cellist of explosive emotional energy, gave the New York premiere of her new project, “Fragments,” at Zankel Hall on Saturday. I was there, but she wouldn’t want me to tell you exactly what happened.

headline: ‘Prima Facie’ and ‘My Neighbour Totoro’ Win Big at the Olivier Awards
abstract: The Jodie Comer-starring legal drama won best new play at Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys and an adaptation of ‘Totoro’ won six gongs — the most of any production.
lead_paragraph: “Prima Facie,” a Broadway-bound play about a lawyer who represents men accused of assault, then is herself sexually assaulted, was the big winner on Sunday at the Olivier Awards, Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Donald Trump’s Legal Tactics
abstract: Also, China’s lessons from the war in Ukraine and Volodymyr Zelensky denounces Russia’s U.N. role.
lead_paragraph: Delay. Delay. Delay. Attack. Attack. Attack.

headline: A Front Company and a Fake Identity: How the U.S. Came to Use Spyware It Was Trying to Kill.
abstract: The Biden administration has been trying to choke off use of hacking tools made by the Israeli firm NSO. It turns out that not every part of the government has gotten the message.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The secret contract was finalized on Nov. 8, 2021, a deal between a company that has acted as a front for the United States government and the American affiliate of a notorious Israeli hacking firm.

headline: Finland’s Prime Minister Loses Tight Election; Her Party Came Third
abstract: Prime Minister Sanna Marin’s party was outpolled by a rival that stressed economic concerns. Petteri Orpo of the National Coalition Party may now come to power, but coalition talks will be daunting.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Prime Minister Sanna Marin and her Social Democratic Party lost a tight election in Finland on Sunday to a center-right party that focused on economic concerns.

headline: How Nashville Prepared for the Day It Never Wanted to Face
abstract: Dispatchers, police and paramedics in Nashville had for years trained for a school shooting as if it was inevitable. An attack in Uvalde, Texas, underscored that there was no margin for error.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — The first 911 calls started coming in just before 10:13 a.m. Teachers and staff members, hiding in rooms, bathrooms and closets across the Covenant School and its church, whispered prayers and pleas for help on the line, children’s voices and gunshots audible in the background.

headline: Tulare Lake Was Drained Off the Map. Nature Would Like a Word.
abstract: A barrage of storms has resurrected what was once the largest body of fresh water west of the Mississippi River, setting the stage for a disaster this spring.
lead_paragraph: CORCORAN, Calif. — It is no secret to locals that the heart of California’s Central Valley was once the largest body of fresh water west of the Mississippi River, dammed and drained into an empire of farms by the mid-20th century.

headline: Review: The Dreamy Precision of an Everyday Surrealist
abstract: The choreographer Beth Gill’s “Nail Biter,” at the Fisher Center at Bard College, is absolutely deliberate but also mysterious.
lead_paragraph: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — Nail-biter: The phrase is vivid, evoking an agitated psychological state through a physical image that is both banal and disturbing. It’s an apt title for the latest work by the choreographer Beth Gill.

headline: Louisiana State Wins N.C.A.A. Women’s Title With Rout of Clark and Iowa
abstract: Angel Reese starred and talked trash as her Tigers held Caitlin Clark and Iowa at bay in a 102-85 victory.
lead_paragraph: Louisiana State Coach Kim Mulkey had been trying to temper expectations all season.

headline: What We Know About the Weekend Storm Damage in the Midwest, South and East
abstract: The severe weather system spawned numerous tornadoes that killed dozens of people, injuring scores. It also created heavy snow in the North and fueled wildfires in Oklahoma.
lead_paragraph: It collapsed a theater in Illinois. Tossed cars in Little Rock, Ark. Flattened homes in Tennessee. And left thousands without power in New Jersey.

headline: Come to a Point
abstract: David Distenfeld’s puzzle uses some vowel language.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Endeavor and W.W.E. Said to Be Close to Deal Combining Fighting Leagues
abstract: A union of Endeavor’s U.F.C. combat league and World Wrestling Entertainment would increase the combined company’s leverage in negotiations with content distributors.
lead_paragraph: Endeavor, the Hollywood entertainment colossus that owns the Ultimate Fighting Championship, is close to a deal that would combine that league with World Wrestling Entertainment, two people familiar with the negotiations said on Sunday. The combination would establish a behemoth in combat entertainment, both real and scripted.

headline: For Sarah Bakewell, Nothing Human is Alien
abstract: In “Humanly Possible,” Bakewell brings her signature blend of wit and philosophical sophistication to the complex, sometimes contentious 700-year history of humanist thought.
lead_paragraph: What does it mean to be human? It’s an ancient question that’s hard to answer, but easy to ask.

headline: Arrest Made in Robberies and Murders of Gay Men Who Were Drugged
abstract: Jacob Barroso, 30, arrested Saturday in the murder of Julio Ramirez, a 25-year-old social worker, is the third person charged in the cases.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department said on Sunday that a man had been arrested and charged with murder in connection with a series of killings and robberies at Manhattan gay bars that has terrorized the city’s L.G.B.T.Q. community and drawn attention to the use of drugs to incapacitate, rob and kill.

headline: After Indian Wells and Miami, Intrigue Awaits at the Top of Tennis
abstract: Daniil Medvedev, Carlos Alcaraz, Jannik Sinner and Elena Rybakina had a rousing month in the United States. With Europe, red clay and the return of the biggest stars on the horizon, this could get very interesting.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — It doesn’t take an expert in code cracking to figure out the pattern that has emerged in professional tennis in the past month as the tours descended on the United States for the winter-spring swing in California and Florida.

headline: Montenegro’s President, Europe’s Longest-Serving Elected Leader, Loses Runoff
abstract: The incumbent, Milo Djukanovic, conceded to Jakov Milatovic, who had campaigned on pledges to root out corruption and organized crime.
lead_paragraph: The shape-shifting president of Montenegro, Milo Djukanovic, Europe’s longest-serving elected leader, lost a re-election bid on Sunday, according to provisional official results, raising hopes across the Balkans of a long-awaited end to a political era stamped by the Yugoslav wars of the early 1990s.

headline: A Steep Learning Curve and a Steeper Forkball for Mets Rookie
abstract: In his first regular-season start since coming over from Japan, Kodai Senga baffled the Marlins with his signature pitch: the ghost fork.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — At 2 p.m. Eastern time on Sunday, Kodai Senga threw the first pitch of his major league career. It was a 99-mile-per-hour fastball that dropped out of the strike zone. What would unfold over the next several innings of the Mets’ 5-1 win over the Miami Marlins exemplified both the adjustment period Senga faces in Major League Baseball and his tantalizing potential.

headline: Seymour Stein, Record Industry Giant Who Signed Big Names, Dies at 80
abstract: Steeped in music, he championed Madonna, the Ramones, Talking Heads, the Pretenders and more on his Sire label, and helped found the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: It was early 1957, and a nervous teenager named Seymour Steinbigle sat in a midtown office with his father and a hard-bitten record producer who was offering to mentor the young man in the ways of the music business.

headline: Kim Mulkey, a Colorful and Divisive Coach, Wins Another Title
abstract: Mulkey’s L.S.U. players say they appreciate her tough approach. But her relationship with Brittney Griner continues to receive scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: Kim Mulkey, Louisiana State’s basketball coach, crouches on the sideline like a catcher in high heels and wears sleeves adorned with pink flowers and artificial flowers that suggest, “No hibiscus died in the making of this jacket.”

headline: L.S.U. Set Scoring Records. But the Points Came From an Unlikely Source.
abstract: Louisiana State won the championship on 3-pointers. The Tigers can thank Jasmine Carson, who led the team with a surprise 22 points.
lead_paragraph: Louisiana State scored 32 points in the second quarter of the N.C.A.A. women’s championship game, setting a tournament record for most points in a quarter. At the end of the half, the Tigers had 59 points, setting another record, for most points in a half. They set one more at the buzzer, with the most points scored in a tournament game, as they defeated Iowa, 102-85.

headline: Quotation of the Day: How Nashville Prepared for a Day That It Hoped It Would Never Endure
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 3, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “We know we have to keep moving toward the threat, and we knew that we had to go in and we could not wait.”

headline: Alanis Obomsawin Wins MacDowell Medal
abstract: The filmmaker, a member of the Abenaki Nation, has created more than 50 films documenting the rights and lives of First Nations people.
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker Alanis Obomsawin is this year’s recipient of the Edward MacDowell Medal, MacDowell announced on Sunday.

headline: ‘Succession,’ Season 4, Episode 2 Recap: The Serious People
abstract: Logan Roy does not care about any of your social norms, and he lacks the patience for apologies.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know about Logan Roy: He does not care about any of your social norms or niceties. In last week’s “Succession,” while his kids were stealthily trying to outbid him for Pierce Global Media, Logan did not bother to play their little games. He demanded that Tom call Shiv to find out what was what — and he did it in a room full of Waystar executives, so Tom could not say no. Logan never minds coming off as rude or presumptuous. Manners are a waste of time, which is a waste of money.

headline: Succession Style, Episode 2: The Power of a White Tank Top
abstract: Shiv goes for comfort, the “4chan Swede” makes a call and Kerry’s pink dress is tragically unable to carry the day.
lead_paragraph: Season 4 of “Succession,” the HBO series about the very rich, utterly venal, entirely power- hungry (and compulsively watchable) Roy family is underway — and we can’t stop talking about it. Not just because of what they do and say, but because of how perfectly their clothes reflect their characters and maybe even presage changes to come. So starting today, members of the Styles staff will analyze, debate and otherwise get inside the show’s closets each week. Tune in.

headline: Spring Storm Bringing Snow From Rockies to Upper Midwest
abstract: The storm began on Monday and was expected to gain momentum with a mix of snow and winds on Tuesday, creating whiteout conditions in some areas.
lead_paragraph: A powerful storm is forecast to deliver heavy snow and strong winds from Utah to Minnesota starting on Monday, just days after another storm pummeled much of the United States.

headline: St. Petersburg Blast Kills Russian Blogger Who Backed War in Ukraine
abstract: Russian police officers inspected the aftermath of the explosion at a cafe where the blogger popularly known as Vladlen Tatarsky had been giving a public talk.
lead_paragraph: Russian police officers inspected the aftermath of the explosion at a cafe where the blogger popularly known as Vladlen Tatarsky had been giving a public talk.

headline: Lamont Butler, Ever Steady After His Winning Shot, Buoyed by Family
abstract: Butler doesn’t like a lot of attention, his father said, but that’s what he got after sending San Diego State to the national title game. “He was more happy that we were happy,” Lamont Butler Sr. said.
lead_paragraph: After all the TV cameras had gone away, after all the questions from reporters had stopped, after Lamont Butler Jr. boarded the bus back to his team’s hotel on Saturday night, the euphoria began to ebb. His parents asked Butler to come down to the lobby to celebrate the moment — his go-in-or-go-home jumper at the buzzer that sent San Diego State into the N.C.A.A. men’s championship game.

headline: Life Happened, and Somehow Put Them in the Championship Game
abstract: After a middling season at the University of San Diego, Joey Calcaterra, a guard, transferred to UConn and Sam Scholl, the fired head coach, was hired as a basketball adviser by San Diego State.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — After Joey Calcaterra, Connecticut’s brash, sharpshooting guard, swished an open 3-pointer late in the first half of a Final Four game on Saturday, making a Miami defender pay for an ill-advised gamble, he slapped hands with Coach Dan Hurley.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Donald Trump’s expected surrender at a Manhattan courthouse.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is expected to arrive in New York today from his estate in Florida and head to his former home in Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue, before surrendering at the office of the Manhattan district attorney early tomorrow afternoon. He will then be arraigned in the Manhattan Criminal Courts Building.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘La Frontera’ and ‘The English Patient’
abstract: This week we’re watching a docuseries about the U.S.-Mexico border, the Oscar-winning 1996 film starring Ralph Fiennes and lots more.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, April 3-9. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Why Dutch Farmers Turned Their Flag Upside Down
abstract: In some important ways, the Netherlands looks like a test case.
lead_paragraph: GOUDA, the Netherlands — In the fields around where I live, in the countryside near Rotterdam in the Netherlands, the flags are flying the right way up again.

headline: Word of the Day: inexorable
abstract: This word has appeared in 55 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word inexorable has appeared in 55 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 2 in “Kareem Abdul-Jabbar Was the ‘Best Weapon in Basketball’” by Tania Ganguli and Scott Cacciola:

headline: Hail the Bagel: Rockefeller Center Flags Honor N.Y.C. Food
abstract: To celebrate the city’s resilience, the flags salute New York’s cornucopia of culinary delights.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll see why different flags are flying in Rockefeller Center this month. We’ll also find out about state regulators’ biggest push yet to get cannabis dispensaries open to the public.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Donald Trump and New York City Brace for a Consequential Week
abstract: As the former president traveled to Manhattan for his arrest on Tuesday, his team weighed how to capitalize on it, while officials in New York prepared for potential turmoil.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump made his heavily anticipated arrival in New York on Monday as he prepared to walk into a Manhattan courtroom as both a defendant and a candidate.

headline: Drug-Resistant Bacteria Tied to Eyedrops Can Spread Person to Person
abstract: The C.D.C. traced deaths and cases of blindness to products imported from India. The agency said it was concerned that the bacteria could gain a foothold in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: A highly drug-resistant bacteria that was linked to eyedrops imported from India and that spread from person to person in a Connecticut long-term care center has prompted concerns that the strain could gain a foothold in U.S. health care settings, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: LIV Golf Talks a Big Game to the Global Elite. Now Come the Majors.
abstract: Despite setbacks, LIV’s executives insist the Saudi-backed league is soaring. For many fans, the rhetoric is less important than results at events like the Masters Tournament.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH — On Thursday afternoon, one week before the Masters Tournament, Greg Norman sat not at a golf course, but in a building populated that day by billionaires, royals and former prime ministers.

headline: Tiger and Phil Return to the Masters
abstract: Players set out for official practice rounds ahead of the first men’s golf major of the year although more than a few have tested the course recently.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Augusta National Golf Club will be thick with spectators Monday, as one player after another sets out for official practice rounds before the Masters Tournament, the year’s first men’s golf major.

headline: Battered by Storms, the Midwest and South Brace for More
abstract: Days after powerful storms pummeled much of the U.S., another weather system is expected to bring blizzards, hail and thunderstorms.
lead_paragraph: Days after powerful storms pummeled much of the U.S., another weather system is expected to bring blizzards, hail and thunderstorms.

headline: Sanna Marin’s Party Finishes Third in Finland’s Election
abstract: The prime minister and her Social Democratic Party conceded the parliamentary election as Peter Orpo and the National Coalition Party celebrated victory.
lead_paragraph: The prime minister and her Social Democratic Party conceded the parliamentary election as Peter Orpo and the National Coalition Party celebrated victory.

headline: Russia’s assault in eastern Ukraine appears stalled.
