abstract: Evidence is mounting that Moscow has failed to make much progress in the Donbas of eastern Ukraine, despite months of fighting in the industrial and agricultural region close to the Russian border.
lead_paragraph: Evidence is mounting that Moscow has failed to make much progress in the Donbas of eastern Ukraine, despite months of fighting in the industrial and agricultural region close to the Russian border.

headline: Speculation flares after an influential Russian military blogger is killed by a bomb in St. Petersburg.
abstract: An influential Russian military blogger who called for an escalation of the war in Ukraine was killed when a bomb exploded in a cafe in St. Petersburg, Russia, on Sunday, in what appeared to be one of the most high-profile attacks on a supporter of Moscow’s invasion.
lead_paragraph: An influential Russian military blogger who called for an escalation of the war in Ukraine was killed when a bomb exploded in a cafe in St. Petersburg, Russia, on Sunday, in what appeared to be one of the most high-profile attacks on a supporter of Moscow’s invasion.

headline: A Psychedelics Pioneer Takes the Ultimate Trip
abstract: “Life has been more beautiful, more wonderful than ever,” says Dr. Roland Griffiths, who has stage 4 cancer.
lead_paragraph: “Life has been more beautiful, more wonderful than ever,” says Dr. Roland Griffiths, who has stage 4 cancer.

headline: Should the United States Ban TikTok?
abstract: Officials say the app is a national security risk. Do you think their concerns are warranted?
lead_paragraph: Do you use TikTok? If so, how much and what for? Do you use it mainly to consume content, or are you a creator yourself?

headline: I’m a Wheelchair User. What’s the Best Thing to Wear to a Formal Event?
abstract: A reader preparing for a black-tie wedding seeks options for adaptive clothing that are both comfortable and festive.
lead_paragraph: I have long felt that one of fashion’s most ingrained shortcomings is its almost total failure to embrace adaptive clothing. According to the C.D.C., one in four adult Americans lives with a disability, and given that fashion plays an enormous and crucial role in how we feel about ourselves, this error seems to be both a moral failure and an enormous missed business opportunity.

headline: The 2024 Election Is Already Here
abstract: So we go directly to party insiders who are working to shape the next election, out of public view.
lead_paragraph: It may seem way too early to be thinking about next year’s presidential election — and it is too soon to ask who’s going to win. But actually, it’s the perfect time to understand what the parties took away from the last election and how that’s already shaping their plans for the next one.

headline: Baby’s First Social Media Handle
abstract: Sorry, that profile name is taken. It belongs to a newborn.
lead_paragraph: Sophie Kratsas was only a few hours old when she received her first email: a “welcome to the world” message from her father, Nick Kratsas. He had created an email account for his newborn daughter while still standing in the delivery room. This was 2014, and Mr. Kratsas, 44, had already noticed a dearth of unclaimed email addresses with a person’s full name without numbers, special characters or other concessions.

headline: In Days Before Trump Appears in Court, Few Signs Point to a Jan. 6 Repeat
abstract: Even as Donald Trump’s arraignment differs from the Capitol riot, law enforcement’s response is informed by lessons learned from that day and the nationwide protests against police violence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former President Donald J. Trump’s expected appearance on Tuesday in a Manhattan court is a volatile moment for the country with an unpredictable outcome, but law enforcement officials have not yet seen indications of a disruptive, organized backlash akin to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.

headline: Britney Spears Didn’t Feel Like She Could Live ‘a Full Life.’ There’s Another Way.
abstract: Experts call it a consequential change in the care of some older people and others with limits on their mental functioning.
lead_paragraph: Conservative Texans and liberal Californians disagree on much in politics. But legislators in both states agree on a new approach to giving people with cognitive impairments a greater chance for self-determination. It’s called supported decision-making, and it is shaping up to be the most consequential change in the care of older people and others with limitations in mental functioning since the rise of advance care directives in the 1990s.

headline: Once a Scrappy Underdog, the Padres Adjust to Penthouse Life
abstract: A roster that boasts 37 All-Star selections has one of Major League Baseball’s highest payrolls. It comes with loads of enthusiasm, and expectations to match.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Xander Bogaerts faced a dilemma. He had just unboxed a custom pair of spiffy brown cleats with yellow accents that popped. And as he sat at his locker handling them some four hours before his first opening day with the Padres, he asked someone standing nearby a colorful question.

headline: Republicans Can’t Agree on a Path Out of Their Own Debt Crisis
abstract: House Republicans have become so factionalized that their leaders cannot speak in one voice.
lead_paragraph: It’s been obvious for months that Republicans in the House of Representatives intend to lead the country toward a calamitous debt ceiling crisis in order to get their way on spending. Only in the last few weeks, however, has it become clear just how truly chaotic that process will be.

headline: To Boldly Go Where No President Has Gone Before
abstract: “Uncharted territory” doesn’t begin to cover it.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I have a clear memory of Democrats defending Bill Clinton tooth and nail for lying under oath in the Paula Jones case, about his affair with Monica Lewinsky. At the time, they said it was “just about sex” and that Clinton lied to protect his family and marriage.

headline: Noncompete Clauses Get Tighter, and TV Newsrooms Feel the Grip
abstract: Job-switching barriers are routine at TV stations, even for workers not on the air. A proposed federal rule would curb the practice across all fields.
lead_paragraph: Of all the professions, perhaps none is more commonly bound by contracts that define where else an employee can go work than local television news.

headline: The Rich World Has a Shockingly High Tolerance for Cruelty
abstract: We’re living in a world where the sanctuaries are actually prisons.
lead_paragraph: When a fire broke out last week at a Mexican detention center for migrants and asylum seekers in Ciudad Juárez, just across the border from El Paso, it seemed like cosmically bad luck, a double tragedy: People forced — by political instability, criminal violence, climate change or economic deprivation — to flee their homes, faced a devastating fire while trying to seek refuge. At least 39 people died. The world took notice. Mexican authorities launched a criminal investigation.

headline: Hoping to Travel Abroad? Don’t Put Off Your Passport Application.
abstract: Processing times for new and renewed passports have increased again. The updated timeline, 10 to 13 weeks, leaves some would-be travelers feeling desperate.
lead_paragraph: With international travel beckoning this summer, Americans applying for new or renewed passports will have to practice patience: The State Department warned that it will take even longer to get their documents.

headline: How Long Without Outdoor Exercise Is Too Long for a Prisoner in Solitary?
abstract: “Exercise is a basic human need, and its long-term denial may constitute cruel and unusual punishment,” said prison officials, who also asserted three years was tolerable. The case could reach the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Michael Johnson, a prisoner in Illinois, suffered from what the corrections system acknowledged was profound mental illness. That made him hard to handle, and prison officials responded by putting him in solitary confinement. Total isolation, in a windowless cell, made things worse.

headline: A Rape Conviction Was Tossed Out Because the Investigation Was Too Slow
abstract: The decision by the New York Court of Appeals could give prosecutors a reason to abandon difficult cases, advocates for victims say.
lead_paragraph: In August 2009, two couples went out drinking after a wedding.

headline: ‘Hot Ones’ Was a Slow Burn All Along
abstract: This YouTube talk show’s premise is simple: Disarm celebrities with deep-cut questions and scorchingly spicy wings. Nearly 300 episodes later, the recipe still works.
lead_paragraph: Bob Odenkirk was dubious when he walked onto the set of the long-running YouTube interview show “Hot Ones” last month. He was, after all, about to take on the “wings of death,” as the lineup of treacherously spicy chicken is called.

headline: California Salmon Stocks Are Crashing. A Fishing Ban Looks Certain.
abstract: Scientists say alarming declines at the southern end of the fishes’ range may be a sign of what’s to come as waters warm farther north.
lead_paragraph: This week, officials are expected to shut down all commercial and recreational salmon fishing off California for 2023. Much will be canceled off neighboring Oregon, too.

headline: Netflix’s Approach Shifts, Pushing Content That Can ‘Pop’
abstract: The streaming service long thought spending on ads didn’t result in more viewers. That has subtly changed under the marketing chief Marian Lee.
lead_paragraph: Netflix made sure viewers had ample opportunity to hear about “Wednesday,” its macabre hit starring Jenna Ortega.

headline: As Classic Novels Get Revised for Today’s Readers, a Debate About Where to Draw the Line
abstract: Agatha Christie. Roald Dahl. Ian Fleming. Classics are being reworked to remove offensive language. But some readers wonder, when does posthumous editing go too far?
lead_paragraph: The estates of several revered literary figures are altering portions of well-known works to conform to current sensibilities, stirring a heated debate among readers and the literary world over whether, and how, classics should be updated.

headline: She Was Killed in Front of Her Son. It Took 26 Years to Crack the Case.
abstract: Inside a cold-case detective’s dogged quest to solve the murder of Jasmine Porter.
lead_paragraph: The officers entering the room saw her slender frame lifeless on the bed. Her baby bump was visible. A little boy was wiping the blood under her nose.

headline: How the U.S., Family and Hollywood Freed the ‘Hotel Rwanda’ Hero
abstract: Paul Rusesabagina, depicted in the 2004 film about genocide in his country, was reunited with his family last week. It took years of pressure to get him out of Rwanda, where he was convicted on terrorism charges.
lead_paragraph: Rwanda’s leader was in combative form last December when, on a visit to Washington, he was asked about his country’s most famous political prisoner, and his personal foe.

headline: What Would Happen if Women Athletes Got the Mythology Treatment They Deserve?
abstract: Time, instead of adding to the luster of women’s sports as it does men’s, erodes it.
lead_paragraph: The photograph of Muhammad Ali flexing over a fallen Sonny Liston is one of the most famous in sports history. The moment, and the image, are iconic, sold in every format imaginable, while also helping mythologize an athlete, a sport and even an era.

headline: New Weapons Aren’t Enough: The Challenges of Ukraine’s Coming Assault
abstract: With powerful Western weapons, newly formed assault units and even a reconstituted Azov battalion, Ukraine is poised for a critical spring counteroffensive. But overcoming casualties and keeping war-weary troops motivated will be stern tests.
lead_paragraph: In vicious but mostly static fighting in snowy, artillery-cratered fields and ruined cities, Ukraine rebuffed a Russian offensive over the winter. Now, it is Ukraine’s turn to go on the attack.

headline: Ex-Principal Extradited From Israel Is Convicted of Abuse in Australia
abstract: Malka Leifer, who had led an ultra-Orthodox Jewish girls’ school in Melbourne, was found guilty of sexually abusing students more than 15 years ago.
lead_paragraph: The former principal of a girls’ school in Melbourne, Australia, was found guilty Monday on 18 charges of sexually abusing two students more than 15 years ago in a case whose yearslong extradition battle tested relations between Australia and Israel.

headline: Oil Prices Jump, as OPEC Production Cut Draws U.S. Concern
abstract: A Saudi-led move to reduce output among major oil producers pushed prices higher. The White House said it didn’t think the cuts were warranted.
lead_paragraph: Oil prices surged on Monday and U.S. officials voiced their displeasure a day after OPEC members announced substantial cuts in production, a move that reaffirmed Saudi Arabia, the group’s leader, as a headstrong giant in the oil market.

headline: Fear and Bravado: Inside Trump’s Reaction to the Indictment
abstract: What the impending arrest of former President Donald J. Trump means both for him and for the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: After Donald J. Trump was indicted over his role in paying hush money to a porn star during the 2016 presidential campaign, he called the move an act of political persecution.

headline: Super PAC Backing DeSantis Says It Has Raised $30 Million
abstract: Fund-raising is predicted to be a strength for Ron DeSantis, who is expected to announce his bid for the Republican presidential nomination in the coming months.
lead_paragraph: The super PAC that is likely to serve as the main vehicle supporting Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida in a Republican presidential primary has raised $30 million since March 9, a senior official with the group said on Sunday night.

headline: The Year’s Biggest Election
abstract: The battle for a state Supreme Court seat in Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: Wisconsin is a microcosm of the country. It is narrowly divided politically, though Democrats have a slight advantage in the popular vote in statewide elections. And, as in Washington, Republicans have structural advantages in the government that give them outsize power.

headline: Sam Shepard and the Art of Expressing the Unsaid
abstract: “True West” is a new biography of a playwright and actor who was laconic in person but spoke volumes in his work.
lead_paragraph: The first rule of being Bob Dylan’s friend, it’s said, is to not talk about Bob Dylan. A similar code of omertà appears to apply to Sam Shepard, the playwright and actor, and it has held since his death in 2017. A lot of people have lined up to not talk to his latest biographer, mostly the same people who lined up to not talk to the previous ones.

headline: Endeavor and W.W.E. Join Forces to Create Live-Combat Tag Team
abstract: The new company, with the stock ticker “TKO,” is betting that the value of rights for live events like wrestling will continue to soar.
lead_paragraph: The tens of thousands of fans who crowded into SoFi Stadium in Los Angeles for WrestleMania this weekend got to watch the wrestling icon John Cena be hurled to the canvas by Austin Theory, one of World Wrestling Entertainment’s biggest stars.

headline: ‘Pretty Baby: Brooke Shields’ Review: Girlhood, Interrupted
abstract: Lana Wilson’s documentary blossoms in moments of cultural commentary, where it builds a mood of reminiscence gone rancid.
lead_paragraph: In the 1978 Louis Malle drama “Pretty Baby,” Brooke Shields plays a child whose virginity is auctioned off in a New Orleans brothel. She was 11 at the time of filming. That film’s title gets reappropriated in the director Lana Wilson’s absorbing documentary, “Pretty Baby: Brooke Shields,” which emulsifies its biography of Shields with lucid insights into the culture that shaped her.

headline: Right-Wing Media Splits From DeSantis on Press Protections
abstract: Gov. Ron DeSantis’s war against mainstream media outlets is poised to wound even his boosters in the conservative press. Is the Florida governor biting the hand that feeds him?
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis has long courted right-wing news outlets, while dismissing mainstream reporters as biased and untrustworthy. But legislation that would sharply curb press freedom in Florida is creating a rare rift between the governor and the media that have helped propel his rise.

headline: A Hollywood Superagent Buys a Pro Wrestling Heavyweight
abstract: Ari Emanuel’s Endeavor acquires World Wrestling Entertainment to create a live event and combat sport giant.
lead_paragraph: Ari Emanuel’s media colossus Endeavor, whose properties include the Ultimate Fighting Championship, has agreed to buy World Wrestling Entertainment, creating a live event behemoth and cementing its status as a leader in combat sport competitions.

headline: $900,000 Homes in California
abstract: An 1895 Victorian in Los Angeles, a two-bedroom condominium in San Diego and a 1929 Tudor Revival house in El Cerrito.
lead_paragraph: This house, known as the John C. Hayes Residence, was moved to its current site in Boyle Heights in 1925 by Charles Lantz, a previous owner. Many of the original details, including the Douglas fir floors, are well preserved, and several rooms have period-appropriate light fixtures.

headline: Why You Should Double-Check That S.T.I. Test
abstract: Fake tests for sexually transmitted infections are readily available online — “for entertainment purposes only.” But what happens when they’re used deceptively?
lead_paragraph: After messaging with a man on Tinder for about a week, a Las Vegas woman decided she wanted to sleep with him. She shared with him her recent S.T.I. test and asked for his — a standard practice for her — but pretty soon she noticed something strange about the document.

headline: Andrew Tate Is Released From Jail and Placed Under House Arrest
abstract: Mr. Tate, the social media influencer, and his brother Tristan had been in custody since December, when they were arrested on allegations of human trafficking, rape and forming an organized criminal group.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Tate, an online personality known for his misogynistic comments, has been released from jail in Romania along with his brother and placed under house arrest while they are being investigated on allegations of human trafficking, rape and forming an organized criminal group.

headline: Wagner claims ‘legal’ control of Bakhmut, while Ukraine says it is still fighting.
abstract: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the Wagner group founder, said Russian forces had raised their country’s flag in the center of Bakhmut.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — The head of Russia’s Wagner mercenary group claimed that Russian forces had raised their country’s flag in the center of Bakhmut, but a senior Ukrainian official said on Monday that Kyiv’s forces were still fighting for the embattled eastern city.

headline: In Paris Referendum, 89% of Voters Back a Ban on Electric Scooters
abstract: A referendum emphasized how many residents had come to regard the scooters as dangerous nuisances with little environmental benefit. Other cities were closely watching the vote.
lead_paragraph: An overwhelming majority of Parisians who took part in a referendum on rental electric scooters have voted to ban the devices from the streets of the French capital, reflecting exhaustion with a public-transit alternative that was once seen as convenient and climate-friendly but is now largely regarded as dangerous and environmentally questionable.

headline: North Koreans Trapped in ‘State-Sponsored Slavery’ in Russia
abstract: Despite sanctions and the pandemic, laborers from the country remain abroad, earning desperately needed cash for the regime, according to a new report.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — For more than three decades, North Korea ​has sent workers abroad to make money for its regime.

headline: The Resurrection of Tulare Lake
abstract: The largest body of fresh water west of the Mississippi was drained by farmers more than a century ago. Now it’s back.
lead_paragraph: CORCORAN — Crisscrossing the dry flatlands of the San Joaquin Valley last week, I drove along a narrow country road just outside this small agricultural town known as the “Farming Capital of California,” tilled dirt fields on either side of me as far as the eye could see.

headline: The Best Carry-On Travel Backpacks
Assassinated Pro-War Blogger Was Part of a Radical Russian Movement
abstract: The blogger killed in a bombing in St. Petersburg was one of the influential ultranationalists pushing for harsher pursuit of Russia’s war against Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The Russian military blogger killed on Sunday in an explosion in St. Petersburg was a prominent figure in an increasingly vocal and influential movement of hawkish, ultranationalist figures who broadly support the Kremlin’s war against Ukraine, but often criticize how the war is conducted.

headline: Biden’s Reluctant Approach to Free Trade Draws Backlash
abstract: A law intended to bolster clean energy manufacturing has ignited debate over whether the U.S. should work to break down international trade barriers — or keep them intact to protect American workers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since President Biden came into office two years ago, the United States has declined to pursue new comprehensive free-trade agreements with other countries, arguing that most Americans have turned against the kind of pacts that promote global commerce but that also help to send factory jobs overseas.

headline: Death and Justice on the Border: A Migrant Is Killed, a Rancher Is Charged
abstract: An unarmed Mexican man was shot as he crossed an Arizona ranch. The case against the ranch owner has prompted a backlash among supporters who say he is the real victim.
lead_paragraph: KINO SPRINGS, Ariz. — Gabriel Cuen-Buitimea was slipping across a rancher’s land near the border with Mexico when the shooting started. “I’m hit,” he said, before his eyes rolled back and he crumpled face down by a mesquite tree.

headline: Make Way for Generously Buttered Gochujang Noodles
abstract: Eric Kim’s pantry-friendly recipe is perfect for days when you haven’t gone grocery shopping.
lead_paragraph: One genre of home cooking consistently saves me on days when I haven’t gone food shopping, and I need to eat something immediately: the pantry pasta.

headline: Bubba Watson Knows People Are Mad. He Loves LIV Golf Anyway.
abstract: The two-time Masters Tournament winner talked with The Times ahead of his return to Augusta National Golf Club, where every member of his LIV team will be in the field.
lead_paragraph: MARANA, Ariz. — A decade ago, Bubba Watson returned to Augusta National Golf Club as the Masters Tournament’s reigning winner. Back then, he seemed to be known as much as the champion who had cried as the one who had beaten Louis Oosthuizen in a playoff.

headline: Morgan Wallen Makes It Four Weeks at No. 1 With ‘One Thing at a Time’
abstract: The country superstar’s latest album easily held off new releases by Lana Del Rey and Jimin of the K-pop group BTS.
lead_paragraph: Another week, another No. 1 for Morgan Wallen, the mullet-maned country superstar whose latest album, “One Thing at a Time,” notches a fourth time at the top despite competition from new releases by Lana Del Rey and Jimin of the K-pop giants BTS.

headline: Auto Sales Withstand Higher Interest Rates, So Far
abstract: General Motors and several rivals cited robust demand in the first quarter. But affordability is a growing challenge for many buyers.
lead_paragraph: Automakers have mostly overcome the supply-chain challenges that upended production early in the pandemic. Now they are trying to weather a new challenge: higher borrowing costs for their customers.

headline: The Legacy of the Hip-Hop Visionary J Dilla
abstract: The producer and artist, born James Dewitt Yancey, died in 2006 at 32. The debate continues over who should control his legacy.
lead_paragraph: Watch our new documentary on FX and Hulu.

headline: Meet the four astronauts of Artemis II.
abstract: Three NASA astronauts and a Canadian will fly around the moon in 2024. Here’s what you need to know about them.
lead_paragraph: NASA on Monday announced a crew of four astronauts who will head to the moon within the next two years. The crew will travel around the moon and back on a 10-day mission.

headline: Why Does Our Society Produce So Many Mass Murderers?
abstract: Readers react to the mass shooting in Nashville. Also: Cheaper baseball games; listening to adversaries; Daniel Ellsberg’s inspiration to many.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: See What California’s Record Snowpack Looks Like, Up Close
abstract: Sensors on low-flying planes can measure mountaintop snow with great precision, helping forecasters predict what will happen as it melts.
lead_paragraph: Up and down the high slopes of the Sierra Nevada, the barrage of heavy storms that deluged California this winter also left behind a giant frozen reservoir, one whose thawing will shape the next phase of what has already been a remarkably wet year for the drought-weary state.

headline: Ex-Leader of Kosovo Pleads Not Guilty to War Crimes Charges
abstract: Hashim Thaci, the former president and prime minister, went on trial in The Hague on charges related to the country’s bloody fight for independence.
lead_paragraph: Hashim Thaci, the former president and prime minister of Kosovo, is seen as a war hero in many parts of his homeland, where he led the Balkan country in its fight for independence from Serbia that started nearly a quarter of a century ago.

headline: A Plan to Force More Housing Development in New York Has Failed
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul’s plan for addressing the state’s housing shortage met resistance in places like Westchester County and Long Island.
lead_paragraph: An aggressive housing plan promoted by Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York, which she hoped would create 800,000 new homes across the state over the next decade, has fallen apart in Albany after meeting fierce resistance from state legislators.

headline: Golden State Ponders Defending a Title When It Can’t Win on the Road
abstract: A loss to the Nuggets dropped the champions to 9-30 away from home.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — As various members of the Golden State Warriors began to filter out of the visiting locker room at Ball Arena on Sunday night, Klay Thompson sat silently on a folding chair with his head bowed. He fiddled with a wristband. He was still wearing his game shorts.

headline: At 150, Rachmaninoff and His Music Are ‘Here to Stay’
abstract: Kirill Gerstein, who has recorded a new account of the Second Piano Concerto with the Berlin Philharmonic, discusses the composer’s polarizing legacy.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — What should we think of Sergei Rachmaninoff 150 years after his birth?

headline: Hot Cross Buns Are the Pumpkin Spice Latte of Australia
abstract: The warmly spiced Easter bread and the arrival of fall are a match — and mania — made Down Under.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — To Kate Reid, the founder of Lune Croissanterie, there’s only one way to eat a hot cross bun: torn apart, with cold butter and salt, after a few minutes in the oven just to get the top crisp.

headline: Chelsea Ran Up the Bill. Its Coach Paid the Price.
abstract: American owners spent billions to buy the Premier League club and then millions more on players. But as Chelsea sinks in the standings, is the worst still ahead?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Every week, it seemed, Chelsea officials worked their phones to quiet the whispers that Graham Potter was about to be fired. And every week the news media quickly relayed those reassurances to Chelsea’s fans, even as the defeats mounted, the grumbling grew louder and the team’s plunge down the Premier League table showed little sign of slowing.

headline: DeSantis and Disney Clash Anew Over Florida Theme Park’s Authority
abstract: The Florida governor wants the state inspector general to look into Disney’s efforts to limit oversight of Walt Disney World. The company called his action “anti-business.”
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida and the Walt Disney Company clashed anew on Monday, with the governor requesting an investigation into Disney’s effort to sidestep state oversight of its theme parks and Robert A. Iger, Disney’s chief executive, blasting Mr. DeSantis as “anti-business” and “anti-Florida.”

headline: Canada Earns a Spot Among NASA’s Artemis II Crew
abstract: A Canadian astronaut will join the Artemis II crew in return for Canada’s future delivery of a robotic arm to the American-led lunar Gateway project.
lead_paragraph: The space program in Canada may not have a whopping budget, but it does have one thing that other countries don’t: a spot aboard NASA’s Artemis II mission to the moon.

headline: NASA Names Diverse Astronaut Crew for Artemis II Moon Mission
abstract: The crew’s 10-day journey around the moon and back in 2024 is a crucial step toward returning Americans to the moon on a sustained basis.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — For the first time in more than half a century, NASA has named a crew of astronauts headed to the moon.

headline: What to Know About Bacteria and Eye Drops
abstract: Watch for symptoms of infection and do not use recalled or expired products.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has warned people to stop using “artificial tear” eye drops sold by EzriCare or Delsam Pharma, noting that an “extensively” antibiotic-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacteria has been found in multiple open containers of the drops. Officials investigating the outbreak have also seen signs of a spread beyond those who used the drops to others in the same health care center. The products have been subject to a nationwide recall.

headline: Trump Arrives in New York for an Arraignment That Will Make History
abstract: Mayor Adams told protesters that the city “is always ready” as Donald J. Trump returned to Trump Tower on the eve of becoming the first ex-president to be indicted.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump traveled to New York from Florida on Monday to face arraignment in the first indictment of a former American president, his trip monitored minutely from the moment he left his Palm Beach estate until he arrived at Trump Tower in Midtown.

headline: They Have Finished Moving 225 Tons of Reimagined Art
abstract: With considerable effort, a landscape sculpture featuring huge granite boulders has been trucked across Washington, D.C., to its new home at American University.
lead_paragraph: For four decades, a sculpture of artfully placed granite boulders bordering a reflecting pool occupied the courtyard of an international headquarters in Washington D.C., creating an urban oasis in the shadows of the tall modernist buildings.

headline: Yeshiva University’s Ban on L.G.B.T.Q. Club Leads to Scrutiny of Funding
abstract: A lawmaker asked inspectors to look at millions given to the university, which has argued it is a religious institution, not an educational one, to justify its ban on an L.G.B.T.Q. club.
lead_paragraph: A state inspector has been asked to review whether Yeshiva University, which is in a court battle with a group of L.G.B.T.Q. students over whether it must recognize their campus club, should have received $230 million in taxpayer funds after the university has said that it is a religious institution.

headline: What Is the Ideal Retirement Age for Your Health?
abstract: Average life expectancy has risen by 16 years since the national retirement age was set at 65. We asked health experts when they think people should stop working now.
lead_paragraph: In 1881, the conservative German Chancellor Otto von Bismarck, plagued by a rise in socialist ideology, proposed a national retirement benefit to appease the leftist masses. He set the retirement age at 70. Average life expectancy at the time? About 40 years.

headline: F.T.C. Orders Gene-Sequencing Company Illumina to Divest Acquisition
abstract: The move by the commission is seen as a test of regulators’ efforts to prevent big companies from buying small innovators.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission on Monday ordered Illumina, the leading maker of gene-sequencing machines, to divest Grail, a cancer-test developer.

headline: Millions on Medicaid May Soon Lose Coverage as Pandemic Protections Expire
abstract: A requirement that states keep people on Medicaid during the coronavirus pandemic has come to an end, and 15 million people could lose their coverage as a result.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — In a closet-sized windowless office, Kialah Marshall maintains an Excel spreadsheet with a prosaic title, “Medicaid Unwinding,” the source material for a mind-numbing routine.

headline: New Marburg Outbreaks in Africa Raise Alarm About the Deadly Virus’s Spread
abstract: The spread of the Ebola-like virus has claimed lives but could be a crucial chance to test a vaccine — if supplies and researchers are mobilized in time.
lead_paragraph: Two concurrent outbreaks of the Marburg virus, a close cousin of Ebola that can kill as many as 90 percent of the people it infects, are raising critical questions about the behavior of this mysterious bat-borne pathogen and global efforts to prepare for potential pandemics.

headline: We’re Told to Forgive. What Does That Mean?
abstract: In “Seventy Times Seven,” Alex Mar traces the complex, human story of a heinous tragedy and its fallout.
lead_paragraph: For a culture with a simmering anger problem, we spend a lot of time preoccupied with forgiveness: From 12-step programs advocating amends, to asana yoga classes dedicated to radical compassion, to forgiveness spells available for purchase on Etsy, we are regularly reminded that personal growth requires us to forgive.

headline: Hamline University’s President Announces Retirement After Prophet Muhammad Controversy
abstract: Fayneese S. Miller found herself in a fierce debate over academic freedom and Islamophobia, after an art history lecturer lost her job for showing images of the prophet.
lead_paragraph: The president of Hamline University, who had been under sharp criticism for the treatment of an adjunct professor who showed images of the Prophet Muhammad in an art history class, announced on Monday that she would retire in June 2024.

headline: ‘What Happened to My Brother?’: A Desperate Search in Mexico
abstract: After a deadly fire in a migrant detention center in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, some victims’ families and friends are still looking for answers about their loved ones.
lead_paragraph: After a deadly fire in a migrant detention center in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, some victims’ families and friends are still looking for answers about their loved ones.

headline: ‘No One Gives Me Answers:’ Migrants Search for Bodies of Loved Ones After Mexico Fire
abstract: After a deadly fire in a migrant detention center in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, some victims’ families and friends are still looking for answers about their loved ones.
lead_paragraph: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — One week after a deadly fire in a migrant detention center in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, left 39 people dead and dozens more seriously injured, some victims’ families and friends are still looking for answers about their loved ones.

headline: ‘Yes, I Can Say That!’ Review: The Freedom to Offend
abstract: The comedian Judy Gold’s new solo show at 59E59 Theaters is deliberately uncomfortable — and packed with laughs.
lead_paragraph: The knuckle-dragging notion that women aren’t funny makes only a cameo in the comedian Judy Gold’s new solo show, “Yes, I Can Say That!” It’s tucked amid her homage to pioneering forebears like Totie Fields and Joan Rivers, who, Gold tells the audience, “said out loud what women whispered about when their husbands weren’t around.”

headline: The 2020s Don’t Have to Be a ‘Lost Decade’
abstract: A new World Bank report warns of a global slowdown of economic growth. But there’s hope.
lead_paragraph: How fast a country grows is important. What’s even more important — but harder to know — is how fast the country is capable of growing. The leader of a country that’s growing rapidly may be all smiles, but if the growth is faster than what’s sustainable, it will end in tears — and high inflation, as the demand for goods and services exceeds what the economy is capable of producing in the long run.

headline: The Brides Wore ’90s Dior. And ’00s Margiela. And ’80s Chanel.
abstract: With vintage fashion in high demand, the hunt for archival designer wedding dresses is becoming serious business.
lead_paragraph: One of the most intimate questions you can ask eBay power users is to show you their negotiations — the private DMs they exchange with sellers bargaining over the price of an item. But Alexis Novak humored me.

headline: 2 Construction Workers Dead at J.F.K. After Being Buried Under Rubble
abstract: The workers died after being trapped under debris while moving utility lines at the airport, officials said. An investigation was underway.
lead_paragraph: Two workers were killed at Kennedy International Airport on Monday when they were buried under construction rubble inside a trench while moving utility lines as part of a broader overhaul at the airport, officials said.

headline: Film Club: Explore Wonders of the World Through New York Times 360 V.R. Videos
abstract: Where in the world would you most like to travel?
lead_paragraph: Do you love to travel? What’s the most memorable place you have ever visited?

headline: Who Is NASA Sending to Fly Around the Moon?
The woman arrested in a Russian pro-war blogger’s death had attended opposition rallies.
abstract: Russian investigators arrested Daria Trepova, a 26-year-old native of St. Petersburg, on Monday in connection with the killing of the blogger known as Vladlen Tatarsky
lead_paragraph: The woman who has been arrested in the bombing death of a popular pro-war blogger in Russia was at least a casual supporter of the country’s opposition, according to a friend, court records and local news reports.

headline: Daft Punk’s Thomas Bangalter Reveals Himself: As a Composer
abstract: After more than two decades at the forefront of electronic dance music (while in a robot-style helmet), the French artist is releasing “Mythologies,” a score for traditional symphony orchestra.
lead_paragraph: The most shocking part of “Mythologies,” a ballet that premiered last summer in Bordeaux, France, came after the dance was over. It was a seemingly normal moment: The composer of the music came out and took a bow.

headline: Evan Gershkovich, the American reporter detained in Moscow, appeals his arrest.
abstract: Mr. Gershkovich was detained last Thursday while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinberg, Russia. His newspaper, The Wall Street Journal, and U.S. officials reject the charges of espionage against him as bogus.
lead_paragraph: Evan Gershkovich, the Wall Street Journal reporter who was detained in Russia last week, has appealed his arrest, according to Russian state news agencies, which cited Moscow’s Lefortovo court in their reports on Monday.

headline: Remembering the Last Night of the Titanic Through Food
abstract: Join the author of a book on the ship’s sinking at the 92nd Street Y,  try pasta made from upcycled flour and more.
lead_paragraph: Coinciding with the anniversary of the Titanic sinking, on April 15, 1912, there will be a two-part virtual talk from the 92nd Street Y covering the ways of not just top-hatted and bejeweled first class passengers like the Astors and Guggenheims, but also the less fortunate huddled in steerage, and even the crew. Veronica Hinke, the author of “The Last Night on the Titanic: Unsinkable Drinking, Dining and Style,” to be published in paperback next week, will provide the details‌. As in the book, she plans to cover the demands of style that defined luxury in the late Edwardian era, the games the passengers played on board, menus from the ship with recipes for some dishes, like English pea soufflé and apple meringue, and the pre-Prohibition drinks that were served in first class. Included will be what people down in third class ate and drank. She will also describe life on board as recounted by survivors and family members of those who sailed.

headline: This Is Not a Moment in Women’s Basketball. It’s Momentum.
abstract: This year’s women’s N.C.A.A. tournament brought new depth, a breadth of talent and record numbers of viewers. But what you are seeing isn’t new.
lead_paragraph: Get ready for the declarations.

headline: A Matzo Brei That’s Sweet, Savory and Just a Little Spicy
abstract: Melissa Clark tweaks the classic, adding feta, hot honey and herbs.
lead_paragraph: Passover lasts eight days, and you might attend one or even two Seders. But how many matzo breis will you fry?

headline: Twitter Users Are Still Waiting for a Check-Mark Reckoning
abstract: The promised changes to the platform’s verification program have been slow. Attention has focused instead on the image of a doge in place of the blue Twitter bird.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter users anticipated a reckoning over the weekend as the verification check marks that denoted the accounts of celebrities, politicians and other notable figures and organizations were set to be removed en masse.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Ukraine Prepares a Counteroffensive
abstract: Also, Trump returns to New York to surrender and North Koreans remain in “state-sponsored slavery” abroad.

headline: Jury Says Tesla Must Pay Worker $3.2 Million Over Racist Treatment
abstract: A former Tesla factory worker, who is Black, challenged a judge’s earlier award of $15 million, but came away with less in a new trial.
lead_paragraph: A federal jury in San Francisco ordered Tesla on Monday to pay about $3.2 million to a Black man who had accused the carmaker of ignoring racial abuse he faced while working at its California factory.

headline: Gov. Murphy Signs Law Decried as a ‘Frontal Assault’ on Good Government
abstract: The bill doubles New Jersey’s campaign contribution limits and quashes investigations by a watchdog agency.
lead_paragraph: In January, a watchdog agency created 50 years ago to safeguard the integrity of campaign fund-raising in New Jersey filed four complaints. Three cited irregularities in powerful Democrat-led accounts, and one dinged a committee set up to elect Republicans.

headline: Trump Arrives in New York City for His Arraignment
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump is expected to surrender at the office of the Manhattan district attorney, before being arraigned in the Manhattan Criminal Courts Building on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump is expected to surrender at the office of the Manhattan district attorney, before being arraigned in the Manhattan Criminal Courts Building on Tuesday.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Comedians in Stores Selling Lamps
abstract: Mike Karnell, a writer and director for “Late Night With Seth Meyers,” recently opened FloraLuce, a specialty lighting shop in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: While on hiatus last spring from his job as a writer and director for “Late Night With Seth Meyers,” Mike Karnell went to Mercanteinfiera, a trade fair in Parma, Italy, where he had one mission: Find the lamps. There, he met an older Italian vendor who invited Mr. Karnell to visit his warehouses in Milan.

headline: Russia Accuses Dissidents and Ukraine of Killing Pro-War Blogger
abstract: The authorities detained a woman they said had delivered the bomb, hidden in a statuette, that killed the blogger, and called it the work of antigovernment activists and Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The Russian authorities on Monday detained a suspect in the bombing that killed a popular pro-war blogger in the center of St. Petersburg, and blamed Ukraine and Russian opposition activists for the attack, signaling that the Kremlin could use the explosion to escalate its harsh crackdown against what remains of antiwar activism in Russia.

headline: Lesson Plan: What Does the Indictment of Donald Trump Mean for the Country?
abstract: Donald J. Trump was indicted on March 30 in Manhattan, becoming the first American president, current or former, to be charged with a crime. What does that mean for our democracy?
lead_paragraph: Update: Former President Donald J. Trump pleaded not guilty to 34 felony counts in a Manhattan courtroom on Tuesday, April 4; and the charges were unsealed in the case. You can read more about his dramatic day in court and the indictment charges.

headline: 3 Men Charged in Drugging Murders and Robberies at Manhattan Gay Bars
abstract: The men were arraigned after their arrests in connection to a string of attacks at the bars last year.
lead_paragraph: Three men were charged on Monday, two of them with murder, in a series of fatal druggings at Manhattan gay bars that killed two people and have spread fear through the city’s L.G.B.T.Q. community.

headline: Raghavan Iyer, 61, Dies; Made Indian Cooking Accessible Across America
abstract: He broke with traditions in writing cookbooks, teaching thousands of cooks, consulting for restaurants, leading tours, catering meals and creating frozen dinners.
lead_paragraph: Raghavan Iyer, who left India for the United States  as a young man clueless about how to cook even a simple potato curry and went on to teach America’s heartland how to prepare one of the world’s most complex cuisines, died on Friday in San Francisco. He was 61.

headline: Brooke Shields and the Curse of Great Beauty
abstract: “Pretty Baby,” a new documentary on Hulu, explores the toll that sexual and commercial objectification takes on women.
lead_paragraph: What is the price of great, commercially celebrated beauty? What pain and loss accompany it? And what happens to a young girl turned into an icon before even hitting puberty? These key questions are addressed in “Pretty Baby,” a thoughtful and moving documentary about Brooke Shields that premiered on Hulu on April 3.

headline: Strange Days at the U.N. as Russia Takes the Helm of the Security Council
abstract: The monthlong presidency of an organization dedicated to preserving world peace is now in the hands of a nation waging the biggest land war in Europe in decades.
lead_paragraph: The world panel created three-quarters of a century ago to maintain international peace and security met in New York on Monday under its new leadership: the nation that has plunged Europe into its biggest land conflict since World War II.

headline: Trump, on Eve of Surrender, Adds Former U.S. Prosecutor to Defense Team
abstract: Todd Blanche previously represented Mr. Trump’s former campaign chairman, Paul Manafort.
lead_paragraph: A day before former President Donald J. Trump was to surrender to face charges stemming from a hush-money payment, he added a new lawyer to his defense team, a former federal prosecutor with wide experience in white-collar cases.

headline: Emahoy Tsegué-Maryam Guèbrou, Nun With a Musical Gift, Dies at 99
abstract: Ethiopian-born, she was on track to be a concert pianist before choosing a monastic life. But her later piano recordings gained fans. Norah Jones called them “beautiful.”
lead_paragraph: “Honky tonk” and “nun” are words not often seen in combination, but in 2017, when the BBC broadcast a radio documentary about the pianist and composer Emahoy Tsegué-Maryam Guèbrou, “The Honky Tonk Nun” was the title of choice.

headline: Understanding the Red State Death Trip
abstract: Politics probably explain America’s poor life expectancy.
lead_paragraph: Last Friday the Medicare trustees released their latest report on the system’s finances, and it contained some unexpected good news: Expenditures are running below projections, and the Hospital Insurance Trust Fund won’t be exhausted as soon as previously predicted.

headline: San Diego State’s Deep Run Plays Right Into Conference Realignment
abstract: San Diego State had set itself up for this moment. Not just for a run at a championship, but for jumping to a bigger conference.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Whether or not John David Wicker, the San Diego State athletic director, owns many leather-bound books or an apartment that smells of rich mahogany, he could be pardoned for channeling his inner Ron Burgundy.

headline: N.C.A.A. Women’s Tournament Shatters Ratings Record in Final
abstract: The average 9.9 million viewers for Louisiana State topping Iowa was significantly more than the previous record of 5.7 million for an N.C.A.A. women’s tournament game, achieved in 2002 when Connecticut won the title.
lead_paragraph: The gritty battle for the women’s college basketball championship on Sunday between Louisiana State and Iowa drew an average of 9.9 million viewers, making it the most viewed N.C.A.A. women’s basketball final in television history, ESPN said on Monday. Peak viewership hovered around 12.6 million views and overall viewership was about double the viewership of the championship game last year.

headline: Nigel Lawson, Economic Force Under Thatcher, Dies at 91
abstract: As chancellor of the Exchequer, he helped lift Britain with tax cuts and other Conservative measures — the “Lawson Boom” — but harder times followed, and he resigned in bitterness.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Nigel Lawson, a Conservative politician and journalist who helped turn around Britain’s economy under Margaret Thatcher but who quit the government in a bitter dispute over monetary policy, has died. He was 91.

headline: Corrections: April 4, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, April 4, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about Russian shelling that killed six civilians in Ukraine referred incorrectly to the number of civilians killed in Ukraine. The United Nations has recorded roughly 8,400 civilian deaths, not roughly 18,000, since Russia launched its full-scale invasion in February 2022.

abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, April 4, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Most of the salmon populations around the entire Pacific Rim have been doing very, very poorly.”

headline: UConn Wins Fifth N.C.A.A. Title by Overwhelming San Diego State
abstract: UConn’s 76-59 victory ended a dominant tournament run in which it won every game by double figures.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The Connecticut men’s basketball team has endured many tribulations in recent weeks. The Huskies walked into soiled hotel rooms when they arrived in Las Vegas for their first games in the N.C.A.A. tournament. Their bus was broken into while they were at practice. And Jordan Hawkins, their star guard, was curled up on the floor of his hotel room on Friday, stricken with illness and complaining about some calamari.

headline: As Temperatures Rise, Melbourne’s Bats Get Their Own Sprinkler System
abstract: On the hottest days, a refreshing mist will cool down flying foxes, which have suffered mass death in Australian heat waves.
lead_paragraph: Every evening, tens of thousands of gray-headed flying foxes fan across the sky above Melbourne, Australia.

lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: China Strikes Back at U.S. Chip Maker Even as It Signals Openness
abstract: Beijing’s security review of Micron Technology, which has deep roots in China, could have wide-ranging ramifications for other foreign businesses.
lead_paragraph: When top Chinese officials held receptions for dozens of American and European business executives at back-to-back annual economic forums last week, the intended message was clear: China is open for business.

headline: Wisconsin’s High-Stakes Supreme Court Race: What to Watch
abstract: The election for a swing seat on the court is likely to determine whether abortion remains illegal in Wisconsin, as well as the future of the state’s heavily gerrymandered political maps.

headline: Mass Yellowstone Hunt Kills 1,150 Bison
abstract: A months-long event, just outside the park, was intended to keep the animals from spreading a disease to livestock. But its scope and other removal measures affecting hundreds more have generated opposition.
lead_paragraph: HELENA, Mont. — An unusually harsh winter that buried Yellowstone National Park under a heavy blanket of snow and ice this year pushed a large portion of the park’s bison herd down to lower elevations and out of the park in search of milder climes and food.
