abstract: NASA officials found it more difficult than they expected to surprise the astronauts of the Artemis II mission with the news that they were going to the moon.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Telling three NASA astronauts that they had been chosen to go to the moon was like trying to hold three surprise birthday parties — surprise parties where the recipients of the surprise inadvertently thwarted the plans of the organizers.

headline: ‘Vanderpump Rules’ Star Lets Her Clothes Do the Talking
abstract: Ariana Madix, a jilted lover on the popular Bravo series, didn’t miss her chance to tell the world how she felt: Boys Lie.
lead_paragraph: When Ariana Madix, one of the stars of the Bravo series “Vanderpump Rules,” was photographed on her way to the show’s Season 10 reunion, she knew all eyes were on her. This wasn’t a typical end-of-season gathering for Ms. Madix, or the rest of her cast members, for that matter — this was guaranteed to be a day of explosive confrontation after she discovered Tom Sandoval, a co-star on the show and her partner of nine years, had a secret, six-month affair with Raquel Leviss, the couple’s friend and castmate.

headline: Bob Lee, Cash App Creator, Is Fatally Stabbed in San Francisco
abstract: Mr. Lee, 43, was chief product officer at the cryptocurrency start-up MobileCoin. The case remains under investigation.
lead_paragraph: Bob Lee, a tech executive and investor who was instrumental in creating the mobile payment service Cash App, was fatally stabbed on the street in San Francisco on Tuesday, according to his family.

headline: Review: Kyle Abraham Takes on Cunningham and, as Always, Love
abstract: Abraham and his company, A.I.M, returned to the Joyce Theater with a program of mixed repertory, including new dances and a Bebe Miller solo.
lead_paragraph: Kyle Abraham has a mission — and it’s bigger than himself. He likes to spread the love with his company, A.I.M., and, in doing so, broaden the viewer’s experience of what a dance concert by a choreographer-led company can be.

headline: U.S. Tensions With China on Display as McCarthy Hosts Taiwan’s Leader
abstract: Speaker Kevin McCarthy became the most senior elected official to meet with a Taiwanese president on American soil since the United States established diplomatic relations with Beijing.
lead_paragraph: SIMI VALLEY, Calif.— Speaker Kevin McCarthy on Wednesday hosted a carefully choreographed series of meetings with President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan, underscoring the juggling act facing the United States as it tries to confront an increasingly aggressive China without precipitating a military crisis around the island.

headline: ‘The Mandalorian’ Season 3, Episode 6 Recap: Nuts and Revolts
abstract: Most of this week’s episode is about Mandalorians doing what they do best: acting as hired muscle.
lead_paragraph: For those of us who scan every frame of “The Mandalorian” looking for nifty new droids and alien creatures, this week’s episode offered a real bounty. Din Djarin, Grogu and Bo-Katan Kryze pay a visit to Plazir-15, an Outer Rim planet known for having a diverse population and a nearly all-droid work force, all sharing space within a spectacular domed city. “Guns for Hire” is an eye-candy smorgasbord.

headline: Finding Freedom and Feminism in Ballet. (It’s Possible.)
abstract: With new books and a podcast taking another look at the legacy of George Balanchine and the culture of ballet, where does a modern ballerina stand?
lead_paragraph: Ballet requires — no, demands — devotion. But what is the price of that devotion, especially for women? Ballet these days is under fire in some quarters, and the very idea of devotion to it has become suspect. A myth has grown around it: That its price is physical and mental abuse, eating disorders, bloody toes, suffering, pain and blind subservience to patriarchal leaders.

headline: Chicago Mayor’s Race Could Be a Blueprint for Democratic Messaging on Crime
abstract: Brandon Johnson, a progressive Democrat, prevailed over his more moderate challenger after holding the position that officials must take a fundamentally different approach to public safety.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The mayoral victory on Tuesday of Brandon Johnson, a once little-known progressive and former teacher, over a more moderate veteran of this city’s burly political realm injected confidence in the Democratic Party’s most liberal wing — and may have pointed a way forward for the party on the fraught issue of crime.

headline: Biden’s Ambassador to Israel, at the Center of the Storm
abstract: A longtime Democratic insider, Thomas Nides navigates a fraught U.S.-Israel relationship with humor, if a sometimes all-too-quotable candor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Thomas R. Nides, the U.S. ambassador to Israel, was speaking in typically colorful fashion on the subject of the Israeli government’s divisive plan to reduce the power of the judiciary.

headline: As Young People March for Their Lives, Tennessee Crushes Dissent and Overrides Democracy
abstract: To remove legitimately elected officials from the chamber to which voters sent them is nothing short of authoritarianism.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Yesterday the eyes of the country were on the indictment of a former president, along with the all too real possibility that political or public chaos would erupt as a result. Here in Tennessee, we were watching a different kind of chaos unfold as our state government doubled down on its love affair with guns, even in the immediate aftermath of a horrific school shooting. I wish I could tell you that guns were the worst of it.

headline: Macron, in China, Says He’ll Urge Xi to Work for Peace in Ukraine
abstract: President Emmanuel Macron of France spoke of the need for a “shared responsibility for peace and international stability.”
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France, speaking at the start of a three-day visit to China, said Wednesday that Beijing could play a “major role” in bringing peace to Ukraine, and made clear that he would urge the Chinese president, Xi Jinping, to get deeply involved in this effort.

headline: Twitter Labels NPR ‘State-Affiliated Media,’ in Change to Policy
abstract: The broadcaster denounced the move as “unacceptable.” Until Tuesday evening, NPR was cited as an exception to Twitter’s policy on the label.
lead_paragraph: Twitter on Tuesday evening added a label to National Public Radio’s account on the social network, designating the broadcaster “U.S. state-affiliated media.”

headline: Program That Fights Homelessness Is Mired in Dysfunction, Advocates Say
abstract: Some renters are being inexplicably cut off from the city’s voucher program, a crucial tool for stemming homelessness. Housing advocates say it is a symptom of deeper problems.
lead_paragraph: In early 2022, Tabitha Daniel used a New York City rental voucher to move out of a homeless shelter and into a Staten Island apartment.

headline: The Trump Indictment Is a Legal Embarrassment
abstract: Why it was a setback for the rule of law and established a dangerous precedent for prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday was historic for the rule of law in America, but not in the way Alvin Bragg, the Manhattan district attorney, would have imagined. The 34-count indictment — which more accurately could be described as 34 half-indictments — was a disaster. It was a setback for the rule of law and established a dangerous precedent for prosecutors.

headline: Trump, the Incredible Shrinking Defendant
abstract: The former president’s post-arraignment speech at Mar-a-Lago reinforced just how stale he’s become.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump captured one thing correctly on Tuesday: It was “SURREAL.”

headline: Italian Ex-Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi Is Hospitalized
abstract: The 86-year-old businessman-turned-politician, now a senator, was admitted to an intensive care unit in Milan. He was said to have a “problem related to a previous infection.”
lead_paragraph: The former Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi was admitted to intensive care at a hospital in Milan on Wednesday and is expected to remain for a few days, hospital officials said.

headline: Pence Won’t Appeal Ruling Forcing Testimony to Jan. 6 Grand Jury, Aide Says
abstract: The decision may clear the way for potentially consequential testimony that federal prosecutors have long sought as they explore Donald J. Trump’s attempts to stay in office.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Mike Pence will not appeal a federal judge’s ruling forcing him to testify in front of a grand jury investigating former President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to thwart the transfer of power after the 2020 election, an aide said Wednesday.

headline: France, Guardian of Égalité, Leads the List of Ultrarich
abstract: Two French business titans, Bernard Arnault of the LVMH empire and Françoise Bettencourt-Meyers of L’Oréal, are named the world’s wealthiest man and woman.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France, which has been riven lately by angry protests over income inequality, can now claim to have the world’s richest man and woman: Bernard Arnault, the chief executive of the LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton luxury empire, and Françoise Bettencourt-Meyers, the heiress of the global cosmetics giant L’Oréal.

headline: Can A.I. and Democracy Fix Each Other?
abstract: Some technologists make a convincing case.
lead_paragraph: Democracy isn’t working very well these days, and artificial intelligence is scaring the daylights out of people. Some creative people are looking at those two problems and envisioning a solution: Democracy fixes A.I., and A.I. fixes democracy.

headline: ‘Lewis Capaldi: How I’m Feeling Now’ Review: Breakout Crooner in Meta Form
abstract: The Scottish musician’s infectious presence makes every familiar documentary trick here go down easy.
lead_paragraph: The Scottish musician Lewis Capaldi knows the drill: In pop star documentaries, we hear the rough cut of a song and then, inevitably, we watch as the crowd eats up every word of the resulting hit. When he mocks just how commonplace that particular scene is in his own doc, “How I’m Feeling Now,” you sense he gets it — this one will be different. But the director Joe Pearlman sticks to that trajectory, where triumph comes after a tough era for Capaldi, who released his debut in 2019 and then returned home during the pandemic to live with his parents in his hometown in Scotland. That would be more of a knock had the film not already winked at embracing that conventional course as the outcome, or if Capaldi’s infectious presence alone didn’t make every familiar documentary trick here go down easy.

headline: Nikki Haley Raises Over $11 Million to Start Her 2024 Campaign
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump, in comparison, raised only $9.5 million during the same period after announcing his third presidential run.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley, the former South Carolina governor and United Nations ambassador, raised more than $11 million in the first six weeks of her presidential run, her campaign said on Wednesday, a sizable sum that easily eclipses what former President Donald J. Trump was able to raise during the same period after announcing his candidacy.

headline: Where to Eat With Teens in NYC
abstract: Nikita Richardson, who writes the Where to Eat: New York City newsletter, offers suggestions adults will enjoy, too.
lead_paragraph: Nikita Richardson, who writes the Where to Eat: New York City newsletter, offers suggestions adults will enjoy, too.

headline: Dating Advice From Jay Shetty
abstract: The author and podcaster Jay Shetty on how the lessons he learned as a monk shaped his romantic life.
lead_paragraph: When Jay Shetty graduated from college, he was prepared for two different paths in life: to work in finance, or become a Hindu monk.

headline: The Glorious and Barbarous Bartering of Settlers of Catan
abstract: With calculated trades of wood for brick and sheep for wheat, Catan players love building cities and bullying friends. The game’s designer, who died this month, created a monster.
lead_paragraph: Ancient Egyptians had senet and Mesopotamians had the Royal Game of Ur. Chessmen have marched for hundreds of years across boards in Asia, Europe and the Middle East. People are still tangling, sometimes against computers, over the millenniums-old Chinese game of Go.

headline: Johnny Depp Film About Louis XV Will Open Cannes Film Festival
abstract: The inclusion of “Jeanne du Barry,” directed by Maïwenn, is Depp’s first public embrace by the film industry since he won a bitter defamation trial against his ex-wife Amber Heard.
lead_paragraph: Johnny Depp’s first major film since winning a lurid and contentious defamation trial last year — a costume drama in which he plays King Louis XV of France — will open the Cannes Film Festival in May, the festival announced on Wednesday.

headline: Why Michael Roberts Mattered
abstract: Through his long career at Vanity Fair, The New Yorker and other publications, the editor-artist-stylist-art director helped shape the course of fashion.
lead_paragraph: “The Jean Cocteau of the fashion world.” That’s how the New Yorker editor Tina Brown described Michael Roberts, the British illustrator-writer-stylist-photographer-art director, when he joined the magazine in the mid-1990s as its fashion editor.

headline: Did You Have Your First Child After 40?
abstract: The Times wants to hear about your parenting experience.
lead_paragraph: The number of women over 40 who are having babies has risen steadily over the last 30 years. The challenges a woman may face while trying to conceive after age 35, including age-related infertility and a higher rate of miscarriage, have been well documented, but we want to hear firsthand about what it’s like to raise children later in life, especially for those who had their first child after 40.

headline: Four Opinion Writers on Trump’s Indictment and ‘the Borderlands of Illegality’
abstract: Four Opinion writers discuss the indictment of President Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Four Opinion writers discuss the indictment of President Donald Trump.

headline: China Publishes Data Showing Raccoon Dog DNA at Wuhan Market
abstract: Scientists from the Chinese C.D.C. confirmed that DNA from raccoon dogs and other animals susceptible to the coronavirus was found at the market in early 2020.
lead_paragraph: Chinese government scientists on Wednesday published a long-awaited study about a market in the city of Wuhan, acknowledging that animals susceptible to the coronavirus were there around the time the virus emerged. But the scientists also said that it remained unclear how the pandemic began.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing: Diplomatic Visits Highlight Tension With China
abstract: Also, what’s next for Donald Trump and Israeli police raid a Jerusalem mosque.
lead_paragraph: Two meetings — between the U.S. House speaker and the president of Taiwan and between the leaders of France and China — are highlighting the West’s delicate diplomacy with China amid rising tensions.

headline: Heroin Dealer Who Sold Michael K. Williams a Fatal Dose Pleads Guilty
abstract: Irvin Cartagena, who prosecutors said sold fentanyl-laced heroin in Brooklyn to the “Wire” actor, pleaded guilty to narcotics charges and faces at least 24 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: A heroin dealer who sold a fatal dose to Michael K. Williams, the actor who shot to fame with his powerful portrayal of a fearsome drug-world figure in the series “The Wire,” pleaded guilty to a narcotics conspiracy charge in Manhattan federal court on Wednesday.

headline: Wisconsin Rout Points to Democrats’ Enduring Post-Dobbs Strength
abstract: A resounding victory by a liberal judge who ran on abortion rights showed that a largely unified political left is keeping up its momentum, and served as a new warning sign to Republicans.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — The commanding victory on Tuesday by a liberal candidate in a pivotal race for the Wisconsin Supreme Court showed the enduring power of abortion rights and issues of democracy as motivators for Democratic voters, as well as a continuing struggle among conservatives to put forward candidates who can unite Republicans and win general elections.

headline: Rupert Murdoch Can Be Forced to Testify in Defamation Trial, Judge Says
abstract: Star hosts for Fox News like Tucker Carlson and Sean Hannity may also appear in person at the high-profile trial, which is set to start April 17.
lead_paragraph: The witness list for the Fox News $1.6 billion defamation trial now has more big names than a prime-time lineup.

headline: Neal Boenzi, 97, Top New York Times Photographer for Four Decades, Dies
abstract: He built a reputation for finding compelling subjects on the street. “Anyone can take a picture,” he liked to say, “but are you a journalist?”
lead_paragraph: Neal Boenzi, a photographer who for more than 40 years at The New York Times deftly captured aspects of city life from firefighters fleeing a falling wall to a man walking a goose, died on Monday at an elder care facility in Newhall, Calif. He was 97.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Who Gets to Use a Hair Oil?
abstract: When bottles of a hair-care product favored by Black women started getting harder to find, all eyes turned to the influencers.
lead_paragraph: When vials of Mielle Organics’ rosemary-mint hair oil started disappearing from store shelves this year, Black women who had come to rely on the product were appalled.

headline: Jill Biden Stumbles by Inviting N.C.A.A. Winners (and Losers) to the White House
abstract: The first lady waded into the aftermath of a women’s basketball championship game that was about more than who won and who lost.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was, to borrow from sports parlance, an unforced error.

headline: For Now, Trump and Allies Focus on Political Upside of a Criminal Case
abstract: The indictment of the former president has unlocked a rush of fund-raising and has frozen the 2024 Republican primary, but he faces deeper legal peril in multiple inquiries.
lead_paragraph: Just hours after he became the first former president in American history to be indicted, Donald J. Trump sat on the patio of his private club in Palm Beach, Fla., on Tuesday night and played disc jockey.

headline: Do Critics of Trump’s Indictment Have a Point?
abstract: This case may be a legal stretch, but it would be a problem to give a boss impunity after imprisoning his underling.
lead_paragraph: Republican leaders and Fox News personalities have erupted at the arrest of Donald Trump, so let’s consider some of their concerns.

headline: Trump’s Charges Bring Doubts, Hopes and Uncertainty in Both Parties
abstract: To some Republicans and Democrats, the charges appeared flimsy and less consequential than many had hoped. To others, the case had the potential to reverberate politically.
lead_paragraph: In an ordinary presidential-primary season, the indictment of a front-runner over hush money paid to a porn star would, at the least, be an opening for rivals to attack. But a day after the arraignment of former President Donald J. Trump on 34 felony counts, one thing was clear: This will not be an ordinary political season.

headline: N.Y. Governor Walks Back Push to ‘Weaken’ Climate Law After Uproar
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul had proposed revising the state’s landmark 2019 law in an effort to reduce costs for state residents.
lead_paragraph: Under pressure from scientists, environmentalists and lawmakers, Gov. Kathy Hochul backed off on Wednesday from a proposal to rewrite the state’s landmark climate law — an effort that her critics said would have fundamentally undermined the measure.

headline: Putin and Lukashenko will confer in Moscow on deepening ties, including nuclear-capable arms.
abstract: The leader of Belarus is in Russia for talks on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus arrived at the Kremlin on Wednesday, ahead of a planned meeting the following day with his Russian counterpart, Vladimir V. Putin, on the expanding military and economic ties between the two countries.

headline: Robert Kennedy Jr., a Noted Vaccine Skeptic, Files to Run for President
abstract: While he has not yet announced his plans, he filed the federal paperwork for a campaign to run as a Democrat.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the political activist known most recently for his campaign to discredit coronavirus vaccines, filed paperwork on Wednesday to run for president as a Democrat, offering a potential long-shot challenge to President Biden.

headline: Baltimore Catholic Clergy Abused Hundreds of Children and Teens, Attorney General Says
abstract: A 463-page investigation released by the Maryland attorney general detailed the “enormous scope and scale” of scandal.
lead_paragraph: Clergy members across the Archdiocese of Baltimore abused hundreds of children and teenagers over the course of six decades, abetted by a church hierarchy that systematically failed to investigate and restrict their access to children, according to a detailed report from the Maryland attorney general released on Wednesday.

headline: Review: ‘A Little Life’ Is Quite a Lot
abstract: Self-harm, lashings, child prostitution, rape: Ivo van Hove’s adaptation of the 2015 novel tests the audience’s trauma threshold.
lead_paragraph: How much is too much? The question recurs a lot during “A Little Life,” the theatrical pileup of suffering and woe that opened on Wednesday at the Harold Pinter Theater in London. The play is beautifully acted but surpassingly bleak, and spectators may find their own threshold for trauma tested more than once. I know mine was.

headline: Zelensky Gets Hero’s Welcome in Poland, Cementing Ukraine’s Ties
abstract: Polish leaders backed Ukraine’s bid for NATO membership, but even without that, Russia’s invasion is making the alliance’s eastern flank more united, and more important.
lead_paragraph: Feted as a hero who is saving Europe from Russia’s maw, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, on his first official visit to Poland, on Wednesday cemented a new axis of shared interests and military power that is pushing Europe’s center of geopolitical gravity eastward.

headline: What It Was Like Inside the Courtroom During Trump’s Arraignment
abstract: Here are some of the most important moments from the hearing where criminal charges against Donald Trump were unveiled.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump sat quietly in a Manhattan courtroom on Tuesday as prosecutors described the accusations against him. The proceeding marked his first experience as a criminal defendant.

headline: Republicans Vowed to Grill Bragg About Trump, but It’s Not So Simple
abstract: G.O.P. leaders have talked tough about investigating the New York prosecutor bringing charges against the former president, but behind the scenes, they are weighing how to move ahead.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Alvin L. Bragg, the Manhattan district attorney, prepared to bring criminal charges against former President Donald J. Trump, House Republicans rallied to Mr. Trump’s side, vowing to use their power in Congress to haul in Mr. Bragg and force him to turn over documents and answer questions.

headline: How Brandon Johnson Made Up Ground and Won Chicago’s Mayoral Race
abstract: Mr. Johnson, a progressive county commissioner, won over liberal voters across the city after finishing second in a first round of balloting.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In the final days of the mayoral campaign in Chicago, Brandon Johnson drew more than 4,000 people to a jubilant rally featuring Senator Bernie Sanders, who endorsed him. He crisscrossed the South and West Sides, visiting six churches in a single Sunday. In a last push on Election Day, an army of volunteers for Mr. Johnson knocked on 46,000 doors across the city, whipping up enthusiasm and encouraging last-minute voters to get to the polls.

headline: Picasso: Love Him or Hate Him?
abstract: Fifty years after the artist’s death, a critic wrestles with her mixed feelings.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years after the artist’s death, a critic wrestles with her mixed feelings.

headline: Tennessee House Poised to Expel 3 Democrats Over Gun Control Protest
abstract: The Republican-dominated House was set to vote on Thursday on taking the rare and punitive action of removing the Democrats from office for their part in the protest.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — As teenagers and demonstrators flooded the Tennessee state legislature last week to call for lawmakers to toughen access to guns after a deadly shooting at a Christian school, three Democrats headed to the well of the House chamber.

headline: ‘Outrageous’: Russia Accused of Spreading Disinformation at U.N. Event
abstract: Moscow used its rotating presidency of the Security Council to host a session on deported Ukrainian children, leading some officials to walk out.
lead_paragraph: Days after Russia took the helm of the U.N. Security Council’s rotating presidency, a coalition of more than 50 countries on Wednesday called Moscow’s first event a brazen disinformation showcase and an abuse of its role at the world body.

headline: Green Movement
abstract: Sam Buttrey makes his New York Times debut. Bring your GPS with you.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Quotation of the Day: As K-Pop Eyes Global Growth, Korean Fans Feel Cast Aside
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, April 6, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “There’s a sense that the industry is targeting the West and leaving Korean fans behind.”

headline: Corrections: April 6, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, April 6, 2023.
lead_paragraph: A picture caption with an obituary on Monday about the composer Ryuichi Sakamoto, using information from The Associated Press, misidentified the man pictured with him, David Bowie and Nagisa Oshima, the director of the movie “Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence.” He is the actor Jack Thompson, who appeared alongside Mr. Sakamoto and Mr. Bowie in that film — not the producer Jack Thomas.

headline: Idaho Bans Out-of-State Abortions for Minors Without Parent’s Consent
abstract: The first-of-its-kind law imposes criminal penalties on anyone who helps a person under 18 leave the state for an abortion and classifies it as “abortion trafficking.”
lead_paragraph: Idaho on Wednesday became the first state to make it illegal for minors to leave the state to get an abortion without parental consent.

headline: Keeping an Old Italian Tradition Alive in Australia: ‘Passata Day’
abstract: Two sisters are among the dwindling few who gather family and friends once a year to make a 12-month supply of tomato passata, a purée that is a staple of Italian cuisine.
lead_paragraph: In the years after World War II, as a new wave of migration scattered Italians abroad, tens of thousands made the long journey to Australia to escape the poverty and devastation in their defeated nation.

headline: For a Humbled Bryson DeChambeau, Augusta National Looms Long
abstract: The major champion used scientific research to engineer prodigious drives, but enters the Masters knowing a return to the top of the leaderboards will take workshopping, too.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — It was only two years ago that Bryson DeChambeau arrived at the Masters Tournament as the reigning U.S. Open champion, having earned that title by bludgeoning Winged Foot Golf Club in New York with prodigious 350-yard drives to win by six strokes. He was the new face of golf and promised to shape the sport in his image, which at the time was a musclebound 240-pounder who had gained 45 pounds and swung so hard it almost hurt to watch.

headline: A New Twist for the Tradition-Bound Masters: The LIV Golf Era
abstract: LIV, Saudi Arabia’s breakaway league, split men’s professional golf. Now, the drama is coming to one of the sport’s most hallowed stages.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The mystery started in earnest last spring and lasted until autumn’s twilight. But Phil Mickelson — among the most famous frontmen for LIV Golf, the league bankrolled by Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund — insists that he believed he would be allowed to play the 2023 Masters Tournament, which opens Thursday.

headline: With Russia’s Exit, Norway Becomes Europe’s Energy Champion
abstract: It is now the continent’s largest supplier of natural gas, and last year the country’s energy earnings jumped $100 billion.
lead_paragraph: The new front line for Europe’s energy security is a modest office building overlooking a fjord in Stavanger, Norway. Inside, a company called Petoro oversees three dozen of the largest oil and natural gas fields in Europe, on Norway’s petroleum-rich continental shelf.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: The reaction to criminal charges against Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: A day after the arraignment of Donald Trump on 34 felony counts, the U.S. political landscape is more uncertain than ever as the former president’s legal peril grows.

headline: Macron’s meeting with Xi could affect the direction of the war.
abstract: President Emmanuel Macron of France and China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, are holding talks in Beijing on Thursday in a meeting that could have broad implications for China’s relationship with Europe and the direction of Russia’s war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France and China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, are holding talks in Beijing on Thursday in a meeting that could have broad implications for China’s relationship with Europe and the direction of Russia’s war in Ukraine.

headline: Word of the Day: venomous
abstract: This word has appeared in 47 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word venomous has appeared in 47 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 25 in “Spiders Are Caught in a Global Web of Misinformation” by Oliver Whang:

headline: Stephen Colbert on Trump: ‘Business Fraud Is His Brand’
abstract: Colbert recapped Donald Trump’s post-arraignment return to Mar-a-Lago, “where he held an angry rally for all his cult members.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: A New York Walk-Up? No, an Art Installation in New Jersey.
abstract: A four-story apartment facade becomes a stage that helps people look at it in a different way.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at a four-story facade that has that New York City look, but that’s not where it is. We’ll also find out why Gov. Kathy Hochul has walked back her proposal to rewrite the state’s climate change law.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: A Bird’s-Eye View of the Chinese Balloon
abstract: The New York Times’s Visual Investigations team tracked the balloon’s path across the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Visual Investigations team at The New York Times relies on visual evidence, such as video footage, photography and forensic analysis, to conduct its investigations and offer readers a more holistic view of crucial news moments.

headline: House G.O.P.’s Plan to Cut Food Stamps Threatens a Tough Vote
abstract: A proposal to tighten work requirements for federal nutrition programs has generated fissures among Republicans, highlighting the difficult choices ahead in coming up with a budget plan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican Representative Marc Molinaro, a former mayor who flipped an open seat in the Hudson Valley last year and helped the G.O.P. take back the House, frequently tells the story of how his mother relied on food stamps and subsidized school lunches to keep him fed as a child.

headline: 2 Generals Took Over a Country. Will They Deliver Democracy or War?
abstract: The deadline is approaching for the generals who took power in a military coup in Sudan to turn over their authority to a civilian government. The mood in the capital, Khartoum, is anxious.
lead_paragraph: KHARTOUM, Sudan — It’s not in Berlin, Jerusalem or along the southern U.S. border. But the long concrete wall that is rising in the heart of Sudan’s capital, snaking around the perimeter of its military headquarters, has, like other more famous barriers, come to symbolize the precarious divisions of a fractured country.

headline: The Math That Makes Videos Go Viral: Exponential Growth and Decay
abstract: In this lesson, students use exponential models to explore why companies big and small are hiring young people to make videos.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Wanted: Interns Who Can Make TikTok Hits,” by Sapna Maheshwari

headline: 36 Hours in Tokyo
abstract: Think of Tokyo as a warren of concealed gems: Wander down side streets and be richly rewarded.
lead_paragraph: Think of Tokyo as a warren of concealed gems: Wander down side streets and be richly rewarded.

headline: The U.S. Built a European-Style Welfare State. It’s Largely Over.
abstract: Medicaid and food stamps are the latest of the pandemic relief policies to expire. But some benefits, even if temporary, made way for more generous social policies.
lead_paragraph: Medicaid and food stamps are the latest of the pandemic relief policies to expire. But some benefits, even if temporary, made way for more generous social policies.

headline: They Had $350,000 and a Dream to Live Together. Could They Make It in Manhattan?
abstract: After years of managing a long-distance relationship, a couple decided that buying a small co-op together would be more affordable than renting forever. But they had a few requirements.
lead_paragraph: After years of managing a long-distance relationship, a couple decided that buying a small co-op together would be more affordable than renting forever. But they had a few requirements.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Dubious Muesli
abstract: Should you tell your family members they probably ate some worms with their breakfast?
lead_paragraph: Bruce writes: My sister-in-law visited, and we all ate my wife’s muesli for breakfast. After her sister left, my wife discovered worms crawling around in the muesli, evidently hatched from eggs she found in the oats. She wants to tell her sister. Please order her to stay silent.

headline: Save a Life, or Commit a Felony? For One Tennessee Doctor, the Answer Is Often Both.
abstract: A doctor’s fight for the right to save women’s lives.
lead_paragraph: When Roe fell last year, Tennessee became the state with the strictest abortion ban in the country — no abortions, no exceptions. Any doctor who performed one was knowingly committing a class C felony, punishable by up to 15 years in prison. That is a risk Dr. Elise Boos, an obstetrician specializing in high-risk pregnancies, has been willing to take for patients who need lifesaving care.

headline: Poem: The Privilege of Thinking
abstract: Illumination is no one-way street.
lead_paragraph: Stacy Szymaszek’s “The Privilege of Thinking” borrows its title from the poem of the same name by the filmmaker and poet Pier Paolo Pasolini. In both poems, the terrain of thought is the shared space of this world, its landscapes and social conditions. Illumination is no one-way street. Thinking doesn’t radiate solely from the depths of the individual mind, but as Pasolini writes, “there’s light/in the world all around.” In Szymaszek’s poem, thinking in the city — eked out in scraps of survival-inflected time — reflects the city’s qualities: those of motion and vigilance, even a kind of gentle arrogance. But the city is a past-tense place. The present of the poet is in the desert, where a newfound stillness issues its own stark reply. Selected by Anne Boyer

headline: Three Takeaways From a Tumultuous Day in Politics
abstract: A blowout in Wisconsin, an indictment in New York and a progressive victory in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: It has been a big — even historic — week in American politics. Donald J. Trump was indicted. The liberal candidate for Wisconsin Supreme Court, Janet Protasiewicz, easily prevailed over a conservative, Daniel Kelly. And Brandon Johnson, a progressive, was elected the mayor of Chicago.

headline: Doorways
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration or, tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: Susanna Hoffs Has a Dollar Bill Signed by William S. Burroughs
abstract: “I queued up to get his autograph with nothing but a dollar bill for him to sign,” says the pop star, whose debut novel is “This Bird Has Flown.” “He glanced up, amused, gave me a mischievous half-smile and said, ‘Ah, defacing U.S. currency,’ and proceeded to sign it.”
lead_paragraph: “Dickens and Prince: A Particular Kind of Genius,” by Nick Hornby. “Lincoln in the Bardo,” by George Saunders. “The Love Songs of W.E.B. Du Bois,” by Honorée Fanonne Jeffers. “Giovanni’s Room,” by James Baldwin. “A Single Man,” by Christopher Isherwood. And always on my night stand, “The Book of Questions,” by Pablo Neruda. At the moment, I’m reading Truman Capote’s novella “Breakfast at Tiffany’s.” He’s a gorgeous writer. And somewhere in the stack is George Eliot’s “Middlemarch,” which I keep meaning to read but never seem to get around to.

headline: The Republican Party Sorts Through Its Mess
abstract: We travel to an exclusive resort in California where party insiders are reeling from their midterms losses, and quietly trying to solve their Donald Trump problem.
lead_paragraph: In our first episode, we join the Republican National Committee in Dana Point, Calif., as it gathers for its winter meeting. After a disappointing midterms, fractures have formed within the committee’s ranks. After targeting Kevin McCarthy in the fight for House speaker, the grass roots turned their ire on Ronna McDaniel, the chair of the R.N.C.

headline: What Songs Explain You?
abstract: A Times writer introduces herself to readers through 11 songs. Which songs would you pick to tell your life story?
lead_paragraph: Do you love music?

headline: The Wind Beneath Kara Goucher’s Wings? A Solid Teammate.
abstract: When she met with possible collaborators to talk about her memoir, the Olympic runner had her sights trained on one who would listen.
lead_paragraph: Imagine you’re about to tell someone the story of your life and your audience says, “No thanks. I’ve heard it already.”

headline: You Can Be Fired for Being Overweight. Should New York Change That?
abstract: The City Council is expected to approve a bill this spring that would ban weight discrimination in hiring and housing.
lead_paragraph: Victoria Abraham has attracted a huge online following as a self-described fat activist who preaches body positivity and calls out bias. But after graduating from New York University last year with a degree in public policy, she cannot avoid wondering if her job search will be hampered by her size.

headline: Attacks on Dominion Voting Persist Despite High-Profile Lawsuits
abstract: Unproven claims about Dominion Voting Systems still spread widely online.
lead_paragraph: With a series of billion-dollar lawsuits, including a $1.6 billion case against Fox News headed to trial this month, Dominion Voting Systems sent a stark warning to anyone spreading falsehoods that the company’s technology contributed to fraud in the 2020 election: Be careful with your words, or you might pay the price.

headline: A Naïve Reading of the Gospels May Be Just What Christianity Needs
abstract: Lent and especially Holy Week in Catholic Christianity provide a strong encounter with the Gospel narrative.
lead_paragraph: In the not-so-distant past when 90 or 95 percent of Americans identified as Christian, it was hard for almost anyone in that vast majority to read the Christian Gospels naïvely — to come to them without preconceptions, in the way of their original intended audience, a person hearing the “good news” about Jesus of Nazareth for the first time.

headline: Ready. Set. Wed.
abstract: Most celebrations are more than a year in the making, while others can be thrown together in as little as a week. Such spontaneity, though, has its advantages and disadvantages.
lead_paragraph: Four days before their wedding, Richie Romero and Tiffany Wong emailed family members a “save the date” invite. It was void of time, location and dress code — the couple were still deciding those details.

headline: 6 Picasso Shows to See This Year
abstract: Fifty years after his death, the Cubist painter will be featured in art exhibitions in New York, Paris and Madrid.
lead_paragraph: Pablo Picasso died 50 years ago this month, on April 8, 1973. This year, the cultural wings of the French and Spanish governments will observe the anniversary by collaborating on “Celebration Picasso 1973-2023,” a collection of exhibitions across Europe and the United States that play off each other like the colors and textures of a Cubist painting. These are six shows to seek out.

headline: Her Unusual Wheeze Was Getting Worse. What Was It?
abstract: She constantly felt the need to clear her throat. Then she started to feel winded on stairs. A flurry of tests narrowed down the cause.
lead_paragraph: One of the first things she noticed was how she had to keep clearing her throat. Everyone does it every now and then, but for her, a healthy woman in her early 70s, it had become constant. Her husband never complained. He was a surgeon, and when the throat-clearing started, he showed her a few breathing exercises. Those were sometimes helpful, but eventually she would be ahem-ing every few minutes again. Even more annoying was that any exertion could trigger a strange, harsh-sounding wheeze. Even when she was on the phone, she often muted herself so friends and family wouldn’t worry.

headline: 8 Years in Trump Prison and Still Awaiting Parole
abstract: Much as I hope to see justice served — if not, at this late point, piping hot — it feels as though we’re the ones who are already in jail.
lead_paragraph: On Monday a friend breathlessly and sheepishly emailed: “Yes, I admit it: I’m watching the motorcade from La Guardia to Trump Tower. It’s like O.J.’s Bronco ride! And I swear, the lead car in the motorcade looks like a white Bronco! Could this be an inside joke by the N.Y.P.D.?”

headline: A Visit to the Peeps Factory
abstract: As Easter approached, The New York Times for Kids took a trip to a world of marshmallow magic.
lead_paragraph: Visiting the factory where Peeps are made, in Bethlehem, Pa., is a true Willy Wonka experience. The building is crammed with pipes full of marshmallow and hoses full of sugar. Spray guns spray food coloring and flavors. Even the “whoops” moments that occasionally happen when the candymakers are testing new products seem like fun: “We have an engineer who is known for pushing buttons he’s not supposed to,” says Daniel Moyer, a food scientist at Just Born Quality Confections, the company that makes Peeps. “Sometimes he ends up completely covered in marshmallow.”

headline: How Russia’s Offensive Ran Aground
abstract: Whatever happens in Bakhmut, a once-ambitious winter offensive never really went anywhere.
lead_paragraph: Whatever happens in Bakhmut, a once-ambitious winter offensive never really went anywhere.

headline: Dining in Style, at 90 Miles an Hour
abstract: Train travel is thriving in Central Europe, and so are dining cars. We rode the rails from Prague to Zurich and beyond, sampling regional dishes and savoring the views.
lead_paragraph: It was a familiar sound in any decent Central European restaurant: the reassuring whack-whack-whack of a chef flattening the schnitzel I’d ordered from the waiter a minute earlier. The crisp tablecloth in front of me shined bright white, and the banquette seating offered the same minimalist design as some of the region’s trendiest spots. But one aspect was different from my other recent fine-dining experiences: In the panoramic window facing my table, an Old World landscape was flying by at over 90 miles an hour.

headline: If It’s Advertised to You Online, You Probably Shouldn’t Buy It. Here’s Why.
abstract: Surveillance-based advertising is not only destroying democracy; it also pitches us lousy, overpriced goods.
lead_paragraph: If you saw a Facebook ad recently for Jeremy’s Razors, which bills itself as a “woke-free” razor for men, you may well be a father of school-age children who likes ultimate fighting, Hershey’s chocolate, hunting or Johnny Cash. This is according to Facebook’s ad library, which describes the audiences to which marketers target their advertisements.

headline: The Brooklyn Navy Yard Has Become a Lab for Planet-Saving Tech
abstract: Once a building ground for battleships, the site is a city-within-a-city where companies can test their solutions for a greener future.
lead_paragraph: Brendan Hermalyn started a company in 2021 to reduce carbon emissions from buildings by making a special filter, one that captures greenhouse gases and converts them into a powder that can be recycled. But when he pursued testing of his company’s carbon-capture system in New York City, some building owners were skeptical.

headline: The Enduring Appeal of ‘Wagatha,’ Now on Stage and Screen
abstract: A dramatization of the trial between the wives of two soccer stars is returning to the West End in London, joining TV shows, podcasts and documentaries about the high-profile spat.
lead_paragraph: With its stage transformed into a green soccer pitch, “Vardy v. Rooney: The Wagatha Christie Trial” at Wyndham’s Theater in London last November promised its nearly sold-out audience a game, and the two women onstage were both trying to score a goal.

headline: McIlroy Looks to Shake Thursday Blues as the Rounds That Count Begin
abstract: Plus, N.C.A.A. champions will be invited to play the Masters, and Larry Mize and Sandy Lyle are preparing to say farewell to the tournament.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — In the last five years, Rory McIlroy has spent 27 weeks ranked as the world’s best men’s golfer. He has earned nine PGA Tour victories, including at the Tour Championship and the Players Championship. He was on a Ryder Cup-winning team. In the final round of last year’s Masters Tournament, he carded an eight-under-par 64.

headline: How Fox Chased Its Audience Down the Rabbit Hole
abstract: Rupert Murdoch built an empire by giving viewers exactly what they wanted. But what they wanted — election lies and insurrection — put that empire (and the country) in peril.
lead_paragraph: On the evening of Nov. 19, 2020, Rupert Murdoch was watching TV and crawling the walls of his 18th-century mansion in the British countryside while under strict pandemic lockdown. The television hosts at Murdoch’s top cable network, Fox News, might have scoffed at such unyielding adherence to Covid protocols. But Jerry Hall, his soon-to-be fourth ex-wife and no fan of Fox or its conservative hosts, was insisting that Murdoch, approaching his 90th birthday, remain cautious.

headline: Chinese Officials Flock to Twitter to Defend TikTok
abstract: The company has tried to distance itself, but the information push shows just how deeply invested Beijing is in its fate.
lead_paragraph: When members of Congress grilled TikTok’s chief executive last month on Capitol Hill, the app’s supporters sprang to its defense online.

headline: Trump’s Indictment Is Karmic Justice, Regardless of the Verdict
abstract: This brings us full circle, back to the sleaziness we knew about before Trump ever set foot in office.
lead_paragraph: Finally, here we are: Donald Trump’s first indictment. The 34 felony counts unsealed at his arraignment this week focus on the falsification of business records in the first degree, a low-level felony charge. This indictment may not prove to be the rock-solid legal case one might hope it to be. It neither addresses the gravest allegations leveled at Trump — subverting the vote, attempted coup, rape — nor is it the most potentially persuasive case against him under consideration. Whether the evidence proves strong enough to convict him will be up to legal analysts to parse and ultimately, a jury to decide months from now.

headline: 5 Lessons for Democrats From Victories in Wisconsin and Chicago
abstract: The Wisconsin results show that the salience of abortion is not fading, and in Chicago, a “tough-on-crime” message fell short.
lead_paragraph: Victories by a liberal judge and a progressive mayoral candidate in two Midwestern states this week offered a glimpse of the mood of the electorate five months after the midterms, and it is a promising one for Democrats.

headline: Booking the Paris Olympics for 2024? What You Need to Know.
abstract: Next year’s Summer Olympic Games in Paris are expected to draw millions of spectators. Here’s how to get tickets if you want to be one of them.
lead_paragraph: All eyes will be on Paris in 2024, when the French capital hosts the 33rd Summer Olympic Games. The global sporting event, which runs from July 26 to Aug. 11, is expected to draw 10,500 Olympic athletes vying for some of the biggest accolades of their careers — and millions of spectators watching them do it.

headline: Safety Net Barriers Add to Child Poverty in Immigrant Families
abstract: Both legal immigrants and undocumented parents face hurdles in getting aid. The problem has grown more acute as children of immigrants account for a growing share of young people.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Jacqueline Acevedo is a shy seventh grader who spends long hours at the Baptist church where her father serves as a volunteer pastor after earning a scant wage from his day job selling bread.

headline: It’s Not Just Willow: Oil and Gas Projects Are Back in a Big Way
abstract: Alaska’s controversial Willow project has drawn criticism, but a global analysis shows that it’s just one of hundreds of investments approved in the past year or so.
lead_paragraph: When the Biden administration greenlighted the enormous $8 billion Willow oil project on Alaska’s North Slope last month, many decried the move as a betrayal of the United States’ pledge to move away from fossil fuels in the fight against climate change.

headline: 10 Artists on Picasso’s Enduring, Confounding Influence
abstract: Faith Ringgold, Mickalene Thomas, George Condo and others talk to our critics about the visual world he helped create.
lead_paragraph: Georges Braque, in 1907, looked at his Spanish friend’s new painting, “Les Demoiselles d’Avignon,” and felt “as if someone had drunk kerosene to spit fire.” Henri Matisse said he and his friendly rival from Málaga were “as different as the North Pole is from the South Pole.” Pablo Picasso has been getting artists talking since those first days in Montmartre, and even 50 years after his death, they are still coming to terms with his influence — positive and malign, indelible either way — on what art looks like and how we talk about those who make it.

headline: In Northern Ireland Town, Painful Memories Lie Beneath a Fragile Peace
abstract: Twenty-five years after the Good Friday Agreement ended an era of bloodshed, this is a moment to celebrate reconciliation across Northern Ireland. But for many, the past is not always easy to leave behind.
lead_paragraph: A few days after a gunman fired multiple shots into a police detective in this busy market town six weeks ago, Pauline Harte’s young son came home and asked her, “Whose side are we on?”

headline: In Pristine Alaska, an Oil Giant Prepares to Drill for Decades
abstract: Scientists say nations must stop new oil and gas projects to avoid climate catastrophe. But after the Biden administration greenlit the $8 billion Willow project, ConocoPhillips is racing ahead.
lead_paragraph: On the snowy tundra at the northernmost tip of the United States, more than two dozen yellow dump trucks wait on a glistening ice pad.

headline: Fans of Women’s Sports Walk Into a Bar Inspired by Women’s Sports
abstract: The Sports Bra in Portland, Ore., is a rarity dedicated exclusively to women’s sports. The latest highlight was the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball final.

headline: Politics Complicates Chinese Reaction to U.S. Visit by Taiwan’s President
abstract: For Beijing, showing displeasure too openly carries risks, particularly of harming the chances for its preferred party in Taiwan’s coming presidential election.
lead_paragraph: China fired off a volley of condemnations on Thursday after Taiwan’s president, Tsai Ing-wen, met the speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives, Kevin McCarthy, but it held off from the kind of military escalation that threatened a crisis last summer, when Mr. McCarthy’s predecessor visited Taiwan.

headline: Ivanka Trump Is Pained
abstract: With Daddy in disgrace, what’s a fair-haired, fair-weather daughter to do?
lead_paragraph: We’ve talked plenty about how Donald Trump’s indictment and arraignment might affect his latest presidential bid. We’ve pondered their meaning for the future of the republic.

headline: America Has a Problem in Africa: China
abstract: What’s at stake as the U.S. races to deepen its relationships with African countries.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s visit to Africa last week was designed to send a simple message to its governments and people — China is not your friend. The United States is.

headline: New Indian Textbooks Purged of Muslim History and Hindu Extremism
abstract: The changes removed or shrank references to material that the governing party of Prime Minister Narendra Modi finds inconvenient to its Hindu-first vision.
lead_paragraph: When Indian children began the school year this week, students in thousands of classrooms were issued new textbooks on history and politics that either watered down or purged key details from India’s past that Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s ruling party finds inconvenient to its Hindu nationalist vision for the country.

headline: Man Accused of Kidnapping Platypus Is Charged in Australia
abstract: The police had appealed for help after the platypus was spotted at a train station in Queensland. The animal was later released, but the authorities have been unable to find it.
lead_paragraph: A man in Australia is facing charges after he was accused of kidnapping a wild platypus and later showing it off at a shopping center, the police said on Thursday.

headline: The Power and Limits of Abortion Politics
abstract: What should we make of the role that abortion played in both the Chicago and Wisconsin elections this week?
lead_paragraph: The elections this week in Chicago and Wisconsin were different in many ways. One was for mayor, the other for a state Supreme Court seat. One was in an overwhelmingly Democratic city, the other in a closely divided swing state.

headline: ‘Sam Now’ Review: When Mom Leaves
abstract: Sensitive and surprising, Reed Harkness’s documentary follows the reverberations in his family after their mother abruptly departs.
lead_paragraph: At the heart of the disarming documentary “Sam Now” is the challenge of coming to terms with familial pain. The director, Reed Harkness, traces how his younger brother Sam and other relatives coped with the abrupt departure of their mother, Jois. Drawing on friendly but frank interviews and 25 years of home-movie adventures shot by Reed with Sam, it’s a film whose emotional reality seems to evolve before your eyes.

headline: ‘How to Blow Up a Pipeline’ Review: A Different Kind of Oil Boom
abstract: A book that proposed violent action in response to the climate crisis becomes a propulsive heist thriller.
lead_paragraph: Discussions of the 2021 book “How to Blow Up a Pipeline” inevitably note that it does not really contain instructions for blowing up a pipeline, although its author, Andreas Malm, a Swedish academic who has pressed for radical action on the climate crisis, hardly opposes the idea. He argues that the status quo has grown so dire that activists would be foolish not to turn to sabotage, and that peaceful protest alone is unlikely to achieve results quickly enough.

headline: ‘Chupa’ Review: A Terrifying Myth Made Cuddly
abstract: On a trip to his grandfather’s ranch in Mexico, a boy makes an astonishing discovery that turns into a family adventure.
lead_paragraph: Alex is an outcast at his school in Kansas City — for the picadillo he brings for lunch (“It’s just hamburger meat,” he tells one bully), for the video games he plays, and for apparently being the only Mexican kid in the lunchroom.

headline: ‘Paint’ Review: Watch It Dry
abstract: Owen Wilson plays a Bob Ross-inspired painter in this dated, mildly amusing parody of male privilege.
lead_paragraph: In “Paint,” an aging TV star with punchline hair and a storied libido lords it over his superfans, so wrapped in the cocoon of celebrity that he fails to recognize his rapidly waning significance.

headline: ‘Praise This’ Review: An Unlikely Savior
abstract: The R&B singer-songwriter Chloe Bailey stars in this musical comedy about an aspiring pop singer who lands in a scrappy competitive gospel group.
lead_paragraph: For an aspiring pop star from L.A., heading to the South to sing about Jesus might feel like a detour. But that’s where Sam, played by the R&B singer Chloe Bailey, finds herself to at the start of the musical comedy “Praise This.” After the death of her mother and a struggle to set herself straight, Sam is sent to Atlanta to stay with her aunt, her uncle and her peppy, God-loving cousin, Jess (Anjelika Washington).

headline: ‘Ride On’ Review: Jackie Chan, Back on the Horse
abstract: Chan, playing a former stuntman, has a few good trademark fight scenes, but the film is too busy stuffing sentimental elements into its lowbrow comedy premise.
lead_paragraph: One doesn’t necessarily expect much going into a slapstick stunt animal comedy, and yet even by these softened standards, the director Larry Yang’s “Ride On” cooks up an egregiously, almost comically bad movie. Starring Jackie Chan as Luo, a washed-up former stuntman who trains his horse, Red Hare, to become his partner, this film from China is a consistently awkward, over-the-top mess, attempting to infuse a cheaply written, sentimental father-daughter (and father-horse) story into its lowbrow laughs.

headline: ‘Alan Pakula: Going for Truth’ Review: A Hollywood Memorial for a Friend
abstract: A heartfelt documentary about the director of such celebrated films as “All the President’s Men” has the feel of an A-list memorial service.
lead_paragraph: “Alan Pakula: Going for Truth,” by the director Matthew Miele, is suffused with mourning. The documentary about the titular filmmaker opens with actors — Meryl Streep, Julia Roberts, Dustin Hoffman and Kevin Kline among them — recalling how news of his death affected them. In November 1998, Alan Pakula was driving on the Long Island Expressway when a metal pole crashed through his windshield. Piano notes sound beneath Harrison Ford’s especially affecting speechlessness.

headline: ‘What If? Ehud Barak on War and Peace’ Review: An Israeli Leader’s History
abstract: Former Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak discusses his career in power in this lifeless, often confusing documentary.
lead_paragraph: In “What If? Ehud Barak on War and Peace,” the former Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak comments on the key military and diplomatic events that took place from his early years as an army commander through his tenure as head of state, from 1999 to 2001. Directed by Ran Tal, this lifeless documentary plays like a cable-TV special slapped together from one long interview with Barak, then fattened up with archival footage and bottom-shelf explanatory graphics.

headline: It’s Not ‘Deaths of Despair.’ It’s Deaths of Children.
abstract: Deaths among children are now driving the country’s life expectancy declines.
lead_paragraph: How long a person can expect to live is one of the most fundamentally revealing facts about a country, and here, in the richest country in the world, the answer is not just bleak but increasingly so. Americans are now dying younger on average than they used to, breaking from all global and historical patterns of predictable improvement. They are dying younger than in any peer countries, even accounting for the larger impact of the pandemic here. They are dying younger than in China, Cuba, the Czech Republic or Lebanon.

headline: French Unions, Still Furious Over Pension Law, Resume Protests
abstract: Hundreds of thousands again took to the streets to rally against raising the retirement age, but there were signs that the demonstrations were losing some steam, at least for now.
lead_paragraph: French workers marched and went on strike around the country on Thursday for the 11th time in three months, as the stalemate between President Emmanuel Macron and labor unions endured even after his pension overhaul, which raised the legal age of retirement to 64 from 62, has become law.

headline: Investors Face a Conundrum Over the Jobs Market
abstract: Inflation, recession and labor market concerns loom large over the stock market ahead of Friday’s jobs report.
lead_paragraph: Stock markets will be closed for Good Friday, but investors still will be tuning in early for one of the most consequential jobs reports of the past year.

headline: Saudi and Iranian Foreign Ministers Meet in China After Thaw
abstract: The high-level talks were a sign that the regional rivals were moving ahead with an agreement to re-establish relations, mediated last month by Beijing.
lead_paragraph: The foreign ministers of Saudi Arabia and Iran held talks in Beijing on Thursday, in the highest-level meeting between the regional rivals since they cut ties seven years ago and a sign that China would continue to host talks that could shift the geopolitics of the Middle East.

headline: European Tour May Punish LIV Golfers, Arbitrators Rule
abstract: The decision by a panel in London was an early test for the Saudi Arabia-backed circuit, which is also facing legal battles in the United States.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Golf’s European tour may punish players who defected to the rival Saudi-financed LIV Golf series, an arbitration panel in London ruled in a decision released on Thursday, the first day of the Masters Tournament.

headline: Millennial Homeowners Finally Outnumber Millennial Renters
abstract: But there are still fewer millennial homeowner households than in older generations.
lead_paragraph: Millennials have had a tough time establishing themselves as homeowners. The generation, comprising people born from 1981 to 1996, has been saddled with student debt and economic uncertainty; the oldest of the cohort faced the housing crisis and the Great Recession of the late ’00s, and the youngest graduated from college right into the pandemic.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and the Bronx
abstract: This week’s properties are on Central Park South, the Upper West Side and in Riverdale.
lead_paragraph: A one-bedroom, one-bath, 887-square-foot apartment with a windowed kitchen that has a dishwasher and garbage disposal; two Juliet balconies; good closet space; motorized window shades; central air-conditioning; two deeded storage units and floor-to-ceiling windows, on the 14th floor of The Plaza, the 20-story hotel with a doorman, concierge, bar, restaurant, cafe, housekeeping, room and laundry service, a gym, spa and beauty salon. David Kong and Seth Levin, Keller Williams, 917-755-9380; kwnyc.com

headline: A Major Ansel Adams Exhibition Arrives in San Francisco
abstract: The self-described “California photographer” captured far more than the Golden State’s national parks.
lead_paragraph: Ansel Adams’s crisp black-and-white photographs of Yosemite National Park are iconic, inescapable even.

headline: Homes for Sale in New Jersey and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s properties are a three-bedroom Co-op in Red Bank, N.J., and a three-bedroom house in New Milford, Conn.
lead_paragraph: A three-bedroom, three-bath, 4,950-square-foot co-op in a former dairy barn of a grand estate built in the late 1920s by Herbert Straus, an heir of Macy’s co-owner and congressman Isidore Straus. It includes Gothic arches and windows, a sunken living room, a formal dining room, a solarium, a greenhouse, five parking bays and a covered, arched patio on a bridge that crosses a man-made lake, on 13 total acres of property with an in-ground pool, cabanas, lavender beds and fields shared with four other co-op units. Katherine Raftery, Resources Real Estate, 732-212-0440, resourcesrealestate.com

headline: A New Exhibition Shows That Barkley L. Hendricks Was Never Simply a Painter
abstract: Plus: an expanding group of Japanese restaurants in Brooklyn, exuberant tableware from Kit Kemp and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: My morning routine depends on how much time I have. Lately I’ve become a huge fan of using gadgets like the Red Light Face Mask from HigherDose while I’m still in bed in the morning. Or I do that old-fashioned trick of dunking your face in ice water. A male co-star of mine would do it and I got into doing it too. I’m into pre-cleansing. I love rose and I’ve been using this Best Skin Ever Rose oil cleanser. Osea makes a couple of cleansers that I rotate between — there’s the Ocean Cleanser that’s milky and the Ocean Cleansing Mudd that I use at night after wearing makeup. I like when I can feel a product doing stuff, and the latter has a cooling effect that feels like it’s activating your pores. I warm it up in my hand with some water and leave it on for a minute or two like a mask. I struggle with hyperpigmentation, and microneedling has helped tremendously. For a gentle version at home, FaceGym makes a Faceshot Electric Microneedling Device and a Brightening Active Roller. I’ve been using this natural mask from Simply Divine Botanicals called Honey, I Shrunk the Pores. I accidentally ate a little bit of it from the corner of my mouth and I swear you could put it on toast. I’ll use Thayers Witch Hazel toner or Biologique Recherche Lotion P50 to tone.

headline: Airbus to Double Production in China as It Moves Ahead With New Orders
abstract: The France-based plane maker announced the agreement despite pressure on Europe from the Biden administration to isolate Beijing.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Airbus agreed on Thursday to build a second assembly line at its factory in China and was given a green light by Beijing to move ahead with 160 previously announced plane orders. The announcement was a pointed reminder of how China remains a critical market for European companies, even as American manufacturers are pulling up stakes.

headline: Silvio Berlusconi, Former Italian Prime Minister, Is Being Treated for Leukemia
abstract: Mr. Berlusconi, who is in the intensive care unit at a Milan hospital, has had the blood disorder for “some time,” his personal physician said.
lead_paragraph: Silvio Berlusconi, the former Italian prime minister, is being treated in the intensive care unit of a Milan hospital for a lung infection related to a kind of leukemia that he has “had for some time,” his personal physician said on Thursday.

headline: Ukrainian forces are ‘not going anywhere,’ Prigozhin says.
abstract: Yevgeny Prigozhin, who leads the mercenary group, also said that Russia would need better organization and more ammunition to push beyond the besieged city.
lead_paragraph: Yevgeny Prigozhin, the leader of Russia’s Wagner militia, said on Thursday that Ukrainian forces were “not going anywhere” and were continuing to fight in Bakhmut, contradicting his previous assertions that the mercenaries he commands were close to taking control of the bitterly contested city in eastern Ukraine.

headline: Why Oral Hygiene Is Crucial to Your Overall Health
abstract: Gum disease has been associated with a range of health conditions, including diabetes, heart disease, dementia and more. Here’s what experts say you can do to manage the risk.
lead_paragraph: The inside of your mouth is the perfect place for bacteria to thrive: It’s dark, it’s warm, it’s wet and the foods and drinks you consume provide nutrients for them to eat.

headline: Tennessee House Expulsions: What You Need to Know
abstract: A week after Republicans ousted two Democratic lawmakers over a gun control protest, both have returned to their seats.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of a school shooting in Nashville that left six people dead, three Democratic lawmakers took to the floor of the Republican-controlled Tennessee House chamber in late March to rally for stricter gun control.

headline: A World Chess Championship Without the World’s Best Player
abstract: A victory by Ian Nepomniachtchi or Ding Liren would come with political overtones. But Magnus Carlsen’s absence is the talk of the final.
lead_paragraph: When Ian Nepomniachtchi and Ding Liren face off on Sunday in the first game of the world chess championship, their matchup — tinged with politics — will play out in the shadow of an absent rival: Magnus Carlsen.

headline: Six Places to Drink Wine in Napa Valley and Sonoma
abstract: The restaurants in California wine country can be superexpensive or somewhat dull, but these places offer great combinations of intrigue and value.
lead_paragraph: NAPA, Calif. — Napa Valley and Sonoma County, the most popular destinations for those traveling to Northern California wine country, are full of alluring restaurants. But wine lists that offer both wide selections and good values are not so easy to find.

headline: Retirement-Age Money Issues: Planners Weigh In on Your Questions
abstract: Readers sent some of their most urgent financial queries, asking about issues like Social Security and student loan debt. Financial planners offered ideas.
lead_paragraph: People often think of planning for retirement as a combination of saving and picking an ideal mix of investments, all to arrive at just the right size nest egg. But it is also about juggling trade-offs and avoiding costly mistakes, all while paying for immediate needs. It’s a difficult calculus.

headline: How to Spring Clean Your Bed
abstract: Five tips for freshening your bed as the summer season approaches.
lead_paragraph: Five tips for freshening your bed as the summer season approaches.

headline: Applications Open! The New York Times Illustration Portfolio Review
abstract: We’re inviting illustrators from around the world to share their work with art directors from The New York Times. Apply by June 16.
lead_paragraph: We are selecting 80 illustrators to be paired with art directors from The New York Times for individual portfolio critiques. The art directors will offer feedback and guidance to further your work.

headline: Biden Administration to Curb Toxic Pollutants From Chemical Plants
abstract: The rule would chiefly affect plants along the Gulf Coast, the Ohio River Valley and in West Virginia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Thursday proposed a new regulation to significantly reduce hazardous air pollutants from chemical plants, a move that environmental advocates predicted would significantly reduce the health risks to  people living near industrial sites.

headline: ‘I’ve Lost a Lot of Flesh and Bone,’ Jeremy Renner Says, Recalling Snow Plow Accident
abstract: The actor, who sustained more than 30 broken bones when a 14,000-pound plow ran him over in January, described his arduous recovery in an interview with ABC News.
lead_paragraph: The actor Jeremy Renner, who was severely injured on Jan. 1 when a heavy snow plow ran over him, said in a TV interview on Thursday night that the truck had hit him as he was trying to save his nephew, an accident that broke more than 30 of his bones and upended his life.

headline: Macron and Xi Call for Return to Ukraine Peace Talks
abstract: President Emmanuel Macron of France and Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, called for a return to peace talks over Russia’s war on Ukraine during a meeting in Beijing.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France and Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, called for a return to peace talks over Russia’s war on Ukraine during a meeting in Beijing.

headline: Staring Down a Debt Crisis, McCarthy Toils to Navigate G.O.P. Divisions
abstract: The House speaker has little trust in his Budget Committee chairman or his No. 2 as he works to unite the fractious Republican majority around a spending plan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was midway through Representative Kevin McCarthy’s drawn-out battle for the House speakership when Representative Jodey C. Arrington of Texas, one of his public supporters, began quietly approaching colleagues to see whether they would be open to backing his No. 2, Representative Steve Scalise of Louisiana, instead.

headline: ‘On a Wing and a Prayer’ Review: Faith as Flight Insurance
abstract: A family receives impromptu flight lessons when their pilot dies in the middle of a chartered flight in this spiritually insincere action film.
lead_paragraph: Doug White (Dennis Quaid) is a person whose happiness has grown from deep roots. He possesses a steady Christian faith. He has a warm and loving partnership with his wife, Terri (Heather Graham), and together, they are the proud parents of two teenage daughters. But when Doug’s beloved brother suddenly dies, Doug’s faith in a higher power is shaken. And his spiritual crisis is amplified when Doug charters a small plane to return from his brother’s funeral.

headline: The Many Faces of Cauliflower
abstract: Riced, kung pao spiced, stuffed in a pita — we’ve asked so much of this cruciferous vegetable.
lead_paragraph: On a résumé, in an airport or on a date, it’s a dangerous game trying to be someone you’re not. It’s always a safer bet to be yourself. That is, unless you are a head of cauliflower.

headline: Virginia Rolls Back Voting Rights for Ex-Felons, Bucking Shaky Bipartisan Trend
abstract: State after state has eased restrictions on voting for former felons in recent years. But Gov. Glenn Youngkin’s reversal suggests growing wariness on the right.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than a decade, states around the country have steadily chipped away at one of the biggest roadblocks to voting in the United States — laws on the books that bar former felons from casting a ballot.

headline: No More Hush Money at National Enquirer, Its New Publisher Says
abstract: “Catch and kill,” the tactic of buying and burying stories at the heart of the case against former President Trump, is no longer in practice, said Ted Farnsworth, who is now overseeing the tabloid.
lead_paragraph: The National Enquirer and the publication’s longtime practice of “catch and kill” — buying, then burying, unsavory stories about powerful people — are at the center of New York’s criminal charges against former President Donald J. Trump.
