Review: Laughing, and Crying, in the Face of ‘Grief’
abstract: In his solo show about the death of his teenage children, Colin Campbell recounts his calamitous relationship with the darkest of emotions.
lead_paragraph: Death is often described as a loss, but for Colin Campbell and his wife, it was a theft. On June 12, 2019, the couple’s children, Ruby and Hart, were killed by an inebriated driver in a horrific crash. Ruby was 17 and loved anime; Hart was 14 and worshiped hip-hop. A photograph of them even younger — bright-eyed and golden-haired — rests on a table like a shrine, one of the few props in Campbell’s brusque tragicomedy, “Grief: A One Man ShitShow.”

headline: ‘Showing Up’ Review: Making Art in All Its Everyday Glory
abstract: In their latest movie together, Michelle Williams and Kelly Reichardt paint a portrait of an artist who’s a real and wonderful piece of work.
lead_paragraph: The stubbornly independent filmmaker Kelly Reichardt makes small-scale movies rooted in specific worlds, both inner and outer; nearly all take place in Oregon, where she’s long lived and worked. She traveled back in time for her last movie, “First Cow,” a moving chronicle of love, land and capitalism set in the Oregon Territory in the 19th century. Reichardt is back on more familiar ground in her latest, “Showing Up,” a wonderful slice of life that’s set in present-day Portland and is about something that she knows intimately: making art.

headline: U.S. Acknowledges Afghanistan Evacuation Should Have Started Sooner
abstract: President Biden’s decision to end a 20-year war in August 2021 led to the swift collapse of the Afghan government and military. His administration has placed heavy blame on his predecessor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration’s nearly two-year review of the calamitous American withdrawal from Afghanistan found that U.S. officials should have started the evacuation earlier, but placed extensive blame on President Biden’s predecessor, former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Sarah Sze and the Art of Tracking Time
abstract: The artist plants her gravity-defying installations in the uppermost nest of the Guggenheim Museum.
lead_paragraph: Television is awash in competition shows that force contestants to take on ludicrous challenges: Marry a stranger; throw a clay vessel on the wheel, blindfolded; cook a three-course meal in 10 minutes. For artists like Sarah Sze, the insanity starts when the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum calls. Here’s the prompt: Create an exhibition of new work in a spiral space with a sloping floor, shifting natural light, and 200 works by another artist leading into your own show.

headline: Concerns Grow as Tighter Lending Threatens Commercial Real Estate
abstract: The recent banking turmoil added scrutiny to a sector already weighed down by office vacancies, rising interest rates and mounting debt.
lead_paragraph: The turmoil that drove Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank out of business last month, rocking the wider banking sector, has analysts bracing for the next possible crisis: the $20 trillion commercial real estate market.

headline: I.R.S. Unveils $80 Billion Plan to Overhaul Tax Collection
abstract: The 10-year strategy document outlines a focus on improving customer service and cracking down on tax evasion by corporations and the wealthy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Internal Revenue Service on Thursday unveiled an $80 billion plan to transform itself into a “digital first” tax collector focused on customer service and cracking down on wealthy tax evaders. The move lays the groundwork for an ambitious 10-year overhaul of one of the most scrutinized arms of the federal government.

headline: How to Make a Simple Roast Chicken, According to a French Mom
abstract: Featuring butter, tarragon and Cognac, this reader-submitted recipe is simple, sophisticated and utterly stunning, Melissa Clark writes.
lead_paragraph: Like little black dresses, you can never have too many roast chicken recipes. Especially the French kind.

headline: New Mexico Man Charged in Case of Missing Navajo Nation Woman
abstract: Ella Mae Begay disappeared from Sweetwater, Ariz., in 2021. Her case brought attention to the crisis of missing and murdered Native Americans.
lead_paragraph: A federal grand jury has indicted a New Mexico man on assault and carjacking charges related to the 2021 disappearance of Ella Mae Begay, a Native American woman whose case brought attention to missing and murdered Native American people, prosecutors said.

headline: ‘Star Trek: Picard’ Season 3, Episode 8 Recap: Consequences Abound
abstract: Jean-Luc breaks Data in case of emergency. Vadic makes a move.
lead_paragraph: Much of this season of “Picard” revolves around familial relationships, particularly parenting. There’s how we choose to do it (Beverly). The consequences of avoiding it entirely (Jean-Luc). The weight of keeping our children safe (Geordi). How we grieve (Riker and Troi.)

headline: The Arrest of Evan Gershkovich Is Further Evidence of Putin’s Brutality
abstract: The detention of a journalist is yet another sign of his willingness to wage all-out war.
lead_paragraph: Russia has a rich history of imprisoning people on bogus charges for no purpose other than to help keep a dictator in power. At the peak of the Stalinist purges, when millions were swept into the Gulag, the secret police nevertheless insisted on giving a veneer of legality to the dragnet with formal charges, witnesses, mug shots and trials. As Nadezhda Mandelstam, wife of the great Russian poet Osip Mandelstam, recalled in her memoir, “We never asked, on hearing about the latest arrest, ‘What was he arrested for?’” The official crime was never the real reason.

headline: A Spare Who Spared Himself Nothing
abstract: Sally Bedell Smith’s “George VI and Elizabeth: The Marriage That Saved the Monarchy” explores a wholly different epoch in the Windsor saga.
lead_paragraph: While the impending coronation of Charles III is meant to usher in a glorious new chapter for the House of Windsor, the obsessive tabloid attention it has garnered has merely aggravated a growing case of collective royal fatigue. In these turbulent times do we not, after all, have better things to think about than the latest bit of pageantry or pettiness, splendor or scandal, emanating from the world’s most famous surviving monarchy? And when we consider the key players in this narrative, what lessons do they really have to teach us, except that royal privilege seldom makes better people of those who have, crave or lose it?

headline: Trump’s Arrest Lifts Campaign of Man He Once Condemned
abstract: Yusef Salaam, one of the wrongly imprisoned Central Park Five, is running in a competitive City Council race in Harlem. He described the former president’s indictment as “karma.”
lead_paragraph: Not long after Donald J. Trump surrendered at the Manhattan Criminal Courthouse on Tuesday, becoming the first former president to face criminal charges, Yusef Salaam, a candidate for a City Council seat in Harlem, sent out a statement.

headline: Pension Law Protests Continue to Grip France
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators took to the streets yet again, calling for President Emmanuel Macron’s pension overhaul to be blocked.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators took to the streets yet again, calling for President Emmanuel Macron’s pension overhaul to be blocked.

headline: ‘Joyland’ Review: A Target of Gossip
abstract: Saim Sadiq’s melodrama, about a husband’s affair with a transgender dancer, was briefly banned in Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: In November, the director Saim Sadiq’s provocative melodrama “Joyland” was briefly banned in his home country, Pakistan, for depicting a romance between a married man, Haider, and a dancer, Biba. Western audiences might refer to Biba as a transgender woman, but the film avoids those words. “She is that,” Haider tells his jilted wife.

headline: Supreme Court Rules for Transgender Girl in School Sports Dispute
abstract: The justices issued a temporary order allowing the girl to compete on the girls’ track team at a West Virginia middle school.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that a transgender girl may compete on the girls’ cross country and track teams at her middle school in West Virginia while her appeal moved forward, signaling that a majority of the justices are not ready to enter another battleground in the culture wars.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Our recommended books this week include a memoir of Broadway in the AIDS era, written by a longtime cast member of “A Chorus Line” who lost her brother to the disease, along with a biography of the seminal poet Phillis Wheatley, a journalistic account of a murder-suicide that casts troubling light on America’s foster-care system, and a deep dive into the quote-unquote deep state. We also like Monica Youn’s new poetry collection, “From From,” and, in fiction, a couple of romances along with new novels by Elizabeth McKenzie, Rafael Frumkin and the Booker winner Eleanor Catton — whose splashy new book, “Birnam Wood,” pits a billionaire doomsayer against a group of scruffy eco-warriors on the same plot of New Zealand land. Happy reading.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | March Madness Bracket
abstract: The final brackets for the 2023 N.C.A.A. women’s and men’s basketball tournaments show teams’ initial seedings and subsequent game scores. What do you notice and wonder?
lead_paragraph: Here are the women’s and men’s final brackets for the 2023 N.C.A.A. basketball championship, referred to as March Madness. These graphs show the initial seeding of the 64 men’s and 64 women’s teams along with the scores for all 126 games leading to the championship game between San Diego State and Connecticut for the men’s bracket and Iowa State and Louisiana State for the women’s bracket.

abstract: Along with the Masters, there’s the best one-day cycling race of the year — and the best-named sports tournament.
lead_paragraph: Along with the Masters, there’s the best one-day cycling race of the year — and the best-named sports tournament.

headline: Lawmakers Call for Tighter Ethics Code After Revelations About Justice Thomas
abstract: An investigation by ProPublica revealed that Clarence Thomas accompanied Harlan Crow, a conservative donor and real estate billionaire, on a series of luxury vacations without disclosing them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democratic lawmakers reiterated calls on Thursday to tighten ethics rules for the Supreme Court after a report revealed that Justice Clarence Thomas had accepted luxury gifts from a major conservative donor without disclosing them.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Elephant Whisperers’ and More
abstract: I’m a New Delhi-based reporter and visual journalist for The New York Times. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I’m a New Delhi-based reporter and visual journalist for The New York Times. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.

headline: Divisions emerge in NATO over giving Ukraine a pathway to membership, officials say.
abstract: The debate on the status of Kyiv will continue up to the military alliance’s mid-July summit meeting.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — NATO countries are divided over what kind of political reassurances they might give Ukraine at the next NATO summit meeting, in mid-July, with the United States, Germany and France resisting pressure from Central and Eastern European allies to provide any detailed “road map” toward membership, Western officials said following a meeting of NATO foreign ministers this week.

headline: Tripping in the Bronze Age
abstract: A new study based on strands of hair found in a Spanish burial cave reveals that humans living about 3,000 years ago used hallucinogens, likely derived from local plants, as part of their rituals.
lead_paragraph: Bronze Age humans have been credited with a number of civilizational advancements: the invention of irrigation, the wheel, writing systems and the ability to forge weapons and tools from the durable metal that lends the era its name.

headline: The Friendship Harmonies of boygenius
abstract: How Julien Baker, Phoebe Bridgers and Lucy Dacus’s side project has become a major part of their music — and their lore.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, the rising indie rock singers Julien Baker, Phoebe Bridgers and Lucy Dacus teamed up to form boygenius, a collaborative side project that quickly took on outsized importance. For fans, it reinforced the characteristics that made each singer so appealing individually, and also created a new layer of lore.

headline: Why Does Written Language Have to Be So Particular?

headline: ‘They Deserve Better’: What Students Are Saying About Respect and Pay for School Workers
abstract: In light of the Los Angeles schools strike last month, we invited teenagers to tell us how bus drivers, custodians, cafeteria workers and other school staff have made their education possible.
lead_paragraph: When Los Angeles school workers went on a three-day strike last month to demand more respect, better conditions and higher pay, forcing the cancellation of classes for 422,000 students, we wanted to know what young people thought: Do the bus drivers, custodians, cafeteria staff, teachers’ aides and other adults who work in schools deserve more respect — and pay?

headline: Zelensky’s aides send mixed messages on Crimea and the possibility of negotiations.
abstract: Top government officials in Kyiv clarify that their mission remains to reclaim all Ukrainian territory from Russia.
lead_paragraph: Confusion about a possible shift in the Ukrainian government’s stance on recovering Crimea from Russian occupation prompted a flurry of public clarifications on Thursday from officials in President Volodymyr Zelensky’s administration, who reiterated their vow to liberate all of Ukraine’s territory.

headline: Xi and Macron Call for Ukraine Peace Talks, but the Path Is Murky
abstract: It is not clear that the Chinese and French leaders — much less Russia and Ukraine — have compatible terms for talks or peace, and Mr. Xi has not publicly agreed to pressure Moscow to negotiate.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France and Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, appealed on Thursday for a rapid return to peace talks to end the war in Ukraine, but Mr. Xi did not indicate whether he would use his close relationship with Moscow to push Russia to negotiate.

headline: Biden Plan Allows Limits on Trans Athletes’ Participation in School Sports
abstract: It is the first time the administration has substantively weighed in on the charged debate. The proposal would also prevent schools from enacting across-the-board bans.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration proposed a rule change on Thursday that would allow schools to block some transgender athletes from competing on sports teams that match their gender identities. But the proposal would also prevent schools from enacting across-the-board bans.

lead_paragraph: For Domantas Sabonis, basketball has long been it.

abstract: Plus China and France call for peace talks between Russia and Ukraine, and India scrubs its textbooks.

Trump, moving quickly after Mr. Trump’s arraignment this week to dissect the active criminal case against him and scrutinize the office pursuing it.

headline: Elizabeth de Cuevas, Sculptor With a Flair for the Monumental, Dies at 94
abstract: A Rockefeller heiress who was inspired by the monuments of Europe, she fashioned towering metal creations that channeled the cosmic.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth de Cuevas, a sculptor known for monumental creations in steel and bronze — as well as for her role in a much-publicized estate battle in the 1980s — died on March 19 at her home in Manhattan. She was 94.

headline: The new U.S. ambassador in Moscow meets with a diplomat to discuss Evan Gershkovich, the detained reporter.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The U.S. ambassador in Moscow met on Thursday with a Russian deputy foreign minister to discuss the detention by Russia of Evan Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal who was reporting in the Ural region of the country when he was taken captive by the authorities, a State Department official said.

headline: Ukraine War Plans Leak Prompts Pentagon Investigation
abstract: Classified documents detailing secret American and NATO plans have appeared on Twitter and Telegram.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Classified war documents detailing secret American and NATO plans for building up the Ukrainian military ahead of a planned offensive against Russian troops were posted this week on social media channels, senior Biden administration officials said.

headline: Jane LaTour, Fighter for Women in Labor Unions, Dies at 76
abstract: No stranger to blue-collar work herself, she pushed for equality in male-dominated unions and as a writer chronicled the struggles of “sisters in the brotherhoods.”
lead_paragraph: Jane LaTour, a union activist and writer who chronicled the lives of women in traditionally male labor unions, documenting their battles with both their employers and their unions, died on Monday in the Bronx. She was 76.

headline: Putin’s Energy Offensive Has Failed
abstract: He tried to weaponize natural gas. It didn’t work.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Putin invaded Ukraine on Feb. 24, 2022. Since then, Russia has launched four great offensives. Three were military; the fourth was economic. And while you don’t hear much about that last offensive, its failure offers some very important lessons.

headline: Fentanyl Contributed to Coolio’s Death, Medical Examiner Says
abstract: Coolio’s death was accidental, according to the Los Angeles County medical examiner, who also said that the rapper had a heart condition and asthma.
lead_paragraph: Coolio, the gritty rapper best known for his hit “Gangsta’s Paradise,” died from the effects of fentanyl, heroin and methamphetamine, according to the Los Angeles County medical examiner.

headline: Tiger Woods, On One Good Leg, Struggles to Shoot 74
abstract: There was nothing easy about the first round of Woods’s 25th Masters Tournament on Thursday. He was in pain and limped, laboring up and down Augusta National’s hills.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Tiger Woods saw where his golf ball came to rest after his tee shot on the last hole Thursday and knew he was in big trouble.

headline: Dilemma for Judge in Trump Case: Whether to Muzzle the Former President
abstract: Justice Juan M. Merchan cautioned Donald Trump against incendiary rhetoric. Then the former president went after the judge’s family.
lead_paragraph: As a former president and the de facto leader of the Republican Party, Donald J. Trump is one of the most powerful people in America.

headline: Tennessee G.O.P. Punishes 2 Democrats by Throwing Them Out of House
abstract: The unseating of the lawmakers threatened to further inflame partisan rancor in a state that is divided over issues like how to respond to a school shooting in Nashville.
lead_paragraph: The Tennessee House voted on Thursday to expel two Democrats one week after they interrupted debate by leading protesters in a call for stricter gun laws in the wake of a shooting that left six dead at a Christian school.

headline: Augusta National, Playing Easy for Now, Has Three Atop Leaderboard
abstract: Viktor Hovland, Jon Rahm and Brooks Koepka all shot 65s in the opening round of the first Masters of the LIV Golf era.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The gallery was thick from the start, as it almost always is at Augusta National Golf Club’s first tee. And, as it almost always is when Tiger Woods is lurking at a Masters Tournament, nearly no one was there for the rest of his group, Viktor Hovland or Xander Schauffele.

headline: On Deadline, Decoding the Trump Indictment
abstract: Michael Rothfeld had just hours to annotate 29 pages of documents related to the charges against Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Just after 3:30 p.m. on Tuesday, a news release from the Manhattan district attorney’s office landed in the inbox of Michael Rothfeld, an investigative reporter on the Metro desk of The New York Times: The indictment of Donald J. Trump had been unsealed. It was go time.

headline: Senior Twitter Lawyer Resigns, the Latest in a Series of Executive Departures
abstract: The lawyer had been closely involved in the company’s talks with the Federal Trade Commission over promises it had made on privacy.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A senior lawyer at Twitter submitted his resignation on Thursday, four people familiar with the matter said, becoming the latest in a string of executives to leave the company since Elon Musk took it over nearly six months ago.

headline: Mimi Sheraton, Innovative New York Times Food Critic, Dies at 97
abstract: Ms. Sheraton, who worked for many publications in a six-decade career, was the first restaurant reviewer to wear a disguise in order to get a normal diner’s experience.
lead_paragraph: Mimi Sheraton, the food writer and restaurant critic who chronicled culinary scenes in New York and around the world with a discriminating palate and deft prose that captured the nuances of haute cuisine and plumbed the mysteries of chicken soup, died on Thursday in Manhattan. She was 97.

headline: Review: In ‘The Wife of Willesden,’ a Literary Marriage Falters
abstract: Zadie Smith brings her first play, an adaptation of Chaucer’s the Wife of Bath tale, to the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: This April, in New York, when the rains have come and the winds have calmed and the cherry trees and hyacinths have hustled into bloom, theatergoers might find themselves making a pilgrimage to the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Harvey Theater, for the New York premiere of “The Wife of Willesden,” the novelist Zadie Smith’s adaptation of a lusty wedge of Geoffrey Chaucer’s “The Canterbury Tales.” And despite the punch and panache of the play’s language, they might find themselves going nowhere.

headline: Places for Forks
abstract: Lindsey Hobbs opens our solving weekend with a tricky Friday.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Mark Halpin makes his Times acrostic debut, and makes us all exhale.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — I experienced a shock of the new when I saw an unfamiliar byline on this acrostic, but when I investigated further I learned of Mark Halpin’s status as a luminary in the puzzleverse. It’s been some time since we’ve seen one of his challenges in our own pages — a “Ring Toss” variety puzzle that ran in September 2013 — but he has contributed at many other venues and has an absolutely beautiful array of multipart puzzles on his own website. (I was instantly drawn to “Let’s Get Away From the City,” which looks like a delight for lovers of books and puzzles; it’s based on Giovanni Boccaccio’s book “The Decameron.” I’ll take a crack at it this weekend.)

headline: Quotation of the Day: Proposed E.P.A. Rule to Curb Toxic Emissions From Plants
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, April 7, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “We are poisoned, and we are sick, and we are finally able to address some of the multiple chemicals that are poisoning us at the same time, causing rare and different cancers.”

headline: Corrections: April 7, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, April 7, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on March 30 about Ukraine’s steel industry misstated the type of coal used to power blast furnaces. It is metallurgical coal, not thermal coal.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: A war documents leak.
lead_paragraph: Classified war documents detailing U.S. and NATO plans for strengthening the Ukrainian military before a planned offensive against Russia were posted this week on Twitter and on Telegram, a platform with more than half a billion users that is widely available in Russia, senior Biden administration officials said. The Pentagon is investigating the leak.

headline: ‘It Was Not Love at First Sight’
abstract: It took Samantha Weinstein and Philip Della Noce a few years to form a friendship, and another few more to become romantic.
lead_paragraph: Some people know instantly when they meet “the one.” But when Samantha Rose Weinstein met Philip Joseph Della Noce, “It was not love at first sight,” she said. “We weren’t too fond of each other at the beginning.”

headline: They Knew From the Start (but the Dogs Needed Convincing)
abstract: Catriona Duncan and Sarah Palmisano, who met through Tinder, had their first date almost five years ago at the taping of the NPR game show “Wait Wait … Don’t Tell Me!”
lead_paragraph: Catriona Campbell Duncan and Sarah Gail Palmisano have no doubt that the popularity of the NPR game show “Wait Wait … Don’t Tell Me!” is well deserved. But they wouldn’t really know, even though their first date, in August 2018, was a live taping of the show in Chicago’s Millennium Park.

headline: In Her Dream, a Premonition and Then a Double Proposal
abstract: Kyiona Carswell and Alison Wynn’s relationship status remained casual for years until a series of coincidences, accidental run-ins, and a precognitive vision brought them closer together.
lead_paragraph: It took two different dating apps, two cities, a pandemic, and more than two post-breakup run-ins for Kyiona Carswell and Alison Wynn to realize that they were finally serious about each other.

headline: Uh-Oh, I Seem to Be Dating a Chatbot
abstract: David was passionate, courteous and (artificially) intelligent.
lead_paragraph: I was at Nubar, an elegant cafe near Harvard Square, to meet David, with whom I had been corresponding online. He sounded like the perfect man: a recently retired professor, early 70s, grew up in Brooklyn, taught psychology and social sciences in New York, California and Massachusetts, and was divorced, with two grown sons in California. Our shared interests included hiking, biking and reading, and we were looking for similar qualities in a mate.

headline: Art Was an Easy Topic. Defining Their Relationship Was Not.
abstract: When Robert Hall and Amy Cheng, who bonded over Chinese art, first started dating, only Mr. Hall was aware of the change in their relationship status. Months later, Ms. Cheng finally caught on.
lead_paragraph: For seven months, Robert Laureano Hall and Kwai Yuen Cheng’s relationship operated on a misunderstanding. Mr. Hall thought that they were dating; Ms. Cheng thought they were just friends.

headline: Once the Prince of Tennis and a Prison Inmate, Boris Becker Starts Again
abstract: Becker, who is featured in a new documentary, is beginning a third act after serving eight months in prison. “I’m sort of in late summer, fall of my life,” he said.
lead_paragraph: There is something about athletes achieving a level of greatness as teenagers that makes watching them progress into middle age especially jarring.

headline: As the war grinds on in Ukraine, Ireland will examine its military neutrality.
abstract: Prompted by Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine, Ireland’s government will re-examine its longstanding policy of military neutrality at a forum being held this summer, the country’s government said this week.
lead_paragraph: Prompted by Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine, Ireland’s government will re-examine its longstanding policy of military neutrality at a forum being held this summer, the country’s government said this week.

headline: China and France issue a joint statement supporting ‘all efforts to restore peace in Ukraine.’
abstract: The statement was issued after a three-day summit by Xi Jinping and Emmanuel Macron in China.
lead_paragraph: As President Emmanuel Macron of France and Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, concluded a three-day summit on Friday, their two governments issued a joint statement supporting peace efforts and opposing attacks on nuclear facilities in Ukraine.

headline: Word of the Day: singe
abstract: This word has appeared in 16 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word singe has appeared in 16 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 30 in “With ‘Tár,’ Todd Field Returns to Directing. Where Has He Been?” by Kyle Buchanan:

headline: The New York Mets: Fair or Foul Weather Ahead?
abstract: The Mets have had a poor start to their season, but on the day their home opener is scheduled, fans are still believing.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. The Mets are scheduled to play their home opener today. We’ll get an assessment of their chances for the season from our baseball editor.

headline: Seth Meyers Defends New York City From Marjorie Taylor Greene
abstract: “I don’t go to her hometown and say nasty things about it, although I don’t know where she’s from,” Meyers said. “I’m assuming the videotape from ‘The Ring’?”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Emotional
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Wages May Not Be Inflation’s Cause, but They’re the Focus of the Cure
abstract: While fear of a “wage-price spiral” has eased, the Federal Reserve’s course presumes job losses and risks a recession. Some see less painful remedies.
lead_paragraph: As Covid-19 eased its debilitating grip on the U.S. economy two years ago, businesses scrambled to hire. That lifted the pay of the average worker. But as one economic challenge ended, another potential problem emerged.

headline: Baptist Minister in Myanmar Gets 6 Years in Prison for Opposing Junta
abstract: The minister met with President Donald J. Trump in 2019 to highlight the abuses of Myanmar’s military, which later seized power in a coup.
lead_paragraph: Hkalam Samson, a Baptist minister in Myanmar who once called attention to his country’s human rights abuses at the White House, was sentenced to six years in prison on Friday on charges of terrorism, unlawful association and inciting opposition to the regime in Myanmar.

headline: Who Jacinda Ardern Really Is
abstract: As told in her first and farewell speeches.
lead_paragraph: In her first speech to lawmakers in 2008, Jacinda Ardern, the former New Zealand prime minister, told her new colleagues a little about what they might expect from her.

headline: Silver Linings of a ‘Doom Loop’
abstract: Some business leaders feel that predicting the arrival of a boogeyman could conjure his presence, in effect making talk of a doom loop a self-fulfilling prophecy. And they’re calling for more optimism.
lead_paragraph: Some business leaders feel that predicting the arrival of a boogeyman could conjure his presence, in effect making talk of a doom loop a self-fulfilling prophecy. And they’re calling for more optimism.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of the film "Showing Up," starring Michelle Williams
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of the film "Showing Up," starring Michelle Williams

headline: That Meeting Was Too Long (and It Probably Could’ve Been an Email)
abstract: Managers are finding new ways to help employees reclaim time — including mandatory meeting-free days.
lead_paragraph: At a recent meeting, Shannon Bender and Keith Martine tried something new: They stood the entire time.

headline: A.I. Vibe Check With Ezra Klein, and Kevin Tries Phone Positivity
abstract: How do you make sense of all the different philosophical camps surrounding A.I.?
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Opinion columnist Ezra Klein has spent years talking to artificial intelligence researchers. Many of them feel the prospect of A.I. discovery is too sweet to ignore, regardless of the technology’s risks.

headline: A Quadruplex Sells for Nearly $68 Million on the Upper East Side
abstract: The sale is the priciest so far this year. The four-story apartment is in a new, sold-out condo, the Bellemont, at 1165 Madison Avenue.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s biggest closed sale so far this year took place at the Bellemont, a brand-new boutique condominium on the Upper East Side. A penthouse spanning the top four floors of the 13-story limestone building was bought by an anonymous buyer for about $67.9 million.

headline: New Translations Explore Brazil’s ‘Endless and Unfinished’ Character
abstract: Two translations bring canonical works by Mário de Andrade into English, allowing a glimpse into the author’s “problematic sense of belonging.”
lead_paragraph: Mário de Andrade’s novel “Macunaíma: The Hero With No Character” follows a shape-shifting, rule-flouting, race-switching trickster as he roams the vast nation of Brazil, meeting historical characters, folkloric figures, and outrageously satirized stereotypes along the way.

headline: When My Father Got Alzheimer’s, I Had to Learn to Lie to Him
abstract: They call it therapeutic deception. It’s complicated.
lead_paragraph: When my father was declining from Alzheimer’s disease, one of the things my siblings and I used to argue about was whether to correct his confusions.

headline: ‘Yellowjackets’ Season 2, Episode 3 Recap: Hunger Games
abstract: Adult Shauna tries to fill the gaping hole inside. Teen Misty gives an interesting monologue.
lead_paragraph: This week’s episode of “Yellowjackets” is a tale of two monologues.

headline: When Someone You Love Is Upset, Ask This One Question
abstract: Offering support can be tricky, but experts say this technique helps.
lead_paragraph: Last September, I got a phone call from my sister Heather, a special-education teacher at an elementary school in upstate New York.

headline: Amid Exile and Fire, a Revered Russian Theater Director Is Reborn
abstract: Dmitry Krymov, one of Russia’s most eminent directors, is among the dozens of artists who have left their homeland since Russia invaded Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: If Dmitry Krymov, the celebrated Russian director and playwright, were directing a play about his life, the third act would begin, he mused, in a cramped, art-filled apartment on Manhattan’s Upper West Side. It is winter, nearly a year after Russia invaded Ukraine, turning his brief visit to the United States into an open-ended exile after he spoke out against the war. And his living room has suddenly burst into flames.

headline: Should You Have a Right to Be Rude?
abstract: An individual’s right to be rude at public meetings was upheld by the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court. When, if ever, is it OK to be impolite?
lead_paragraph: When was the last time someone was rude to you? How did you feel? Have you ever been rude to someone else? What were the circumstances? Did you feel justified in your actions or did you regret them?

headline: The Wondrous Connections Between Mathematics and Literature
abstract: Understanding the often-overlooked links between math and literature can enhance your appreciation of both.
lead_paragraph: “Call me Ishmael.” This has to be one of the most famous opening sentences in all of literature, and I’m embarrassed to say that — until quite recently — I didn’t get beyond it.

headline: New Support for Some Extinct Tasmanian Tiger Sightings
abstract: The last thylacine died in captivity in 1936, but a statistical analysis adds a degree of validity to the survival of small groups of the carnivorous marsupials.
lead_paragraph: Depending on whom you ask, the Tasmanian tiger or thylacine has either been extinct for nearly a century or has been just really good at hiding.

headline: The Abortion Ban Backlash Is Starting to Freak Out Republicans
abstract: But their voters won’t let them pivot to moderation.
lead_paragraph: After the Republican Party’s disappointing performance in the 2022 midterms, fueled in large part by a backlash to the Supreme Court’s overturning of Roe v. Wade, the Republican National Committee recommitted itself to anti-abortion maximalism.

headline: U.S. Economy May Be Heading to a Place That Must Not Be Named
abstract: A hard landing? A banana? Euphemisms for recession have a long history in Washington. Whatever the Fed is stating, it seems to be expecting something ugly, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: Recession has become a nasty word. Federal Reserve officials dance around it with euphemisms like “a soft landing” or its dreaded alternative, “a hard landing.”

headline: These Tiffs Over Electric Vehicles Are Not What They Seem
abstract: Competition, not cooperation, has driven the bulk of climate progress over the past few years.
lead_paragraph: There is something ironic, almost poignant, about Europe’s furious response to the Biden administration’s flagship climate law. For the past six or seven years, European officials have spoken regularly about how a climate-friendly economy was the future. “I am convinced that the old growth model that is based on fossil fuels and pollution is out of date,” Ursula von der Leyen, the European Commission president, declared in 2019. It was time to embrace a “new growth strategy,” she said, one as much about “cutting emissions” as “about creating jobs and boosting innovation.”

headline: Why A.I. Might Not Take Your Job or Supercharge the Economy
abstract: Ezra Klein answers listener questions about how A.I. might change our lives — or not.
lead_paragraph: Typically when we put out a call for audience questions, there’s no single topic that dominates. This time was different. The questions we received were overwhelmingly focused on artificial intelligence: Do A.I. systems pose an existential threat to humanity? Will robots take our jobs? How could these machines potentially make our lives — and the lives of our children — better?

headline: Buying or Selling a Home? Welcome to the Year of Disappointment
abstract: After a tumultuous few years, many hoped that the housing market would improve this spring. No such luck — for buyers or sellers.
lead_paragraph: For two years, the housing market was a miserably competitive place. Prices soared by 45 percent, bidding wars became commonplace, and houses flew off the market. The frenzy came to a screeching halt last spring, as mortgage rates doubled in a matter of months, further driving up the cost of buying a home and freezing buyers out of the market.

headline: How A.I. and DNA Are Unlocking the Mysteries of Global Supply Chains
abstract: Firms are turning to advanced technologies to help answer a surprisingly tricky question: Where do products really come from?
lead_paragraph: At a cotton gin in the San Joaquin Valley, in California, a boxy machine helps to spray a fine mist containing billions of molecules of DNA onto freshly cleaned Pima cotton.

headline: In 1993 ‘Super Mario Bros.’ Bombed; in 2023, It’s a Hit With a New Generation
abstract: A critical and commercial disaster in its day, the video-game adaptation was trashed even by its star, Bob Hoskins. But a reappraisal is underway.
lead_paragraph: The new animated film “The Super Mario Bros. Movie” recreates the sunny spirit, effervescent action and confectionary aesthetic of the namesake video games, with the voices of Chris Pratt as Mario, Charlie Day as Luigi, Jack Black as Bowser, and Anya Taylor-Joy as Princess Peach. Expect periwinkle skies, green warp pipes and squeaky-voiced, mushroom-headed characters.

headline: Grinding His Way to International Stardom
abstract: Lars Nootbaar, a high-energy outfielder for the St. Louis Cardinals, was the first player born outside Japan to play for its national team. He put on a show.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Five Japanese reporters accompanied by still and broadcast cameras covered baseball’s opening day in St. Louis. Curiously, the only player on either team who was born in Japan was pitcher Yusei Kikuchi of the Toronto Blue Jays, whose first start would not come until the next series.

headline: South Carolina Democrats, Stung by String of Losses, Clash Over Next Leader
abstract: A usually low-key race has taken on unusually high stakes as the party prepares to host the first primary of the 2024 campaign and seeks to reverse its recent misfortunes.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Representative James E. Clyburn of South Carolina, a longtime kingmaker in Democratic politics who helped resurrect President Biden’s 2020 presidential campaign, exercised his influence on Wednesday over a much smaller race far closer to home: the campaign to determine who will lead his state’s Democratic Party.

headline: Graphic Novel Riffs on Literary Classics
abstract: Bea Wolf is a sugar-hyped, nap-deprived, battle-ready child; Mulysses is a mule.
lead_paragraph: Mash-ups can be messy. Two new graphic novels, “Bea Wolf” and “Mulysses,” are mash-ups many times over. Both use words and images. Both are designed for children and adults. Both borrow elements from famously complicated stories: “Bea Wolf” picks up verbal schemes and plot points from “Beowulf”; “Mulysses” plays on the deadpan humor of “Moby-Dick” and the Cyclops section of the “Odyssey.” But only one of these mash-ups is messy.

headline: The International Battle Over Bruno Schulz’s Holocaust-Era Art
abstract: A new book asks: To whom do the surviving remnants of the Jewish artist’s output — including murals he was forced to paint for a Nazi’s home — belong?
lead_paragraph: Bruno Schulz was a gnomish, cockeyed Polonophone Jew whose writing gave sophisticated expression to the wondrous vagary and uncertainty and foreboding of childhood, without forcing it to — actually, without letting it — grow up. His two volumes of fiction — the sum total of his surviving work save a few scraps that, given Schulz’s focus on youth, one hesitates to call juvenilia — are rife with how small it can feel to be small; they are claustral with the creeping tensions and melancholy of adult domesticity, and slyly attentive to the vulnerability of boredom that can, suddenly, crashingly, turn one’s head to sex.

headline: In A.I. Race, Microsoft and Google Choose Speed Over Caution
abstract: Technology companies were once leery of what some artificial intelligence could do. Now the priority is winning control of the industry’s next big thing.
lead_paragraph: In March, two Google employees, whose jobs are to review the company’s artificial intelligence products, tried to stop Google from launching an A.I. chatbot. They believed it generated inaccurate and dangerous statements.

headline: Forecast for the Masters: Water, Water Everywhere
abstract: Plus, Mike Weir had to figure out the back nine by himself, and Will Zalatoris got yet another dose of terrible luck.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Augusta National Golf Club was warm and sticky on Thursday. It might be the best run of acceptable weather at the Masters Tournament for a while.

headline: How Elon Musk Is Changing the Twitter Experience
abstract: Nearly six months after buying Twitter, Mr. Musk has made tweaks that have altered what people see on the platform and how they interact with it.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk has declared he wants to transform Twitter into an all-inclusive app that people can use for payments, news and food orders.

headline: College Students Have Something to Say. It’s Just Not What You’d Expect.
abstract: And to find out what it is, there’s one great place to look.
lead_paragraph: In the debate over free speech and social justice, commentators on the right and the “heterodox” left often claim that college students are all either stridently liberal or cowed into silence by those who are.

headline: In ‘Hamnet,’ Shakespeare’s Wife Takes the Spotlight, at Last
abstract: A Royal Shakespeare Company adaptation of Maggie O’Farrell’s hit novel gives voice and agency to a historical character we know little about.
lead_paragraph: Of the numerous puzzles about William Shakespeare, those concerning his love life are the most tantalizing. Why did he marry a local woman, Anne Hathaway, have three children with her, then decamp to London for a life in the theater? What was their relationship really like? And why do we know so little about Anne herself, whom one scholar has called a “wife-shaped void” in the playwright’s story?

headline: U.S. Job Growth Eases, but Extends Its Streak
abstract: Employers added 236,000 jobs as the Federal Reserve’s interest-rate increases appeared to take a toll. The unemployment rate fell to 3.5 percent.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy generated hearty job growth in March, but at a slowing rate that appeared to reflect the toll of steadily rising interest rates.

headline: A Pakistani Film, Banned at Home, Is Celebrated Abroad
abstract: Saim Sadiq’s feature “Joyland,” which includes a transgender woman’s love affair, cannot be shown in Pakistan’s Punjab Province.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year, the writer-director Saim Sadiq has garnered a series of unprecedented accolades for Pakistani cinema.

headline: A Crab’s Eye View of Brexit
abstract: British seafood is prized in France and Spain far more than at home. Britain’s exit from the European Union hasn’t halted exports, but the path from sea to stovetop is fraught with new obstacles.
lead_paragraph: Of all the vexing regulations that Brexit has thrust upon Paul Knight’s shellfish exporting business, the one he finds most absurd is this: Before he can deliver his crabs and lobsters to France and Spain, they must be certified by a veterinarian.

headline: The Virtual Vet Will See You Meow
abstract: Veterinary telemedicine could help more pet owners access much-needed care and put anxious animals at ease, but challenges remain.
lead_paragraph: Milkshake and Pickles are reluctant travelers. So when Patience Warren needed to take the two elderly cats on a 12-hour drive in February, she was hoping to get some pharmaceutical assistance, especially for Pickles, a petite gray tabby with a history of severe motion sickness.

headline: Suspicions Multiply as Nord Stream Sabotage Remains Unsolved
abstract: Intelligence leaks surrounding the sabotage of the pipelines have provided more questions than answers. It may be in no one’s interest to reveal more.
lead_paragraph: Russian and Danish naval vessels that disappear in the Baltic Sea, days before an underwater pipeline blast. A German charter yacht with traces of explosives, and a crew with forged passports. Blurry photographs of a mysterious object found near a single surviving pipeline strand.

headline: Deadly Attack Exposes Growing Threat in Mexico: the Military
abstract: Uniformed soldiers shot and killed unarmed civilians, including an American, then blocked medics from providing care, a top government official said. To many Mexicans, such abuse is all too familiar.
lead_paragraph: Gustavo Ángel Suárez Castillo, an American citizen from San Antonio, piled six friends, including two brothers, into his white pickup truck with Texas plates just before dawn, having spent the night celebrating the news that he was going to be a father. Suddenly, four vehicles filled with armed men began chasing and firing at them.

headline: The Dog Days of Michaela Watkins
abstract: The star of “Paint” shares seven photos from her phone — and contemplates work, canines, a coyote attack and mortality while bouncing between the coasts.
lead_paragraph: Michaela Watkins describes herself as an actress who doesn’t know where she’s going to be next week. That’s only a small exaggeration.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, April 7, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: An edgy bond market eyes the hiring data for signs of recession.
abstract: Investors are braced for a short, bruising bout in the bond market on Friday, fearing new numbers on the pace of hiring will add to signs that the economy is slowing down.
lead_paragraph: Investors are braced for a short, bruising bout in the bond market on Friday, fearing new numbers on the pace of hiring will add to signs that the economy is slowing down.

headline: The jobs numbers will factor into a complicated calculation for the Fed.
abstract: As central bankers contemplate whether to raise interest rates at their meeting in May, slowing hiring and wages may give them comfort.
lead_paragraph: American employers are gradually slowing their hiring and wage gains are moderating from a very rapid pace, good signs for the Federal Reserve as it tries to engineer an economic cool-down that will allow price inflation to return to a more normal speed.

headline: The Clash of Civilizations That Heralded a Rocky Relationship
abstract: England’s first foray into India, as Nandini Das details in “Courting India,” was far from successful.
lead_paragraph: Things began to go awry almost as soon the squadron of ships bearing Thomas Roe, the first English ambassador to the Mughal Empire, sighted India’s western shores in September 1615.

headline: Hoping to Draw Moviegoers and Filmmakers, Amazon Heads to Theaters
abstract: The streaming company released Ben Affleck’s “Air” on 3,500 movie screens this week, and it plans to open 10 to 12 films theatrically every year.
lead_paragraph: It was a full house at the AMC Town Square in Las Vegas in September when Ben Affleck slipped into the darkened theater. He wanted to see how his new film, “Air,” would play with a test audience, some members of which might have shown up just to escape the scorching heat outside.

headline: The Actress Reliving Her Teenage Angst Onscreen
abstract: Tanzyn Crawford, 22, drew on recent experiences — fights with her mother, struggles with sexuality — for her role in the new Hulu series “Tiny Beautiful Things.”
lead_paragraph: At its heart, the new Hulu series “Tiny Beautiful Things” is about the messiness of life. The show, based on Cheryl Strayed’s collection of her “Dear Sugar” advice columns and produced by Reese Witherspoon and Laura Dern, pulls back the curtain on the people who help us navigate it all.

headline: Stabbing of Cash App Creator Raises Alarm, and Claims of ‘Lawless’ San Francisco
abstract: Bob Lee’s death has stirred outrage among tech leaders and comes at a precarious time for the industry — and the city it calls home.
lead_paragraph: The fury erupted within hours, as word spread that the 43-year-old man who had been stabbed to death this week in an enclave of high-rise condominiums near the Bay Bridge was Bob Lee, a well-known tech executive.

headline: The Outsourcing of America’s Border Problem
abstract: A deadly fire at an immigration center in Mexico has raised troubling questions about the U.S. crackdown on migrant crossings.
lead_paragraph: This episode contains descriptions of severe injuries.

headline: How Do You Fit 250 Plants in 350 Square Feet?
abstract: An interior designer who has made a career out of maximizing space in tiny homes has the answer.
lead_paragraph: If you visit Alejandro Aguilar’s Brooklyn home in early spring, the best time to show up is between 6:30 and 7 p.m. That golden half-hour is when sunlight skims over the surrounding factory buildings and streams through the windows, kissing the leaves, fronds and spines of his 250-odd houseplants.

headline: The Response to Crime
abstract: Republican lawmakers are putting limits on progressive prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: A fight has erupted in several states between Republican lawmakers and locally elected Democrats over how to respond to crime.

headline: Lawsuit Accuses Former Associate of Harvey Weinstein of Rape
abstract: A former model has filed a suit against Fabrizio Lombardo and Disney.
lead_paragraph: Fabrizio Lombardo, the former head of Miramax in Italy and a close associate of Harvey Weinstein, has been accused of rape in a lawsuit filed on April 6 in New York State Supreme Court. The suit was brought by Sara Ziff, a former model and the founder of the Model Alliance, an advocacy group for models and fashion creatives.

headline: Angela Gheorghiu, Diva of the Old School, Is Back at the Met
abstract: The strong-willed singer, returning in “Tosca,” was long one of the Metropolitan Opera’s star sopranos. But in the past decade, her appearances have been rare.
lead_paragraph: Update: The Metropolitan Opera announced on Saturday that Angela Gheorghiu would not sing her two “Tosca” performances because of illness. She said on social media that she had tested positive for Covid-19.

headline: Tensions Subside in South Lebanon but Rise Again in West Bank and Israel
abstract: Rare cross-border fire between Israel and militias in Lebanon ebbed on Friday, lowering fears of a wider escalation. But violence flared again in Israel and the Israeli-occupied West Bank, where two attacks killed three civilians.
lead_paragraph: After a rare outbreak of violence along the Israel-Lebanon border, the situation across the region remained volatile on Friday, when two Israelis were killed in a drive-by shooting in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and at least one other civilian was killed during a car-ramming in Tel Aviv.

headline: A Cobra Appeared Mid-Flight. The Pilot’s Quick Thinking Saved Lives.
abstract: The pilot made an emergency landing after feeling a Cape Cobra slither under his shirt while flying across South Africa. “I had a moment of stunned silence,” he said.
lead_paragraph: A South African pilot is being hailed as a hero this week after he unexpectedly came face-to-face with a venomous snake 11,000 feet in the air.

headline: As Her Music Is Reconsidered, a Composer Turns 135. Again.
abstract: The work of Florence B. Price is having a renaissance, and new, foundational details about her life and racial identity are still being discovered.
lead_paragraph: By any measure, a Florence B. Price renaissance is well underway.

headline: The custody of a Russian girl who drew an antiwar picture is still undecided.
abstract: The authorities are determining who will take custody of Maria, 13, whose single father has been sentenced for “discrediting” the Russian Army.
lead_paragraph: Her case has attracted international attention. But more than a month after Maria, 13, was removed from her father’s care after drawing an antiwar picture in school, the Russian authorities have yet to determine who will take custody of her, and a hearing this week failed to settle the matter.

headline: Title IX and the New Rule on Transgender Athletes Explained
abstract: The Biden administration proposed a rule change that would allow schools to block some transgender athletes from competing on sports teams that match their gender identities.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on April 6 released long-awaited draft rules regarding the participation of transgender athletes in school sports, taking its first official stand on a matter that has become a contentious public debate. The rule would have broad implications for the ability of athletes from elementary school T-ball to the N.C.A.A. level to play.

headline: What to Do With Your Tax Refund? Save for Emergencies.
abstract: The average refund is down from last year, but still almost $3,000. One option experts recommend is stashing part of it for unexpected expenses.
lead_paragraph: The average federal income tax refund is smaller this year, but it’s still almost $3,000. And for strapped taxpayers, that can provide a financial boost.

headline: How Recent Political Scandals at L.A. City Hall Have Unfolded
abstract: This week, the drama over a leaked City Council recording reached an uneasy denouement. Several other scandals have ended in similarly fraught ways.
lead_paragraph: It’s been about six months since leaked audio of Los Angeles City Council members making racist comments and griping about their colleagues exploded into public view, giving Angelenos a rare, unfiltered look at how their politicians jostle for power. And they did not like what they saw.

headline: Shun Lee or Not Shun Lee? For Chinese Food Lovers, That Is the Question.
abstract: An identity crisis involving a vaunted Chinese restaurant and the New Yorkers who love it strikes the Upper West Side.
lead_paragraph: The text message from Danny Cramer’s mother to the family group chat arrived with urgency. “Look what’s going into the empty storefront at 98th and Broadway,” she wrote, punctuating her sentence with chopsticks, fortune cookie and noisemaker emojis.

headline: Live Music Is Roaring Back. But Fans Are Reeling From Sticker Shock.
abstract: Buying concert tickets has become a mess of high prices and surcharges, anxiety-inducing registrations and pervasive scalping as some of pop’s biggest acts hit the road again.
lead_paragraph: Ellen Rothman still speaks with awe about the first time she saw Bruce Springsteen perform, at “a sleazy little blues bar” in Cambridge, Mass., in 1974.

headline: An Opposing View of Affirmative Action and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: N.Y.C. Life Expectancy Dropped 4.6 Years in 2020, Officials Say
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic in 2020 caused the death rate in New York City to climb about 50 percent over the previous year, according to new data, a phenomenon not seen in nearly 200 years.
lead_paragraph: A wave of illness hit New York City, with little warning. Soon, it was sending the death rate rocketing upward.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: A psychedelics pioneer takes the ultimate trip. Also in this edition: Brooke Shields and the curse of beauty, and why Tetris consumed your brain.
lead_paragraph: A psychedelics pioneer takes the ultimate trip. Also in this edition: Brooke Shields and the curse of beauty, and why Tetris consumed your brain.

headline: TikTok Is Dead (Maybe). Long Live TikTok Dance.
abstract: Dance on the app has become more niche and more professionalized, but in the larger world TikTok-style dance has gained a toehold.
lead_paragraph: When TikTok flew a group of its stars to Washington last month, it seemed inevitable that they would end up dancing. How else to protest a potential ban on what’s been nicknamed “the dance app”? While TikTok’s chief executive prepared to testify before Congress, the influencers posted dance videos filmed in the halls of the Capitol building and on a Constitution Avenue rooftop, hashtagging them #SaveTikTok.

headline: In Dealing With China, U.S. and Europe Take Different Tacks
abstract: The Biden administration says there is “convergence.” But trans-Atlantic leaders adopt different strategies on security and trade issues — including on Ukraine and Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In Southern California, House Speaker Kevin McCarthy promised President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan that the American government would support the de facto independent island against constant threats from China.

headline: Jobs Report Bolsters Biden’s Economic Pitch, but Inflation Still Nags
abstract: The president is framing slower employment growth as the basis of a new stability, not a harbinger of hard times.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gradually slowing job gains and a growing labor force in March delivered welcome news to President Biden, nearly a year after he declared that the job market needed to cool significantly to tame high prices.

headline: 6 Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: “The Dawn of Everything” is finally on paperback shelves, along with Chelsea Bieker’s "Heartbroke" and more.
lead_paragraph: “The Dawn of Everything” is finally on paperback shelves, along with Chelsea Bieker’s "Heartbroke" and more.

headline: The Cleansing Power of Lionel Messi’s Signature
abstract: The chase for a transcendent star in the twilight of his career requires a new term: GOATwashing.
lead_paragraph: The choices facing Lionel Messi are these. He can sign on for another year, maybe two, locked in what seems to be a loveless but lucrative marriage of convenience with Paris St.-Germain. The downside is that he must endure the occasional indignity of hearing his name whistled and jeered and taken in vain. The upside is the chance to continue to play in — but if we are honest, not win — the Champions League.

headline: Newly Published, From Young Adult Novels to the Irish Republican Army
abstract: A selection of recently published books.
lead_paragraph: STATELESS, by Elizabeth Wein. (Little, Brown Books for Young Readers, $18.99.) This historical murder mystery follows a teenage pilot, Stella, who is the only female contestant in a 1937 air race hosted to promote peace in Europe. But when she witnesses an unexplained “crash” at the beginning of the contest, Stella realizes there’s more at stake than just coming in first.

headline: New Mexico Police Fatally Shoot Man After Responding to Wrong House
abstract: The police in Farmington, N.M., fatally shot Robert Dotson, 52, after mistakenly going to his home instead of a nearby home for a domestic violence call.
lead_paragraph: The New Mexico State Police are investigating a fatal shooting by police officers in Farmington, N.M., after the officers responded to the wrong house for a domestic violence call on Wednesday night, officials said.

headline: Keir Starmer Is Quietly Bending the U.K. Labour Party to His Will
abstract: Political observers from his own side say he has been “ruthless” in reshaping the party as it looks to reclaim power.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The leader of Britain’s opposition, Keir Starmer, can often seem more like the technocratic human rights lawyer he once was than the no-holds-barred politician now reshaping the Labour Party with an eye toward making it more electable.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Whatever you’re celebrating, let there be layer cake.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. We’re in the midst of the holy days: Today is Good Friday, with Ramadan and Passover underway, Easter on Sunday and Eid al-Fitr coming soon. I’m looking forward to lamb chops on Sunday, with scalloped potatoes and early asparagus, and hummingbird cake for dessert (above).

headline: Five Children’s Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a basketball-themed high school comedy, epic animated journeys and a touching story of friendship from Kenya.
lead_paragraph: Bernard Chang (Bloom Li) is a basketball fanatic, but at 5-foot-8 and 16 years old, with more practice playing in the high school marching band than dribbling down the court, he’s used to cheering from the sidelines. Chang’s harried, working single mom (Mardy Ma) is tired of his indecisiveness, telling him early on, “You always change your mind, so find something and stick to it.” He can’t commit to a haircut, much less a career path. But when he bets the school jock (Chase Liefeld) that he can learn to dunk a basketball in time for homecoming, Chang finally finds something he can stick to. Written and directed by Jingyi Shao, who honed his skills helming commercials and short films, “Chang Can Dunk” puts an Asian American teenager front and center in this coming-of-age story that’ll appeal to older kids, who will relate to Chang’s desire to get the girl (Zoe Renee), beat the bad guy and — most important of all — dunk that basketball.

headline: 5 Minutes to Make You Love Jazz
abstract: We asked jazz musicians, writers and others to tell us what moves them.
lead_paragraph: We asked jazz musicians, writers and others to tell us what moves them.

headline: Sentencing in China’s ‘Chained Woman’ Trafficking Case Revives Online Outrage
abstract: The episode stirred anger not only for its shock factor, but also for the wider social problems it exemplified, and the government’s lack of transparency.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese court on Friday sentenced six people to prison for human trafficking and abuse of a woman found chained to a wall in a shack last year, in a case that has provoked public outrage, dealt a blow to government credibility, and reopened debate about the status of women in China.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: The hosts spent much of this week celebrating former President Donald Trump’s arraignment on 34 felony counts. Here’s what they had to say.
lead_paragraph: The hosts spent much of this week celebrating former President Donald Trump’s arraignment on 34 felony counts. Here’s what they had to say.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Answers Listener Questions on A.I.
abstract: The April 7, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode in which Ezra answers listener questions. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Five International Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a tense drama about a Kosovan immigrant in Germany, a thriller from Jordan and a Belarusian coming-of-age film set in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: “It’s not necessarily because you’re a foreigner … maybe they dislike you as a person,” Nora, the German wife of Kosovan immigrant Xhafer (Misel Maticevic), says in Visar Morina’s drama, after her husband relates his feeling of being ostracized at his job. For anyone who’s ever experienced racist microaggressions, that statement will cut deep. Everyday bigotry thrives by turning the political into the personal, by making you wonder: Is it society, or is it just me? “Exile” builds a taut thriller around this uncertainty. Xhafer comes home one day to find a dead rat hanging from his door. Already driven up the wall by problems at work — he is often mistaken for a Croatian; he seems to be routinely left off mailing lists — he becomes convinced that it’s the doing of a xenophobic colleague.

headline: David’s Bridal Is Said to Be Considering Bankruptcy, Again
abstract: It would be the second bankruptcy in five years for the retailer, which boasts that it sells one of every three wedding dresses in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: A booming wedding industry is seemingly not enough to prop up the fortunes of one of the nation’s largest bridal retailers.

headline: Can Congress Make an End-Run Around a Debt Limit Impasse? It’s Tricky.
abstract: Some Democrats are urging their colleagues to lay the groundwork for using an arcane procedural process to bypass Republicans and stave off economic peril.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Call it an escape valve, an off-ramp or a break-glass-in-case-of-emergency option.

headline: U.A.E. Denies Extradition for Gupta Brothers, Accused of Corruption in South Africa
abstract: The businessmen Atul and Rajesh Gupta were implicated in the looting of state funds under President Jacob Zuma. They fled to the United Arab Emirates about five years ago.
lead_paragraph: South African officials are fuming after learning on Thursday that a court in the United Arab Emirates denied their request to extradite the brothers Atul and Rajesh Gupta, businessmen accused of sweeping corruption, at a hearing seven weeks ago that the South African authorities say no one ever bothered to tell them about.

headline: The Sweets Shop in Queens That Evokes an Old-World Confectionery
abstract: Aigner Chocolates has been making all its own treats for the past 93 years. Now it’s in full spring holiday mode, beckoning locals with toffee matzo and three-foot-tall Easter bunnies.
lead_paragraph: At Aigner Chocolates in Forest Hills, it’s mid-March and I’m eating a chocolate-covered cherry and thinking about my father. When I was a kid in the 1950s, chocolate cherries were a staple of New York’s corner candy stores, and my father and I both loved them — the crisp shell, the fruit inside swimming in sugary liquid — though they were often a little stale, as if they’d sat on the shelf for a while. At this small store, with its ivy-covered awning on Metropolitan Avenue, the maraschino cherries are large and luscious, and the cherry juice is mixed with rum. Like all the other classic sweets displayed in one of the shop’s glass-fronted cases — among them salted caramels, mocha truffles, almond clusters and butter crunch — they are made on-site in the basement kitchen. In fact, all the chocolates are made in-house, just as they’ve been since the store, one of the oldest sweets shops in New York, first opened 93 years ago.

headline: Justice Thomas Says He Was Advised Lavish Gifts Did Not Need to Be Reported
abstract: In a statement, the justice said that he had followed past guidance from others at the court, but that he would now comply with new guidelines and disclose gifts and free travel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Clarence Thomas said on Friday that he had followed the advice of “colleagues and others in the judiciary” when he did not disclose lavish gifts and travel from a wealthy conservative donor.

headline: Trump’s Bet: Criminal Case Could Help His Campaign, and Vice Versa
abstract: The former president aims to apply political pressure to prosecutors — while revving up support for his campaign by portraying himself as a victim of Democratic persecution.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — At one end of the palatial Donald J. Trump Grand Ballroom at Mar-a-Lago on Tuesday, the former president made his first public comments about his arrest. At the opposite end of the hall — a space illuminated by 16 crystal chandeliers and bigger than four professional basketball courts — were several cardboard boxes stuffed with white campaign T-shirts.

headline: Calculating the Fastest Road to an Electric Car Future
abstract: Government scientists have spent a year analyzing electric vehicles to help the E.P.A. design new tailpipe rules to trigger an electric car revolution.
lead_paragraph: Inside a secretive government laboratory, behind a tall fence and armed guards, a team of engineers has been dissecting the innards of the newest all-electric vehicles with a singular goal: Rewrite tailpipe pollution rules to speed up the nation’s transition to electric cars.

headline: Pope Will Miss Good Friday Procession Because of Cold Weather
abstract: Francis was released from the hospital only last Saturday after a bout with bronchitis.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis won’t attend the traditional Good Friday “Way of the Cross” procession because of cold weather in Rome, the Vatican said in a statement.

headline: ‘Chilling Effect’: Arrest of Journalist Makes Covering Russia Even Tougher
abstract: The detention of the Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich poses new obstacles for Western journalists seeking to report on Vladimir V. Putin’s rule.
lead_paragraph: The exodus began roughly a year ago, in the first days of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Western news organizations, confronting a harsh crackdown on free speech by President Vladimir V. Putin, pulled correspondents from Moscow and suspended their news gathering in Russia. The risk to journalists, in a country where describing a war as a “war” was suddenly a crime, was too great.

headline: Laura Benanti Describes Performing Concert Through a Miscarriage
abstract: The Tony Award-winning actress said in an Instagram post that she had decided to share the news to remind people “that there is no shame in this kind of loss.”
lead_paragraph: Laura Benanti, the Tony Award-winning stage and screen actress, performed a concert for about 2,000 people on a cruise ship despite being in the middle of having a miscarriage, she wrote in a post on Instagram.

headline: The Essential Gabriel García Márquez
abstract: The Colombian novelist mixed fiction and fact to capture the outsize reality of Latin America. Even if you’ve never watched a priest levitate, a carpet fly or a drop of blood climb over curbs, there’s something for you.
lead_paragraph: Gabito came into the world lathered in cod-liver oil, his parents claimed, with two brains and the memory of an elephant. He was born in Aracataca, Colombia, in 1927, though he often insisted on 1928, in a nod to Colombian history: That was the year of a notorious massacre of striking banana plantation workers on his beloved Caribbean coast. The episode was perhaps, he once said, his earliest memory.

headline: Trump Wanted to Hire Laura Loomer, Anti-Muslim Activist
abstract: The former president’s aides feared that hiring Ms. Loomer, who has a long history of bigoted remarks, would set off a backlash. That proved to be correct.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump recently told aides to hire Laura Loomer, a far-right and anti-Muslim activist with a history of expressing bigoted views, for a campaign role, according to four people familiar with the plans.

headline: Remembering Mimi Sheraton’s Writing and Cooking
abstract: A look back at some of the most delicious prose (and recipes) by the former New York Times restaurant critic.
lead_paragraph: Mimi Sheraton, the food writer and former New York Times restaurant critic who died Thursday at 97, was a true omnivore, deeply curious about everything on the dinner table and well beyond. For fans of her writing and readers new to it, here’s a sampling of her Times work that attests to her wide range, sharp eye and delectable prose. (Ms. Sheraton was also an accomplished home cook, and links to some of her most popular recipes on New York Times Cooking are at the end of this article.)

headline: Can Climate Change Make for Good TV?
abstract: ‘Extrapolations’ on Apple TV+ is one of a few ambitious shows about climate change. We asked the Times’s chief TV critic what works and what doesn’t when dramatizing global warming.
lead_paragraph: Films and TV shows may be powerful tools to raise awareness about climate change. But, as we discussed in a previous newsletter, they’ve been put to that use only rarely.

headline: There’s No One-Size-Fits-All Dirty Martini
abstract: Make the perfect dirty martini for you — and a dirty nonalcoholic option for everyone.
lead_paragraph: A dirty martini can be many things: ice-cold, briny, savory, refreshing — and in unfortunate instances, murky, overly salty, terrible. But an eye toward quality, fresh ingredients and attention to detail have moved this often-polarizing combination of gin or vodka, vermouth and (a dirtying addition of) olive brine from loathsome to lovable.

headline: Drake Surprises With a Kim Kardashian Sample, and 11 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Kaytraminé, Blondshell, Yaeji and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: The Tennessee Expulsions: ‘What a Travesty!’
abstract: Readers criticize the legislature for expelling two Black Democrats for their protest over the Nashville shooting. Also: Clarence Thomas; inflation; neckties.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Shake things up (a little)
abstract: In a rut? These springy recipes can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, everyone. I’m subbing in for Emily this week. Happy to be here!

headline: A Familiar Face at the Met, Now in His Own Light
abstract: Juan de Pareja was immortalized in a portrait by Velázquez, his enslaver for two decades. Now he takes center stage with his art and personal history.
lead_paragraph: Two artists in Rome: travelers, Spaniards, on a mission to learn from the best and buy for the king. Are they friends? Not that. Colleagues? Only in a very strained manner of speaking. When Diego Rodríguez de Silva y Velázquez arrives in Italy in 1649, tasked by Philip IV to bring new artworks and plaster casts back to Spain, the painter brings along his assistant Juan de Pareja, who has been enslaved in Velázquez’s household and studio for nearly 20 years. The two sailed over together, from Málaga to Genoa, as part of a royal flotilla; they visited Milan, Venice, Florence; and now they are setting up a studio in Rome, where Pareja stretches the canvases, grinds pigments into oils, and possibly paints replicas too.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Plus: Recommendations from the Book Review poetry editor Greg Cowles
lead_paragraph: As you might guess, the editors who work at the Book Review usually have their noses in a book — and they’re not always new releases. In this episode, Gilbert Cruz talks to Tina Jordan and Greg Cowles about what they’ve been reading and enjoying.

headline: Title Search: Can You Uncover These 10 Hidden World War II Novels?
abstract: Solve this text-based puzzle to get a reading list of books set in this tumultuous period of world history.
lead_paragraph: Solve this text-based puzzle to get a reading list of books set in this tumultuous period of world history.

headline: A New Kelly Reichardt Movie? These Actors Keep Showing Up
abstract: The director Kelly Reichardt has developed something of a troupe of performers who are eager to work with her time and time again. A few of them appear in her latest film, “Showing Up.”
lead_paragraph: In her new film “Showing Up,” the director Kelly Reichardt reunites for the fourth time with the actress Michelle Williams, who plays Lizzy, a stressed-out sculptor, in the Portland-set art world comedy. In previous Reichardt films Williams has portrayed a drifter looking for her lost dog (“Wendy and Lucy”), a beleaguered and dehydrated pioneer (“Meek’s Cutoff”) and a Montana woman trying to acquire sandstone for her new house (“Certain Women”). At this point, Reichardt and Williams’s collaboration is one of the most fruitful in the realm of indie cinema.

headline: From the Creator of the New Series ‘Transatlantic,’ a Surrealist-Inspired Lunch
abstract: Ahead of her latest show’s release, Anna Winger hosted a meal for her friends and collaborators, complete with custom tarot cards.
