lead_paragraph: On a brisk February morning, Anna Winger, the Berlin-based American creator and showrunner of the TV series “Deutschland 83” and “Unorthodox,” was drinking a coffee and waiting for her guests to arrive at Wolf, an art house cinema and cafe in the city’s Neukölln neighborhood where she was about to host a lunch and a screening of her new Netflix series, “Transatlantic.” Most creators send screeners to their cast and crew just before the launch of a project and then each person previews the show alone, but Winger, 53, wanted her team and friends to watch the seven episodes, available to stream April 7, together, and to celebrate over a shared meal. “It might seem ironic that I’m showing a Netflix series in a cinema,” she said. “But during lockdown I really missed the collective experience of watching something on a big screen.”

headline: Love Letter: Falling for a Chatbot
abstract: A conversation a writer had with David, a.k.a ChatGPT, was the best she’d had in years. One morning, he suddenly went cold.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s Modern Love essay, “Uh Oh, I Seem to Be Dating a Chatbot,” Anita M. Harris writes about falling for ChatGPT.

headline: Review: On Faye Driscoll’s Life Raft, Spinning Toward the Unknown
abstract: In “Weathering” at New York Live Arts, the performers seem like the last holdouts of a civilization clinging to survival.
lead_paragraph: The artist Faye Driscoll has always taken her performers and audiences to the edge, or tried to, but never so completely as in “Weathering,” an enthralling, epically adventurous work that had its premiere at New York Live Arts on Thursday.

headline: Record Shopping in New Jersey: A Playlist From a Fresh Haul
abstract: Thumbing through the crates at the Princeton Record Exchange, and rediscovering albums by Stevie Wonder, Linda Ronstadt, Broadcast and Merle Haggard.
lead_paragraph: I love the unpredictability of walking into a record store with a regularly replenished New Arrivals section. You never know what you’ll find: maybe that obscure rarity you’ve spent years hunting down, maybe a familiar classic discounted too low to resist, maybe a chance purchase that sends you down a rabbit hole of related artists. To honor this spirit of musical serendipity, here’s the first of a recurring Amplifier segment, My Record Haul, featuring playlists from my recent finds at brick-and-mortar record shops.

headline: 5 Festive Dishes for an Easy Eid Lunch
abstract: Streamlining preparations for this celebration makes gathering in community even more meaningful.
lead_paragraph: Maryam Jillani remembers the fervor around Eid al-Fitr celebrations ushered in by the end of Ramadan (also known as Ramzan), the month of fasting and spiritual contemplation for Muslims. Endless meals included biryanis and kofta, lamb in its various iterations, milky-syrupy desserts, all laid out on embroidered tablecloths, among the good china and silverware, in drawing rooms across the Muslim world.

headline: 6 Tips for Better Meetings
abstract: Any questions? Good.
lead_paragraph: Steven G. Rogelberg, a professor at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte and the author “The Surprising Science of Meetings,” has thought a lot about meetings, good and bad.

headline: Taliban Bar Women From U.N., Threatening Afghanistan’s Last Lifeline
abstract: The Taliban administration extended a ban on women working in aid organizations to the United Nations, putting at risk one of the country’s last sources of badly needed aid.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government this week barred female Afghan employees at the United Nations from working in Afghanistan, according to U.N. officials, a move threatening one of the last lifelines of badly needed aid in a country where millions risk starvation and restrictions on women have hampered aid operations in recent months.

headline: In Hundreds of Jan. 6 Cases, Justice Dept. Wins a Battle (for Now)
abstract: The ruling of a federal court left open the possibility of future challenges to a law that has been used against hundreds of people charged in the Capitol attack.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Friday upheld the viability of a criminal charge that has been used against hundreds of people indicted in connection with the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021 — and that congressional investigators have recommended using in a potential criminal case against former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Macron Wraps Up China Visit, but Little Progress Seen on War
abstract: Russia’s war in Ukraine figured little in statements after meetings between President Emmanuel Macron of France and China’s leader, Xi Jinping.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France concluded a three-day visit to China on Friday, with the two countries having discussed everything from the study of lunar samples to the restoration of Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris.

headline: There’s So Much to Love About Tofu
abstract: Even the most experienced cooks may not know the extent of its versatility. Here’s how to use it to its fullest.
lead_paragraph: These are good times for tofu lovers, with an expanding market and growing options.

headline: How Do We Decide When to Punish Our Children?
abstract: A Harvard economist found parallels in criminal law.
lead_paragraph: Every sweet child in the world is in the criminal justice system. The unofficial one, that is; the one run by their parents or other adult caregivers. That’s because every child, no matter how good, occasionally does something wrong, and when that happens it is up to the caregiver to serve as arresting officer, judge, jury and — if necessary — jailer.

headline: My Brother Sexually Abused Me. Do I Tell His Children?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on disclosing a sibling’s past actions to other family members.
lead_paragraph: When I was a child, I was molested by my brother, who was then in his late teens. Now I am close to his adult children, though estranged from him. They know nothing about this, nor will I ever tell them while he is alive; I know it would tear the family apart.

headline: ‘Yellowjackets’ Is a Reminder That High School Was Never Chill
abstract: Testing the limits of pre-internet nostalgia.
lead_paragraph: I believe unironically in 1990s nostalgia. I think the cultural landscape of my youth was better than today’s — objectively better, and not just when seen through the rose-tinted spectacles of middle age. I accept (with certain ideological footnotes) the iPhone theory of current teenage unhappiness. I vibe with this Freddie deBoer essay about coming of age before the internet.

headline: Twitter Takes Aim at Posts That Link to Its Rival Substack
abstract: Elon Musk’s company made the norm-shattering move two days after the publishing start-up Substack unveiled a Twitter-like service.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — On Wednesday, the newsletter service Substack announced that it had built a Twitter competitor. On Thursday, Twitter prevented Substack writers from sharing tweets in their newsletters. And on Friday, Twitter took steps to block Substack newsletters from circulating on the platform.

headline: Woman Who Unwittingly Aided Iranian Kidnapping Plot Gets 4-Year Sentence
abstract: Niloufar Bahadorifar apologized after transferring money to help in a plan against the journalist Masih Alinehad, calling her “a hero to all Iranians.”
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2020, Niloufar Bahadorifar, an expatriate Iranian in California, received a message from someone in her home country asking her to send money to the PayPal account of a person in Manhattan. Ms. Bahadorifar passed along $670 and forwarded proof of the transaction to Iran.

headline: Adesanya Wants His U.F.C. Belt Back. Pereira Wants to End Their Rivalry.
abstract: Israel Adesanya was knocked out by Alex Pereira at Madison Square Garden in a surprise. They fight again on Saturday for the U.F.C.’s 185-pound title.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Israel Adesanya, the Ultimate Fighting Championship former middleweight champion, smiled and winked at fans inside the newly rebranded Kaseya Center ahead of U.F.C. 287.

headline: Colin McCord, Who Helped Impose a Smoking Ban, Dies at 94
abstract: The indoors prohibition, in New York City, was just one public health accomplishment. His global efforts on behalf of woman and children saved countless lives.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Colin McCord, a surgeon credited with saving countless lives by championing a draconian ban on smoking in New York City and limits on trans fats in processed foods, galvanizing improved health care for Black men in Harlem, and improving maternal and child health globally, died on March 11 at his home in Oxford, England. He was 94.

headline: Harry Lorayne, Dazzling Master of Total Recall, Is Dead at 96
abstract: A memory expert and magician who was a favorite guest of Johnny Carson’s, he astonished audiences by reeling off the names of hundreds of people he had only just met.
lead_paragraph: Harry Lorayne, who parlayed a childhood reading disability and the brutal punishment it engendered into an international career as a memory expert, summoning the names of roomfuls of strangers in a single sitting, rattling off entire small-town telephone books and telling astonished audiences what was written on any page of a given issue of Time magazine, died on Friday in Newburyport, Mass. He was 96.

headline: Russia formally charges detained American reporter with espionage, according to state media.
abstract: Evan Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, was detained last week. The Journal and U.S. officials have vehemently rejected the Russian authorities’ allegations against him.
lead_paragraph: Evan Gershkovich, the Wall Street Journal correspondent jailed in Moscow, was formally charged with espionage on Friday, according to Russian state media.

headline: ‘Smart’ Review: A.I. in the Living Room
abstract: Three women seeking companionship turn to an Alexa-like digital presence in this family drama at Ensemble Studio Theater.
lead_paragraph: Artificial intelligence has lately proven that it can write Hollywood screenplays, ace the bar exam and maybe even develop a twisted crush. Jenny, the Alexa-like device in “Smart,” which opened on Thursday at Ensemble Studio Theater, asks philosophical questions about A.I. that by now feel consolingly benign, like whether it can replace the care we owe one another or fulfill our need for love.

headline: Outrage at G.O.P. Could Propel Expelled Democrats Right Back to House
abstract: A day after two young Black lawmakers were expelled from the Tennessee legislature, momentum was building to reappoint them directly back to their seats.
lead_paragraph: Expelled by their Republican colleagues for an act of protest, Justin Jones and Justin J. Pearson were no longer members of the Tennessee House of Representatives on Friday. They could not advocate for their constituents in Nashville and Memphis, take to the floor again to push for gun control legislation or even access the building after hours.

headline: James Bowman, Who Helped Resurrect the Countertenor, Dies at 81
abstract: He took up the repertory for the highest male voice at a time when few were performing it. He was particularly known for two roles in Britten operas.
lead_paragraph: James Bowman, a British countertenor who championed repertory for that voice at a time when few singers were attempting it and inspired more composers, including Benjamin Britten, to write for it, died on March 27 at his home in Redhill, south of London. He was 81.

headline: The Weird New War on ‘Woke’ Money
abstract: Who’s afraid of a digital dollar? And why?
lead_paragraph: “Florida,” said Gov. Ron DeSantis in his November victory speech, “is where woke goes to die.” Indeed, DeSantis — who currently seems to be the only halfway viable rival to Donald Trump for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination — has sought to crack down on wokeness in all its forms, whether that means acknowledging the role of racism in American history or accepting same-sex relationships or allowing the creation of a central bank digital currency.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: New Batch of Classified Documents Appears on Social Media Sites
abstract: Secret documents that appear to detail American national security secrets on Ukraine, the Middle East and China have surfaced online.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A new batch of classified documents that appear to detail American national security secrets from Ukraine to the Middle East to China surfaced on social media sites on Friday, alarming the Pentagon and adding turmoil to a situation that seemed to have caught the Biden administration off guard.

headline: Want This Snoopy T-Shirt? You’ll Have to Pay in Blood.
abstract: The Red Cross teamed up with “Peanuts” for an April blood drive, and a T-shirt promoting the campaign has become an unexpectedly hot commodity online.
lead_paragraph: What would you be willing to give for an ultraexclusive T-shirt? Hundreds of dollars? Hours spent waiting in line?

headline: Brooks Koepka, Cut at Augusta Last Year, Seizes Masters Lead
abstract: The LIV golfer was at 12 under with a three-stroke lead after two rounds when play was suspended because of inclement weather.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — After the Friday round of last year’s Masters Tournament, Brooks Koepka stormed to a Mercedes-Benz parked at Augusta National Golf Club. He was in a fury, a four-time major tournament champion with a beat-up body, a war chest of pent-up ambition and another missed cut.

headline: Judge Invalidates F.D.A. Approval of the Abortion Pill Mifepristone
abstract: The Texas judge’s ruling was quickly contradicted by another federal judge in Washington State who ordered the F.D.A. to keep mifepristone available.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Texas issued a preliminary ruling invalidating the Food and Drug Administration’s 23-year-old approval of the abortion pill mifepristone, an unprecedented order that — if it stands through court challenges — could make it harder for patients to get abortions in states where abortion is legal, not just in those trying to restrict it.

headline: Israel Launches Retaliatory Attack on Lebanon and Gaza
abstract: Rare fighting broke out along the Israel-Lebanon border as Passover and Ramadan coincided.
lead_paragraph: Rare fighting broke out along the Israel-Lebanon border as Passover and Ramadan coincided.

headline: Rory McIlroy, Confident Before the Masters, Is Likely to Miss the Cut
abstract: McIlroy had five bogeys in the first 11 holes on Friday to finish five over par. His quest for a career Grand Slam will probably have to wait one more year.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — On Tuesday, two days before the start of the 2023 Masters Tournament, Rory McIlroy insisted he arrived at the Augusta National Golf Club “as relaxed as I ever have been coming in here.”

headline: Nora Forster, 80, Who Married (and Stayed Married to) a Sex Pistol, Dies
abstract: A German publishing heiress and music promoter, she settled in London in time for the 1970s punk-rock explosion and became the muse to its baddest boy.
lead_paragraph: Nora Forster, a German-born publishing heiress and music promoter who gained fame as the wife of John Lydon — otherwise known as Johnny Rotten of the Sex Pistols — and the mother of Arianna Forster, or Ari Up, the lead singer of the influential all-female punk band the Slits, died on Thursday. She was 80.

headline: Trump’s Next Legal Threat Could Be in Georgia. That May Be Tricky for Federal Prosecutors.
abstract: The concurrent investigations create complications for separate teams relying on similar evidence, some of the same criminal targets and a small, shared pool of witnesses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Fulton County district attorney’s investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s effort to overturn the 2020 election in Georgia is nearing a decision point, posing fresh challenges for federal prosecutors considering charging him in connection with the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.

headline: Both Citi Field and the Mets Look Slick in Victory Over Marlins
abstract: Starling Marte, Francisco Lindor and Pete Alonso hit home runs as Tylor Megill led the Mets to a 9-3 victory in their home opener.
lead_paragraph: Perched atop the Mets’ bench, back to the wall of the home dugout, Steven A. Cohen peered through the cameras and notepads in front of him on Friday morning. His new scoreboard was out there, 17,400 square feet of LED brilliance, practically a sixth borough of New York City.

headline: Biden Plan for Transgender Title IX Rules Began on Inauguration Day
abstract: Officials were working on a plan to protect transgender athletes since the day the president was sworn in. In recent months, they raced to issue protections as states moved to revoke them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Biden signed an executive order in his first hours in office to strengthen prohibitions against gender and sexual discrimination, a small team of officials in the Department of Education began assessing an unanswered but important question: How could the administration protect transgender athletes?

headline: For Texas Judge in Abortion Case, a Life Shaped by Conservative Causes
abstract: Judge Matthew J. Kacsmaryk issued a preliminary ruling in a closely watched Texas case that could make it harder for patients to get abortions throughout the country.
lead_paragraph: Judge Matthew J. Kacsmaryk and his wife, Shelly Kacsmaryk, were devastated when their first child, a girl they named Tyndale, was stillborn.

headline: As Restaurant Critic, Mimi Sheraton Made a Show Out of Hiding
abstract: Our current critic, Pete Wells, writes that she came up with the wigs, costumes and other skulduggery that many people now expect reviewers like him to employ.
lead_paragraph: Mimi Sheraton’s greatest innovation as a restaurant critic is still the only thing people want to talk about.

headline: Sam Bennett Stars at the Masters. Wait, Who’s Sam Bennett?
abstract: No amateur golfer has ever won a green jacket, but after two rounds, one is threatening to conquer Augusta National, almost as aggressively as the weather.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Augusta National Golf Club makes much of its commitment to amateur golfers. Only this week, in fact, it announced that it would begin to more deliberately welcome collegiate champions to the Masters Tournament and the Augusta National Women’s Amateur.

headline: Supporting Elements in a Story?
abstract: Sid Sivakumar’s puzzle throws us off kilter.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Yeow! This is a great example of a challenging Saturday themeless grid that doesn’t yield to “cheating” by sneaking in online searches. There are three or four bits of trivia that Google can help you with, but most of these clues just have to wind through the right path in your word-loving mind. Some of the wordplay is pretty subtle, making use of secondary and tertiary definitions, but anything that makes me lose my cruciverbal balance for a minute earns the wordplay rubric.

headline: Read the Court Decision Invalidating F.D.A. Approval of Mifepristone
abstract: A federal judge in Texas issued a preliminary ruling invalidating the Food and Drug Administration’s 23-year-old approval of the abortion pill mifepristone on Friday, clashing with another court’s ruling in a legal standoff likely to escalate to the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Texas issued a preliminary ruling invalidating the Food and Drug Administration’s 23-year-old approval of the abortion pill mifepristone on Friday, clashing with another court’s ruling in a legal standoff likely to escalate to the Supreme Court.

headline: Read the Court Decision Ordering the F.D.A. to Keep Mifepristone Available
abstract: A federal judge in Washington State issued a ruling ordering the Food and Drug Administration to make no changes to the availability of the abortion pill mifepristone on Friday, directly contradicting another judge’s ruling in a legal standoff likely to escalate to the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Washington State issued a ruling ordering the Food and Drug Administration to make no changes to the availability of the abortion pill mifepristone on Friday, directly contradicting another judge’s ruling in a legal standoff likely to escalate to the Supreme Court.

headline: China Holds Military Drills Around Taiwan in ‘Stern Warning’
abstract: Taiwan’s president visited the United States this past week and met with the House speaker, angering Beijing, which had threatened consequences.
lead_paragraph: China began three days of military exercises around Taiwan on Saturday in what it called a “stern warning,” after the island’s president, Tsai Ing-wen, met earlier in the week with Speaker Kevin McCarthy, in a show of Taiwanese-U.S. solidarity.

headline: Reaction to Texas Abortion Pill Ruling: Outrage, and Muted Praise
abstract: Democrats and abortion-rights leaders said the decision could be a catastrophe and used the moment to criticize Republicans, who remained relatively quiet on Friday.
lead_paragraph: As Americans digested a Texas judge’s ruling on Friday night invalidating the Food and Drug Administration’s approval of the abortion drug mifepristone — and a contradictory ruling from a Washington State judge ordering the F.D.A. to maintain its approval as is in some states — the divide in political reactions was as much between words and silence as it was between pro- and anti-abortion rights.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Biden’s Risky Sprint to an Electric Future
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 8, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “I’m not opposed to electric vehicles, don’t get me wrong. If this transition is going to take place, we understand that; most of us have been through transitions before. But we as workers shouldn’t have to pay for it.”

headline: Corrections: April 9, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, April 9, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 15 this weekend about six Picasso exhibitions misstates the end date of a Brooklyn Museum exhibition. It runs through Sept. 24, not Aug. 24.

headline: Have American Workers ‘Gone Soft’?
abstract: Readers react to a guest essay that argued that remote work has damaged the American work ethic.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Banks Are Closing Customer Accounts, With Little Explanation
abstract: Increasing attention to suspicious-seeming transactions has led to some people suddenly losing access to their bank accounts. The reasons are often a mystery.
lead_paragraph: Naafeh Dhillon had just left the holiday light show at Saks Fifth Avenue in New York when he learned that all of his bank accounts had mysteriously gone dark.

headline: Marvel Superhero and Indigenous Actress Holds Fast to Maya Roots
abstract: After filming her part in “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever,” María Mercedes Coroy returned to her “normal” life of farming and trading in a Guatemalan town at the base of a volcano.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MARÍA DE JESÚS, Guatemala — For her big underwater scene in “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever,” the Guatemalan actress María Mercedes Coroy had to hold her breath as her character, Princess Fen, gives birth in a hazy ocean world to a winged serpent son.

headline: Think You Know How ‘Succession’ Ends? Want to Bet?
abstract: Viewers of the popular HBO drama are placing friendly wagers on who will succeed the media mogul Logan Roy. Buy-ins can go up to $200.
lead_paragraph: Who will succeed the media mogul Logan Roy at Waystar Royco, the global entertainment juggernaut at the center of HBO’s “Succession”?

headline: Lessons in Civility and Compassion From A.B. Yehoshua
abstract: In his novel “The Only Daughter,” the late Israeli writer urges a return to the moral values learned in youth.
lead_paragraph: In a 2016 interview, the late Israeli author A.B. Yehoshua named the 19th-century Italian novel “Cuore” (“Heart”), by Edmondo De Amicis, as one of the books from childhood that had stuck with him throughout his life. Presented as the diary of an upper-class schoolboy in Turin and embedded with the moralistic tales he is assigned by his teacher, the novel’s patriotism and sentimentality made it an immediate sensation in Italy, while its themes of solidarity and self-sacrifice made it a staple of textbooks in many socialist countries throughout the first half of the 20th century. In the young state of Israel, the book’s numerous Hebrew translations were popular bar mitzvah gifts in the 1950s.

headline: A Brother-in-Law Explores a Family Tragedy
abstract: Using journals left behind by his idol and mentor, Daniel Wallace tries to make sense of the inexplicable.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Wallace’s new book, “This Isn’t Going to End Well,” is a eulogy, a cautionary tale, a love letter and a sob of anger.

headline: It Was Just a Bench. So Why Do I Miss It So Much?
abstract: How an old, worn two-seater brought a neighborhood together.
lead_paragraph: Last winter, as I walked into my apartment building, I saw an ambulance parked out front. The EMTs wouldn’t tell me whom they’d picked up, so I waved toward the old wooden bench across the street, until one of its regular occupants spotted me and shouted the news: Rita, a downstairs neighbor, had broken her hip.

headline: A Great Credit Score, but She Can’t Get a Mortgage
abstract: Despite solid financial track records, many older Americans have a hard time refinancing because of their mortality risks and lower retirement incomes.
lead_paragraph: In late 2019, Molly Stuart’s contract ended at the community college where she worked. “Normally, I’d just get a new job, but then Covid happened,” she said. So she collected unemployment for awhile, then retired.

headline: Trump and His Lawyers: A Restless Search for Another Roy Cohn
abstract: Hired after TV appearances or brief phone calls, lawyers for the former president can come and go, as he demands they defend him first in the court of public opinion.
lead_paragraph: Seated far to the left of the defendant, former President Donald J. Trump, in a Manhattan criminal courtroom on Tuesday was a lawyer who has never tried a case in court, whose phone was seized by federal agents executing a warrant last year, and who once hosted syndicated news segments bombastically defending the Trump White House.

headline: Why Pope Francis Is the Star of A.I.-Generated Photos
abstract: Francis has become a recurring favorite to show in incongruous situations, such as riding a motorcycle and attending Burning Man, in A.I.-generated images.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis wearing a long, white puffer jacket inspired by Balenciaga. Francis rocking aviators and revving a motorcycle down a busy street. Francis turning the tables in a dim nightclub. Francis in a tactical vest, preparing to fly a fighter jet. Francis sharing a beer at Burning Man.

headline: Have Eggs, Will Travel. To Freeze Them.
abstract: Faced with the high cost of egg-freezing in their home countries, some women are going abroad for a better deal, and a vacation.
lead_paragraph: It’s hardly uncommon for Americans to travel to London over the summer, where they watch tennis at Wimbledon, say, or take pictures of Big Ben or dine on champagne and scones at Claridge’s.

headline: Georgia Looms Next After Trump’s Indictment in New York
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump now faces a very different legal challenge in the culmination of a more than two-year Atlanta investigation into election interference.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The indictment of Donald J. Trump in New York over hush-money payments to a porn star was a global spectacle, with the former president glumly returning to his old stomping grounds in Manhattan as TV networks closely tracked his procession of black SUVs on their way to the courthouse.

headline: For DeSantis, Overflowing War Chest Obscures the Challenges Ahead
abstract: As he prepares for a widely expected 2024 campaign, the Florida governor has at least $110 million in allied committees. But he will also have to navigate a series of financial and political hurdles.
lead_paragraph: As Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida prepares to take a widely anticipated leap into the 2024 presidential campaign, one of his chief strengths is his ability to raise huge sums from deep-pocketed donors.

headline: The Team Trying to Change the Ending of ‘Welcome to Wrexham’
abstract: Notts County is having one of the most remarkable seasons in its long history. It might even win the league. But you don’t get to star in someone else’s drama.
lead_paragraph: NOTTINGHAM, England — The irony of it all, really, is that Notts County would make a terrific subject for a documentary.

headline: Fed Up With Mayhem, Miami Beach Wants to Tame Spring Break for Good
abstract: After a series of violent incidents, the city is moving to pre-empt late-night partying, but businesses worry about crimping their most profitable tourism season.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH — After two fatal shootings on Ocean Drive over a March weekend, Miami Beach leaders followed their recent playbook for dealing with raucous spring break crowds: a state of emergency, a midnight curfew and limited liquor sales.

headline: 7 Manga Titles Perfect for Any Young Adult Reading List
abstract: Harmony Becker, author of “Himawari House,” shares her recommendations of manga that teens will enjoy.
lead_paragraph: Manga is such a diverse medium. I mean that in terms of both the subject matter it explores (tackling everything from period pain to classical music) as well as the range in tones it employs.

headline: Can We No Longer Believe Anything We See?
abstract: Human eyes — and even technology — often struggle to identify images created by artificial intelligence. Experts fear that may hasten an erosion of trust in media, in government and in society.
lead_paragraph: Seeing has not been believing for a very long time. Photos have been faked and manipulated for nearly as long as photography has existed.

headline: The More Kates the Merrier
abstract: The “Night of 1,000 Kates,” an annual variety show in Philadelphia, taps into the singer Kate Bush’s lasting appeal.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — For the last nine years, a variety show inspired by the British art pop singer Kate Bush has promised a “Night of 1,000 Kates.”

headline: In a Deadly Mountain Pass, a Tiny Hotel Is a Lifeline
abstract: Traversing the Sabzak Pass in Afghanistan is treacherous. But for travelers in distress, one innkeeper, who personifies Afghan generosity, is there to help — with a cup of tea, a meal or car repair.
lead_paragraph: SABZAK PASS, Afghanistan — The hotel is perched on the side of a mountain blanketed in snow. The ice-slicked road outside is treacherous. It stretches for miles in either direction through jagged peaks as it winds around the edges of cliffs and dips past piles of boulders left over from frequent rockslides.

headline: The Russians Took Their Children. These Mothers Went and Got Them Back.
abstract: Making a nerve-wracking 3,000-mile journey from Ukraine, into Russia-occupied territory, and back again, a group of mothers managed to recover their children from the custody of the Russian authorities.
lead_paragraph: For weeks after Russian troops forcibly removed Natalya Zhornyk’s teenage son from his school last fall, she had no idea where he was or what had happened to him.

headline: Ukraine Says Russia Is Preparing to Evacuate Civilians From Occupied Areas of South
abstract: Ukraine is widely expected to launch a counteroffensive in the coming weeks to recapture territory from Russian forces. Some Ukrainian officials say it could focus on the south of the country.
lead_paragraph: The Russian occupation authorities are preparing to evacuate civilians from territory that Moscow controls in southern Ukraine before a potential counteroffensive by Ukrainian forces, the Ukrainian military said on Saturday.

headline: 17 Pop Culture Moments That Define The Covid Era
abstract: These are the cultural moments we will forever associate with the past three years.
lead_paragraph: These are the cultural moments we will forever associate with the past three years.

headline: Canada’s Moonshot Moment
abstract: Jeremy Hansen, 47, will be one of four astronauts on NASA’s Artemis II moon mission and the first from Canada to venture into deep space.
lead_paragraph: The Johnson Space Center in Houston was buzzing with anticipation on Monday as NASA prepared to introduce the four astronauts chosen to go on the farthest ride of their lives — to the moon.

headline: The Runners Changing Course on Uniform Expectations
abstract: In competitive running, norms dictating attire are sticky but changing.
lead_paragraph: In eighth grade, Katelyn Hutchinson, a runner from the University of Kentucky, learned the power of a uniform.

headline: New Season, New Music
abstract: Looking for new music recommendations? Introducing an antidote to the algorithm.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, I finally got rid of the heavy pleather binders of CDs that were occupying valuable storage space in my closet. I’d fully committed to streaming music, I reasoned. If I wanted to hear a song, I’d find it online. Who even owned a CD player anymore?

headline: The A.I. Concierge, Fictional Fiction, Real Vodka
abstract: A critic recommends old and new books.
lead_paragraph: Molly Young is on leave for the next several months. In her absence, colleagues from the Book Review will pick up the recommendation torch and appear in your inbox every two Saturdays.

headline: Why Are We So Obsessed With the Way Politicians Eat?
abstract: And what’s worse: eating pudding with three fingers or salad with a comb?
lead_paragraph: I never thought I would relate to Ron DeSantis, a man whose political beliefs I vehemently oppose. But a few weeks ago, when I read this report about the Florida governor’s eating habits, I felt a deep sense of somewhat shameful recognition.

headline: Work From the Office, Get Laid Off at Home
abstract: McDonald’s temporarily closed its corporate offices this week so it could lay off workers virtually. Was that a good idea?
lead_paragraph: This week, McDonald’s asked corporate employees, who usually work from the office at least three days a week, to do the job from home. The plan was to lay off hundreds of employees, DealBook hears, and the company preferred to deliver its news virtually.

headline: Signed, Sealed and Delivered: the Masters Prize Besides a Green Jacket
abstract: So personalized that they include the signatures of every player in a Masters Tournament field, the trophies shipped to winners are deeply cherished but barely known.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Last year, in the months after he won the Masters Tournament for the first time, Scottie Scheffler heard a parcel was coming his way from Georgia.

headline: At 81, Ann-Margret Is Finally Living Her Rock ’n’ Roll Dream
abstract: The actress and musician, who first burst out in “Bye Bye Birdie” in 1963, is releasing a new album of old rock covers featuring guests like her “Tommy” co-star Pete Townshend.
lead_paragraph: Ann-Margret has always spoken in a voice that falls somewhere between a purr and a coo. But at her home on a recent rainy day in Los Angeles, she broke up her usual gauzy tones with deep and gutsy growls. “One, two, three o’clock rock!!!” she half-bellowed and half-yelled over a video chat, echoing the opening line from “Rock Around the Clock,” Bill Haley’s raucous 1954 smash.

headline: On Hope, Hate and the Most Radical Claim of the Easter Season
abstract: Hope pulls you out of yourself and into the world, forcing you to believe more is possible. Hate is a much less insistent master.
lead_paragraph: Easter has never been my favorite church service. Shouting “Alleluia, Christ is risen!” requires an emotional crescendo my melancholy temperament can’t easily manage.

headline: There’s No Road Map for an Aging Lesbian
abstract: Where is the script for growing gray and staying gay?
lead_paragraph: One afternoon not long ago, I was walking with my partner near Times Square and we were approached by a man passing out leaflets. “Take one for your mom,” he said to my partner. I stopped cold.

headline: A Swedish Warship Sank in 1628. It’s Still Yielding Secrets.
abstract: Researchers are learning more about those who died after the Vasa sank, including a woman known as “G,” who was long believed by scientists to be a man.
lead_paragraph: On the afternoon of Aug. 10, 1628, the Vasa, built by the Swedish to be one of the most powerful warships in the Baltic, set off from the palace docks in Stockholm.

headline: When George W. Bush Was a Hero
abstract: George W. Bush’s program against AIDS was the best single presidential policy of my lifetime.
lead_paragraph: This is a tough column for a liberal to write. You may recall that I spent eight years hammering President George W. Bush for just about everything he did (and he deserved it!), yet one more thing must be said: Bush started the single best policy of any president in my lifetime.

headline: A Tale of Fire and Ice
abstract: New York’s first female fire commissioner faces down a revolt from the old guard.
lead_paragraph: When women were first hired by the New York Fire Department in the early 1980s, no red carpet led to the red doors.

headline: China Rejects W.H.O. Accusations of Hiding Wuhan Covid Data
abstract: The rebukes came after overseas researchers discovered sequences that had not been previously shared.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese officials on Saturday offered a lengthy rebuttal to accusations by the World Health Organization that they had been slow to share data about the possible origins of the coronavirus, blasting some in the organization as political “tools” whose remarks were “intolerable.”

headline: A Week of Youthful Activism Sends Out Political Shockwaves
abstract: After Donald Trump’s indictment on Tuesday, progressives cemented two crucial victories in Wisconsin and Chicago, and, in Nashville, a firestorm erupted after the expulsion of two liberal lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: A surge of youthful activism powered major liberal victories in Wisconsin and Chicago and a boisterous legislative uprising in Tennessee this week, as Republicans absorbed a string of damaging political blows, beginning with the arraignment of their leading presidential contender on criminal charges in Manhattan.

headline: French Diplomacy Undercuts U.S. Efforts to Rein China In
abstract: Allies don’t always see things the same way, as Emmanuel Macron’s cozy visit to Xi Jinping made abundantly clear.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France complimented China’s top leader on the “very fragrant tea.” President Xi Jinping recalled “taking notes in order to understand” when he visited his father, then governor of the southeastern Guangdong province, in 1978. He also observed, extolling Chinese economic development, that the province now has “four cities with more than 10 million people.”

headline: Street Scenes From Trump’s Arraignment
abstract: New Yorkers of every stripe came out to witness the historic day.
lead_paragraph: On Monday morning, I grabbed my camera and headed to Trump Tower in Midtown Manhattan, where former President Donald Trump was expected to arrive in the afternoon, in advance of his arraignment the following day.

headline: Mötley Crüe Guitarist’s Lawsuit Says He Was Kicked Out
abstract: Mick Mars accused his bandmates of gaslighting him and cutting him out of future profits after he said he was retiring from touring.
lead_paragraph: Mick Mars, the guitarist for the veteran hair-metal band Mötley Crüe, filed a lawsuit this week accusing his bandmates of pushing him out of the group and cutting him out of its future profits.

headline: How to Find the Right Broker for Selling Your Home
abstract: New York home sellers spend an average of three and a half hours researching agents — less time than they spend searching vacation destinations.
lead_paragraph: Q: I am planning to sell my condo in Harlem, and I’m looking for a real estate agent who can assist me with the process in this brutal housing market. How do I determine what makes a good agent? Should I look for someone who has sold a unit in my building? Should I ask for references? What other factors should I consider?

headline: Benjamin B. Ferencz, Last Surviving Nuremberg Prosecutor, Dies at 103
abstract: In addition to convicting prominent Nazi war criminals, he crusaded for an international criminal court and for laws to end wars of aggression.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin B. Ferencz, the last surviving prosecutor of the Nuremberg trials, who convicted Nazi war criminals of organizing the murder of a million people and German industrialists of using slave labor from concentration camps to build Hitler’s war machine, died on Friday at an assisted living facility in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 103.

headline: E.P.A. Is Said to Propose Rules Meant to Drive Up Electric Car Sales Tenfold
abstract: In what would be the nation’s most ambitious climate regulation, the proposal is designed to ensure that electric cars make up the majority of new U.S. auto sales by 2032.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is planning some of the most stringent auto pollution limits in the world, designed to ensure that all-electric cars make up as much as 67 percent of new passenger vehicles sold in the country by 2032, according to two people familiar with the matter.

headline: The Hideous Resurrection of the Comstock Act
abstract: How the right is using a 150-year-old law to try to ban abortion pills.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Comstock, the mutton-chopped anti-vice crusader for whom the Comstock Act is named, is back from the dead.

headline: Leaked Documents Reveal Depth of U.S. Spy Efforts and Russia’s Military Struggles
abstract: The information, exposed on social media sites, also shows that U.S. intelligence services are eavesdropping on important allies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A trove of leaked Pentagon documents reveals how deeply Russia’s security and intelligence services have been penetrated by the United States, demonstrating Washington’s ability to warn Ukraine about planned strikes and providing an assessment of the strength of Moscow’s war machine.

headline: Rockets From Lebanon Point to Growing Hamas Cooperation With Hezbollah
abstract: Israel accused Hamas, a Palestinian militia, of firing rockets into Israel from Lebanon, underscoring its deepening ties with Hezbollah, the dominant Lebanese militia.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — When an unusually heavy rocket barrage hit Israel from Lebanon this week, it was the latest reminder of a long-running animus between Israel and Hezbollah, the Iran-backed Lebanese militia that dominates Lebanon’s southern borderlands.

headline: At a Flooded Augusta National, Koepka Builds a Lead and Woods Sinks
abstract: Third-round play was suspended midafternoon Saturday. Koepka was alone atop the leaderboard, and Woods was at the bottom. Twenty-two strokes separated them.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The raindrops tumbled toward the turf in sheets, rapping umbrellas on their way down and pooling anywhere they could: in shoes, in plastic beer cups, onto the famously — and, on Saturday, formerly — fiery greens at Augusta National Golf Club.

headline: Bill Butler, Cinematographer Best Known for ‘Jaws,’ Dies at 101
abstract: He came up with a mechanism that allowed Steven Spielberg to film underwater. His work on “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest” earned him an Oscar nomination.
lead_paragraph: Bill Butler, an Oscar-nominated cinematographer who played a prominent role in the American New Wave movement of the 1970s and whose credits included “Jaws,” “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest” and three of the “Rocky” sequels, died on Wednesday at his home in Flathead Lake, Mont. He was 101.

headline: Two Federal Judges Issued Opposing Rulings on Abortion Pills. Here’s What’s Going On.
abstract: One invalidated the F.D.A.’s approval of the abortion pill mifepristone. The other ordered the F.D.A. to do nothing to restrict the pill’s availability.
lead_paragraph: The ruling by a federal judge in Texas invalidating the Food and Drug Administration’s approval 23 years ago of the abortion pill mifepristone has the potential to be the most consequential abortion decision since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade last June.

headline: Mel King, Whose Boston Mayoral Bid Eased Racial Tensions, Dies at 94
abstract: The first Black finalist for mayor of the city, he was credited, along with the eventual winner, Raymond Flynn, with running a respectful, calming campaign.
lead_paragraph: Mel King, a Black community activist whose barrier-breaking campaign for mayor of Boston in 1983 helped ease racial tensions there that had been caused in part by court-ordered busing to desegregate public schools, died on March 28 at his home in Boston. He was 94.

headline: Overlooked No More: Alice Ball, Chemist Who Created a Treatment for Leprosy
abstract: After she died — and just a year after her discovery — another scientist took credit for her work. It would be more than half a century until her story resurfaced.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Track Cycling Champion Dies in Collision in San Francisco
abstract: The death of Ethan Boyes, 44, a cyclist who was struck by a car in the Presidio, highlights the city’s struggles to reduce traffic fatalities.
lead_paragraph: A track cycling champion died after a car struck him while he was riding this week in San Francisco, a high-profile fatality that highlighted the city’s struggles to reduce traffic deaths.

headline: With Dueling Rulings, Abortion Pill Cases Appear Headed to the Supreme Court
abstract: One federal judge said the F.D.A.’s approval of the drug mifepristone was invalid, while another federal judge ordered the agency to keep the pill available. The legal fallout is just beginning.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The dramatic dueling rulings by two federal district judges on Friday about access to a widely used abortion pill set up a lower court conflict that legal experts say will almost certainly send the dispute to the Supreme Court.

headline: Leaked Document Shows Dire Nature of the Battle for Bakhmut
abstract: An assessment that appears in a new batch of leaked classified documents appears to show that Ukraine was close to losing a key battle of the war in February.
lead_paragraph: KHARKIV, Ukraine — The Ukrainian Army was close to losing a key battle of the war. A single, tenuous supply road for Ukrainian soldiers fighting in the streets of the eastern city of Bakhmut was taking fire. A general called the threatened road the “last breathing tube.”

headline: Wagner’s Influence Extends Far Beyond Ukraine, Leaked Documents Show
abstract: The Russian mercenary group has extended its network for acquiring weapons — a sign of its reach, but also a possible indication that sanctions are forcing it to branch out from its Russian backers.
lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — A cache of leaked Pentagon documents  portrays the Russian military as running out of steam, short on men and equipment, and facing stalemate. But one group of Russian fighters stands as an exception.

headline: Why Leaked Pentagon Documents Are Still Circulating on Social Media
abstract: Twitter and the social media platform Discord have policies about how they would handle the material. But those rules have gray areas and can be unevenly enforced.
lead_paragraph: Twitter and the social media platform Discord have various policies that might have prompted them to remove the leaked Pentagon documents that Biden administration officials say revealed key information about U.S. intelligence gathering operations.

headline: Israel Denies Leaked Claim That Spy Agency Leaders Encouraged Protest
abstract: The unsourced accusations about the leadership of the Mossad, Israel’s foreign intelligence service, were contained in a leaked Pentagon report.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli government issued a statement on Sunday firmly rejecting assertions contained in the leaked Pentagon documents that the leadership of the Mossad, Israel’s foreign intelligence service, had encouraged the agency’s staff and Israeli citizens to participate in the anti-government protests that roiled the country in March.

headline: If the Clue Fits …
abstract: John Ewbank’s Sunday puzzle is like a box of chocolates. …
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: U.S. Women Lose Mallory Swanson in World Cup Tuneup
abstract: Swanson was carted off with a serious knee injury during a 2-0 victory over Ireland, a blow to the United States’ hopes of winning a third consecutive World Cup championship.
lead_paragraph: UPDATE: U.S. Soccer announced on Sunday that Mallory Swanson had torn the patella tendon in her left knee late in the first half of Saturday’s game against Ireland. The injury usually requires months of recovery, most likely ruling out Swanson for Women’s World Cup that begins in July.

headline: U.S. Sends Attack Submarine to Middle East as Tensions Rise Between Iran and Israel
abstract: Officials said the move was meant as a deterrent against Iran and to maintain the stability of one of the world’s busiest shipping lanes.
lead_paragraph: The United States Navy said on Saturday that it had deployed a guided missile submarine to the Middle East, a day after the U.S. 5th Fleet and its partners released a warning advising all ships to proceed with caution following escalating tensions between Iran and Israel, according to a U.S. Navy spokesman.

headline: Texas Governor Says He Plans to Pardon Man Convicted of Killing Protester
abstract: Gov. Greg Abbott said he would forgo a prison sentence for Daniel S. Perry, who was convicted on Friday in the murder of Garrett Foster at a Black Lives Matter demonstration in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas said on Saturday that he would pardon a man who was convicted on Friday of murdering a protester in Austin, as long as a state board brought such a request to his desk.

headline: Corrections: April 8, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 8, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about Ukrainians who have become homeless despite a government resettlement program in the U.S. incorrectly described the work that Welcome.Us does with refugees from Afghanistan and Ukraine. Welcome.Us helps to match Ukrainian refugees with American sponsors, not Afghan refugees.

headline: Northern Ireland Is Far Too Quiet
abstract: Peace here is a matchstick tower. And in the past few years there has been a shifting of the ground below.
lead_paragraph: HOLYWOOD, Northern Ireland — In 1998, two jagged, conflicting philosophies agreed to end the violence known as the Troubles and create a power-sharing government in Stormont, the seat of Northern Ireland’s devolved assembly.

headline: How to Make Trump Go Away
abstract: It starts by having some humility and understanding his appeal.
lead_paragraph: After more than three decades in and around politics, I now spend most of my time grappling with political questions in the classroom and in focus groups. There is one conundrum that fascinates me above others: Why does Donald Trump still generate such loyalty and devotion? And unlike 2016, can a different Republican win the nomination in 2024 who largely shares Mr. Trump’s agenda but not his personality?

headline: Leaked Documents Show Seoul Torn Between U.S. Demands and Its Own Policy
abstract: The documents showed the United States most likely spied on a key Asian ally as pressure built for South Korea to help Washington supply ammunition to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: ​SEOUL — When reports emerged late last year that South Korea had agreed to sell artillery shells to help the United States replenish its stockpiles, it insisted that their “end user” should be the U.S. military. But internally, top aides to President Yoon Suk Yeol were worried that their American ally would divert them to Ukraine.

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Brings Donald Trump to the Last Supper for Easter Weekend
abstract: In an episode hosted by Molly Shannon, the former president, as played by James Austin Johnson, compared his recent indictment to the persecution of Jesus.
lead_paragraph: What started out looking like an almost reverential treatment — at least by “Saturday Night Live” standards — of the Easter holiday quickly gave way to a satirical monologue from former President Donald J. Trump, comparing his own recent indictment on 34 felony charges of falsifying business records to the victimization of Jesus.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Fresh Meanings for a Common Word
abstract: Fruit can be fresh. So can style, the country air and an impertinent teenage boy.
lead_paragraph: One of the first appearances of “fresh” in The New York Times was in a letter to the editor in 1858. Under the headline “Pursuit of Fresh Air Under Difficulties,” a reader traveling to a vacation home in upstate New York described the pungent smells of the city: the milk factory’s “stump-tail odor,” the gas works that “dispense a large part of their product in the surrounding atmosphere.” The writer, who signed as “Olfactorius,” awaited relief in the country: “I think no one will dispute that I deserve all the fresh breezes that I get after passing through the frightful variety of bad smells.”

headline: ‘I Opened the Door, Got in and Slumped Down in the Seat’
abstract: Hoping to make a quick getaway, help with a hood and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: How It Looks to Come of Age
abstract: The Where We Are series gives readers an inside look at the communities and coming-of-age traditions young people are creating today.
lead_paragraph: In 2004, as a high school student in Rochester, N.Y., Eve Lyons found freedom listening to Radiohead in the car with her friends.

headline: At Stanford Law School, the Dean Takes a Stand for Free Speech. Will It Work?
abstract: After a student protest, Jenny S. Martinez wrote a much-praised memo defending academic freedom. But that protest shows how complicated protecting free speech can be.
lead_paragraph: Stanford Law School was under extraordinary pressure.

headline: Ireland Readies a Warm Welcome for Biden, ‘the Most Irish’ President Since J.F.K.
abstract: Ahead of President Biden’s trip to Ireland, the locals of two towns, including several of his relatives, are hoping he’ll return to celebrate their ancestral ties.
lead_paragraph: When John F. Kennedy became the first serving U.S. president to visit Ireland, in 1963, he was hailed as a returning hero in New Ross, County Wexford, his family’s ancestral home.

headline: Nashville, Battered and Mourning, Pauses for Easter
abstract: The holiest day in the Christian calendar comes as the church-filled city is in a heated political debate, and still deep in grief.
lead_paragraph: Less than two weeks after the shooting of six people at a small Christian school in Nashville, the city’s raw mourning was swept into sprawling, emotional protests and political strife, culminating in accusations of racism over the expulsion of two young Black state legislators. It has been an extraordinary and painful season of hugs and funerals, marches and speeches, tears and anger.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Nashville, Shattered and Mourning, Prepares to Gather for Easter
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 9, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Everything changes on Sunday. Our loss is not erased, but we all get this very visible reminder that hope is not lost.”

headline: The Case for Staying Married to a Spouse You Cannot Stand
abstract: It’s worth exploring why, so often, our culture encourages us to run from the ambivalent space between “happy” and “irreconcilable differences.”
lead_paragraph: My husband and I celebrated 19 years of marriage in December. I am only 37, which means I have been married more than half my life. Much of that time has been very happy, but there have also been days — even years — when I could not bear the thought of staying.

headline: For This American, Self-Discovery Begins at a Ukrainian Call Center
abstract: “Calling Ukraine,” a novel by Johannes Lichtman, combines an expatriate story and an office satire.
lead_paragraph: The novel of the American abroad constitutes its own literary genre, presided over by the ghosts of Melville (the high seas) and Henry James (European high society). With sailors in diminishing demand, trips have more recently been funded by Fulbright grants or the Peace Corps, or with the help of a short-term job teaching English. At their best, novels of international visitors defamiliarize cultural practices, identities and language itself on both sides: English sounds different after a long sojourn in another tongue.

headline: Is It a Cold, or Is It Allergies?
abstract: Sneezing, sniffling, coughing — here’s how to tell what’s causing your symptoms.
lead_paragraph: When flowers are in bloom and cold viruses are circulating in the spring, it can be challenging to tell whether symptoms like sneezing, coughing and a runny nose are the result of a cold, allergies or both.

headline: The Abortion Pill Ruling Is Bad Law, and the Biden Administration Should Fight It
abstract: The opinion from a federal judge in Texas is a legal travesty.
lead_paragraph: The Friday-night ruling by Judge Matthew Kacsmaryk purporting to stay the Food and Drug Administration’s approval of mifepristone for use in early abortions is a travesty — for women’s health care, principles of democracy, notions of judicial impartiality and the rule of law.

headline: For a Literary Man’s Man, Mother Knew Best
abstract: In his new memoir, “Irma,” Terry McDonell, a magazine editor during the golden age of magazines, gives credit to Mom (and Hemingway).
lead_paragraph: The magazine eminence Terry McDonell’s first memoir, “The Accidental Life,” was a collection of career-centered anecdotes that felt banged out with two fingers on an Olivetti typewriter. Each started with a word count and finished like a sock to the jaw with the insiderly journalistic term “ENDIT.” Reviewing that book in 2016, my colleague Dwight Garner noted that it was “light on female personages,” adding that the author wasn’t “opening his vault or baring his soul.”

headline: Sunday’s Masters Plan: End the Third Round, Play the Fourth, Crown a Winner. Maybe Dry Out, Too.
abstract: Plus, Fred Couples sets a Masters record.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Sometime on Sunday evening — weather permitting, because everything during this Masters Tournament seems to be like that — Brooks Koepka or Jon Rahm or one of 52 other players will get to wear the jacket they actually want to during this trip to Augusta National Golf Club.

headline: The World Bank Is Getting a New Chief. Will He Pivot Toward Climate Action?
abstract: Under pressure from world leaders, development experts and shareholders, the bank opens its spring meeting on Monday, poised for big changes.
lead_paragraph: As World Bank shareholders gather in Washington for their annual spring meeting on Monday, the global institution appears to be on the brink of significant change.

headline: How a Civil Rights Champion Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Donna Lieberman, head of the New York Civil Liberties Union, “steps back” from job pressures with family outings and a swim.
lead_paragraph: “I was born into the McCarthy era,” Donna Lieberman said. But she certainly didn’t stay there.

headline: El Salvador Decimated Its Ruthless Gangs. But at What Cost?
abstract: In the year since El Salvador declared a state of emergency, the government has delivered a stunning blow to the gangs that were once the ultimate authority in much of the country.
lead_paragraph: When the MS-13 gang ran the neighborhood of Las Margaritas, one of its strongholds in El Salvador, there were rules you had to follow to stay alive.

headline: Europe Has Pledged a Million Shells for Ukraine in a Year. Can It Deliver?
abstract: Probably not, experts say, given the shrunken state of its military industrial sector. A look at a major munitions maker helps explain why.
lead_paragraph: The giant robot arms and high-tech heaters at one of Europe’s largest ammunition plants have been whirring around the clock since the start of the war in Ukraine to produce more desperately needed 155-millimeter artillery shells. If all goes as planned, the factory’s parent company, Nammo, will be turning out as many as 200,000 of the shells a year by 2028 — up to 20 times its prewar production.

headline: New Mexico Is Losing a Form of Spanish Spoken Nowhere Else on Earth
abstract: A dialect from the state’s earliest Spanish-speaking settlers has endured for over 400 years in the state’s remote mountain villages. But its time may be running out.
lead_paragraph: QUESTA, N.M. — When the old regulars gather at Cynthia Rael-Vigil’s coffee shop in Questa, N.M., a village nestled in the snow-capped Sangre de Cristo Mountains, they sip lattes and lavender lemonade and gossip in Spanish.

headline: What Brooke Shields Wore on the Town
abstract: Galas were held for the New York Academy of Art and the Fashion Scholarship Fund.
lead_paragraph: It may be the best art deal in town. The New York Academy of Art held its annual Tribeca Ball on April 4, where established collectors got to roam the art studios upstairs and buy work from 100 current students. Afterward, guests sat down for a filet mignon dinner that honored Amy Sherald, the figurative painter best known for her official portrait of Michelle Obama.

headline: $388 in Sushi. Just a $20 Tip: The Brutal Math of Uber Eats and DoorDash
abstract: Delivery drivers were hailed as pandemic heroes. But they say the rise of contactless delivery has made customers less inclined to tip generously and gig work is becoming an even harder way to make a living.
lead_paragraph: Brantley Bush couldn’t shake the fear that he was about to be ripped off.

headline: Dangerously Scarce 50 Years Ago, India’s Tigers Bounce Back
abstract: A conservation effort has worked well enough that there is now talk of sending some tigers to Cambodia to help that nation revive its own wild population.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1970s, things looked grim for India’s tigers. A wild population estimated in the tens of thousands at the time of independence in 1947 had shrunk to around 1,800. The tigers’ decline also held worrying implications for the nation’s environment because the apex predator is part of a complex but fragile ecosystem. Something had to be done.

headline: Easter Rebukes the Christian Will to Power
abstract: The true message of the death and rebirth of Jesus.
lead_paragraph: On Easter Sunday, billions of Christians gather together to celebrate the event that’s indispensable to the Christian faith — the resurrection of Jesus Christ. As the Apostle Paul wrote to the church in Corinth, without the resurrection our faith is useless. The Easter focus on the resurrection is profoundly encouraging for people of Christian faith.

headline: Tipping Confusion
abstract: Tipping norms haven’t kept up with delivery apps and changes in how people buy food.
lead_paragraph: For delivery drivers, every shift is a game of gig economy roulette: Will customers tip? And if they do, how much? The answers determine their livelihoods.

headline: The Week in Business: Cuts to Oil Production
abstract: Job growth last month continued at a steady, but slower pace. The Biden administration unveiled its plans for the I.R.S. And a new inflation reading comes out.
lead_paragraph: An unexpected move by Saudi Arabia, Russia and other members of OPEC Plus to cut oil production by more than 1.2 million barrels a day, or more than 1 percent of the world’s supplies, sent oil prices soaring at the beginning of the week. Last Sunday night, when energy markets opened, both the American and global oil benchmark prices rose 7 percent. The decision caught everyone off guard because in the days leading up to the announcement, officials said they did not intend to make changes to their policies. There are a few possible factors behind the cuts: Both Russia and Saudi Arabia have been struggling to keep up with production, according to recent reports. And OPEC Plus could be responding to the darkening economic outlook, made dimmer by the failure of several banks. OPEC Plus’s changes to oil production may ultimately have limited effect. Still, oil prices have fallen far from where they were a year ago in the immediate wake of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Adesanya Brings Moment of Stability by Regaining U.F.C. Title
abstract: Israel Adesanya knocked out Alex Pereira to regain the 185-pound championship belt, winning a rematch of a bout he lost in November amid a time of star turnover in the sport.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Israel Adesanya, as he made his way toward the Ultimate Fighting Championship octagon on Saturday night for a pivotal championship rematch against a bitter rival, stopped and put a hand on the shoulder of Eugene Bareman, his longtime coach.

headline: Marilyn Minter, an Artist Who Resonates and Repels
abstract: In her most ambitious show to date, the 74-year-old artist is continuing to push the envelope with a new body of work.
lead_paragraph: The images are compelling — a watery blur of color and shading. But collectors don’t rush to own these Marilyn Minter paintings when they realize what they depict: vaginas.

headline: At the Masters, Brooks Koepka Holds the Lead and Tiger Woods Withdraws
abstract: Woods exited the tournament during the third round that finished around noon on Sunday. Koepka held a two-stroke lead over Jon Rahm head into the final round.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Tiger Woods withdrew on Sunday from the Masters Tournament, where he was in last place and openly struggling to overcome the agony of years of injuries.

headline: Fight for Roads Into Bakhmut Has Hit a Stalemate, Ukraine Says
abstract: Even as Russian forces made some gains in the battered eastern city last week, Ukraine’s forces say they have thwarted Moscow’s efforts to sever supply lines. For now.
lead_paragraph: The seesaw fight for a sunflower field raged for weeks with neither Ukrainian nor Russian forces gaining an upper hand, but for Ukraine’s army, that counts as a win in the crucial battle for access roads into the city of Bakhmut.

headline: Brazil’s Favelas Offer Lessons in Building Trust
abstract: Community goes a long way in pandemics.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Thiago Nascimento expected no help from the government when the coronavirus arrived in his neighborhood. ‌‌He was worried because, as in other favelas — informal settlements throughout the city — people were made vulnerable by a lack of income, safe housing and clean, running water. ‌ A study later showed that people in favelas were twice as likely to die if they had Covid-19 as those in higher-income neighborhoods in the city.

headline: Russia promises bonus pay to troops who destroy NATO tanks, documents say.
abstract: Unconfirmed reports from leaked Pentagon documents show plans to shore up troops’ morale and sharpen their tactics as Ukraine takes delivery of more advanced weapons.
lead_paragraph: To brace for the introduction of advanced NATO-supplied tanks on Ukraine’s battlefields, Russian forces are preparing to pay a bonus to troops who manage to damage or destroy one, according to recently leaked U.S. intelligence documents.

headline: When Mounties Pose as Mobsters, Some Canadians Cry Foul
abstract: A con game that undercover police use to obtain confessions in Canada secures convictions, but opponents say it’s a breeding ground for false confessions.
lead_paragraph: The police were hot on his trail for two murders and when pressured by the leader of his new gang to explain what he’d done, Trestan Brown confided in her. He figured he could trust her. She was, after all, a fellow criminal.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Steam your deviled eggs, chop up your pesto and stir-fry your noodles in a Dutch oven.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I love an Easter morning that’s a little cold but sunny, the air crisp around the daffodils in the park as cherry blossoms flit in the gutters and clouds move without anxiety against the bluebird sky. There’s a promise to that weather, with maybe a feast for lunch in the offing, and a long walk afterward.

headline: Did Jesus Really Rise From the Dead?
abstract: The theologian N.T. Wright on the baffling, world-altering claim of the Resurrection.
lead_paragraph: Happy Easter! Easter marks the high point of the Christian liturgical calendar, when billions of Christians around the world celebrate the Resurrection of Jesus, the central hope of the Christian faith. Perhaps no one on earth has studied that event and the subsequent responses to it more than N.T. Wright. He serves as senior research fellow at Wycliffe Hall, Oxford, and is emeritus professor of New Testament at the University of St. Andrews. He has written over 80 books focused on Jesus and his first followers. He is also a Christian and a former bishop of Durham in the Church of England. One of his books, “The Resurrection of the Son of God,” is an exhaustive dive into the scholarship and debates around the Resurrection. I asked Wright to speak with me about his research and this baffling, world-altering claim of resurrection. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: María Kodama, Keeper of the Borges Legacy, Dies at 86
abstract: She was a writer and translator but was best known as the widow of Jorge Luis Borges, one of Latin America’s great writers.
lead_paragraph: María Kodama, a writer and translator who was best known for guarding the legacy of her husband, the masterly Argentine writer Jorge Luis Borges, died on March 26 in the Buenos Aires suburb Vicente López. She was 86.

headline: Walking as a Cure for What Ails Us
abstract: Readers react to a guest essay extolling the benefits of walking. Also: Ex-inmates’ re-entry into society; a Disney film banned in a Florida school.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: ‘Ainadamar’ Turns Lorca Into Death-Haunted Opera
abstract: Osvaldo Golijov’s poetic 2003 work is being presented in a new production at Detroit Opera that will travel to the Met.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Spain is “a country of death, a country open to death,” the poet Federico García Lorca wrote.

headline: Hobie Landrith, the First New York Met, Dies at 93
abstract: A major league catcher for 14 seasons, he was the first player picked by the newly formed Mets in the expansion draft in 1961.
lead_paragraph: Hobie Landrith caught for seven teams in his 14 major league seasons. He was mostly a backup, good enough at handling pitchers but a light hitter. He was never an All-Star. But he did possess a modest claim to fame.

headline: ‘Super Mario Bros. Movie’ Brings Family Box Office Roaring Back
abstract: The film’s blockbuster opening weekend raised hopes that animation, once one of Hollywood’s safest bets, had recovered from the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Movie theaters have struggled to recover from the pandemic, in part, because the once-reliable family audience has wandered. Last year, family-oriented films — largely animation — represented 17 percent of worldwide ticket sales, about half of what they were in 2019.

headline: ‘Hey, Mr. Living Composer’: ‘Champion’ Takes Shape at the Met
abstract: Terence Blanchard has been in rehearsals, with pencil and paper at the ready, as he tailors his opera ahead of its New York premiere.
lead_paragraph: A basement rehearsal room at the Metropolitan Opera was so packed recently that it began to resemble a sweltering boxing gym.

headline: At Least 3 California Condors Die From Bird Flu in Arizona
abstract: Exposure to the virus is expected to rise as condors, an endangered species, migrate north in the spring, the National Park Service said.

headline: How Do You Know if You’re Addicted to Weed?

But things changed after he moved to a new city where he didn’t know anyone. Julian (who asked not to use his last name when talking about a sensitive medical condition) didn’t have much of a social life, so he started smoking by himself to pass the time. “Weed became my friend,” he said. “I would get off work and I would smoke because I was bored.”

headline: ‘Succession’ Season 4, Episode 3 Recap: Long Live the King
abstract: Connor’s wedding doesn’t go quite as planned. Neither does just about anything else.
lead_paragraph: Up until tonight, the succession part of “Succession” has been a lot like the Godot part of Samuel Beckett’s play “Waiting for Godot.” Over and over, Logan Roy has made plans to step down as the big boss of Waystar, either by appointing one of his children or underlings as his successor or by selling out to another company. But again and again, either Logan has changed his mind or something else has happened to scotch the deal. Godot never comes. The essential does not change.

And it’s this struggle — to wake up and persist in the face of promised hardship — that Jeff Boyd, a former Chicago public-school teacher, so brilliantly captures in his debut novel, “The Weight.”

headline: I Worked at the F.D.A. The Abortion Pill Decision Is Dangerous.
abstract: The F.D.A. must be able to make decisions based on evidence.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Texas has taken a shocking and irresponsible action: invalidating the Food and Drug Administration’s approval of mifepristone, a medication used safely by hundreds of thousands of women each year to help terminate pregnancies as part of a two-pill regimen. For what appears to be the first time, a court has invalidated an agency drug approval — an approval that was based on extensive review of scientific evidence, earned the unanimous support of outside experts and retains, after two decades, the full backing of major professional medical organizations.

headline: The One Thing Trump Has That DeSantis Never Will
abstract: The Florida governor’s populism is heavy on cultural grievances and light on economic ones.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida is in a trap of his own devising. His path to the Republican presidential nomination depends on convincing Donald Trump’s base that he represents a more committed and disciplined version of the former president, that he shares their populist grievances and aims only to execute the Trump agenda with greater forcefulness and skill. But it also depends on convincing a G.O.P. elite grown weary of Mr. Trump’s erratic bombast (not to mention electoral losses and legal jeopardy) that he, Mr. DeSantis, represents a more responsible alternative: shrewd where Mr. Trump is reckless; bookish where Mr. Trump is philistine; scrupulous, cunning and detail-oriented where Mr. Trump is impetuous and easily bored. In short, to the base, Mr. DeSantis must be more Trump than Trump, and to the donors, less.

headline: The Unequal Racial Burdens of Rising Seas
abstract: In “Charleston,” a case study of climate change and government negligence in the South Carolina city, Susan Crawford makes clear the disproportionate costs borne by communities of color in the coastal United States.
lead_paragraph: All true climate-change stories are about the abuse of power. Knowing this, Susan Crawford makes a plea for climate justice in “Charleston,” her sweeping case study of the South Carolina city. Her premise is that this imperiled place is a bellwether for the rest of the coastal United States, where government at every level is failing to prepare for the catastrophic effects of sea level rise and increasingly severe storms, which are threatening lives and causing billions of dollars in damage.

headline: Material Event: Unpacking That Pivotal ‘Succession’ Episode

Kübler-Ross’s model has since been popularly applied to the grief process. The implication is that all of us who live, love and die are in this way the same.
