abstract: The Portuguese giant knew selling Enzo Fernández would make it harder to win Europe’s richest prize. But cashing out early is a story the club knows well.
lead_paragraph: On the night Enzo Fernández left Benfica, nobody mentioned his name. As they gathered in the changing room before their game on the last day of January, his soon-to-be-former teammates would have known roughly what was happening. The club was settling the finer points of Fernández’s $130 million transfer to Chelsea. The player was awaiting permission to fly to London.

headline: What Next for Banks?
abstract: The wider reverberations from the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank will be felt for some time, and investors are watching for new signs of trouble.
lead_paragraph: The S&P 500 has rebounded by 6.5 percent since the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank last month, and there are encouraging signs that deposit outflows are slowing at regional lenders.

headline: Is There a Better N.H.L. Team Than the Bruins?
abstract: The Bruins won their 63rd game on Sunday, setting a league record for most regular season wins. Now the hard part begins.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Bruins players and staff have been saying for months that they were not trying to break the record for most wins in a season come April. Their focus was on winning the Stanley Cup in June. But try or not, they did it anyway.

headline: ‘I’m Planning on Running’ for Re-election in 2024, Biden Says
abstract: But the president said he was not ready to formally announce a campaign yet, and a delayed announcement would not be out of character for him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Monday said he was “planning on” seeking re-election next year but was not ready to launch his campaign yet.

headline: Rutgers University Faculty Members Strike, Halting Classes and Research
abstract: The walkout is the first in the public university’s 257-year history and follows nearly a year of bargaining.
lead_paragraph: Three unions representing an estimated 9,000 full- and part-time faculty members at Rutgers University went on strike on Monday for the first time in the school’s 257-year history, bringing classes and research at New Jersey’s flagship public university to a halt.

headline: Morgan Wallen Spends a Fifth Straight Week at No. 1
abstract: The country superstar, on his latest chart streak, holds off challenges from the sardonic pop singer Melanie Martinez and a deluxe reissue from Tyler, the Creator.
lead_paragraph: For the fifth time in a row, the country superstar Morgan Wallen tops the Billboard album chart with his latest extra-long LP, “One Thing at a Time,” easily holding off challenges from new releases by the singer Melanie Martinez and the indie-rock supergroup boygenius.

headline: How We Make Games at The Times
abstract: A new offering is being beta tested, and a small team of passionate puzzle makers at The Times talk about how an idea becomes a game.
lead_paragraph: A new game called Digits will be available this week for a limited-time beta release by the New York Times Games team. The beta test is available to everyone and is free to play.

headline: Gunman Kills 5 Co-Workers at Louisville Bank on Livestream, Police Say
abstract: The police did not give a motive for the shooting in the Kentucky city but said that the gunman, who also died, had been a bank employee.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — A 25-year-old man shot and killed five colleagues with a rifle on Monday at the downtown bank where he worked, the police said. Eight others were wounded in the attack, two of them critically. The suspect, who officials said was livestreaming the rampage, was killed by the police after exchanging fire with them.

headline: Bank Turmoil Squeezes Borrowers, Raising Fears of a Slowdown
abstract: Economists are watching for the aftereffects of recent bank collapses across many industries. How bad could it get?
lead_paragraph: Sarah Puil needs to buy $500,000 to $1 million of premium wine and other inventory by the end of the year to make into the specialty blends that her company sells and ships to customers around the country. But after the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank started a chain reaction that is causing many types of funding to dry up, she is not sure where she is going to get the cash.

headline: Dalai Lama Apologizes Over an Exchange With a Boy
abstract: In a video, the 87-year-old Tibetan spiritual leader sticks out his tongue and asks the child to “suck” it. His office said the actions had been lighthearted.
lead_paragraph: The Dalai Lama, the Tibetan spiritual leader, apologized on Monday after a video surfaced online showing him kissing a boy on the lips at a public event earlier this year and then saying to the child, “Suck my tongue.”

headline: The Wide World of Tofu
abstract: Andrea Nguyen brings us a primer and three delicious recipes that demonstrate the breadth of tofu styles.
lead_paragraph: “These are good times for tofu lovers,” Andrea Nguyen writes in The New York Times this week, for her smart tofu primer that considers three categories: basic, chewy and intensely flavored. She reports that America’s tofu consumption has roughly doubled in recent years, fueled in part by a growing interest in plant-based cooking. Whether smoked, shredded, preserved, fried or sliced into slippery noodles, this staple of Asian cooking, invented in China 2,000 years ago, has a lot to offer.

headline: This Elephant Taught Herself to Peel Bananas
abstract: An elephant at the Berlin Zoo can use her trunk to peel bananas, an unusual behavior she engages in only when conditions are ripe.
lead_paragraph: Pang Pha is an elephant of discriminating taste. Offer her a yellow or green banana and she will hoover it up whole, peel and all. Proffer a brown banana, and she is likely to turn her long nose up at it, casually tossing it aside.

headline: Not Picassos, but Still Precious: Museums Return Silver Lost to the Nazis
abstract: Some German institutions have begun to give back cups, candlesticks, teapots and other items of crafted silver that Jews were forced to surrender during the reign of the Third Reich.
lead_paragraph: It was noon on Nov. 10, 1938, when Nazi officers came to the door of William Bergman’s Munich home, arrested him for being a Jew and shipped him off to the Dachau concentration camp, about a 30-minute drive away.

headline: Mickey Bars, Turkey Legs and the Obsession With Disney Food
abstract: A fascination with the theme parks’ cuisine has spawned fan websites and snagged our critic, who has a Disney back story of her own.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The strawberry Dole Whip sundae at Disneyland, in its first minute or so of life, looks perfect. Billowed with fresh fruit and a syrupy drizzle, veiled with tender cake crumbs, it has the dazzling color and softly drooping tip of a cartoon dessert.

headline: Police Respond to Mass Shooting at a Louisville Bank
abstract: In video from the scene, a series of gunshots can be heard, as well as a man yelling, “Active shooter at the bank.”
lead_paragraph: In video from the scene, a series of gunshots can be heard, as well as a man yelling, “Active shooter at the bank.”

headline: Met Museum Commissions to Bring Contemporary Art Front and Center
abstract: With a new wing years away, the Met will highlight cutting-edge art with Nairy Baghramian on its facade and Jacolby Satterwhite in the Great Hall.
lead_paragraph: For a contemporary artist, the facade of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the walls of its Great Hall are prime real estate for showing work, given the Met’s importance and the huge number of visitors it gets (more than 3.4 million in 2022).

headline: A Pianist Revisits His Youth, in Playful Fragments
abstract: In his new memoir, “Enough: Scenes From Childhood,” Stephen Hough recalls his artistic and sexual coming-of-age with a light touch.
lead_paragraph: On the cover of the book “Enough: Scenes From Childhood,” out this week from Faber & Faber, a young Stephen Hough sits at the piano, wearing a velvet jacket stitched with sequins and fake pearls. He’s dressed as Liberace.

headline: Exploiting Children in the Workplace
abstract: Readers respond to a guest essay about child labor. Also: Political scandals; “unconvictable” Trump; at a pool in Paris; A.I. as an aid for blind people.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Solange Curates Powerful Performances of Black Joy and Pain at BAM
abstract: Through Saint Heron, the musician brought Angélla Christie and the Clark Sisters for a night exploring Black religious music, and Linda Sharrock and Archie Shepp for a show that felt anything but safe.
lead_paragraph: When the alto saxophonist Angélla Christie strode onstage on Friday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, she was joined only by a piano player. But Christie, one of the more prominent instrumentalists in contemporary gospel, was at full throttle from the very first note — playing in high-gloss, reverb-drenched ostinatos — and within moments, the crowd had become her rhythm section, clapping along on every off-beat.

headline: Myriam Ullens, 70, Philanthropic Baroness, Is Killed
abstract: A stepson was held on charges of shooting her over family money. She started institutions in Belgium, Nepal and China, including a major museum in Beijing.
lead_paragraph: Myriam Ullens, a pastry chef who married a billionaire Belgian aristocrat and turned his fortune into a globe-spanning source of philanthropy, was fatally shot on March 29 in Ohain, a village in the Walloon Brabant province of central Belgium. She was 70.

headline: Lethal Surprises Hidden in the Grass: Russia’s Trip Wires and Land Mines
abstract: As Moscow’s troops set booby traps in forests, houses and backyards, finding them has become a dangerous art for Ukrainian soldiers.
lead_paragraph: With a practiced calm, a Ukrainian de-mining expert gingerly pushed aside stalks of dry grass, revealing a lethal surprise — a hand grenade rigged to a trip wire, waiting for someone to heedlessly step on it.

headline: After protests in Poland over Ukrainian grain supplies, Kyiv and Warsaw reach a deal.
abstract: Poland, Romania and Hungary, all of which border Ukraine and are members of the European Union, have struggled with a glut of grain and other Ukrainian agricultural products since last year.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Poland and Ukraine have found what they say is a solution to an influx of Ukrainian grain that has infuriated Polish farmers, an issue that cast a shadow over the two neighbors’ close military and political cooperation against Russia.

headline: Justice Dept. Recently Looked Into Twitter, Lawsuit Says
abstract: The focus of the inquiry was unclear, but several former executives said they had racked up more than $1 million in expenses dealing with it and other legal issues.
lead_paragraph: A lawsuit filed on Monday by several former Twitter executives said they had personally spent more than $1 million on legal expenses related to shareholder lawsuits and several government investigations, including an inquiry by the Justice Department.

headline: Revised Plan for Justice System in Mississippi Capital Leaves Same Bitter Divide
abstract: A new plan for overhauling the police and courts imposed by the mostly white Mississippi Legislature received a cold response in the mostly Black capital of Jackson.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, Mississippi’s overwhelmingly white and Republican Legislature has had an often heated debate over the relationship with its overwhelmingly Black and Democratic capital city, one that reflects the national differences over race and politics writ large.

headline: Hochul Names a New Candidate to Become New York’s Top Judge
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul’s choice of Rowan D. Wilson, who already serves on the highest court, the Court of Appeals, might soothe left-leaning Democrats who spurned her previous pick.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, N.Y. — Gov. Kathy Hochul announced a new, left-leaning nominee to lead New York’s highest court, bringing one of Albany’s most divisive intraparty clashes closer to a resolution nearly two months after state lawmakers rejected the governor’s original choice.

headline: Italy’s Coast Guard Rescues Hundreds of Migrants in ‘Chaotic’ Few Days at Sea
abstract: About 2,000 people have been rescued since Friday, and ships were dispatched to help boats carrying 1,200 more on Monday as disquiet grows about the high numbers undertaking the risky crossing.
lead_paragraph: The Italian Coast Guard said on Monday that it had dispatched rescue operations for two overcrowded boats, carrying a total of about 1,200 migrants, in the Mediterranean Sea, capping a busy few days for the service and fueling concern about the volume of people attempting the dangerous crossing from Africa to Europe.

headline: Drug Company Leaders Condemn Ruling Invalidating F.D.A.’s Approval of Abortion Pill
abstract: More than 400 executives said that the decision ignored both scientific and legal precedent and that, if the ruling stood, it would create uncertainty for the pharmaceutical and biotech industries.
lead_paragraph: The pharmaceutical industry plunged into a legal showdown over the abortion pill mifepristone on Monday, issuing a scorching condemnation of a ruling by a federal judge that invalidated the Food and Drug Administration’s approval of the drug and calling for the decision to be reversed.

headline: Shelter-in-Place Order Lifted in Tacoma, Wash., Area Days After Vessel Fire
abstract: A fishing boat carrying fuel and Freon caught fire on Saturday, raising concerns about smoky conditions in nearby cities.
lead_paragraph: A shelter-in-place order for residents in the Tacoma, Wash., region was lifted on Monday, two days after a fishing vessel caught fire in the Puget Sound area, sending thick smoke into the air and diverting maritime traffic, the authorities said.

headline: Trump Appeals Decision Forcing Pence to Testify to Jan. 6 Grand Jury
abstract: The appeal seeks to narrow the scope of testimony that former Vice President Mike Pence can provide the grand jury investigating former President Donald Trump’s efforts to stay in power.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump asked a federal appeals court on Monday to narrow the scope of the testimony that former Vice President Mike Pence has to give a grand jury investigating Mr. Trump’s efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 election, according to a person familiar with the matter.

headline: Trump Ignores Deadline for Personal Financial Disclosure to F.E.C.
abstract: The disclosure will eventually provide the first look at the former president’s businesses since leaving the White House.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has a minor addition to his mounting pile of legal challenges after he failed to meet the deadline to disclose his personal financial holdings.

headline: R.I.P., W.F.H.? Not So Fast.
abstract: Working from home isn’t as common as at the pandemic’s start, but experts agree it’s here to stay.
lead_paragraph: When the Covid-19 pandemic shut down the U.S. economy three years ago, workers and their employers adjusted astonishingly well to what came to be called W.F.H. — work from home. Workers liked working from home for the most part, but many employers were cool toward it, and ever since the threat of the virus waned, they have been trying to get their people to R.T.O. — return to office.

headline: Spelling Bee Buddy: Personalized Hints That Update as You Play
abstract: Customized hints that update based on your progress in today’s puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Customized hints that update based on your progress in today’s puzzle.

headline: Introducing Spelling Bee Buddy: Your Personalized Daily Bee Helper
abstract: It will offer customized hints, but only if you want them.
lead_paragraph: Spelling Bee Buddy is a new interactive tool for Spelling Bee players that provides real-time personalized hints and analysis based on your progress throughout the day.

headline: Expelled Democratic Lawmaker Is Sworn Back in to Tennessee House
abstract: The move to reappoint Representative Justin Jones was a swift rebuke to the Republican supermajority over its decision to expel him and another lawmaker for leading a gun control protest.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Justin Jones, one of the two Black Democrats expelled from the Tennessee House of Representatives for leading a gun control protest on the House floor, was sworn back in to his seat on Monday in a swift rebuke to the state’s Republican supermajority.

headline: Charges Filed Against Mother of 6-Year-Old Who Shot a Teacher
abstract: Prosecutors had previously decided not to charge the boy, a first grader who took the gun to his Newport News, Va., elementary school in January.
lead_paragraph: The mother of a 6-year-old who shot his first-grade teacher in a Virginia classroom faces criminal charges of neglect and endangerment, the authorities said on Monday, the latest development in a case that stunned the community and brought a new level of concern to the charged debate over guns and school safety.

headline: Papaya King’s Reign Continues Just Across the Street
abstract: The Upper East Side fixture makes a short move, Murray’s Cheese Shop serves up cacio e pepe mac and cheese, and more.
lead_paragraph: Papaya King, the Upper East Side fixture known for its hot dogs and tropical fruit juices, is moving to a new location, across the street from its longstanding spot on the corner of 86th Street and Third Avenue. The manager, Mohammed Alam, said there is no firm opening date, but they hope to open in the next two weeks. This seemingly ends a chapter in a long saga between the owners of the restaurant and Extell Development, a luxury apartment developer, which plans to demolish the one-story commercial building the hot dog restaurant called home for decades. Extell purchased the lot last summer for $21 million. The restaurant’s founder, Gus Poulos, was a Greek immigrant who started the business as a juice stand in Brooklyn called Hawaiian Tropical Drinks. He opened Papaya King on the Upper East Side in the late 1940s and added hot dogs to the menu. Relations between Extell, the restaurant’s former landlord, and its current owner were tense and had been tied up in litigation since 2020. CHRISTINA MORALES

headline: A Growing W.N.B.A. Still Boxes Out Some Personalities
abstract: Ahead of the W.N.B.A. draft, women’s basketball remains troubled by racial disparities in how its stars are showcased.
lead_paragraph: Aliyah Boston, one of the most dominant and decorated players in women’s college basketball, was selected with the top pick in the W.N.B.A. draft Monday night.

headline: Taylor Swift Fans Grapple With Breakup Reports
abstract: After “Entertainment Tonight” and People published stories reporting that the singer’s relationship with Joe Alwyn was over, many Swifties went online to vent their feelings.
lead_paragraph: To quote Taylor Swift’s own lyrics, “The rumors are terrible and cruel, but honey most of them are true.”

headline: Netanyahu Reverses Firing of Israeli Defense Minister
abstract: Yoav Gallant was dismissed last month after expressing concern about the pace of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s judicial overhaul plan.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel announced on Monday night that he had reversed his decision to fire Defense Minister Yoav Gallant, 15 days after Mr. Gallant was nominally dismissed for criticizing the pace of the government’s contentious plan to overhaul Israel’s justice system.

headline: Jennifer Muller, Choreographer Whose Dances Told Human Tales, Dies at 78
abstract: In a postmodern era dominated by minimalism and conceptual themes, her work focused on emotion and storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Muller, a prolific choreographer and dancer whose humanistic works emphasized emotion and storytelling in an era when minimalism and conceptual themes prevailed, died on March 29 at her home in Jersey City, N.J. She was 78.

headline: The State Department declares Evan Gershkovich ‘wrongfully detained’ by Russia.
abstract: The finding means that the U.S. government sees the Wall Street Journal reporter as the equivalent of a political hostage.
lead_paragraph: The State Department on Monday designated Evan Gershkovich, the Wall Street Journal reporter arrested in Russia and charged with espionage earlier this month, as “wrongfully detained,” a finding that means the U.S. government sees him as the equivalent of a political hostage and reflects its belief that the charges are fabricated.

headline: Michael Lerner, Actor Seen in ‘Elf’ and ‘Barton Fink,’ Dies at 81
abstract: “I am a chameleon,” Mr. Lerner, who was nominated for a supporting-actor Oscar in 1992, said of his long career as a character actor in movies and television.
lead_paragraph: Michael Lerner, a veteran character actor whose dozens of film and television credits included small but memorable roles in “Barton Fink” and “Elf,” died on Saturday at a hospital in Burbank, Calif. He was 81.

headline: Al Jaffee, Inventive Cartoonist at Mad Magazine, Dies at 102
abstract: For 55 years he created the fold-in (as opposed to, say, Playboy’s fold-out), giving readers a satirical double-take on whatever was going on in the news.
lead_paragraph: Al Jaffee, a cartoonist who folded in when the trend in magazine publishing was to fold out, thereby creating one of Mad magazine’s most recognizable and enduring features, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 102.

headline: What Is Discord, the Social App Where Leaked Pentagon Documents Were Found?
abstract: Discord gained popularity among gamers. But as it has become mainstream, it has run into controversy over the past few years.
lead_paragraph: Discord, the eight-year-old social media and messaging platform popular among young people and video game players that has increasingly become a mainstream part of the internet, has once again run into controversy.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: China’s Display of Force Around Taiwan
abstract: Also, President Biden prepares to visit Northern Ireland and Ireland.
lead_paragraph: China sent record numbers of military aircraft, naval ships and an aircraft carrier near Taiwan yesterday on the final day of military exercises. The spectacle capped three days of drills designed to put pressure on the self-governed island.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What does ‘wrongfully detained’ mean?
abstract: Evan Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, is the latest American to bear the designation, which indicates that the U.S. government sees him as the equivalent of a political hostage.
lead_paragraph: The State Department on Monday said that Evan Gershkovich, a Wall Street Journal reporter arrested in Russia last month and charged with espionage, was “wrongfully detained,” a designation that indicates that the U.S. government sees him as the equivalent of a political hostage and reflects its belief that the charges are fabricated.

headline: Nashville Council Returns Justin Jones to Tennessee House
abstract: Within an hour of the Metropolitan Nashville Council unanimously voting to temporarily appoint Justin Jones back to the seat, the young lawmaker had returned to take his place in the Republican-controlled legislature.
lead_paragraph: Within an hour of the Metropolitan Nashville Council unanimously voting to temporarily appoint Justin Jones back to the seat, the young lawmaker had returned to take his place in the Republican-controlled legislature.

headline: Senate Judiciary Committee Promises Supreme Court Ethics Hearing
abstract: Democrats on the panel wrote to the chief justice, urging an investigation into gifts and travel provided to Justice Clarence Thomas.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democratic members of the Senate Judiciary Committee on Monday promised a hearing looking into the Supreme Court’s ethical standards and urged Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. to investigate Justice Clarence Thomas’s undisclosed acceptance of gifts and luxurious excursions from a wealthy businessman and Republican donor.

headline: What Do Peace Talks in Yemen Mean for Its 8-Year War?
abstract: The surprise rapprochement between Saudi Arabia and Iran, whose rivalry fueled the war, has raised a glimmer of hope for a breakthrough in resolving one of the world’s worst crises.
lead_paragraph: After eight years of crushing civil war in Yemen, where hundreds of thousands of people have died of violence and hunger, a new round of talks this week has raised a glimmer of hope for a breakthrough in one of the world’s worst humanitarian crises.

headline: A Holy Day for Hat People
abstract: Fedoras! Fascinators! Flower crowns! At the Easter Parade in Manhattan, elaborate headpieces put an exclamation point on celebrants’ style.
lead_paragraph: Milling around in the crowd at the Easter Parade and Easter Bonnet Festival on Sunday, it did not take long to deduce that many had come for the same reason: the hats.

headline: The Meaning of an Awesome Employment Report
abstract: This is the best job market in a generation.
lead_paragraph: Americans, they said, just don’t want to work. Socialism has made them lazy. They’d rather play video games. They don’t have the skills required by a 21st-century economy. High unemployment is “structural” and can’t be solved with monetary and fiscal stimulus.

headline: The N.B.A. Was Redesigned for Drama, and It’s Working
abstract: The last day of the regular season saw flashes of brilliance from the best teams, punches thrown and disappointing defeats.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A.’s Western Conference has been a confusing mash of disarray this season, with few teams seeming capable of separating themselves and the rest mired in a chaos borne of some combination of injuries, disillusion and malaise.

headline: W.N.B.A. Draft: Aliyah Boston Goes No. 1 to Indiana Fever
abstract: Boston, a senior forward from the University of South Carolina, was the second-ever top pick from her college.
lead_paragraph: When Aliyah Boston was 12 years old, she took a 1,700-mile journey with her sister to their aunt’s home in Massachusetts from the U.S. Virgin Islands, hoping to become a good enough basketball player to go to college for free and maybe one day make it to the W.N.B.A.

headline: Clues Left Online Might Aid Leak Investigation, Officials Say
abstract: A large number of people potentially had access to the Pentagon intelligence documents posted on social media.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A surprisingly large number of people potentially had access to the Pentagon intelligence documents leaked on a social media site in early March, but clues left online may help investigators narrow down the pool of possible suspects relatively quickly, U.S. officials said on Monday.

headline: Abortion Pill Ruling May Face Headwinds at the Supreme Court
abstract: Even justices hostile to abortion and the administrative state may think twice, legal scholars said, before embracing a Texas judge’s decision.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The conservative legal movement has long had two key goals: to limit access to abortion and to restrict the authority of administrative agencies.

headline: The Cold Truth at the Heart of ‘Succession,’ Lying on an Airplane Floor
abstract: The comforting fantasy that the rich are miserable.
lead_paragraph: One dark pleasure of HBO’s “Succession” is that, in a plutocratic age, it makes having an obscene fortune look like a curse. This worldview is reflected in the relentless corporate blandness of its aesthetic, one that mostly eschews wealth porn for a soulless series of S.U.V. back seats, badly lit conference rooms, private airport terminals and generic lofts. (The show’s cinematographer once described it as “the anti-‘Billions,’” referring to the Showtime series that regularly dwells on the rarefied indulgences of its hedge fund antiheroes.) But the perspective is reflected even more in the show’s emotional austerity, its vision of a world in which love is almost always a weakness. Despite the extreme affluence, there is not a single person in “Succession” worth envying.

headline: Two Young People Killed in E-Bike Fire in Queens
abstract: The bike’s battery was being charged near the front door of the apartment building when the blaze ignited and quickly spread.
lead_paragraph: Two young people were killed in “an explosion of fire” caused by an e-bike that was being charged near the front door of an apartment building in the Astoria neighborhood in Queens on Monday afternoon, New York City fire officials said. It was the latest in a series of deadly blazes caused by e-bike batteries.

headline: House Panel Plans Manhattan Hearing. Bragg Calls It a ‘Political Stunt.’
abstract: The Republican-led Judiciary Committee hopes to tarnish the Democratic prosecutor who is leading the criminal case against former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: The Republican-led House Judiciary Committee said on Monday that it would hold a hearing in Manhattan on what it called the “pro-crime” policies of the borough’s district attorney, Alvin L. Bragg, a Democrat who is leading the criminal prosecution of former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: What Happened to America? We Asked 12 People in Their 70s and 80s.
abstract: The participants discuss aging, ageism and life in America after the age of 65.
lead_paragraph: The participants discuss aging, ageism and life in America after the age of 65.

headline: For Biden, an Era When Treaties Are More Likely to Be Broken Than Brokered
abstract: The president’s trip to Northern Ireland will mark the 25th anniversary of the Good Friday Agreement, which ended decades of violence. But such breakthroughs are harder to achieve in today’s fractious world.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden leaves on Tuesday for Northern Ireland to mark the 25th anniversary of the Good Friday Agreement, which ended decades of sectarian violence. But the commemoration also serves as an unspoken reminder that such diplomatic breakthroughs have become a thing of the past.

abstract: Della shreds a witness in court. The prosecution shreds Perry’s credibility.
lead_paragraph: I can’t remember the last time I shouted at the screen as much as I did during this episode of “Perry Mason.” I’m not kidding: I was hooting and hollering for what seemed like half the duration of this week’s installment. It didn’t work out as well as I’d hoped in the end, of course. But in the meantime? What a rush!

headline: Review: ‘White Girl in Danger’ Flips the Script on Soap Operas

lead_paragraph: What comes to mind when you think of soap operas? Amnesia, murders, cliffhangers, catfights?

headline: 17 Trees That Planters Hope Will Grow in Brooklyn
abstract: Big oaks and sweetgums have been moved into a former sugar factory, to make it a more inviting space for prospective tenants and their employees.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll find out what 17 big, heavy trees are doing indoors in Brooklyn. We’ll also look at a City Council bill to ban the sale of guinea pigs in pet stores, which comes up for a vote today.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: The investigation into leaked Ukraine war documents.
lead_paragraph: As many as thousands of U.S. officials have the security clearances needed to gain access to documents that were leaked last month, but clues left online may help investigators narrow down the pool of possible suspects, U.S. officials said. It is not only unclear who is responsible, but also why and what kind of damage the release of the material may have done.

headline: He’s a Brutal Dictator, and One of the West’s Best Friends
abstract: Paul Kagame has reduced Rwanda to tyranny.
lead_paragraph: His grip on power is nearly unassailable. Since becoming president over two decades ago, he has extended constitutional term limits, shut down the free press and clamped down on dissent. Reporters have been driven into exile, even killed; opposition figures have been imprisoned or found dead. His country has been reduced to tyranny.

headline: Word of the Day: insufferable
abstract: This word has appeared in 37 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word insufferable has appeared in 37 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 6 in “She Is Africa’s First Heat Officer. Can She Make Her City Livable?” by Elian Peltier:

headline: Stephen Colbert Isn’t Fazed by the News About Clarence Thomas
abstract: “‘Wow, I can’t believe Clarence Thomas did something inappropriate,’ said a woolly mammoth reanimated after being frozen in the Siberian permafrost,” Colbert joked.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: These Devices Save Lives, but Almost Nobody Has One at Home
abstract: While researchers are divided over whether more people should have automated external defibrillators at home, those who have used one have no doubts.
lead_paragraph: On the evening of Jan. 15, 2021, in a remote Arizona desert town, Christine Benton saved a life.

headline: Can Intelligence Be Separated From the Body?
abstract: Some researchers question whether A.I. can be truly intelligent without a body to interact with and learn from the physical world.
lead_paragraph: What is the relationship between mind and body?

headline: TikTok Dances
abstract: Have you ever learned choreography from a TikTok influencer? Participated in a dance challenge?
lead_paragraph: Are you a fan of TikTok dance? If so, who are your favorite artists? Have you ever learned choreography from a TikTok influencer? Participated in a dance challenge?

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: The Direct Effects and Existential Dread Created by Gun Violence
abstract: Christina Caron, a reporter for the Well section of The New York Times, asked readers how mass shootings had affected them. More than 600 people responded.
lead_paragraph: As of mid-April, there have been at least 145 mass shootings in the United States in 2023, according to the Gun Violence Archive, a nonprofit research group that tracks gun violence. (The group defines a mass shooting as one in which at least four people are killed or injured.) And mass shootings represent just a small fraction of shootings nationwide. How has this pervasive violence affected our mental states or changed the way we live?

headline: In China, Young People Ditch Prestige Jobs for Manual Labor
abstract: Some people who’ve walked away from China’s grueling corporate culture say it’s worth the financial sacrifice. “I was tired of living like that,” one said.
lead_paragraph: By the usual measures, Loretta Liu had it made. She graduated in 2018 from one of China’s top universities, rented an apartment in the glamorous city of Shenzhen, and had been hired as a visual designer at a series of high-flying companies, even as youth unemployment in China was reaching record highs.

headline: Automakers Face Test in Reaching U.S. Target for Electric Vehicles
abstract: New federal rules are expected to speed the transition to E.V.s, a shift that car companies have embraced but will be challenged to carry out.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration’s plan to accelerate the adoption of electric vehicles — reaching a two-thirds share of new cars in less than a decade — pushes automakers further in a direction they have already been going. But meeting the new timetable will be a challenge.

headline: What Pop Culture Moments Define the Covid Era?
abstract: Tell us the shows, movies, songs, podcasts, books, games or other activities that you think capture this moment in time.
lead_paragraph: It has been three years since the World Health Organization declared the spread of Covid-19 a pandemic, and we’re just starting to see how it is “not just a crisis of public health but also a distinct cultural era,” writes the Times Opinion section.

headline: Leaked Documents and Accusations of U.S. Spying Spark Outrage in Seoul
abstract: The reaction to the leak in South Korea is perhaps the strongest so far as the Biden administration scrambles to contain the damage from apparent spying on allies.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — Opposition lawmakers in South Korea criticized the leaked Pentagon documents as a major security breach and possible evidence of U.S. spying as the government of President Yoon Suk Yeol on Tuesday sought to downplay the disclosures and defend Seoul’s alliance with Washington.

headline: The Great American Labor Trap
abstract: We made this video for the three people who can end an absurd workplace nightmare for millions of Americans.
lead_paragraph: We made this video for the three people who can end an absurd workplace nightmare for millions of Americans.

headline: The Great American Labor Trap
abstract: We made this video for the three people who can end an absurd workplace nightmare for millions of Americans.
lead_paragraph: If you have a steady job in the United States, there’s a good chance you are bound by an employment contract that sets the terms of your work, including hours, salary and benefits. But the contract’s reach may not be limited to that job. It may also contain language that puts restrictions on your life even after you leave that job.

headline: The Picaresque Life of an 18th-Century Black English Polymath
abstract: Born into slavery, Charles Ignatius Sancho became a writer, composer, merchant and voter. In a winning first novel, Paterson Joseph conjures his voice and his world.
lead_paragraph: The privations and polymathy that marked the life of Charles Ignatius Sancho (1729?-80) make him an obvious subject for biography. He was a man born into slavery who became a lord’s valet, a writer, a composer of music, a gambler, a merchant and possibly the first Black man to vote in a British general election. And yet, even the collection of exuberant letters published shortly after Sancho’s death cannot make up for a dearth of archival evidence. In a brief, useful life released last year, Simon Webb had to fall back on speculative phrasing (“may have been,” “might have thought”) to paper over the gaps.

headline: Hollywood’s Newest Stars? Nike, BlackBerry and Cheetos.
abstract: A new spate of films stars not people but consumer products.
lead_paragraph: Your standard-issue Hollywood biopics foreground people caught in the wheels of history. We meet titans of industry, genius mathematicians, brave astronauts and dogged journalists. We hear stories of fearless, unyielding figures whose visions changed the world. Some, like presidents and generals, already know their own importance; others still think they’re ordinary. But the stories generally revolve around people and events, showing us how laws were changed, wars won, villains defeated.

headline: What We Know About the Louisville, Ky., Bank Shooting
abstract: The gunman told at least one person that he was suicidal before the rampage that killed five people, and on Wednesday the police released 911 calls that shed more light on the harrowing attack.
lead_paragraph: Five people were killed and eight others wounded on Monday after a 25-year-old man opened fire at a bank in downtown Louisville, Ky., where he worked. The gunman, who used an AR-15-style rifle and livestreamed the attack, was killed by the police after exchanging fire with them.

headline: The Diabetes Drug That Could Overshadow Ozempic
abstract: Demand is mounting for Mounjaro — though like some other trendy medications, it has yet to be approved for weight loss.
lead_paragraph: Over the last year, the injectable diabetes medication Ozempic steamrollered through TikTok, talk shows and tabloids as people raved about using it off-label to lose weight. Then the hype intensified this fall around Wegovy, a similar medication approved for weight management.

headline: Mathletes and Poets: Allies at Last!
abstract: In “Once Upon a Prime,” Sarah Hart explores the surprisingly deep relationship between mathematics and literature.
lead_paragraph: C.P. Snow opens a famed 1959 essay, “The Two Cultures,” with an anecdote about a dinner at Cambridge, during which a visiting historian attempted to make conversation with the men on either side of him, only to be met with bemused grunts. The scholar’s host quickly set him at ease, explaining, “Oh, those are mathematicians! We never talk to them.”

headline: What I Learned Dogsitting for New York City’s Opulent Elite
abstract: In a city of yawning class inequality, some side hustles let you glimpse how the other half lives.
lead_paragraph: Atop a hulking Manhattan skyscraper, there’s this gorgeous, sterile apartment that costs upward of $20,000 a month in rent. The only real sign of life in the place is a prodigiously large stash of Hot Cheetos hidden in a pantry. I know all this because, first, I’ve been there, and second, because I am endlessly nosy. I was tasked with caring for one of its residents, a shiba inu, while its owner was away — an absence that created an intestinal disturbance in the poor dog, such that a third of my time in the apartment was spent soaping goopy excrement out from under my fingernails. But this seemed like a fair enough price to pay for the opportunity to rattle open a wealthy stranger’s kitchen cabinets and slip, for a little while, into a life foreign to mine.

headline: Why I Keep My Eyes — and My Mind — on the South
abstract: To understand where the country is headed, look to the South.
lead_paragraph: While the world was watching the former president surrender to authorities in a New York City courthouse last week, I was watching Nashville and Raleigh. I live in North Carolina, and these two seats of government and capitals in bordering Southern states have been roiled with political unrest in the shadow of the Donald Trump Show.

headline: What Biden’s Top A.I. Thinker Concluded We Should Do
abstract: Alondra Nelson discusses how the public could benefit from an Artificial Intelligence Bill of Rights.
lead_paragraph: In October, the White House released a 70-plus-page document called the “Blueprint for an A.I. Bill of Rights.” The document’s ambition was sweeping. It called for the right for individuals to “opt out” from automated systems in favor of human ones, the right to a clear explanation as to why a given A.I. system made the decision it did, and the right for the public to give input on how A.I. systems are developed and deployed.

headline: Shadow of Abuse Scandal Hangs Over a World Cup Soccer Team
abstract: Vera Pauw was accused of body-shaming players while coaching in the N.W.S.L. Sinead Farrelly helped expose abuse in the league. The two are now working together for Ireland.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Texas — As Ireland prepares for its first Women’s World Cup, its coach and a newly included midfielder find themselves on opposite sides of an abuse scandal that has roiled soccer in the United States. But their separate conflicts have fused into a tentative and pragmatic alliance.

headline: Record Executive’s Art Collection to Be Auctioned at Sotheby’s in May
abstract: Mo Ostin, a force in the music industry who died in August, was also an art enthusiast whose major works include Magritte, Basquiat and Twombly.
lead_paragraph: Publicly, Mo Ostin was a powerful executive in the music industry for almost 50 years who worked with some of the most respected musicians of the 20th century — Frank Sinatra, Jimi Hendrix, Madonna, Neil Young — before his death in August at age 95.

headline: He Enslaved Hundreds of People, but Freed Them in His Will. Maybe.
abstract: A contested deathbed declaration; multiple, contradictory wills; allegations of insanity: These are the issues at the heart of “A Madman’s Will,” Gregory May’s account of a Virginia statesman who held men and women in bondage during his lifetime only to emancipate them as he lay dying.
lead_paragraph: Why would a notorious states’ rights defender of slavery, a United States congressman and one of the most prolific enslavers in the country, choose to emancipate every one of the people he held in bondage, in one of the largest single acts of manumission in the nation’s history? Was he insane? Just as important, were his people and his nation prepared to accept his choice and its consequences? These are some of the questions that made the enslaver’s final wishes such a sensation in its day and that propel Gregory May’s eye-opening and vigorously researched new book, “A Madman’s Will.”

headline: Pressured by Their Base on Abortion, Republicans Strain to Find a Way Forward
abstract: Some in the party are urging compromise, warning of dire electoral consequences for 2024, while other stances, on guns and gay rights, also risk turning off moderates.
lead_paragraph: Republican leaders have followed an emboldened base of conservative activists into what increasingly looks like a political cul-de-sac on the issue of abortion — a tightly confined absolutist position that has limited their options ahead of the 2024 election season, even as some in the party push for moderation.

headline: Clarence Thomas Is as Free as Ever to Treat His Seat Like a Winning Lottery Ticket
abstract: This is not how a republic should work.
lead_paragraph: We have Clarence Thomas to thank for the latest illustration of how the Supreme Court’s outsize power, isolation and virtual immunity from public pressure has made it a magnet for corruption and influence-peddling.

headline: Her Father Vanished. Years Later, Her Family Is Figuring Out How to Mourn.
abstract: In her second novel, “Life and Other Love Songs,” Anissa Gray explores memory and inheritance through a family that suffers an inexplicable loss.
lead_paragraph: How do you move on from a life interrupted? Grieve when a loved one is gone but not dead? Let go when there are endless questions and no answers? What precipitates and heals that kind of loss? These dilemmas propel Anissa Gray’s second novel, “Life and Other Love Songs.”

headline: Can Boracay Beat Overtourism?
abstract: Called one of the world’s best islands, the Philippine resort was closed by the government for six months and reopened with a cap on visitors. Now, with travelers coming back, will it continue to hold the line?
lead_paragraph: When the Philippine island of Boracay was in the rogues’ gallery of destinations marred by overtourism, large sections of its 2.5-mile main White Beach were jammed with thousands of visitors and long trains of beach beds and umbrellas. Fleets of boats motored up to the sand’s edge, and multitudes of peddlers sold trips and trinkets and gave massages, braided hair and applied henna tattoos right on the beach.

headline: ‘Succession’ and ‘Dr. Pimple Popper’ Together in New Warner Streaming App
abstract: The service, expected to be called Max, is meant to help the company compete more directly with Netflix and Disney.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, the media mogul David Zaslav said he had a plan to compete with the streaming titans Netflix and Disney: Combine the scripted entertainment of HBO Max with Discovery’s library of reality and unscripted series. The goal, he said in 2021, was to be “one of the top streaming companies in the world.”

headline: The R.T.O. Whisperers Have a Plan
abstract: A niche group of consultants is trying to get you back to the office. It’s not going too well.
lead_paragraph: Being the boss doesn’t mean you get exactly what you wish for. That’s what Craig Knoblock discovered when he tried to get his employees to come back to the office in the fall of 2021.

headline: U.S.-Born Children, Too, Were Separated From Parents at the Border
abstract: A government task force is tracking the fates of U.S. citizen children taken from migrant parents during the Trump administration. Some have spent years in foster care.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Trump administration intentionally separated thousands of migrant children from their parents at the southern border in the spring of 2018, an aggressive attempt to discourage family crossings that caused lasting trauma and drew widespread condemnation.

headline: 54 Years Ago, a Supreme Court Justice Was Forced to Quit for Behavior Arguably Less Egregious Than Thomas’s
abstract: Lawmakers from both parties urged him to resign.
lead_paragraph: There are two distressing aspects to the scandal of Justice Clarence Thomas’s years of accepting luxurious vacations and private jet trips from a billionaire, as revealed last week in a damning investigation by ProPublica.

headline: Getting a Brighter View During Milan Design Week
abstract: New experiments in lighting will be on display at the annual festival of furnishings and household objects.
lead_paragraph: This year, the biennial international lighting fair Euroluce, which runs from April 18 through April 23, will check into the fairgrounds at the edge of Milan and dazzle visitors with the latest innovations in this most revolutionary of design categories. New experiments in lighting will also sparkle at concurrent exhibitions like Alcova and in showrooms, courtyards and commandeered palaces in other parts of the Italian city.

headline: How to Improve the M.T.A.? Experts Offer Five Ideas.
abstract: The agency that runs New York City’s subway and buses has fewer riders and shaky finances. Experts have ideas for addressing the problems.
lead_paragraph: Even as New York returns to something close to prepandemic life, the city’s transit system remains mired in a crisis of decreased ridership and shaky finances.

headline: Even in Exile, Bob Baffert Is the King of the Sport of Kings
abstract: Baffert was barred from Triple Crown races after Medina Spirit tested positive for a prohibited drug at the 2021 Kentucky Derby. But owners keep sending him expensive horses — and he keeps winning.
lead_paragraph: ARCADIA, Calif.— As exiles go, Bob Baffert’s has been a comfortable one. Most mornings, the horse trainer who is barred from competing in the Kentucky Derby, can be found beneath the rouge-tipped San Gabriel Mountains, holding court at Clockers’ Corner, the open-air bistro at Santa Anita Park.

headline: Who Ya Gonna Call? Goosebusters.
abstract: Robert Young explains how the birds can be a menace and why Border collies are his star employees.
lead_paragraph: In 1998, Robert Young and his dog, Boomer, were visiting a golf course in New Jersey when a man asked Mr. Young for his business card.

headline: Plague, Passion, Beheadings and Bloody Coups
abstract: Seventeenth-century England comes thrillingly alive in Jonathan Healey’s energetic new history, “The Blazing World.”
lead_paragraph: Comfortable courtiers in early 17th-century England thanked God for their “gracious happy government.” “Never hath any kingdom or country been blessed with so flourishing an estate, and such a blessed condition,” Charles I’s Bishop of Durham declared. The country had been peaceful and prosperous, enjoying halcyon days at a time when the Thirty Years’ War racked much of continental Europe. Commerce and literature flourished under a benign monarchical regime, while promising colonies grew in the New World.

headline: Textiles Are Part of the Fabric of Milan Design Week
abstract: The annual festival of furnishings and household objects has several presentations involving cloth materials and techniques.
lead_paragraph: If it’s denim you like, you can check out the decommissioned church where the Dutch fashion brand G-Star has invited the designer Maarten Baas to produce a full-size airplane from the material. If your tastes in textiles fly higher, Hermès is showing a carpet by the French designer Pierre Charpin made with the exquisite, labor-intensive cordélie technique.

headline: As Mental Health Crisis Grows, More Doors Open to Care
abstract: Developers are working with health care providers to add psychiatric hospitals, addiction recovery centers and other behavioral health clinics.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic and its lockdowns accelerated a mental health crisis in the United States, leaving treatment providers racing to keep up with the growing demand for care.

headline: How Ukraine’s Power Grid Survived So Many Russian Bombings
abstract: Russia was determined to break Ukrainians’ will by plunging them into cold and darkness. Its failure, in the face of Ukrainian resilience, offers lessons as winter has released its icy grip.
lead_paragraph: Electric trams are running again in Kyiv, and electric scooters dot the sidewalks. With curfew extended to midnight, the streets are bright and buzzing. Portable generators, nearly impossible to find as they flew off the shelves in December, are being sold at half price.

headline: At Home With Jamila Norman
abstract: The urban farmer, who hosts the Magnolia Network series “Homegrown,” has a simple home-décor philosophy: “I don’t like buying new stuff.”
lead_paragraph: The urban farmer, who hosts the Magnolia Network series “Homegrown,” has a simple home-décor philosophy: “I don’t like buying new stuff.”

headline: Sex Abuse, Beatings and an Untouchable Mississippi Sheriff
abstract: As abuse allegations in a rural jail piled up, criminal inquiries dragged on or went nowhere. No one scrutinized how the sheriff ran his jail.
lead_paragraph: Terry Grassaree was dogged for years by questions about how he did his job as a law enforcement officer in Macon, Miss., a tiny, rural town near the state’s eastern border.

headline: An Urban Farmer and TV Host on Why She Recycles Almost Everything
abstract: Jamila Norman — a.k.a. Farmer J from the Magnolia Network series “Homegrown” — has a simple home-décor philosophy: “I don’t like buying new stuff.”
lead_paragraph: Jamila Norman has a few houseplants, for the record, all thriving, at her home in the West End neighborhood of Atlanta. But although she has room out back, there is no garden.

headline: ‘The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel’ Takes Its Final Curtsy
abstract: In its final season, the pioneering Amazon hit wanted to go out the way it came in: fabulously, in heels and with a dizzying words-to-minutes ratio.
lead_paragraph: On a morning in mid-October, on the set of the Amazon comedy “The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel,” set dressers readied the grimy Midtown office of Susie Myerson, the talent manager played with a newsboy cap and signature glare by Alex Borstein. An animal wrangler oversaw a flock of pigeons outside a false window as a scenic artist painted on their droppings. In a haze of herbal cigarette smoke, the actors — Borstein, Alfie Fuller and Rachel Brosnahan — ran the scene again, again, again, until the pauses vanished and the dialogue sang.

headline: New Ways to Take a Seat at Milan Design Week
abstract: Designers are showing off some of their latest works at the furniture fair.
lead_paragraph: Chairs are to furniture makers what bread is to bakers: a cultural staple that is harder to make than it looks. At Milan Design Week, which runs from April 18 through April 23, exhibitions of new seating will include a lounge chair called Tortello because of its resemblance to a piece of stuffed pasta; a reissued 44-year-old seat by the Polish-Brazilian designer Jorge Zalszupin, who was inspired by a kangaroo; and an experimental side chair that is built to decay.

headline: Inside Russia’s Crackdown on Dissent
abstract: How a social media post landed a 19-year-old on the Kremlin’s official terrorist list.
lead_paragraph: Days after Russia invaded Ukraine, the Kremlin made it a crime to oppose the war in public. Since then, it has waged a relentless campaign of repression, putting Russian citizens in jail for offenses as small as holding a poster or sharing a news article on social media.

headline: The Military’s Leaked Secrets
abstract: Officials are worried that leaked documents could damage U.S. operations around the world.
lead_paragraph: The recently leaked U.S. military documents aren’t just an embarrassment for American officials. They are also likely to have more tangible consequences: Ukraine is changing its battle plans against Russia in response to the leak, CNN reported yesterday.

headline: To Become Oscar Levant, Sean Hayes Revisited His First Role
abstract: Years before “Will & Grace,” Hayes was a classical pianist. In the new Broadway play “Good Night, Oscar,” he returns to the piano to portray a famously troubled musician and witty guest of late-night TV shows.
lead_paragraph: The version of Sean Hayes who arrived at a Midtown Manhattan rehearsal space on a Wednesday morning last month was the one everyone knows from his years as a television star on the series “Will & Grace” and as an entertainer. The effervescent Hayes tossed off a quip about the perceived snobbishness of the Hamptons. (“It’s like Shake Shack,” he said. “Anybody can go. It’s not that fancy.”) With similar ease, he sat at a piano and played a few measures of “Rhapsody in Blue.”

headline: Why Drugmakers’ Battle in Texas Is Such a Big Deal
abstract: The decision by a Texas judge to overturn F.D.A. approval for the abortion pill mifepristone could upend the pharmaceutical industry.
lead_paragraph: The decision by a judge in Texas to overturn F.D.A. approval for the abortion pill mifepristone could have consequences far beyond the fraught area of reproductive health, throwing the regulatory regime for medicines into disarray and potentially upending the business of drug making. The ruling to reverse a green light given more than 20 years ago has sparked a furious response from pharmaceutical executives, and the Biden administration is pushing for the decision to be blocked.

headline: During Ramadan, Palestinians Picnic in Aqsa Compound to Break Fast
abstract: A coveted Middle Eastern rice dish has become a social media star at Al Aqsa Mosque, even as tensions escalate at a site also revered by Jews.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — With under 30 minutes until sundown, Anas Shalodi hurried through the Old City’s covered souk carrying a large pot, hot off the stove and wrapped in a green prayer rug, zipping past others making their way to the mosque to break their daily Ramadan fast.

headline: What Should California’s Official State Food Be?
abstract: With so many options, state leaders have shied away from choosing just one.
lead_paragraph: In its nearly 173 years as a state, California has officially declared a state reptile, a state marine mammal, a state dinosaur, a state dance and a state tartan. The Golden State was even the first to name a state rock.

headline: I.M.F. Lowers Growth Outlook Amid Financial System Tremors
abstract: The International Monetary Fund says a painful slowdown, which could include a recession, has become a bigger risk for the global economy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The world economy faces the increasing risk of a painful slowdown amid worries about the global banking system and concerns that rising interest rates could force banks to curtail lending, the International Monetary Fund said on Tuesday.

headline: Airstrike in Rebel-Held Region of Myanmar Kills at Least 100
abstract: It was the junta’s deadliest attack since seizing power in 2021. As resistance forces have become better armed, the military has doubled down on its strategy of carrying out air raids and targeting civilians.
lead_paragraph: Myanmar’s military regime continued its relentless campaign of airstrikes on Tuesday by bombing a large gathering in rebel-held territory, killing at least 100 people in the junta’s deadliest attack since seizing power in a coup more than two years ago.

headline: Bitcoin Rally Continues, Gaining More Than 80% This Year
abstract: The cryptocurrency extended its gains after another big jump on Tuesday, topping $30,000 for the first time since June.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin is still the market’s runaway success story of the year. The cryptocurrency topped $30,000 on Tuesday for the first time since June.

headline: Formula 1 Driver Charles Leclerc Asks Fans to Stop Coming to His Home
abstract: Mr. Leclerc said on Instagram on Sunday that his address had become public and that fans had been gathering at his apartment asking for pictures and autographs.
lead_paragraph: A Ferrari Formula 1 driver in Monaco is drawing firm boundaries with overzealous fans who have shown up uninvited at his private residence, about a year after he was robbed while taking a selfie.

headline: Nation’s First Religious Charter School Could Be Coming to Oklahoma
abstract: If approved, the online Catholic school would be funded by taxpayer dollars, teeing up a high-profile constitutional battle.
lead_paragraph: An Oklahoma state education board is weighing whether to approve the nation’s first religious charter school this spring, potentially setting up a high-profile constitutional battle over whether taxpayer money can be used to directly fund religious schools.

headline: How I Transformed My 140-Square-Foot Queens Balcony Into a Garden Oasis
California Economy Is on Edge After Tech Layoffs and Studio Cutbacks
abstract: As recession fears persist, the troubles in major industries have hurt tax revenues, turning the state’s $100 billion surplus into a deficit.
lead_paragraph: California has often been at the country’s economic forefront. Now, as fears of a national recession continue to nag, the state is hoping not to lead the way there.

headline: Alison Goldfrapp Dials Up Her Own Disco Fantasy
abstract: The singer of the London duo Goldfrapp is going solo with “The Love Invention,” an album of dance music that reflects her craving for euphoria.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 25 years, the name Goldfrapp has represented the musical partnership between the singer Alison Goldfrapp and the keyboardist and producer Will Gregory.

headline: French Police Face Scrutiny for Heavy Hand During Pension Protests
abstract: An audio recording of officers threatening and intimidating young people has reignited a debate over harsh and discriminating tactics.
lead_paragraph: “I would gladly have broken your legs.”

headline: Chicago Will Host 2024 Democratic Convention as Party Returns to Midwest
abstract: For their flagship gathering, President Biden and Democrats chose a city in the heart of a battleground region, which had argued that it embodied the party’s liberal values.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and his party have selected Chicago to host the 2024 Democratic National Convention, elevating a large liberal city in the heart of the Midwest, a critical battleground region.

headline: Spring Cleaning Was Once Backbreaking Work. For Many, It Still Is.
abstract: In an earlier, dirtier era, a thorough post-winter scrubbing was a labor-intensive necessity. Today, the tradition lives on as an annual rite of purification and renewal.
lead_paragraph: It is a cold day in northeastern New Jersey, and Jessica Holoka is carefully taking inventory around the home she shares with her husband of 11 years. She is not planning to move, nor is she preparing for doomsday. She’s gearing up for her annual spring cleaning marathon, some three months away.

headline: Why Does My Neck Look So Much Older Than My Face?
abstract: Nora Ephron once wrote, “Our faces are lies and our necks are the truth.” What do skin experts have to say?
lead_paragraph: Q: Why does my neck look like it’s aging twice as fast as the rest of me, and what can I do about it?

headline: Sinema’s Senate Seat Draws First Major Republican Contender
abstract: Mark Lamb, a sheriff and an ally of former President Donald J. Trump, will run for the seat held by Kyrsten Sinema, a Democrat-turned-independent.
lead_paragraph: Mark Lamb, a right-wing sheriff and an ally of former President Donald J. Trump known for his policing of elections and his defiance of a pandemic lockdown, announced Tuesday that he would run for Senate in Arizona next year, a contest that could determine control of the closely divided chamber.

headline: A Second Drug Can Be Used on Its Own for Medication Abortion
abstract: The drug, misoprostol, was not part of a federal judge’s recent ruling invalidating the F.D.A. approval of the abortion pill mifepristone.
lead_paragraph: An order by a federal judge in Texas invalidating the approval of the abortion pill mifepristone did not apply to the second drug used in the typical two-medication abortion regimen, misoprostol.

headline: Is There Life After Influencing?
abstract: The internet personality Lee From America wanted to see what life was like as plain old Lee Tilghman. She’s not alone. But leaving behind lucrative brand partnerships and high follower counts is harder than it looks.
lead_paragraph: At her first full-time job since leaving influencing, the erstwhile smoothie-bowl virtuoso Lee Tilghman stunned a new co-worker with her enthusiasm for the 9-to-5 grind.

headline: ‘Covid Vortex Anxiety Opera’ Review: Gloom, Zoom and a New Bloom
abstract: The veteran performance artist Karen Finley leads the audience through the troubles that plagued New York City at the peak of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Restlessness, fear, despair, loneliness, exhaustion, worry, anomie: Remembering the peak of the pandemic in New York City, the performance artist Karen Finley takes the audience through a maelstrom of feelings in her new solo show, “Covid Vortex Anxiety Opera Kitty Kaleidoscope Disco.” That, of course, is after her grand entrance, wearing a white hazmat jumpsuit and a surgical mask zhuzhed-up with sequined fringe, she sashayed through the Laurie Beechman Theater to a mix of the disco classic “Don’t Leave Me This Way” and a chorus of pot-banging like the one that cheered frontline workers in 2020.

headline: Helping People of Color Find Their Footing in the Arts
abstract: As cultural institutions work to address their diversity problems, a new recruitment firm has a plan to make those changes last.

headline: Greywind, From Chef Behind Loring Place, Opens Near Hudson Yards
abstract: A spot offering coffee by day and noodles, dumplings and more by night in Long Island City, a lobster-based spinoff from the Seamore’s team, and a return for a fine-dining personality.
lead_paragraph: Dan Kluger, the former executive chef at ABC Kitchen who went on to open Loring Place and its pizza sideline, Washington Squares in Greenwich Village, is opening this restaurant and bakery just north of Hudson Yards. The executive chef, Caitlin Giamario, who worked with him at Loring Place, and the pastry chef, Jake Novick-Finder, from Gramercy Tavern, are in the kitchen. Mr. Kluger’s vegetable-forward approach, developed at ABC and furthered at Loring Place, is on full display here: focaccia with homemade ricotta, pea and asparagus fritters; mixed radishes with grapefruit and mint; sea bream with honshimeji mushrooms and sugar snaps; lumache pasta with Long Island duck and Swiss chard; and, from a busy rotisserie, a half chicken and a whole cauliflower. Amply windowed, the 58-seat dining room has some rustic elements, using natural wood, linen and bronze, and a wall covering showing gray clouds. Opening adjacent to the restaurant next month will be the Bakery at Greywind, selling housemade breads, pantry items, grab-and-go sandwiches and such, some of them laid on a farmhouse table with a view of the kitchen for breakfast and lunch. By night, it will become an eight-seat chef’s table with a tasting menu. Beverages focus on New York State producers. (Opens Wednesday)

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘What the Ukrainian Grandmothers Have Written’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: At my Ukrainian grandmother’s house in Chicago, circa 1970, Easter began right after Christmas. The aroma of burning candle, melting beeswax, vinegar dye and fresh coffee would wake me. Grandma would be sitting at her table, barefoot. In one hand she cradled an egg. In the other, she held a kistka, a wooden stylus dipped in wax. As she painted, Ukrainian flowers bloomed, musical scores played, golden wheat sprouted. Grandma translated her memories of home for me. Ukrainians call these eggs “pysanky,” from “pysaty," meaning “to write.” And oh, what the Ukrainian grandmothers have written — each and every springtime. — Karen Doornebos

headline: In Italy, a Home With Renaissance Frescoes and a Giant Mirrored Cube
abstract: By reimagining an apartment inside a storied palazzo, the designer Paola Moretti both preserved its history and gave it a bold new chapter.
lead_paragraph: Situated midway between Lake Garda and Lake Iseo, at the southern foot of the Italian alps, the city of Brescia is sleepy but handsomely built, its cobblestone lanes flanked by the occasional Roman ruin and a wealth of Renaissance-era palazzos. Among the most impressive of these is Palazzo Martinengo della Motella. Built in the Brescian Baroque style, its yellow-hued stone facade has large windows topped with dramatic pediments and a tall arched entryway carved with images of shields and of knights on horseback. The palazzo was constructed in the 15th century by its namesake family — “one of Brescia’s most aristocratic,” says the designer Paola Moretti, who in December 2020 was commissioned by an Italian art collector and her husband, the owner of a steel foundry, to reimagine the 5,000-square-foot second-floor apartment they’d recently purchased in the storied building.

headline: Inflation Cools Notably, but It’s a Long Road Back to Normal

headline: You Call This ‘Flexible Work’?
abstract: Labor fought for a long time to draw a bright line between work and home. It took almost no time at all to erase it.
lead_paragraph: Rush hour, lunch hour, happy hour — not so long ago, anyone who worked in Lower Manhattan could tell you what time it was. From 7 to 9 in the morning, men and women streamed toward their offices. Between 5 and 7 in the evening, they streamed home again, maybe stopping by a bar on the way. Then the pandemic hit. The office towers emptied out. Work went on, but from living rooms, dining rooms and bedrooms, over the internet. People had worked from home for years, but not on this scale. Before the pandemic, the rhythms of the day, at least for office workers, were mostly unchanged for a hundred years. But now the industrial-era social compact that governed how we experienced the working day for generations is breaking down. The terms of that compact are so familiar to us that we almost never name them: Labor should be measured by time, in hours and days; people should be paid the same amount for the same work; the day should be broken into periods of labor and leisure.

headline: My Son Was Addicted and Refused Treatment. We Needed More Options.

headline: Yotam Ottolenghi’s Top 10 Ingredients, in One Dish
abstract: After 20 years of tinkering with flavors, the chef makes his way back to the classic hits.
lead_paragraph: I’m still thinking about ingredients as friends. Last month it was cabbage, a complex friend, one of those mates who challenge me yet still manage to keep delivering and delighting. This time it’s other old friends I’m thinking about: the friends I sometimes take for granted but who are always there, who have always been there. I see now, though, that I’m inadvertently cooking with them as well. I say inadvertently because the list of ingredients in this month’s recipe pretty much happens to be a roll call of my Top 10 all-time favorites.

She hadn’t studied voice or movement. Her comfort was in the close-up, the medium shot. She knew how to make her face still and her voice quiet, and to let the camera do the rest. headline: My Husband Is Obese. Can I Refuse to Buy Him Fattening Snacks?
abstract: Eager not to participate in his husband’s junk-food habit, a reader hesitates to draw a line in the sand, stung by memories of disagreements over his spouse’s smoking.
lead_paragraph: My husband, 53, finally stopped smoking after 30 years — not because of my prodding or refusal to buy him cigarettes (which he called self-righteous), but because he could no longer breathe easily. That was two years ago. Since then, he has gained a lot of weight. He is now obese, according to the body mass index. He can’t even bend over to tie his shoes. His father and uncles died young, and I am worried about him. Still, he expects me to buy him highly processed junk food when I go shopping. I see this as a slow death wish, and I want no part in it. Is it reasonable for me to refuse to buy fattening, sugary treats without nutritional value? He can always buy them himself.
