abstract: It would take an eight- or 10-hour mini-series to deal with all the issues this documentary raises about the legal travails of Ehud Olmert, the former prime minister of Israel.
lead_paragraph: “Honorable Men: The Rise and Fall of Ehud Olmert” is a rare instance of a two-hour documentary that should have been an eight- or 10-hour mini-series, because it would take that long to clarify all the issues it raises, then present persuasive evidence. It concerns the legal travails of Ehud Olmert, the former prime minister of Israel. Olmert was under investigation for corruption when he announced his resignation in 2008. He ultimately went to prison in 2016 for bribery and obstruction of justice, but he has consistently denied doing anything criminal.

headline: Inspired by Jane Goodall, Onscreen and in Real Life
abstract: “Jane,” a new Apple TV+ series, tries to deliver Goodall’s environmental message through a young protagonist with insatiable curiosity.
lead_paragraph: Jane Goodall is not a fan of television. In her limited free time, this renowned British primatologist and environmentalist may occasionally watch a wildlife documentary by her friend David Attenborough, or, after a hard day, “something mindless,” as she said in a recent video interview.

headline: Tucker Carlson and Rupert Murdoch Were Right
abstract: The defamation case against Fox News reveals lies galore — and one scary truth.
lead_paragraph: If you missed the previous newsletter, you can read it here.

headline: F.B.I. Arrests National Guardsman in Leak of Classified Documents
abstract: Authorities say Jack Teixeira, a 21-year-old member of the Massachusetts Air National Guard, posted sensitive materials in an online chat group.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on the leak of classified intelligence documents.

headline: Should All States Have Aid in Dying Laws?
abstract: Readers cite stories of their own illness and that of a father and a beloved dog. Also: Long lives of humorists; baseball’s new look; protest songs.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Why Mary Quant Mattered
abstract: A salute to the British designer who made Sixties fashion swing.
lead_paragraph: Mary Quant was one of the best-known designers of the Swinging Sixties, a creative and commercial trailblazer who put London fashion on the world map.

headline: Biden Will Expand Health Care Access for DACA Immigrants
abstract: The DACA program has shielded hundreds of thousands of young adults from deportation, but they have not been able to access federal health insurance programs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Thursday said his administration would expand health care coverage for nearly 600,000 immigrants who were brought to the country as children and are protected from deportation.

headline: Two States Have Proposed Bans on Common Food Additives Linked to Health Concerns
abstract: Here’s what to know about the five chemicals, which most often show up in baked goods, candy and soda.
lead_paragraph: Newly proposed bills in California and New York are putting food additives — the chemicals manufacturers add to food to act as preservatives or to enhance color, texture or taste — under the microscope.

headline: Once Shocking, U.S. Spying on Its Allies Draws a Global Shrug
abstract: Compared with revelations in 2013 of mass surveillance by the National Security Agency, intelligence reports in a trove of recently leaked documents have resulted in limited outrage abroad.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The last time a trove of leaked documents exposed U.S. spying operations around the world, the reaction from allied governments was swift and severe.

headline: I Was Wrong About Cecily Brown
abstract: After panning an artist’s work 23 years ago, our veteran critic had a change of mind following three visits to “Death and the Maid” at the Met.
lead_paragraph: Artists change, but so do critics. Welcome to my turnaround — from a fairly negative first take on the work of the New York-based painter Cecily Brown, to a largely positive one. The shift in opinion — which, off and on, took the better part of 23 years — has been pushed over the finish line by “Cecily Brown: Death and the Maid,” a revelatory if crowded survey of around 20 paintings accompanied by 25 drawings and prints, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: How Silicon Valley Bank’s Failure Could Have Spread Far and Wide
abstract: New research suggests large parts of the country remain vulnerable to widespread bank failure in the event of a run on deposits.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government’s rescue of two failed banks last month has drawn criticism from some lawmakers and investors, who accuse the Biden administration and the Federal Reserve of bailing out wealthy customers in California and New York and sticking bank customers in Middle America with the bill.

headline: ‘Wild Life’ Review: Their Land Is Our Land
abstract: This documentary looks at the efforts of Kristine McDivitt Tompkins and Douglas Tompkins to preserve stretches of land in Argentina and Chile.
lead_paragraph: “Wild Life,” the latest eco-conscious documentary from the filmmakers Elizabeth Chai Vasarhelyi and Jimmy Chin (“Free Solo,” “Meru”) is a rickety helicopter tour of a fascinating marriage; nearly every scene makes you want to stop and explore in more detail. Things move fast with barely a beat of introduction. Those unfamiliar with the American philanthropists Kristine McDivitt Tompkins and her husband, Douglas Tompkins, may feel in the film’s opening minutes as disoriented as if they’ve been dropped in the wilderness. One catches on that the Tompkins purchased a lot of it: more than one million acres in Argentina and Chile, with the goal of gifting the land back as recognized national parks. The scale of the couple’s ambition teeters on the surreal. Asked in archival footage about a massive snow-flocked volcano on the horizon, Doug casually replies, “Yeah, that came with it.”

headline: Spotlighting Lady Macbeth’s Anguish: Can What’s Done Be Undone?
abstract: With radical adaptations of Verdi’s “Macbeth” and Puccini’s “Tosca,” Heartbeat Opera shows why it’s so vital to New York’s music scene.
lead_paragraph: Heartbeat Opera, a small, nimble company that has received its share of plaudits over the years, is on the cusp of a milestone birthday: its 10th. But there was a time recently when it didn’t know whether it could go on, its artistic director, Jacob Ashworth, said.

headline: I Made You a Meal Plan: 3 Not Sad Vegetarian Desk Lunches
abstract: These packable, practical recipes make lunch in the office just a little more exciting.
lead_paragraph: Before the pandemic, I went into an office five days a week and, supposedly, ate five lunches, most of them schlepped from home. I say supposedly because what those meals actually looked like is lost to lockdown-induced amnesia, replaced in my mind by a cacophony of trending TikTok sounds and a jumble of sourdough discard recipes.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: In my tentative forays into the world of BookTok (that’s book-themed TikTok, for those of you not on social media), I’ve found it a little hard to get my bearings: There’s a lot of infectious enthusiasm without much explanation or analysis, like a food package that’s missing the nutritional label. But that doesn’t mean there’s nothing of value to be found there. One of our suggested books this week comes from an author who has become an unlikely sensation on BookTok: the midcentury Japanese modernist Osamu Dazai, who wrote bleakly charming novels of existential despair before his death in 1948, at the age of 38. Were recommending “No Longer Human” — but first, read Andrew Martin’s essay about Dazai’s surprising social media stardom, which will give you all the context and nutritional data you need before approaching his work.

headline: ‘Passion’ Review: Friends Fall Apart
abstract: Belatedly making its U.S. debut, a 2008 film from Ryusuke Hamaguchi (“Drive My Car”) offers new insights into his abiding themes and sensibilities.
lead_paragraph: The director Ryusuke Hamaguchi’s latest film to premiere in U.S. theaters, “Passion,” is also one of his oldest — a confident if uneven new piece of 15-year-old context for one of cinema’s most acclaimed contemporary auteurs, whose “Drive My Car” last year earned the Oscar for best international feature.

headline: ‘Suzume’ Review: Gods, Spells and Instagram Posts
abstract: Makoto Shinkai’s latest animated film, about a girl who accidentally unleashes chaos over Japan, is at once mythical and thoroughly modern.
lead_paragraph: Makoto Shinkai is often praised as a descendant of the great Hayao Miyazaki for his masterly animation, and his latest film, “Suzume,” is no exception. The film speaks the same cinematic language, employing an ethereal, emotive color palette that enlivens every splash of water and blade of grass.

headline: Northern Ireland Shows How Hard It Is to End a Conflict
abstract: Northern Ireland had tremendous economic, political, and geographic advantages — but ending the Troubles still proved extremely difficult.
lead_paragraph: For decades, bombs and gunfire battered Belfast in a cycle of violence, known as the Troubles, that often seemed intractable — fueled by profound sectarian divisions and disputes over national identity that had no easy answer.

headline: When Is a Chair a Work of Art? A Bushwick Gallery Weighs In
abstract: In a furniture store, it’s a chair. In an art gallery, it’s a sculpture. But at International Objects in Brooklyn, it could be either, neither or both.
lead_paragraph: Picture an object with a horizontal surface, four legs and a back that rises along one edge. In a design showroom, or a furniture store, you’d call it a chair. On the display floor of a typical art gallery, it might be a sculpture. But at International Objects, a gallery that opened last month in Bushwick, Brooklyn, you’ll just have to ask.

headline: Has Affirmative Action Affected Your Life? We Want to Know.
abstract: The U.S. Supreme Court is considering ending race-conscious college admissions. We would like to hear from those whose lives have been touched by affirmative action.
lead_paragraph: Affirmative action has been a factor in college admissions decisions for decades. But it’s also been highly divisive, with states like Michigan, California and Washington banning it. Now affirmative action may go away altogether, as the high court considers cases, involving the University of North Carolina and Harvard, whose outcomes could profoundly change education in America.

headline: Dan Snyder Agrees to Sell Washington Commanders for $6 Billion
abstract: The N.F.L. team is on track to be sold for a record figure to a group led by Josh Harris, as investigations into sexual harassment claims and the team’s finances continue.
lead_paragraph: Josh Harris, an owner of the N.B.A.’s Philadelphia 76ers and the N.H.L.’s New Jersey Devils, agreed in principle to buy the Washington Commanders for a record $6 billion from Dan Snyder, the longtime owner of the team plagued by scandals that drew investigations from the N.F.L., Congress and other government agencies.

headline: ‘Star Trek: Picard’ Season 3, Episode 9 Recap: A Familiar Home
abstract: Home is where the ship is. In this week’s episode of “Picard,” the crew goes home.
lead_paragraph: If you’re going to lean into nostalgia, might as well go the whole way. If you’re going to bring back the old cast, bring back the old ship and the old villains, too.

headline: F.B.I. Feared Lawmaker Was Target of Foreign Intelligence Operation
abstract: An Illinois congressman whose name was used in a botched search of messages intercepted under an expiring surveillance law was working on trade talks with China at the time.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. was examining whether a foreign government had targeted a Republican lawmaker for an intelligence operation when the bureau conducted botched searches for information about him within messages swept up under an expiring warrantless surveillance law, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Law Enforcement Arrives at Home Where National Guardsman Resides
abstract: Law enforcement outside the home of a member of the intelligence wing of the Massachusetts Air National Guard.
lead_paragraph: Law enforcement outside the home of a member of the intelligence wing of the Massachusetts Air National Guard.

headline: As World Warms, Droughts Come On Faster, Study Finds
abstract: When rains fail unexpectedly, higher temperatures can more rapidly parch the ground, to devastating effect.
lead_paragraph: Flash droughts, the kind that arrive quickly and can lay waste to crops in a matter of weeks, are becoming more common and faster to develop around the world, and human-caused climate change is a major reason, a new scientific study has found.

headline: ‘Hilma’ Review: An Artist With Spirit
abstract: The film gets off to a rough start, but the director wins the audience back with his sincere connection to the artist Hilma af Klint.
lead_paragraph: Before production started on his guilelessly charming biopic “Hilma,” about the mystical artist Hilma af Klint, the Swedish filmmaker Lasse Hallstrom insisted on a séance to meet his subject. The painter, who died in 1944, believed that spirits guided her to create symbols which, when mounted together, would illustrate an energy map of the universe.

headline: ‘Television’ Review: Small-Screen Dreams
abstract: A new show at the Wild Project in Manhattan imagines how a small 1950s community weathers the arrival of the mass media age.
lead_paragraph: In “Television,” which opened Wednesday in a Thirdwing production at the Wild Project, the playwright and director Cameron Darwin Bossert once again zeros in on America’s most sprawling form of soft power: its homegrown media. It’s an uneven production, but one that continues Bossert’s examination of the clash between the country’s cozy self-image and its greedier actions.

headline: Biden Plans an Electric Vehicle Revolution. Now, the Hard Part.
abstract: The administration’s push to supercharge E.V. sales must now surmount resistance from manufacturers and consumers as well as likely legal challenges.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Aggressive rules proposed by the Biden administration to drastically speed up the country’s transition to electric vehicles, and significantly cut the auto pollution that is dangerously heating the planet, face several economic, logistical and legal challenges.

headline: ‘Renfield’ Review: Dracula, Worst Boss Ever
abstract: Nicholas Hoult stars as the long-suffering servant to Nicolas Cage’s Count Dracula in this highly absurd, entertaining comedy.
lead_paragraph: Count Dracula has been dead for so long and gone through so many iterations — exotic, satanic, romantic — that it’s almost surprising there’s any juice left in the thirsty old boy. Yet here he is again, resurrected by a glorious, vamping Nicolas Cage, swinging a cape, baring his fangs and stealing his every scene. The Count is playing second banana in “Renfield,” but he’s nevertheless a main attraction in this cheerfully disposable entertainment, which perfectly understands that sometimes all you want from a movie is 93 minutes of well-wrought absurdity.

headline: Broadway’s Newest Star? It’s Corn.
abstract: “Shucked” is the first Broadway show in which the breakout star is a vegetable, served up in a cornucopia of puns.
lead_paragraph: Outside the Nederlander Theater last Saturday night, hundreds of eager ticket holders lined up for the new Broadway musical “Shucked.” What exactly was the plot of the show? Few in the crowd seemed sure.

headline: How Tennessee Illustrates the Three Rules of MAGA
abstract: The G.O.P. effort to oust two state legislators completely backfired.
lead_paragraph: On Monday afternoon, a previously unknown 27-year-old Tennessee lawmaker named Justin Jones walked triumphantly up the steps of the Tennessee Capitol building and — surrounded by a crush of press and hundreds of supporters — took the oath of office to return to the Tennessee House of Representatives. The Tennessee legislature had expelled him from the chamber for his part in a protest that disrupted business on the House floor after the mass shooting at Covenant School in Nashville.

headline: Protests Continue in France Over Macron’s Pension Overhaul
abstract: Protesters across France demonstrated ahead of a constitutional ruling that may be the final legal obstacle in President Emmanuel Macron’s push to raise the legal retirement age to 64 from 62.
lead_paragraph: Protesters across France demonstrated ahead of a constitutional ruling that may be the final legal obstacle in President Emmanuel Macron’s push to raise the legal retirement age to 64 from 62.

headline: ‘Personality Crisis: One Night Only’ Review: New York Droll
abstract: David Johansen, once the lead singer for the New York Dolls, proves a first-rate raconteur in this documentary co-directed by Martin Scorsese and David Tedeschi.
lead_paragraph: When David Johansen’s alter ego, Buster Poindexter, swings into “Funky but Chic” early in “Personality Crisis: One Night Only” — a documentary co-directed by Martin Scorsese and David Tedeschi — a viewer should consider herself primed for a droll and cheeky evening. A first-rate raconteur, Johansen — wearing a pompadour, sunglasses and bespoke suit — brings the funk. The storied Café Carlyle delivers the chic. The song was the first single Johansen released after having been the lead singer of the iconic 1970s band the New York Dolls.

headline: Review: In ‘Hamnet,’ Shakespeare Becomes Soap Opera
abstract: The Royal Shakespeare Company adaptation of Maggie O’Farrell’s hit 2020 novel is elegant and tasteful — but also formulaic and sentimental.
lead_paragraph: Writers of historical fiction are allowed to take liberties — they are in the business of filling in blanks, after all. But how much is too much? At what point does something become so speculative, its connection to the factual record so tenuous, that it ceases to be historically credible?

headline: The Sports to Watch This Weekend
abstract: The N.B.A. playoffs start in earnest, while the N.C.A.A. will crown champions in gymnastics and bowling.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. playoffs start in earnest, while the N.C.A.A. will crown champions in gymnastics and bowling.

headline: After Shunning Assad for Years, the Arab World Is Returning Him to the Fold
abstract: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria was isolated for years after brutally crushing his country’s Arab Spring uprising. But in most Arab capitals today, the only question is how — not whether — they should deal with him again.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia, like many other Arab states, had refused to engage with President Bashar al-Assad of Syria for more than a decade after he violently crushed his country’s Arab Spring uprising — bombing, gassing and torturing his own people in a conflict that morphed into a long-running war that is still in progress.

headline: 2 Indianapolis Police Officers Face Manslaughter Charges in Death of Black Man
abstract: Herman Whitfield III, 39, died in April 2022 after being restrained by police officers. His mother had called 911 because he was having a mental health crisis.
lead_paragraph: Two Indianapolis police officers were indicted on manslaughter charges on Thursday in the death of Herman Whitfield III, a Black man who died in April 2022 after he was restrained by the police when his parents called 911 because he was having a mental health crisis.

headline: Tech Consultant Arrested in San Francisco Killing of Cash App Creator
abstract: The police said the consultant, Nima Momeni, knew Bob Lee, who was fatally stabbed.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Nine days after the fatal late-night stabbing of Bob Lee set off a furious outcry over public safety in San Francisco, law enforcement officials said on Thursday that they had arrested an acquaintance of the prominent tech executive and would charge him with murder.

headline: Lady Gaga, Shonda Rhimes and More Named to Restored Arts Commission
abstract: The President’s Committee on the Arts and the Humanities, disbanded during the Trump administration, mixes scholars with boldface names from the entertainment world.
lead_paragraph: Lady Gaga, Jon Batiste, Shonda Rhimes, Jennifer Garner and Anna Deavere Smith are among the luminaries to be named Thursday to the President’s Committee on the Arts and the Humanities, a board that will advise President Biden on matters of cultural policy.

headline: Biden, Blending the Personal and the Diplomatic, Thanks Ireland for Backing Ukraine
abstract: “I’m at home,” the president told the Irish Parliament to thunderous applause. “I only wish I could stay longer.”
lead_paragraph: In an emotional address to the Irish Parliament on Thursday, President Biden thanked the Irish people for their support of Ukraine, cited a favorite Irish poet and recounted old family stories amid a three-day trip that is both a personal journey and an exercise in global diplomacy.

headline: Rachel Pollack, Transgender Activist and Authority on Tarot, Dies at 77
abstract: Her science fiction writing won awards. Her tarot books won her a devoted following. And she created DC Comics’ first transgender superhero.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Pollack, a transgender activist and writer who was an expert on interpreting tarot and created the first transgender superheroine for DC Comics, died on April 7 at her home in Rhinebeck, N.Y. She was 77.

headline: F.B.I. Arrests Air National Guardsman in Massachusetts
abstract: Federal authorities arrested Jack Teixeira, a 21-year-old Air National Guardsman, who they believe is linked to a trove of leaked classified U.S. intelligence documents.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities arrested Jack Teixeira, a 21-year-old Air National Guardsman, who they believe is linked to a trove of leaked classified U.S. intelligence documents.

headline: Supreme Court Won’t Block Student Loan Class-Action Settlement
abstract: Three schools challenged the settlement, which would forgive $6 billion, saying the Biden administration had colluded with plaintiffs and exceeded its authority.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday refused to block a class-action settlement that forgave $6 billion in federal loans for students at for-profit schools or vocational programs.

headline: Iran and Nicaragua Discussed Military Cooperation, Leaked Report Says
abstract: The two countries had found common ground in opposing “perceived U.S. efforts to expand influence in Latin America,” according to an intelligence update based on C.I.A. intercepts.
lead_paragraph: Iran and Nicaragua held discussions in February about bolstering their military cooperation as a way of countering American influence in Latin America, according to an intelligence update contained in a cache of leaked documents that appears to be based on electronic intercepts gathered by the C.I.A.

headline: DeSantis Signs Six-Week Abortion Ban in Florida
abstract: The prohibition is among the most restrictive in the country, and Florida will no longer be a destination for women from across the Deep South seeking the procedure.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Florida lawmakers voted to prohibit abortions after six weeks of pregnancy on Thursday, culminating a rapid effort by elected Republicans and Gov. Ron DeSantis to transform the state to one of the most restrictive in the country.

headline: Meir Shalev, Whose Novels Found Humor in Israeli Life, Dies at 74
abstract: He focused mostly on the half-century before Israeli independence, finding the plight of the early Zionists ripe for affectionate satire.
lead_paragraph: Meir Shalev, whose novels affectionately satirizing Israel’s pioneers made him one of the nation’s leading writers, died on Tuesday at his home in the village of Alonei Abba in northern Israel’s Jezreel Valley. He was 74.

headline: Trump Vows Investigations of Democratic District Attorneys
abstract: Mr. Trump’s threats of sweeping inquiries if re-elected came as local prosecutors in New York and Georgia were intensely scrutinizing him.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump said in an online campaign advertisement on Thursday that if he were re-elected he would “completely overhaul” the F.B.I. and the Justice Department and launch “sweeping civil rights investigations” into local district attorneys’ offices.

headline: Massachusetts Air National Guard’s Intelligence Mission in the Spotlight
abstract: A junior enlisted airman assigned to an intelligence unit on Cape Cod is accused of leaking a trove of top-secret information.
lead_paragraph: Jack Teixeira, the 21-year-old Airman First Class in the Massachusetts Air National Guard who was arrested on Thursday in connection with the intelligence breach, was trained as what the military calls a “Cyber Transport Systems Journeyman.”

headline: Where the Likely 2024 Presidential Contenders Stand on Abortion
abstract: Not quite a year after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, abortion continues to be one of the main issues shaping American politics.
lead_paragraph: Abortion is not fading as a driving issue in America, coming up again and again everywhere policy is decided: in legislatures, courts, the Oval Office and voting booths.

headline: Your Friday Briefing: An Arrest in the Documents Leak
abstract: Also, the WTA will return to China.
lead_paragraph: Federal investigators in the U.S. arrested a 21-year-old man who they believe is linked to leaked classified intelligence documents that have upended relations with American allies and exposed weaknesses in the Ukrainian military.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: “Barry” is back for its final season, as intense and dazzling as ever.
lead_paragraph: ‘Barry’When to watch: Sunday at 10 p.m., on HBO.

headline: It’s a Toddler’s Party. How About a $75,000 Budget?
abstract: In Los Angeles, children’s birthday celebrations have spiraled into mini-weddings.
lead_paragraph: One hundred people RSVP’d for William’s sixth birthday party, which was held at a Los Angeles park on a March afternoon. By 12:30 p.m., the fire station-themed event was in full swing, with energetic attendees trying on their own fire-hose backpacks and gleefully coasting down slides into a large custom ball pit, detailed with flames and the slogan “Let’s Get Fired Up.”

headline: Pierre Lacotte, Choreographer Who Aided a Defection, Dies at 91
abstract: He befriended Rudolf Nureyev in 1961 while the Kirov Ballet was in Paris and witnessed his headline-making defection at the height of the Cold War.
lead_paragraph: Pierre Lacotte, a French choreographer and dance historian who was known for researching and restaging 19th-century ballets — and also for playing a modest role in helping the dancer Rudolf Nureyev defect from the Soviet Union in 1961, which made headlines around the world — died on Monday in La Seyne-sur-Mer, in southern France. He was 91.

headline: Leonard Abrams, 68, Chronicler of 1980s East Village Art Boom, Dies
abstract: His newspaper, the East Village Eye, was as scrappy and iconoclastic as the young maverick stars its pages brought to life.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Abrams, the founder of the East Village Eye, a community newspaper dripping with attitude that captured in newsprint the do-it-yourself post-punk ethos that ignited the explosion of groundbreaking art, music and fashion in downtown Manhattan in the 1980s, died on April 1 in New Jersey. He was 68.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Jack Teixeira followed his family into the military.
abstract: While talking with friends online, the air national guardsman who was arrested on Thursday assumed the role of a leader.
lead_paragraph: While talking with friends online, Jack Teixeira, the air national guardsman who was arrested by federal investigators on Thursday for his role in the leak of a cache of classified U.S. intelligence documents, assumed the role of a leader.

headline: Injuries and Illness Slow Senators, as Well as the Senate Itself
abstract: High-profile absences have created complications for Democrats as Congress returns and prompted new questions about the future of Republican leadership.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A pair of high-profile absences has thrown the Senate into a state of uncertainty at a critical time, raising questions about whether Democrats will be able to conduct business and who will lead Republicans through a potentially chaotic period as they try to reclaim the majority next year.

headline: Texas County Keeps Public Libraries Open Amid Book Ban Controversy
abstract: Officials in Llano County considered closing the entire library system in lieu of returning challenged titles to its shelves.
lead_paragraph: A small Texas county decided to keep its public libraries open amid a monthslong fight over keeping challenged material available to residents. During a heated public meeting on Thursday, county commissioners weighed whether to close the library system after a judge had ordered the county to restore 17 banned books to its shelves.

headline: Ex-C.I.A. Psychologist Re-enacts Interrogation Techniques for Guantánamo Court
abstract: Lawyers for a Saudi prisoner had the psychologist show some of his practices in an effort to exclude evidence as derived from torture.
lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — In court this week, a psychologist who waterboarded prisoners for the Central Intelligence Agency rolled up a towel, wrapped it around the neck of a criminal defense lawyer, and slowly pulled the lawyer toward him and up on her toes — a dramatic re-enactment of practices used on a Saudi detainee in the war on terrorism.

headline: Witness Testimony Helps Prosecutors Advance Trump Election Case
abstract: The Justice Department’s success in compelling top aides to former President Donald Trump to testify to a grand jury moves the special counsel closer to a decision on seeking indictments.
lead_paragraph: Without fanfare, the Justice Department’s investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s attempts to overturn the 2020 election is approaching an important milestone.

headline: Why People Are Fleeing Blue Cities for Red States
abstract: Pro-business policies are behind boom towns.
lead_paragraph: There are a lot of us in the Northeastern media who properly spend a lot of time slamming the Republican Party for what a mess it’s become. I have only one question: If we’re right, why are so many people leaving blue states so they can live in red ones?

headline: How Immigrants Are Saving the Economy
abstract: An immigration surge explains some of the recent good news.
lead_paragraph: Although many politicians will never admit it, the U.S. economy is currently performing far better than most analysts expected. We’re still adding jobs at a rapid clip; while inflation remains unacceptably high, it’s probably coming down. How are we pulling this off?

headline: DeSantis Allies Pressure Florida Lawmakers Against Endorsing Trump
abstract: After four members of Congress backed Donald J. Trump, Republicans close to the Florida governor are trying to keep others from wading into the brewing fight for the G.O.P. presidential nomination.
lead_paragraph: Supporters of Ron DeSantis, the Florida governor, who is considering a run for president, have begun pressing members of the state’s Republican congressional delegation to hold off on any endorsements in the brewing presidential primary after four House members from Florida publicly backed Donald J. Trump.

headline: LinkedIn’s Co-Founder Helped Fund the Suit Accusing Trump of Rape
abstract: Reid Hoffman, a billionaire and critic of Donald J. Trump, is backing E. Jean Carroll’s suit against the former president.
lead_paragraph: Reid Hoffman, the co-founder of LinkedIn and a harsh critic of former President Donald J. Trump, has helped pay for a lawsuit by E. Jean Carroll, the New York magazine writer who sued Mr. Trump for rape and defamation, according to newly filed court papers in the case.

headline: The Airman Who Gave Gamers a Real Taste of War
abstract: A group liked online war games. But then Jack Teixeira, a 21-year-old National Guard airman, began showing members classified documents, they say.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on the leak of classified intelligence documents.

headline: Police Officers Answering a Burglary Call Kill 78-Year-Old Resident
abstract: His nephew reported that someone was trying to break in to the apartment. When officers arrived, the man pulled a gun on them, authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A 78-year-old Brooklyn man was shot and killed by police officers who responded to a call about a possible burglary at his apartment, New York Police Department officials said on Thursday.

headline: Justice Thomas Failed to Report Real Estate Deal With Texas Billionaire
abstract: An investigation by ProPublica revealed a deal worth more than $100,000 between the real estate magnate and the justice.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Clarence Thomas did not disclose that he had sold a series of properties to a longtime conservative donor from Texas in 2014, in an apparent violation of reporting requirements.

headline: When ‘Top Secret’ Is Not So Secret
abstract: The arrest of Jack Teixeira, a junior Massachusetts airman, in the leaking of classified documents opens a debate about security clearances.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Why would a 21-year-old national guardsman be in a position with access to top secret documents to begin with?

headline: Old Friends. New Team. Same Knicks Championship Dream.
abstract: Knicks guards Jalen Brunson and Josh Hart were college friends, then took a twisty road to a reunion in the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: When Knicks point guard Jalen Brunson was asked if Josh Hart had changed much in the eight years they had known each other, he feigned exasperation and quickly said no. Then a little smile crept onto his face.

headline: About 18,000 Cattle Are Killed in Fire at Dairy Farm in Texas
abstract: One employee was left in critical condition after an explosion and blaze in Dimmitt, Texas, officials said. A thick plume of smoke mushroomed over the plains.
lead_paragraph: The 911 calls came in rapid succession, with reports of an explosion and fire on Monday that officials would later say had trapped one employee and thousands of cattle inside a milking parlor at a dairy farm in Dimmitt, Texas.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Banning TikTok
abstract: Washington is considering a ban on the popular app. We asked teenagers what they thought. Their answers may surprise you.
lead_paragraph: TikTok, the social media app owned by the Chinese company ByteDance, has long worried American lawmakers, but those concerns — which range from national security risks to the app’s effects on young people — came to a fever pitch last month when a House committee voted to advance legislation that would allow President Biden to ban TikTok from all devices nationwide.

headline: Review: In a Sorkinized ‘Camelot,’ That’s How Conditions Are. Alas.
abstract: A revival of the 1960 musical with the famously great score and infamously bad book gets a gorgeous makeover that makes no difference.
lead_paragraph: About 30 minutes into its 90-minute first act, the Lincoln Center Theater revival of “Camelot” finally wakes up, as if from a pleasant drowse. That’s when Jordan Donica, as Lancelot, who has arrived in England to join King Arthur’s Round Table, tears into the boastful “C’est Moi” like a lion ripping huge bites of dramatic flesh with his teeth.

headline: North Korea Says It Launched a Solid-Fuel ICBM, a First
abstract: If successfully developed, solid-fuel technology would be a significant advance, making the North’s missiles easier to move and harder to target.
lead_paragraph: North Korea said on Friday that it had test-launched a solid-fuel intercontinental ballistic missile for the first time, technology that would be a significant step forward for its missile program if developed successfully.

headline: Key Collaborator
abstract: In college, Billy Bratton introduced his friend Clay Haddock to crossword puzzles. That led to today’s collaboration.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Variety: Diagramless
abstract: Try to untangle this terrifically tortuous diagramless by Alex Eaton-Salners.
lead_paragraph: DIAGRAMLESS — I like to think I become better at each kind of variety puzzle the more I solve them. This might be true for cryptics, but I think I’ve hit a wall on the diagramless. I have a graph paper notebook that I’ve been using for years to solve them, and I always go through five drafts or so with no apparent improvement. No problem! These are still a favorite, and Alex Eaton-Salners does a bang-up job crafting intricate, challenging grids with themes that appear visually in the grid itself as well as in the clues and entries.

headline: Corrections: April 14, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, April 14, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about Ukrainian soldiers’ efforts to find and de-mine booby traps set up by Russia’s military misstated the name of a Russian mine. It is OZM-72, not OMZ-52.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Tech Consultant Arrested in the Killing of Cash App Creator in San Francisco
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, April 14, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “San Francisco does have real public safety problems. But this particular crime does not appear to have anything to do with them.”

headline: Taylor Swift Played Their Wedding. She Just Might Not Have Known It.
abstract: René Hurtado was able to snag front-row seats to the second night of Taylor Swift’s tour — and it was there that she married Max Bochman.
lead_paragraph: Ask René Maria Avalos and Maxwell P Bochman why they chose to get married on March 18, and their answer is simple: “Taylor chose for us.”

headline: When Broadway Shuttered, Her Next Act Was an Improv Proposal
abstract: While cooking a meal during the pandemic, Miki Abraham asked Alex Grayson, a fellow actor, if he wanted to get married. He quickly agreed — once he was certain she meant it.
lead_paragraph: Miki Alden Abraham didn’t show off her acting chops when she asked her former castmate Alex Joseph Grayson to marry her on Oct. 15, 2020. At the time, she was spooning something out of a crockpot in the Nashville apartment that they shared and thinking life couldn’t get much worse.

headline: How Many Couples Can Say ‘Grease 2’ Brought Them Closer?
abstract: Michael Sin-Suarez was shocked when he overheard Kia Zalewski discussing one of his favorite ’80s movies. Neither of them anticipated that reciting dialogue from the film would later lead to romance.
lead_paragraph: It was the summer of 2005, and Kia Dawn Zalewski, a recent graduate of Florida State University with a bachelor’s degree in communications, landed a position in sales and marketing at Nikki Beach Miami, a luxury beach club. While working in the corporate office, she often crossed paths with the then-V.I.P. manager, Michael Anthony Sin-Suarez.

headline: How to Fall Out of Love With Yourself
abstract: My girlfriend thought I might be a narcissist. Maybe it was time to dial back the self-love?
lead_paragraph: This is the story of the love of my life: a 6-foot-2 bald man with an enormous nose. We share a first, middle and last name. I am what’s known as a narcissist.

headline: When ‘the Kitten Lady’ Met ‘the Cat Photographer’
abstract: Hannah Shaw, a kitten educator and advocate, and Andrew Marttila, a feline photographer, are a “meow” made in heaven.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, Hannah René Shaw has become a prominent educator on and advocate for kittens nationally and globally. She’s known as the “Kitten Lady,” and her 1.2 million Instagram followers look to her for advice on things like what to do if you find a stray cat, or how to get a baby kitten to eat.

headline: Germany Quits Nuclear Power, Ending a Decades-Long Struggle
abstract: The last three plants in Germany are scheduled to shut down by Saturday, while other European countries are looking to expand nuclear energy.
lead_paragraph: It began as a movement of pacifists chaining themselves to fences outside nuclear power plants. Five decades later, the effort to close German nuclear power plants will end with echoes of the Cold War era in which it began, as Russia’s war in Ukraine is a reminder of both the risks and promise of nuclear energy.

headline: Have Ideas on How to Fix the M.T.A.? Now It’s Your Turn.
abstract: What do you think could be done to make subways, buses and commuter railroads better? We’d like to hear from you.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’re looking for your ideas on how to improve mass transit in New York. We’ll also look at how the collapse of the commercial real estate market has affected the big development project around Pennsylvania Station.

headline: America, China and a Crisis of Trust
abstract: A trip to Beijing and Taiwan showed me how the United States and China are fated to cooperate and doomed to compete.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — I just returned from visiting China for the first time since Covid struck. Being back in Beijing was a reminder of my first rule of journalism: If you don’t go, you don’t know. Relations between our two countries have soured so badly, so quickly, and have so reduced our points of contact — very few American reporters are left in China, and our leaders are barely talking — that we’re now like two giant gorillas looking at each other through a pinhole. Nothing good will come from this.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: An arrest in the document leak in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Federal investigators in the U.S. arrested a 21-year-old man who they believe is linked to leaked classified intelligence documents that have upended relations with American allies and exposed weaknesses in the Ukrainian military.

headline: Word of the Day: plummet
abstract: This word has appeared in 106 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word plummet has appeared in 106 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 24 in “Where New York’s Sick Sea Turtles Go for Rehab and Squid Snacks” by Dodai Stewart:

headline: Learning to Love My Incomprehensible Kiwi Accent
abstract: It’s surprising how hard it is for New Zealanders to make themselves understood in America.
lead_paragraph: Recently, I was explaining to an American how, as a New Zealander living in New York, I occasionally feel isolated. After a few moments, she stopped me. “I’m sorry, I’m not sure I understand.”

headline: Stephen Colbert Can Tell When Fox News Is Lying
abstract: A judge said he would probably appoint a “special master” to investigate whether Fox had misled the court. The “Late Show” host thinks he’s up to the job.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: On the TikTok Beat, Trends Dance With National Security
abstract: Amid talk of a nationwide ban, a reporter discussed the future for TikTok and its Chinese owner, ByteDance, in the United States.
lead_paragraph: A social media app once known for cat videos and dance challenges has become a political flashpoint among Washington lawmakers.

headline: A Well of Conservative Support for Public Schools in Rural Texas
abstract: A national movement to give parents public vouchers to spend on private schools has run up against the deep loyalty Texas has always had for its public schools.
lead_paragraph: NEW HOME, Texas — Bright yellow uprights tower over what was recently a flat expanse of cotton fields, now transformed into football turf. Nearby, cranes pull up the walls of what will soon be a new elementary school.

headline: ‘The Justins’ Follow a Legacy of Resistance in Tennessee
abstract: The young Black Democrats expelled from the legislature bring an activist approach, and model themselves after civil rights leaders of the past.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Justin Jones arrived at the State Capitol in Tennessee as a freshly elected lawmaker representing parts of Nashville. A 27-year-old Black Democrat, he belonged to a party vastly outnumbered by a largely white Republican majority. The advice was clear.

headline: ‘The Last Kingdom: Seven Kings Must Die’ Review: Flesh Wounds
abstract: Soldiers face off over the fate of England in this overbearingly glib costume drama.
lead_paragraph: Far too often, “The Last Kingdom: Seven Kings Must Die,” an incomprehensible period epic based on the five-season television series “The Last Kingdom,” mistakes the mere presence of blood for a compelling narrative.

headline: This is how Ukraine has survived the war on its power grid.
abstract: Electric trams are running again in Kyiv, and electric scooters dot the sidewalks. With curfew extended to midnight, the streets are bright and buzzing. Portable generators, nearly impossible to find as they flew off the shelves in December, are being sold at half price.
lead_paragraph: Electric trams are running again in Kyiv, and electric scooters dot the sidewalks. With curfew extended to midnight, the streets are bright and buzzing. Portable generators, nearly impossible to find as they flew off the shelves in December, are being sold at half price.

headline: Speaking
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you know or think you know about this image and where it is from? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of Cecily Brown's exhibition at the Met, "Death and the Maid."
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of Cecily Brown's exhibition at the Met, "Death and the Maid."

headline: Reader Mailbag: Presidential Announcements, That Fox Call and What’s Woke
abstract: A look at Tim Scott and whether he has an angle to build a base of support.
lead_paragraph: There’s been surprisingly little post-Trump-indictment polling of the Republican race. As a result, we’re still in wait-and-see mode here at the Tilt — and we’ve been waiting long enough that it has become easy to forget what we were even waiting for.

headline: This Philosopher Wants Liberals to Take Political Power Seriously
abstract: Danielle Allen makes the case for ‘power-sharing liberalism.’
lead_paragraph: America today faces a crisis of governance. In the face of numerous challenges — from climate change, to housing shortages, to pandemics — our institutions struggle to act quickly and decisively. Democratic processes often get captured by special interests or paralyzed by polarization. And, in response, public faith in government has reached a new low.

headline: Harlan Crow, Clarence Thomas’s Benefactor, Is Not Just Another Billionaire
abstract: He and his allies have a lot of explaining to do.
lead_paragraph: If not for his relationship with Justice Clarence Thomas, Harlan Crow would be just another billionaire among many.

headline: A Medium and Her Message
abstract: In Gavriel Savit’s new fantasy, set at the 1893 Chicago World’s Fair, an orphan girl who performs sham séances finds she may have true powers after all.
lead_paragraph: The year is 1893, and the nearly 14-year-old Eva Root, a performer who has spent half her young life conducting sham séances in the service of a drunken grifter, is jaded. But one night, mid-séance, a mysterious voice beckons Eva to “Come see the fair!” She isn’t certain what this means, and yet she jumps on a train for the World’s Fair, driven by the same need she has carried with her from town to town, “the need for things to be different — better, brighter than what they are.”

headline: Before We Invest Billions in This Clean Fuel, Let’s Make Sure It’s Actually Clean
abstract: If the Biden administration botches tax credit rules, it could unintentionally create a dirty hydrogen monster.
lead_paragraph: Down on Page 118 of the ambitious climate law Congress passed last summer is a detail that has the potential to transform America’s energy system: a tax credit for what’s known as “clean hydrogen,” a powerful fuel produced with low or even zero carbon emissions. It’s a provision that could replace a lot of the dirty fossil fuels in the sectors of the economy that are hardest to clean up, like heavy industry and aviation.

headline: What Protects Fox News Also Protects Our Democracy
abstract: The legal hurdles protecting Fox News in the $1.6 billion lawsuit brought by Dominion Voting Systems are necessary and important.
lead_paragraph: Fox News, which is defending itself from Dominion Voting Systems’ $1.6 billion lawsuit, is going to trial on Monday in a hole. In an unusual move, the judge has already ruled that on-air statements — those asserting that Dominion’s voting machines played a role in causing Donald Trump to lose the 2020 election — were false. The main task left for the jury is to decide whether Fox made those false statements with what’s known as actual malice.

headline: A Singer Who Lets Others Shine
abstract: Terrell Grice is the host of “The Terrell Show” a YouTube series that has more than one million subscribers.
lead_paragraph: Name: Terrell Grice

headline: Republican 2024 Hopefuls Embrace Gun Politics at N.R.A. Meeting
abstract: The current and potential 2024 presidential candidates showed strong support for gun owners’ rights — a core issue for the party’s base, but one that can be a tougher sell in a general election.
lead_paragraph: They cited Scripture and issued calls for prayer. They applauded law enforcement and demanded tighter security in schools. They lamented the nation’s mental health crisis and offered tough talk about the death penalty.

headline: Your Adult Child May Be Doing Better Than You Think
abstract: An expert shares four tips for establishing boundaries and reducing conflict.
lead_paragraph: When my parents dropped me off at college, they weren’t as sad as I wanted them to be. And once I graduated, they lobbed me out of the house like a javelin.

headline: Don’t Jump Into Spring Cleaning. Take It Slow.
abstract: A writer discovers the joy of breaking up chores into manageable chunks.
lead_paragraph: I don’t enjoy doing household chores. More than that, I don’t enjoy completing menial tasks in general, or doing one thing for more than 30 minutes, or pushing myself past the point of minor inconvenience. That said, like most people, I do enjoy a clean and comfortable home — or at least the type of home I can invite friends over without wincing as they step over clutter and shoe mud in the hallway. When you live in a small London apartment, as I do, one forgotten plate or hastily flung coat can make the whole place feel chaotic.

headline: The Ethics of Nine of the Most Powerful People in America
abstract: An ethics office at the Supreme Court, similar to ethics committees in the House and the Senate, should be established.
lead_paragraph: At least one member of the Supreme Court told Justice Clarence Thomas that there was no problem accepting privately paid luxury trips and other lavish gifts from “close personal friends” without disclosing them, according to a statement issued earlier this month by Justice Thomas. Whoever it was — names were not disclosed — gave him stunningly tone-deaf advice, given the uproar that followed when ProPublica reported that the justice had for more than 20 years accepted expensive gifts and trips from a billionaire conservative friend.

headline: ‘Yellowjackets’ Season 2, Episode 4 Recap: Hunter/Gatherer
abstract: Teen Lottie goes out in search of prey as her allies back at the cabin become more and more like followers.
lead_paragraph: There’s a lot of driving in this week’s episode of “Yellowjackets.” The adult characters are on the road. Misty and Walter are searching for Natalie and the “purple people,” who they assume have taken her hostage. Shauna takes her daughter, Callie, into the middle of nowhere where she confesses the full extent of her crimes. Natalie sets out with Lisa (Nicole Maines), a member of Lottie’s group, with the ostensible goal of selling honey. And then there’s Taissa, who empties her gas tank on the way to an unknown destination. She hitchhikes the rest of the way there thanks to a kindly trucker.

headline: Twitter Is Broken. Thanks, Elon.
abstract: The site’s new proprietor has ruined it for almost everyone.
lead_paragraph: About six months ago, Elon Musk bought your favorite neighborhood bar. Then he fired veteran bouncers and bartenders, tried to stiff the landlord and at least one vendor, and demanded that regulars pay a cover charge. He’s frequently struggled to serve his customers, yet he’s penalized them for mentioning the competition. He’s tamped down the revelry in general, really — a lot of conversation at his watering hole has been drowned out by Musk’s own never-ending stage act, which consists mainly of him yelling dad jokes at customers through a bullhorn.

headline: Des Linden Keeps Choosing to Run
abstract: In her new memoir, the 2018 Boston Marathon champion writes about her battles with illness and injury, and the meaning of “badassery.”
lead_paragraph: Injuries kept Des Linden out of the Boston Marathon in 2013. She did some television commentary, went for a jog and was in her hotel room when the bombs went off. It made her want to win the race one day even more, which did not seem possible, because she had wanted it so badly for years.

headline: With the Odds on Their Side, They Still Couldn’t Beat the Market
abstract: In 2022, conditions were heavily in stock pickers’ favor, but most trailed the market. This year looks worse, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: It’s awfully hard to beat the stock market consistently. In 2022, despite many advantages, most mutual funds couldn’t do it. There are important lessons in that failure for this year and beyond.

headline: With His Tale of Shipwreck, David Grann Is Steady as He Goes
abstract: The author’s latest book, “The Wager,” investigates the mysteries surrounding an 18th-century maritime disaster off Cape Horn.
lead_paragraph: There were multiple moments while reading David Grann’s new book, “The Wager,” about an 18th-century shipwreck, when it occurred to me that the kind of nonfiction narratives The New Yorker writer has become known for share something essential with a sturdy ship. A vessel freighted with historical controversy, tangled facts and monomaniacal characters needs to be structurally sound, containing and conveying its messy cargo. It should be resilient yet nimble enough to withstand the unpredictable waters of readers’ attentions and expectations. Only an impeccable design will keep everything moving.

headline: Facing Tough Senate Race, Montana G.O.P. Looks to Change the Rules
abstract: An election bill moving through the Republican-led Legislature would rewrite the rules for a single race: the looming battle against Senator Jon Tester, a Democrat.
lead_paragraph: HELENA, Mont. — Republicans typically cry foul when accused of rewriting election laws to benefit their candidates. But as the Montana Legislature debates a new voting bill, even some G.O.P. lawmakers concede that this one appears designed to help them win elections — more precisely, one very important election.

headline: Can Body Shaming Be Outlawed?
abstract: A proposed law in New York aims to do that. How that would work remains unclear.
lead_paragraph: In 1961 at the age of 37, Jean Nidetch, who struggled with her weight for most of her life, signed up for a 10-week program offered by the New York City Board of Health called the “Prudent Diet.” Ms. Nidetch lost 20 pounds, but she grew disillusioned — to keep going, she would need the kind of motivation that she believed could only come from community. Borrowing the central tenets of Alcoholics Anonymous, she began inviting friends in a similar predicament to weekly meetings at her Queens apartment, where they would talk about the emotional roots of overeating and generally buttress one another in a shared commitment toward what was then so often pitifully called “reducing.”

headline: Republicans Are Forgetting One Crucial Truth About People and Their Bodies
abstract: It has become blindingly obvious what happens when the G.O.P. legislates what Americans do with their sex organs. And voters, understandably, don’t like what they see.
lead_paragraph: In the homestretch of the epic Wisconsin Supreme Court race that ended last week with a blowout victory for liberals, voters’ cellphones pinged incessantly with text message ads.

headline: Unemployment Is Low. Inflation Is Falling. But What Comes Next?
abstract: Despite hopeful signs, economists worry that a recession is on the way or that the Federal Reserve will cause one in trying to rein in inflation.
lead_paragraph: There are two starkly different ways of looking at the U.S. economy right now: what the data says has happened in the past few months, and what history warns could happen next.

headline: In Russia’s War in Ukraine, ‘Nature Has Also Suffered’
abstract: A book of photographs taken before February 2022 reveals formerly breathtaking landscapes that may never be the same.
lead_paragraph: In February 2022, the editorial staff at C.P. Publishing in Kyiv was hard at work on THE BEAUTY OF UKRAINE (TENEUES, $70), a book of landscape photography by the Odesa-born Yevhen Samuchenko, when Russian forces invaded the Ukrainian capital and forced them to flee.

headline: 40 Years Later, The Return of Halley’s Day-Glo Comet
abstract: With four shows of work from the ’80s traveling the globe, the artist is still seeing what he can get away with.
lead_paragraph: The colors of a Peter Halley painting are assaultive — lurid hazmat oranges and jaundiced yellows nearly blinding in their acid-dipped fluorescence. And that’s before the dread creeps in, the suspicion that despite being connected in innumerable ways, each of us has never been more alone. In the 1980s Halley devised a simple vocabulary: cells and conduits, rendered in a queasily unnatural palette and precise geometric space, that cut to the heart of a nascent computer age whose byproduct was intensifying social isolation. It turned out that moment never really ended.

headline: Exploring Picasso’s Málaga
abstract: Among the best places to discover the celebrated 20th-century Spanish artist is the sun-splashed, seaside city where he was born.
lead_paragraph: In honor of this year’s 50th anniversary of the death of Pablo Picasso, museums and other cultural institutions are pulling out all the stops, with about 50 exhibitions and events in the United States and Europe. Some offer novel perspectives on the celebrated artist’s seven-decade career: At the Cincinnati Art Museum, “Picasso Landscapes: Out of Bounds” focuses exclusively on the artist’s landscapes, while at the Musée Picasso, Paris, the British men’s wear designer Paul Smith has added bold stripes and saturated hues to the walls where some of Picasso’s best known masterpieces are displayed.

headline: The Conundrum of the DeSantis Base: Pro-Trump and Anti-Trump Voters
abstract: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has had to appeal to two conflicting elements of his base: Republicans who are repelled by Donald Trump, and those who remain enthralled by him.
lead_paragraph: Bob Sikorski, a 57-year-old business owner in Portage Lakes, Ohio, admires the skill Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida shows on policy and is open to supporting him in a presidential primary. But the longtime Republican voter warned there was one sure way to turn him away: any direct criticism of former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: What Can We Learn From Older Adults?
abstract: The Times spoke with 12 seniors about what it’s like to be an older person in American society today. What can we learn from their lives and unique perspectives?
lead_paragraph: Do you have any older adults in your life? If so, what valuable perspectives and lessons have you gained from them?

headline: China’s Car Buyers Have Fallen Out of Love With Foreign Brands
abstract: Domestic companies are now selling more vehicles than their multinational rivals, which have failed to keep up with Chinese consumers’ demand for electric cars and S.U.V.s.
lead_paragraph: For years, foreign automakers in China had a bead on customers drawn to luxury brands, like the Cao family in Shanghai. Not anymore.

headline: Welcome to My Crib. It’s Rented. And It’s a Moneymaker.
abstract: Though they don’t own their apartments, some renters are investing in the décor and design of their units to display on social media and are getting paid to do it.
lead_paragraph: During the summer of 2020, ‌Imani Keal ‌felt like the walls were closing in‌. Her Washington, D.C., studio apartment felt even smaller than it was. To decompress from pandemic-induced stress, she would stroll around the Georgetown neighborhood, picking up knickknacks, items discarded by fleeing students and left on the street.

headline: Rat Horror Stories the New N.Y.C. Rat Czar Needs to Hear
abstract: New Yorkers have encountered rodents in toilets, on trains, in bed. And that’s not all.
lead_paragraph: New York City has a new rat czar, and it is impossible to overstate the urgency of her mission. The rats are everywhere.

headline: As Presenters Cut Back on Streams, Some Disabled Arts Lovers Feel Left Out
abstract: When shuttered venues embraced streaming during the pandemic, the arts became more accessible. With live performance back, and streams dwindling, many feel forgotten.
lead_paragraph: For Mollie Gathro, live theater was a once-a-year indulgence if the stars aligned perfectly.

headline: K-Beauty’s Brush With Fine Art
abstract: Amorepacific partners with the Metropolitan Museum of Art to expand the reach of Sulwhasoo, their luxury Korean beauty brand.
lead_paragraph: “I am ginseng,” boomed the voice of Tilda Swinton to partygoers in the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Temple of Dendur, where Sulwhasoo, the Korean beauty brand, was throwing a lavish dinner to celebrate its new partnership with the 152-year-old institution. A promotional video featuring Ms. Swinton played overhead, depicting a ginseng root spinning in circles.

headline: How Fast Is Eliud Kipchoge? You’ll Fall Down When You Find Out.
abstract: Kipchoge, who will run his first Boston Marathon on Monday, holds the world record for 26.2 miles. This is what happens when mere mortals try to keep his pace.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Some numbers are difficult to comprehend. The human body, for example, is made up of about 40 trillion cells. Earth is about 93 million miles from the sun (give or take a couple of million).

headline: Decades on From Peace, Northern Ireland Schools Are Still Deeply Divided
abstract: The nation’s school system still sees the country’s pupils starkly divided by their religious backgrounds, years after the Good Friday Agreement brought an end to sectarian strife.
lead_paragraph: On weekday mornings, Mark Lynn, 10, walks past the 40-foot-tall metal fence looming over his backyard at the edge of his predominantly Catholic neighborhood in Belfast, and heads to his Catholic school, its crest displayed prominently on his blue sweater.

headline: Ghosts Past and Present Cross Paths as War Comes to Nuclear Wasteland
abstract: Not everyone evacuated when the Chernobyl nuclear plant melted down in 1986. The few who stayed lived through another calamity when Russian troops marched in.
lead_paragraph: The world’s worst nuclear disaster, unfolding only a few miles away, did not force Halyna Voloshyna, 74, to abandon her home in Chernobyl in 1986.

headline: The Phandom of the Opera
abstract: As “The Phantom of the Opera” ends its record-breaking Broadway run on Sunday, its most devoted followers, who call themselves Phans, are mourning.
lead_paragraph: “The Phantom of the Opera,” the longest running show in Broadway history, will give its final performance on Sunday, bringing its glittering chandelier crashing down on the stage of the Majestic Theater for the 13,981st and final time.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, April 14, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Inside the Hunt for the Discord Leaker, and Twitter Chaos Updates
abstract: How Times journalists tracked down the alleged leaker of top secret military intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Aric Toler untangles the web of teens, gamers and memes at the heart of the latest intelligence scandal.

headline: How Electrifying Everything Became a Key Climate Solution
abstract: To tackle climate change, we’ll need to plug in millions of cars, trucks, home heaters, stoves and factories.
lead_paragraph: To tackle climate change, we’ll need to plug in millions of cars, trucks, home heaters, stoves and factories.

headline: Broadway’s Longest-Running Musical Turns Out the Lights
abstract: The story of “Phantom of the Opera’s” meteoric rise and bittersweet closing.
lead_paragraph: ”The Phantom of the Opera,” the longest-running show in the history of Broadway, will close its doors on Sunday after more than three decades.

headline: Jackie Robinson’s Legacy Stretches Beyond the Baseball Field
abstract: As M.L.B. celebrates Jackie Robinson Day, scholars from a foundation created in his honor — like Rep. Lauren Underwood — work to fulfill his vision for society.
lead_paragraph: The closest Lauren Underwood ever came to being a baseball player was the night in 2007 when she was asked to throw out the ceremonial first pitch on Jackie Robinson Day at Comerica Park in Detroit. She practiced for days, tossing pitches from the mound of the baseball stadium of the University of Michigan, where she studied nursing.

headline: Will Abortion Kill the Filibuster?
abstract: Courts don’t make laws. Congress does.
lead_paragraph: Will abortion be the issue that kills the filibuster?

headline: Russia’s ambassador says the U.S. threatened ‘retaliatory measures’ unless a jailed reporter is released.
abstract: American officials and The Wall Street Journal have vehemently denied the accusation that Evan Gershkovich was engaged in any kind of spying activity.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s ambassador to the United States said that Washington had threatened to retaliate if Moscow did not release the Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich, who was arrested in Russia and charged with espionage, marking a new low in tensions between the two countries.

headline: The Secret Behind the Premier League’s Smartest Team
abstract: Brighton has risen into the top half of the league with smart signings, contingency plans and a spreadsheet that sees the future.
lead_paragraph: BRIGHTON, England — The floor-to-ceiling windows in Paul Barber’s spartan office offer a panorama of the lush green practice fields of Brighton and Hove Albion, the Premier League soccer team he has run for the past 11 years. The secret to Brighton’s success, though, is for his eyes only.

headline: Your Guides to the World of Fairies and to the Multiverse
abstract: New science-fiction and fantasy novels from Heather Fawcett, Moses Ose Utomi and M.R. Carey.
lead_paragraph: At a glance, EMILY WILDE’S ENCYCLOPAEDIA OF FAERIES (Del Rey, 317 pp., $28), by Heather Fawcett, evokes both fictional scrapbooking endeavors like “Lady Cottington’s Pressed Fairy Book” (1994) and scholarly surveys of folk beliefs like Katharine Briggs’s “Encyclopedia of Fairies: Hobgoblins, Brownies, Bogies, and Other Supernatural Creatures” (1978). But appearances can be deceiving, and what seems on its surface to be a twee romp is in fact a stirring exploration of mythography and storytelling, with a dark and twisted heart.

headline: Biggest U.S. Banks Report Bumper Profits Amid Industry Turmoil
abstract: JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and Wells Fargo comfortably beat expectations for earnings in the first quarter, when the failures of smaller banks sent jitters through the sector.
lead_paragraph: The country’s largest banks escaped the crisis that just weeks ago brought down two midsize U.S. lenders, unnerving regulators and depositors. If anything, the tumult helped those giants rake in bumper profits.

headline: What Bank Earnings Reveal About the Health of the Economy
abstract: JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo reported solid earnings on Friday, but big questions remain about the sector’s health and a potential recession.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo, two of America’s biggest banks, reported solid earnings and revenue gains on Friday, pushing their stock prices higher in premarket trading. PNC Bank, a smaller lender, also posted a big jump in profit.

headline: The Price of Bitcoin Mining and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: California’s Underdog Team Makes It to the N.B.A. Playoffs
abstract: The Sacramento Kings are in the playoffs for the first time in 17 years, and they’re up against the heavily favored Golden State Warriors. Two Times colleagues, both Kings fans, discuss.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. playoffs are upon us, and all four of California’s teams have made it in the same season for the first time.

headline: Funeral Homes Don’t Have to List Prices Online. That May Change.
abstract: The rule on price disclosure was written before widespread use of the internet. Regulators are considering an update.
lead_paragraph: The federal rule that requires funeral homes to list their prices didn’t envision the internet. Now, regulators are weighing an update that would require the homes to reveal their prices online.

headline: 8 Festive Eid al-Fitr Recipes
6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: This week's roundup includes titles by Margot Jefferson, Nell Zink, Chloé Cooper Jones and more.
lead_paragraph: This week's roundup includes titles by Margot Jefferson, Nell Zink, Chloé Cooper Jones and more.

headline: Wherever These Surgeries Went, the Camera Did, Too
abstract: In a radical experiment, the filmmakers Véréna Paravel and Lucien Castaing-Taylor sought a scalpel-level view of operations in French hospitals.
lead_paragraph: An eye clamped open for a length of time that might make Malcolm McDowell shudder. A bloody robotic prostatectomy. A neurosurgeon turning a screw inside a conscious patient’s skull as they trade stories about their childhood love of construction sets.

headline: Supreme Court Briefly Preserves Broad Availability of Abortion Pill
abstract: The temporary stay is meant to preserve the status quo while the justices study lower court rulings, and it did not forecast how they would ultimately rule.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. issued an order on Friday temporarily ensuring that a common abortion pill would remain widely available while the Supreme Court considered whether to grant the Biden administration’s emergency request to preserve the Food and Drug Administration’s approval of the drug.

headline: The Great Goat War of Southern France
abstract: A former Parisian moved to the country, fell in love with goats and let them roam free and multiply. Her winemaking neighbors are not enchanted.
lead_paragraph: Valérie Corbeaux lives on a rocky hilltop in the dry southwest part of France with her herd of goats.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: The hosts had an abundance of news to discuss this week, including President Biden officially ending the national emergency response to Covid-19 and Justice Clarence Thomas not reporting lavish gifts and travel from a Texas billionaire.
lead_paragraph: The hosts had an abundance of news to discuss this week, including President Biden officially ending the national emergency response to Covid-19 and Justice Clarence Thomas not reporting lavish gifts and travel from a Texas billionaire.

headline: How Much Power Should the Courts Have?
abstract: In Israel, the United States and other democracies, bitter battles are being waged over the same question.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli Supreme Court last month became the subject of a remarkable clash over its role in the country’s democracy. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his governing coalition proposed a change in how judges are appointed in a measure that also stripped them of some essential powers. Netanyahu, who leads a right-wing government with ultra-Orthodox partners, said he was “strengthening” democracy by giving elected lawmakers more say over unelected judges. But many Israelis, especially secular and moderate Jews, feared the opposite. Hundreds of thousands of protesters blocked the highways; military reservists refused to report for duty, and a general strike loomed. The unrest forced Netanyahu to back down for now.

headline: Behind the Backlash Against Bud Light’s Transgender Influencer
abstract: After Dylan Mulvaney promoted the beer on Instagram, well-known conservatives called for a boycott. Two executives at Anheuser-Busch, the beer’s maker, are taking a leave of absence.
lead_paragraph: Some conservative commentators and celebrities began calling for a boycott of Bud Light after the beer was featured in a social media promotion by a transgender influencer, Dylan Mulvaney, on April 1.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Short-rib adobo for Saturday, scallops in béarnaise on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s shoulder season where I stay — warm during the midday hours, but still with a little bite to the evening breeze off the water. I like that juxtaposition, and want to cook to it this weekend: say, Filipino beef short-rib adobo (above), with a bowl of rice and a sharp citrus salad.

headline: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
abstract: Deadly planets and deadly viruses must be contended with in this month’s selections.
lead_paragraph: The writer-director Carlos Amaral’s debut feature seems to be set in the 1980s, including repeated shots of boxy computer consoles with flickering data scrolling on their tiny screens. But this is not the decade we know. Most people seem to have decamped to the planet Proxima Centauri b — the reasons are never explained but Earth appears to be slowly dying — and Miguel (Nuno Nolasco), who has been left behind, looks forlornly at the rockets that take off nightly. He types away on his computer and hacks into the space program’s files; in the evening he drinks at a restaurant whose only other customer is a lonely silent woman. “Infinite Sea” moves at a slow, contemplative pace, and is soaked in existential anomie. At times it feels as if Michelangelo Antonioni had branched out into science fiction.

headline: The Best Time to Fix Soccer Is Right Now
abstract: The game’s authorities, its teams and its fans all agree alterations could help. The problem is that many of them are focused on the wrong things.
lead_paragraph: The consensus, over the last few years, has become perfectly clear. FIFA thinks it. So do UEFA, its great rival, and the architects of the proposed European Super League and most of the major teams in most of the game’s major leagues. Even Gerard Piqué is sure of it. They cannot agree on much, but they all agree that soccer has to change.

headline: ‘Barry’ by Bullet Point: What to Remember Before Season 4 Begins
abstract: Is there still time for Barry to find redemption? He has one season left to figure it out. Here’s where the show left off at the end of Season 3.
lead_paragraph: Will Barry Berkman, a.k.a. Barry Block, the contract killer at the center of the HBO series “Barry,” finally come to terms with who he is? On Sunday, as the fourth and final season premieres with back-to-back episodes, viewers should begin to find out.

headline: Read the criminal complaint against Jack Teixeira
abstract: Mr. Teixeira, a 21-year-old member of the Massachusetts Air National Guard, is facing two counts related to the leaking of hundreds of classified documents on a gaming chat server.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Teixeira, a 21-year-old member of the Massachusetts Air National Guard, is facing two counts related to the leaking of hundreds of classified documents on a gaming chat server.

headline: ‘The Pope’s Exorcist’ Review: A Head-Spinning Genre Mash-Up
abstract: The buddy-priest action-comedy-horror hybrid we didn’t know we wanted has finally landed.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to pick the most surreal part of Julius Avery’s new horror film. It could be that the main character is based on the very real Rev. Gabriele Amorth, who used to be the Vatican’s chief exorcist (in a head-spinning twist, William Friedkin, the director of “The Exorcist,” once made a documentary about him). Or maybe it’s that Father Amorth is portrayed as an espresso-drinking, scooter-riding maverick by Russell Crowe in one of his most engaging performances in years. He is dispatched by the Pope (the cult Italian actor Franco Nero) to an isolated Spanish abbey where a young boy, Henry (Peter DeSouza-Feighoney), has started producing ungodly growls, changing colors and shapes, and making inappropriate moves on his mother (Alex Essoe, a Mike Flanagan horror regular).

headline: Removing Offensive Language From Classic Books
abstract: Readers discuss changes to books by Agatha Christie, Roald Dahl, Ian Fleming and others. Also: Transgender athletes; Taiwan and China; an Emily writes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Broadway Theater Owners Are Trying to Block a Times Square Casino
abstract: A new coalition, organized by the Broadway League, has formed to defeat a casino proposal backed by Caesars and Jay-Z.
lead_paragraph: Some New Yorkers may love Times Square; some definitely hate it. That also goes for a casino that may be headed there.

headline: Here are the two laws that Teixeira is accused of violating.
abstract: The laws cited in the F.B.I.’s criminal complaint against Jack Teixeira, the 21-year-old National Guard airman accused of leaking classified documents, center on protecting government secrets.
