abstract: This shoreline town attracts buyers with its beaches and good schools. But available homes are scarce, and they sell very quickly.
lead_paragraph: By the time they decided they were ready to start a family a couple of years ago, Patrick and Sophie Sayre had become disillusioned with life in Los Angeles. So they began looking for a home in Connecticut, Ms. Sayre’s home state, focusing on the southeastern shoreline.

headline: Colorful Stories for Children, With the Darkest History as Backdrop
abstract: Whimsical children’s books signed El Pintor were a success in the Netherlands during World War II. Behind the pseudonym was a Jewish couple who used the proceeds to help the resistance.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — During World War II, a clutch of whimsical children’s books were published in the Netherlands under a pen name, El Pintor. One book shows children flying on the backs of sparrows. In another, they float, attached to balloons. There is a pop-up book with people and animals nestled in trees and an activity book with paper cutouts.

headline: How to Grow Dahlias? A Ceramist Has Some Advice for You
abstract: Frances Palmer has been making ceramics and growing dahlias in her Connecticut garden for three decades: “They’re just so joyous.”
lead_paragraph: It’s time to unpack the dahlias, and Frances Palmer finds herself surrounded by 25 sizable cardboard cartons full of tubers that she dug up and then stored last fall in the frost-proof cellar of her barn.

headline: The Tree of Life Synagogue Shooting Could Have Destroyed My Family — but Jewish Tradition Rejects the Death Penalty
abstract: It is in the divine realm, not the human one, that justice will be served.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — In nearly three decades together, I had never seen my husband, Jon, who is a rabbi, leave Shabbat services before all his congregants had gone home. But on the morning of Oct. 27, 2018, while I was still dawdling over breakfast and the newspaper, I heard the door open only an hour after he had left the house to go to the Tree of Life synagogue.

headline: China Detains Taiwan-Based Publisher in National Security Investigation
abstract: Li Yanhe’s publishing company put out books that often cast a critical eye on China’s ruling Communist Party. He disappeared while on a trip to China.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — A Taiwan-based publisher who disappeared while in China has been detained for suspected violations of security laws, Chinese authorities confirmed on Wednesday, fanning concerns in Taiwan that Beijing is sending a warning to the island’s vibrant publishing sector.

headline: South Africa’s Shifting Stance on a Sensitive Question: Quit the I.C.C.?
abstract: As the International Criminal Court seeks to arrest Vladimir Putin, South Africa objects to its “unfair treatment” of some countries, but sends mixed signals about withdrawing.
lead_paragraph: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa said on Tuesday that his party, the African National Congress, had decided “it is prudent” to withdraw from the International Criminal Court — only for representatives for him and the party to later clarify that neither was actually advocating quitting the court, at least for now.

headline: Voters Are Wary of Biden. Here’s Why He Might Win Anyway.
abstract: The president’s bid for re-election could be stronger than polls suggest.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has announced that he will seek another term in the Oval Office, despite the fact that he will be 81 on Election Day 2024.

headline: Virginia Man Pleads Guilty to Trafficking Turtles
abstract: Stanlee Fazi admitted that he had bound the turtles in socks and shipped them from his Virginia home, making about $12,700 in the scheme, the Justice Department said.
lead_paragraph: A man in Virginia who illegally caught and sold turtles across the United States has pleaded guilty to conducting a trafficking scheme that made him thousands of dollars and sent many of the animals to Asia, where they are in high demand as pets, the Justice Department said Monday.

headline: Biden’s Quiet Re-election Strategy
abstract: As Biden starts his campaign, we ask why he doesn’t spend more time in the public eye.
lead_paragraph: The biggest reason that many Democratic officials are nervous about President Biden’s age is not his ability to do the job in a second term.

headline: U.K. Blocks Microsoft’s $69 Billion Bid for Activision, a Blow for Tech Deals
abstract: The decision barring the takeover of a big video game publisher is a major victory for proponents of regulating tech giants, which have faced obstacles in the United States.
lead_paragraph: British antitrust regulators dealt a major setback on Wednesday to Microsoft’s plans to acquire the video game giant Activision Blizzard for $69 billion, blocking the proposed deal and handing a notable win to government enforcers around the world who want to rein in Big Tech.

headline: N.Y.C. Libraries Stave Off Sunday Closings in Adams’s New Budget Plan
abstract: The mayor had faced growing outrage over budget cuts to New York City libraries that would have forced many branches to close on weekends.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams announced on Wednesday that he would exempt New York City’s public libraries from his latest round of threatened budget cuts, sparing them from closing many of their branches on weekends.

headline: Mystery of Ex-Dictator’s Whereabouts Adds to Crisis in Sudan
abstract: After speculation that Omar Hassan al-Bashir, who had been serving a prison sentence, had been freed, the army said that he was being held in a military hospital but provided no evidence.
lead_paragraph: As Sudan is ripped apart in a battle between rival generals, one question was swirling around the country on Wednesday: Where is the former dictator Omar Hassan al-Bashir?

headline: Relations between China and Ukraine have been uncertain since Russia’s full-scale invasion.
abstract: President Xi Jinping of China and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine last communicated in January 2022, less than two months before Russia invaded.
lead_paragraph: The last time President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, communicated, they celebrated 30 years of diplomatic ties, hailing their “deepening political mutual trust” and their people’s “profound friendship.”

headline: Facing China, the Philippines and U.S. Join in Biggest Military Drill Yet
abstract: After years of saying it would not choose sides, the Philippines is now asserting a need to stand up to China’s territorial moves in the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: When China’s foreign minister visited the Philippines last weekend, he had a stern message for President Ferdinand E. Marcos Jr. of the Philippines: It was vital that Manila “properly handle issues” related to Taiwan and the South China Sea, and follow through on its earlier commitment not to choose sides, he said.

headline: $450,000 Homes in Georgia, Maryland and Washington
abstract: A townhouse in Atlanta, a 19th-century home in Frederick and a Craftsman bungalow in Spokane
lead_paragraph: This townhouse is one of the largest in the complex and sits at the back, on a quiet cul-de-sac. It is about 15 minutes from downtown Atlanta and a five-minute drive from the Works, a mixed-use development with wine bars, breweries and offices. Two Publix grocery stores are about a mile away.

headline: 6 Podcasts for the Fashion-Conscious, and Curious
abstract: These shows examine breaking news in the style industry, the place of clothing in pop culture, and the forces that shape what we wear.
lead_paragraph: Fashion, being a visual medium with a relatively niche audience, may not appear to be the most conducive subject matter for a podcast. But in a peak podcast era, where there seems to be a show for everything, style has no shortage of audio content.

headline: Meet Jelly Roll, the Rapper Turned Country Singer Rousing Nashville
abstract: The 38-year-old artist born Jason DeFord has been turning his struggles into music for years. Now it has a bit more twang, and a lot more attention.
lead_paragraph: At the CMT Music Awards this month, the least likely nominee turned into the night’s biggest story.

headline: Dads Still Get Extra Leisure Time. Moms Are Still Subsidizing It.
abstract: Mothers continue to work around the clock. The pandemic didn’t change that.
lead_paragraph: Last week, President Biden signed an executive order meant to make child care more accessible and affordable. Though it remains to be seen how much of this order will go into effect, or what impact it will have, it’s an indication that solving the child care crisis is somewhere on the priority list. It’s pretty much the first glimmer of hope for a more functional child care system since Build Back Better’s demise, and a sign that the Biden administration is paying attention to the ways parents have struggled since the pandemic started in early 2020.

headline: The U.K. Deals a Huge Blow to Microsoft’s $69 Billion Activision Bid
abstract: The British antitrust watchdog blocked the takeover attempt, in a decision that will be closely watched in Washington and Brussels.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s mergers regulator on Wednesday blocked Microsoft’s $69 billion takeover bid for Activision Blizzard, ruling that buying the maker of “Call of Duty” would give the tech giant too much control of the thriving market for cloud-based video games.

headline: A Difficult A’s Season Takes a Miserable Turn for Oakland Fans
abstract: The Oakland Athletics agreed last week to buy land on the Las Vegas Strip with plans to move there by 2027.
lead_paragraph: After flirting with Las Vegas for nearly two years, the Oakland Athletics announced last week that they had agreed to buy land near the Las Vegas Strip in the hopes of playing in a new ballpark there by 2027.

headline: A Fake Craigslist Ad Costs a New Hampshire Man His Right to Vote
abstract: By violating the state’s election laws, a man who included a candidate’s phone number in a false Election Day ad has lost his right to vote.
lead_paragraph: On the day of a special election in New Hampshire in April 2021, Michael Drouin posted a fake advertisement on Craigslist offering a free trailer and listed the phone number of Bill Boyd, a candidate for a state House seat.

headline: Why Is My Boyfriend Pursuing Other Options After Planning a Summer With Me?
abstract: A reader is left to make new arrangements after learning that her boyfriend, who had agreed to live with her for the summer, was jockeying for an internship in Washington.
lead_paragraph: My boyfriend and I planned to live together this summer in the town where he goes to college. I lined up a job there months ago; he was going to take classes. But I just discovered he also applied for an internship at NASA in Washington. (He made the first cut.) I’m happy for him, but also upset. If he’s not going to be at school, there’s no reason for me to be there. So, I quickly created a backup plan to do paid research at my school and work on a farm. I can also apply for a grant to cover my living expenses, but only if I commit now. My boyfriend still doesn’t know whether he got the NASA job. I was looking forward to spending the summer with him. Now, I’m not so sure. Thoughts?

headline: Navalny, Top Kremlin Critic, Says New Charge Could Jail Him for Life
abstract: The jailed Russian opposition leader said he faced a terrorism case that he described as “absurd.”
lead_paragraph: Aleksei A. Navalny, the jailed Russian opposition leader, said on Wednesday that Russian authorities had initiated “absurd” new terrorism charges against him that could lead to life in prison.

headline: Pope Gives Women a Vote in Influential Meeting of Bishops
abstract: The move is an important step by Francis as he strives for greater inclusiveness.
lead_paragraph: ROME — When Francis became pope a decade ago, his inclusive tone and openness to change fueled expectations among many Catholic women about a greater role for them in the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Why Do Apes Like to Spin? Maybe for the Same Reasons as People.
abstract: Videos of both captive and wild nonhuman primates suggest an enjoyment of the dizzy buzz that comes from whirling in circles.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, a gorilla named Zola gained internet fame when the Calgary Zoo posted a video that showed him spinning in circles on his knuckles and heels with what appeared to be a huge grin on his face. Zola, the so-called break-dancing gorilla, returned in 2017, this time in a video showing him whirling around a kiddie pool with a level of wild enthusiasm rivaling the most committed human dancer at an all-night rave.

headline: 10 Easy Lunch Ideas
Our Best Lemon Desserts
Is Natural Wine Actually Better for You?
The Best Glazed Ham Recipe
‘Hot Ones’ Was a Slow Burn All Along
Gerard Piqué Has Seen Soccer’s Future
Reducing Heart Attack Risk: Statins vs. Supplements
Central Banker to Britons: You’re Worse Off. Accept It.
abstract: The comment, from the Bank of England’s chief economist, was offered as a way to curb inflation. But the message has fallen flat.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of England’s chief economist has a harsh message for Britons: “Someone needs to accept that they’re worse off.”

headline: House G.O.P. Passes Debt Limit Bill, Paving the Way for a Clash With Biden
abstract: House Republicans narrowly passed a bill to raise the debt ceiling while cutting spending by nearly 14 percent over a decade. President Biden has vowed to veto the measure.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House on Wednesday narrowly passed Republicans’ bill to raise the debt ceiling while cutting spending and unraveling major elements of President Biden’s domestic agenda, in a G.O.P. bid to force Mr. Biden to negotiate over spending reductions or risk a catastrophic debt default.

headline: Nicolas Cage, Ranked From Wild to Mild
abstract: With the release of “Renfield,” we look at 10 of the actor’s performances from the last decade that range from subdued to off the deep end.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1980s, Nicolas Cage got his first big breaks in Martha Coolidge’s “Valley Girl” and Amy Heckerling’s “Fast Times at Ridgemont High,” films that zeroed in on the peculiar allure of his dopey bad boy persona. Watching him was like eating a banana split: You tasted something nutty, sweet, indulgent, all-American.

headline: In an Indian Village, Cultivating Girls’ Big-League Dreams
abstract: A new $500 million women’s cricket league is offering the kind of opportunities that never existed before in India. The girls of one Punjab village are ready.
lead_paragraph: The girls arrive at the makeshift cricket ground on their bicycles, a narrow file of white athletic uniforms breezing down a dirt track that cuts through lush wheat fields in India’s Punjab region. They wear their names and numbers on their backs, their hair tied in long, neat braids. The youngest is 9, the oldest 14.

headline: In Turn to Deterrence, Biden Vows ‘End’ of North Korean Regime if It Attacks
abstract: During a state visit at the White House, Mr. Biden and President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea sought to bolster America’s nuclear umbrella guarding against threats from the North.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden moved on Wednesday to bolster the American nuclear umbrella guarding South Korea and vowed that any nuclear attack by North Korea would “result in the end” of the government in Pyongyang, underscoring a broad turn from diplomacy to deterrence in response to the threat from the volatile dictatorship.

headline: Designers and Meghan Markle Like the Taste of Her Cakes
abstract: The Duchess of Sussex, Simone Rocha and Christopher Kane are fans of desserts by Claire Ptak, who is publishing her fifth cookbook in May.
lead_paragraph: Claire Ptak first learned about Meghan Markle through Ms. Markle’s former lifestyle blog, The Tig, a so-called hub for the discerning palette that she started in 2014.

headline: Your Next Fitness Coach Could Be a Robot
abstract: A.I. fitness trainers are here, at a fraction of the price of human coaching. But how useful are they?
lead_paragraph: Hiring a personal trainer is one of the best ways to stay consistent with your workout, push your limits and try new things. But it often costs more than $100 a session, and getting to and from the gym can be time consuming.

headline: ‘Enjoy Your Ride!’: Kids With Autism Have a Message for Transit Riders
abstract: Transit agencies across the country are broadcasting public service announcements recorded by children with autism for Autism Awareness Month.
lead_paragraph: When Ellison Chang, 7, recently recorded a public service message asking New York City subway riders not to hold the train doors open, he added his own personal greeting at the beginning: “What’s up, chicken wing!”

headline: Is Tom Ford Saying Farewell to Fashion With His Surprise ‘Final Collection’?
abstract: The designer leaves his brand with a trio of videos, a legacy and a last implicit word.
lead_paragraph: Well, that was anticlimactic.

headline: Curried Cauliflower Salad Sandwiches Freshen Up a Lunch Classic
abstract: Also bright (and yellow): Bengali-style fish with mustard oil, no-bake mango-lime cheesecake.
lead_paragraph: Who would have thought that curried chicken salad, that darling of the 1980s fancy picnic scene, was ready for a makeover? Ham El-Waylly, that’s who. In his brilliant new recipe (above), he swaps out the chicken for roasted, charred cauliflower, creating a meatless classic brimming with texture: crunchy toasted walnuts, crisp chunks of apples and sweet, chewy raisins. For the dressing, mayonnaise and yogurt are stained yellow with curry powder, which also adds its lingering flavor. It’s a delightful sandwich for spring.

headline: What Was Your Mother Right About?
abstract: We want to hear from you.
lead_paragraph: What, exactly, does your mother know best? Have you ever told her? For Mother’s Day, The New York Times is inviting you to share instances — big and small — when she provided keen insight.

headline: Germany Deems Youth Wing of Far-Right Party an Extremist Group
abstract: The party, Alternative for Germany, has been accused of radicalizing in recent years. Its youth wing is a threat to German democracy, the country’s domestic spy agency now says.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany’s domestic intelligence agency on Wednesday classified the youth wing of a prominent far right nationalist party as an extremist group that threatens the constitution, dealing another blow to an organization that has come under increasing scrutiny over concerns of radicalization.

headline: Judge Calls Trump’s Posts on Rape Case ‘Entirely Inappropriate’
abstract: After the former president called the trial of E. Jean Carroll’s allegation a scam, Judge Lewis Kaplan said he might be trying to influence the jury.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of E. Jean Carroll’s testimony in Trump rape case.

headline: Disney Sues DeSantis Over Control of Its Florida Resort
abstract: The company claimed “a targeted campaign of government retaliation,” which it said stemmed from its criticism of a contentious state education law.
lead_paragraph: Last year, under pressure from its employees, Disney criticized a Florida education law prohibiting classroom discussion of sexual orientation and gender identity for young students. Almost instantly, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida started calling the company “Woke Disney” and vowing to show it who was boss.

headline: Work, Love, Dignity and Play: 10 Key Harry Belafonte Songs
abstract: He began his career during the 1950s folk revival and continued to record — and helped orchestrate “We Are the World” — while pursing his many other artistic and political interests.
lead_paragraph: Music was the springboard for Harry Belafonte’s lifework: a career that leveraged cultural recognition toward political goals, and that recognized artistic achievements as both pleasures in themselves and symbols to wield.

headline: Review: Byronic Heroism Can’t Save ‘Sardanapal’ in Berlin
abstract: The director and star of the Volksbühne’s new show, based on a play by Lord Byron, picked up another role when one of the lead actors was missing in action.
lead_paragraph: Before the curtain rose at the Berlin Volksbühne for Friday’s premiere of “Sardanapal,” inspired by Lord Bryon’s 1821 play “Sardanapalus,” the audience learned that one of the show’s lead actors, Benny Claessens, was “not doing well.” In heroic, Byronic fashion, the show’s director and lead Fabian Hinrichs rescued the evening by jumping into the fray and assuming his absent co-star’s role, along with his own.

headline: A Rocket Took Off From Sweden. Part of It Landed in Norway.
abstract: The research rocket landed in a mountain range across the border, creating some rare friction between the two neighbors, with Norway saying protocols hadn’t been followed.
lead_paragraph: When Sweden sent a research rocket 155 miles into the air at 7:20 a.m on Monday, the expectation was that it would land in the same country from which it had been launched.

headline: He Calls the Shots for New York’s Governor. He Lives in Colorado.
abstract: Adam Sullivan holds deep influence over Gov. Kathy Hochul, her administration and campaign team, even as skepticism mounts over his judgment and distance from New York.
lead_paragraph: With the Democratic nomination all but assured last spring, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York and her campaign team began to plot a pre-emptive television ad to protect against Republican attacks already bubbling up around rising crime.

headline: Can I Edit Pink Hair Out of My Daughter’s Wedding Photos?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether it’s acceptable to digitally alter someone’s appearance.
lead_paragraph: My daughter recently got married in Washington, D.C., and it was a beautiful day. There was a freak snowstorm, however, that put a layer of white snow down before the ceremony.

headline: In Searing Detail, Trump’s Accuser Tells Her Story
abstract: E. Jean Carroll, who says Donald Trump raped her, told a chilling story on the stand. The former president harangued her from outside the courtroom.
lead_paragraph: The writer E. Jean Carroll on Wednesday told a Manhattan jury a harrowing story of being raped in the mid-1990s by Donald J. Trump in a department-store dressing room — describing a brutal attack that she tried to fight off by stamping on his foot and that has left her traumatized for decades.

headline: A Newspaper Was Planning Its Last Edition. Then the Press Caught Fire.
abstract: For years, the Montclair Local bucked trends and delivered a weekly print edition to subscribers. The end of its run came with a new challenge.
lead_paragraph: In 2017, a tech executive and his wife from New Jersey with a spare fortune to invest in local news and nostalgia started a weekly print newspaper covering their beloved Montclair, an affluent commuter town some 30 minutes from Manhattan.

headline: Emily Meggett, Matriarch of Gullah Geechee Cuisine, Is Dead at 90
abstract: She never used a recipe in cooking, but she published a best-selling cookbook that documented the Gullah Geechee food of the coastal South.
lead_paragraph: Emily Meggett, a Southern home cook who never measured her ingredients or used recipes but became one of America’s most important Gullah Geechee cooks and last year published a best-selling cookbook on Gullah Geechee cuisine, died on Friday at her home in Edisto Island, S.C. She was 90.

headline: How to Become Top Dog at Tiles
abstract: Get tips and tricks for the game from its creator.
lead_paragraph: Many of our solvers like to push themselves and see how fast or how deep they can get into a puzzle. Tiles is meant to be a relaxing game or to keep your hands busy while you listen to music or a podcast. This hasn’t stopped players from finding ways to challenge and enrich themselves.

headline: Kaiser Permanente to Acquire Geisinger
abstract: The California health care organization will create a new nonprofit that aims to acquire a half-dozen additional community health systems.
lead_paragraph: Kaiser Permanente, a large California-based health care group with 39 hospitals and 24,000 doctors, said on Wednesday that it expected to acquire Geisinger Health, a smaller East Coast group, in an effort to develop a new company that would operate nonprofit community health systems.

headline: Biden’s Bid for Re-election, and His Age
abstract: Readers disagree about whether concerns about the president’s age are warranted. Also: Theater unions; China’s population.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Man vs. Mouse: Ron DeSantis Finds Taking On Disney Is a Dicey Business
abstract: Republicans are increasingly taking on corporations they denounce as “woke.” The Florida governor is just the latest to find that it isn’t easy.
lead_paragraph: When Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida went to war against Disney over what he labels its “woke” corporate sensibility and its criticism of state policies, Tim Wildmon was cheering from the sidelines.

headline: It’s Bready. It’s Cheesy. It’s One of Kenji López-Alt’s Favorite Breakfasts.
abstract: A dairy-rich soup from Colombia, changua can be divisive, and deeply lovable.
lead_paragraph: The first time I tasted changua, a dairy-rich Colombian soup, my wife, Adri, a Bogotana from the heart of changua country, grimaced as I swirled the golden yolk of a poached egg through some half-melted cheese. She pulled a sour face as I sopped up the milky broth, seasoned with cilantro and green onions, with a chunk of bread. She pretended, I think, to suppress a gag as I ate it and continued until I finished.

headline: ‘Love & Death’ and the Feminine Urge to Commit Murder
abstract: The HBO Max true-crime docudrama joins a recent crop of fact-based series about women who kill or who kill by proxy.
lead_paragraph: On June 13, 1980, Candy Montgomery, a homemaker and mother of two in a North Texas exurb, dropped her two children and one of their friends at church, picked them up for swimming lessons and then took them to see “The Empire Strikes Back.” At some point in the late morning, she also killed Betty Gore, the mother of that friend, striking her with an ax 41 times in the utility room of the Gore home.

headline: 3 Teens Charged With Murder in Rock-Throwing Spree That Killed Colorado Driver
abstract: Alexa Bartell, 20, was driving in Jefferson County when her Chevrolet Spark was struck by a large rock, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Three teenagers have been charged with first-degree murder in connection with a rock-throwing spree on Colorado roads last week that led to the death of one driver, the authorities said.

headline: How Much Do Voters Really Care About Biden’s Age?
abstract: The evidence suggests it may end up mattering less to voters than their responses to polls indicate.
lead_paragraph: Many Americans say they do not want President Biden to run for re-election, and his age is a big reason. In an NBC News poll released last weekend, 70 percent of adults said Mr. Biden, who is 80, should not run again. Asked if age was a factor, 69 percent of them said yes. Other recent surveys detect a similar lack of enthusiasm, with many voters — including around half of Democrats — calling him too old to seek the White House again.

headline: The Boston Symphony Finds Surprises and Strengths in New Music
abstract: Over two nights at Carnegie Hall, the Boston Symphony Orchestra presented the New York premieres of works by Thierry Escaich and Thomas Adès.
lead_paragraph: When orchestras come to Carnegie Hall, their programs typically tell you two things: who they are and what they can do.

headline: Judge Sentences Trump Allies in ‘We Build the Wall’ Scheme
abstract: Andrew Badolato was sentenced to three years in prison and Brian Kolfage four years and three months, after being accused of channeling donor contributions into their own pockets.
lead_paragraph: In 2019, Brian Kolfage, an Air Force veteran injured in Iraq, formed a nonprofit group to construct the border barrier that then-President Donald J. Trump had promised. It was called simply We Build the Wall.

headline: Ukraine Has Nearly All Combat Vehicles Allies Promised, NATO Says
abstract: Gen. Christopher Cavoli, also the top commander of U.S. forces in Europe, made the comments to the House Armed Services Committee.
lead_paragraph: Nearly all the combat vehicles Ukraine’s Western allies promised to deliver in time for Kyiv’s expected spring counteroffensive have arrived, NATO’s top military commander said on Wednesday.

headline: Boat Sinks in Mediterranean, and at Least 55 People Drown
abstract: The accident is the latest in a series of recent deadly accidents involving migrants trying to reach Europe.
lead_paragraph: At least fifty-five people drowned after their boat sank off the coast of Libya, the United Nations migration agency said on Wednesday, the latest in a series of deadly accidents in just a few days involving migrants trying to cross the Mediterranean to Europe.

headline: Freedom and the American Flag Dominate First Ad for Biden
abstract: The ad, paid for by the Democratic National Committee, tries to take back the mantle of patriotism often claimed by Republicans, leaning heavily on images of the flag and of the Capitol riot.
lead_paragraph: The first television advertisement for President Biden’s re-election campaign aired on Wednesday, an opening salvo that leans heavily on images of the American flag, warns of domestic threats to democracy and repeatedly invokes the word “freedom.”

headline: Street Chaos and Long Hours Push Farmers’ Market Workers to Unionize
abstract: Working at a New York City farmers’ market is not as idyllic as it might seem, employees say. Now they are unionizing, and their employer will recognize their unit.
lead_paragraph: One day last year, a man was slashed as he walked through the Union Square Greenmarket, collapsing to the ground as blood seeped through his sliced-open clothes. One of the first to respond to the chaotic scene was a market employee working an already hectic 12-hour day.

headline: ‘Wynonna Judd: Between Hell and Hallelujah’ Review: The Show Must Go On
abstract: A documentary about the country star, whose mother and singing partner, Naomi Judd, died last year, mostly fails to kindle unguided emotions.
lead_paragraph: As portrayed in the new documentary “Wynonna Judd: Between Hell and Hallelujah,” the country artist Wynonna Judd experiences, in real time, a cruel kind of suffering. Her mother and longtime singing partner, Naomi Judd, died by suicide last year. In the director Patty Ivins Specht’s film, Wynonna is left to pick up the pieces.

headline: A ‘Steak’ Dinner With Vegetarians in Mind
abstract: Cheese-topped cauliflower, roasted to perfection, anchors this springy three-course meal from David Tanis.
lead_paragraph: After the long, gray winter, outside is where I want to be more and more. And somehow all I want to eat is vegetables, perhaps as a kind of tonic.

headline: What Is the Synod of Bishops?
abstract: The assembly includes bishops from all over the world and takes years to prepare for. For the first time, an upcoming synod will allow women and laypeople to vote.
lead_paragraph: The Synod of Bishops is a religious assembly of bishops from all over the world who gather in Rome to discuss issues vital to the Roman Catholic Church and act as an advisory body to the pope. The word synod means “coming together.” It stems from ancient Greek, and is a combination of the word “together” and “road” or “way.”

headline: Where Were the Gatekeepers?
abstract: Finding lessons in the firing of Tucker Carlson.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, I was having a conversation with Pavithra Suryanarayan, a political scientist at the London School of Economics, about what fuels far-right populism, when she suddenly stopped, midsentence, and gasped.

headline: Who’s to Blame for a Million Deaths?
abstract: While fingers are pointed at Trump and Fauci, the virus was an unbeaten foe.
lead_paragraph: “Something clearly went wrong,” Anthony Fauci told me, reflecting on the long pandemic, in an interview for The New York Times Magazine. “I don’t know exactly what it was.”

headline: Biden Welcomes South Korean President to White House
abstract: President Biden and President Yoon Suk Yeol celebrated the 70-year alliance between the United States and South Korea.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and President Yoon Suk Yeol celebrated the 70-year alliance between the United States and South Korea.

headline: The Housing Market Has Cooled, but It’s Not Frozen
abstract: Higher mortgage rates have tethered millions of people to their homes, but that’s not the whole story.
lead_paragraph: Let’s say you would like to move but you’re handcuffed to your house by a low mortgage rate. If you move now, you’ll have to pay a much higher interest rate on your next home loan.

headline: Jai Paul Emerges, Tentatively, for His First Headlining Concert
abstract: After two appearances at the Coachella festival this month, the enigmatic British producer and singer brought an evening of nostalgia to Knockdown Center in Queens.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday night at Knockdown Center in Queens, nearly 2,000 people were handed something fragile and entrusted — implicitly implored — not to break it.

headline: Kevin Durant and Russell Westbrook Evoke Their Early Promise, Just Not Together
abstract: Durant’s Suns bested Westbrook’s Clippers in the first round of the playoffs, but the former teammates held their own.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Russell Westbrook sprinted to steal the ball from Kevin Durant, sending Durant flying to the floor on his backside.

headline: Heat Pump Maker’s $13.3 Billion Sale Raises Questions in Germany
abstract: Carrier Global Corp., plans to acquire a unit of Viessmann Group that produces heat pumps, seen in Berlin as the heating solution for Germany’s green future.
lead_paragraph: The critical importance of heat pumps to the German economy was underscored this week when the sale of a family-owned maker of the heating machines to a U.S. company prompted a review by the government in Berlin.

headline: ‘Fatal Attraction’ Review: Here’s Why She Did It
abstract: A somber, psychology-heavy series tries to take the “erotic thriller” out of the erotic thriller.
lead_paragraph: When is a rabbit an Easter egg? When it hops onscreen in “Fatal Attraction,” the oddly tranquil new series inspired by the infamous, bunny-boiling 1987 film of the same title.

headline: Oklahoma Panel Declines to Spare Death Row Prisoner Richard Glossip
abstract: Recent investigations have cast doubt on his conviction for arranging the 1997 murder of a motel owner. His execution is scheduled for next month.
lead_paragraph: A divided Oklahoma panel declined on Wednesday to recommend clemency for Richard Glossip, a death row prisoner whose case has been taken on by a diverse range of supporters, including state lawmakers, Kim Kardashian and the Republican state attorney general, who argued that it would be “a grave injustice” to put him to death.

headline: Montana G.O.P. Bars Transgender Lawmaker From House Floor
abstract: The move was the culmination of a weeklong battle between House leadership and Representative Zooey Zephyr after her impassioned comments over a bill that would prohibit care for transgender minors.
lead_paragraph: HELENA, Mont. — The Montana House of Representatives took the extraordinary step on Wednesday of blocking a transgender lawmaker from the House floor for the remainder of the legislative session after an escalating standoff over her remarks on transgender issues in House debate.

headline: A reporting team for an Italian newspaper comes under fire in southern Ukraine, and one journalist is killed.
abstract: Another reporter was hospitalized in the city of Kherson and described the attack to the paper, La Repubblica.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — A Ukrainian journalist working with the Italian newspaper La Repubblica was killed and his Italian colleague was injured on Wednesday when they came under attack as they traveled to the city of Kherson in southern Ukraine, the newspaper reported.

headline: Gov. Jim Justice Is Expected to Announce Senate Run for Joe Manchin’s Seat
abstract: Mr. Manchin is viewed as one of the most vulnerable Democrats in next year’s elections, in a state, West Virginia, that has overwhelmingly trended red.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jim Justice of West Virginia is set to announce a Senate campaign on Thursday, giving Republicans a strong recruit against Senator Joe Manchin III, one of the most vulnerable Democrats up for re-election in 2024.

headline: The House narrowly passes Republicans’ debt limit bill, heading for a showdown with Biden.
abstract: The House on Wednesday narrowly passed Republicans’ bill to raise the debt ceiling while cutting spending and unraveling major elements of President Biden’s domestic agenda, in a G.O.P. bid to force the president to negotiate over spending cuts or risk a catastrophic debt default.
lead_paragraph: The House on Wednesday narrowly passed Republicans’ bill to raise the debt ceiling while cutting spending and unraveling major elements of President Biden’s domestic agenda, in a G.O.P. bid to force the president to negotiate over spending cuts or risk a catastrophic debt default.

headline: Karl Berger, 88, Who Opened Minds of Generations of Musicians, Is Dead
abstract: A vibraphonist, pianist, educator and musical thinker, he co-founded the Creative Music Studio to bring musicians together to foster improvisation.
lead_paragraph: Karl Berger, a musician, composer, educator and author who taught improvisation and his concept of an attentive, collaborative “music mind” to generations of musicians and artists at his Creative Music Studio near Woodstock, N.Y., died on April 9 in Albany, N.Y. He was 88.

headline: Supreme Court Wary of Windfall in Seizure of Condo for Unpaid Taxes
abstract: The justices considered the constitutionality of letting states keep all the proceeds of the sale of confiscated property even when they far exceed the taxpayer’s debt.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court seemed united on Wednesday, in the last scheduled argument of its current term, in its distaste for how county officials in Minnesota had treated a 94-year-old woman who had stopped paying property taxes on her condominium after moving into an assisted-living center.

headline: A Fresh View of an Increasingly Familiar Black Hole
abstract: Radio astronomers have captured a wide-angle image of one of the most violent locales in the cosmos.
lead_paragraph: A patch of pure nothing in a faraway galaxy has lately become the gravitational center of attention for radio astronomers. That would be a giant black hole, with the gravity of 6.5 billion suns, that spits high-energy particles from the center of the galaxy Messier 87, which lies some 50 million light-years from Earth.

headline: What to Know About Danny Masterson’s Second Rape Trial
abstract: A retrial is underway on charges that the actor from “That ’70s Show” raped three women in the early 2000s. The first trial ended in a hung jury in November.
lead_paragraph: Opening arguments began on Monday in a retrial of the rape case against Danny Masterson, the actor known for his role in the sitcom “That ’70s Show,” nearly five months after the first trial ended in a deadlocked jury.

headline: Documents Reflect Persistent, if Unfounded, Speculation on Putin’s Health
abstract: Leaked materials include unsubstantiated intelligence about a Ukrainian politician’s claim that the Russian leader is undergoing chemotherapy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than a year, the notion that Vladimir V. Putin is seriously ill has been a subject of lurid speculation, internet video forensics — and potential wartime propaganda, even though U.S. officials say there is no evidence the Russian leader is dying.

headline: The Phone Call Between Belafonte and King That Changed Both Men’s Lives
abstract: Martin Luther King was already famous for his charisma. But Harry Belafonte’s lifelong support brought a different kind of star power.
lead_paragraph: One spring day in 1956, Harry Belafonte picked up the phone and heard the voice of Martin Luther King Jr.

headline: New Rules for Power Plants Could Give Carbon Capture a Boost. Here’s How.
abstract: The technology has struggled to gain traction, but strict new emissions limits for gas and coal stations could encourage broader adoption.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration’s plan to limit, for the first time, greenhouse gas emissions from existing power plants could hinge on the ability of plant operators to capture carbon dioxide before it is pumped into the atmosphere.

headline: Meta Returns to Growth After Struggling With Falling Sales
abstract: The owner of Facebook and Instagram reported a 3 percent revenue increase in the latest quarter, even as spending rose and profits fell.
lead_paragraph: The debate over whether Meta is in decline may become quieted, at least for now.

headline: What Do You Know?
abstract: In his latest work, Simon Winchester devotes his anecdotal powers to why, how and how often we know what we do.
lead_paragraph: Simon Winchester has made an illustrious career of raising anecdote to art. To wit: A correspondence between a British don and an asylum inmate about lexicography became “The Professor and the Madman,” his first blockbuster. His other books of travel, geography, history and biography all illuminate the past via an unerring sense of what might interest, provoke and engage, profiting from a former foreign correspondent’s understanding of how to tease a story out of facts.

headline: Xi and Zelensky Talk at Last, but Words Are Chosen Carefully
abstract: Volodymyr Zelensky has urged discussions with Xi Jinping since the Russian invasion, but in its official account of the phone call, China left out two words: “Russia” and “war.”
lead_paragraph: Two months after issuing a vague plan for ending the war in Ukraine, China’s leader, a close ally of Vladimir V. Putin, on Wednesday acceded to repeated requests from the Ukrainian president to talk.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing: A U.S.-South Korea Nuclear Agreement
abstract: Also, Xi Jinping called Volodymyr Zelensky.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. has agreed to give South Korea a central role in the strategic planning for the use of nuclear weapons in any conflict with North Korea. In return, South Korea agreed to not pursue its own nuclear arsenal.

headline: A Century-Old Vaccine Fails to Protect Against Covid
abstract: Early in the pandemic, scientists began testing an old TB vaccine against the coronavirus. But the trial enrolled fewer participants than expected as new Covid vaccines were introduced, and no discernible effect was found.
lead_paragraph: An old tuberculosis vaccine known to bolster the immune system did not prevent Covid infections among health care workers, scientists reported on Thursday.

headline: Biden Says He Has a ‘Job to Finish,’ Downplaying Concerns Over His Age
abstract: The president also said that he was not the only Democrat who could beat Donald J. Trump, but that “I know the danger he presents to our democracy.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Wednesday dismissed polling that suggests Americans are not interested in seeing a rematch between him and former President Donald J. Trump, saying he has a “job to finish” in bolstering the economy and reasserting U.S. leadership abroad.

headline: Manchester City, Relentless and Ruthless, Strolls Past Arsenal
abstract: Reeling in the league leaders after a season-long chase, City won Wednesday and, with less than 10 games left, positioned itself to claim its third straight Premier League title.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — Quite when Arsenal knew, for certain, that it was all over is difficult to pinpoint absolutely. There was still faith, presumably, after Manchester City’s first goal, which arrived roughly 370 seconds into a game that had been billed — for weeks — as the Premier League’s great championship showdown.

headline: High-Ranking Iranian Cleric Gunned Down by Bank Guard
abstract: The killing comes as attacks on clerics are on the rise, following months of angry protests against the theocratic government.
lead_paragraph: A senior Iranian cleric and member of a powerful government committee was shot and killed by a security guard at a bank in the northern province of Mazandaran on Wednesday, according to the Iranian authorities.

headline: Tweets Become Harder to Believe as Labels Change Meaning
abstract: The elimination of check marks that helped authenticate accounts has convulsed a platform that once seemed indispensable for following breaking news.
lead_paragraph: In the 24 hours after Twitter last week eliminated the blue check mark that historically served as a means of identifying public agencies, at least 11 new accounts began impersonating the Los Angeles Police Department.

headline: Ex-Harvard Professor Sentenced in China Ties Case
abstract: Charles Lieber had been seen as a potential Nobel Prize-winning chemist, but was convicted in 2021 of lying to federal investigators and failing to report income.
lead_paragraph: Charles Lieber, a former Harvard chemistry professor, was sentenced on Tuesday for making false statements to the U.S. government and for failing to declare large sums of money he’d been paid as part of a contract with a Chinese program, Thousand Talents, and Wuhan University in China.

headline: Spielberg, Who Regrets Cutting ‘E.T.’ Guns, Says Don’t Revise Old Works
abstract: “No film should be revised based on the lenses we now are either voluntarily or being forced to peer through,” Steven Spielberg said.
lead_paragraph: Steven Spielberg, one of Hollywood’s most powerful filmmakers, has weighed in on a cultural debate about whether to change books, films and television shows to make them more palatable to contemporary sensibilities, calling such revisions “censorship.”

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Michigan Students Sue School District Over ‘Let’s Go Brandon’ Ban
abstract: The case is seeking declaration that requiring students to remove “Let’s go Brandon” attire violated the students’ First Amendment rights.
lead_paragraph: A mother of two students in Howard City, Mich., filed a lawsuit claiming the public school district violated her sons’ First Amendment rights by asking them to remove sweatshirts with the slogan “Let’s go Brandon” on them.

headline: The Full Guest List for Biden’s State Dinner With South Korea
abstract: The Bidens invited more than 180 guests, including government officials, athletes, business leaders and prominent Asian Americans.
lead_paragraph: The White House invited more than 180 guests to the state dinner hosted by President Biden for President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea on Wednesday night, including government officials, athletes, business leaders and prominent Asian Americans. Here is the full list of those invited as provided by the White House.

headline: On His First Day as a Jet, Rodgers Says the Team Can Win It All
abstract: “I really try and listen to the signs and synchronicities that the universe puts in our face every day,” Aaron Rodgers said, “and this was basically the direction that everything was pointing.”
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Aaron Rodgers walked into the Jets’ facility on Wednesday for his introductory news conference to applause from staffers after they watched a montage of his highlights from his 18-year tenure with the Green Bay Packers.

headline: Trump Seeks to Have Intelligence Agencies Take Over Documents Inquiry
abstract: Lawyers for the former president asked a House committee to pass legislation stripping the Justice Department of authority to investigate his handling of classified material after leaving office.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump asked lawmakers on Wednesday to place the intelligence community in charge of assessing Mr. Trump’s handling of the classified documents found in his possession after leaving office, saying Congress should strip the Justice Department of authority to run the investigation.

headline: Fact-Checking the Kickoff to Biden’s Re-election Campaign
abstract: The president omitted key context when discussing the federal deficit, exaggerated his approval ratings and misstated his family history.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since announcing his re-election bid on Tuesday, President Biden has repeated familiar boasts about his economic record and recounted folksy, personal anecdotes — and sometimes veered from the facts.

headline: First Republic Lurches as It Struggles to Find a Savior
abstract: The bank is sitting on big losses and paying more to borrow money than it is making on its loans to homeowners and businesses.
lead_paragraph: First Republic Bank is sliding dangerously into a financial maelstrom, one from which an exit appears increasingly difficult.

headline: On Eve of Trial, Discovery of Carlson Texts Set Off Crisis Atop Fox
abstract: Private messages sent by Tucker Carlson that had been redacted in legal filings showed him making highly offensive remarks that went beyond the comments of his prime-time show.
lead_paragraph: The day before Dominion Voting Systems’ defamation trial against Fox News was set to begin in a Delaware courthouse, the Fox board of directors and top executives made a startling discovery that helped lead to the breaking point between the network and Tucker Carlson, one of its top stars.

headline: April Stevens Dies at 93; Her ‘Deep Purple’ Became a Surprise Hit
abstract: Her unusual version of the standard, which she recorded with her brother, Nino Tempo, reached No. 1 on the Billboard chart in 1963 and won a Grammy.
lead_paragraph: April Stevens, whose rushed recording of “Deep Purple” with her brother, Nino Tempo, became a chart-topping single in 1963 and won a Grammy Award, died on April 17 at her home in Scottsdale, Ariz. She was 93.

headline: In Bipartisan Bill, Senators Urge Supreme Court to Adopt Ethics Code
abstract: Senators Angus King and Lisa Murkowski introduced the bill after recent revelations about Justices Thomas and Gorsuch.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two senators introduced a bipartisan bill on Wednesday aimed at forcing the Supreme Court to establish an ethics code after recent revelations that some justices had not disclosed gifts, travel and property deals.

headline: California Reconsiders Its Boycotts of States Over Their L.G.B.T.Q. Laws
abstract: San Francisco repealed its ban on city business with conservative states, and California may follow suit by rescinding a similar prohibition on state-funded travel.
lead_paragraph: Furious that North Carolina approved legislation to ban transgender people from using public bathrooms that aligned with their gender identity, Democratic leaders in San Francisco and the California State Capitol quickly moved in 2016 to ban their employees from traveling to states deemed hostile to L.G.B.T.Q. communities.

headline: China’s Search Engines Have More Than 66,000 Rules Controlling Content, Report Says
abstract: Researchers from the Citizen Lab, a cybersecurity research group, found that the most diligent censor in China is Microsoft’s search engine Bing, the only foreign search engine operating in the country.
lead_paragraph: China’s internet censorship is well known, but a report has quantified the extent of it, uncovering more than 66,000 rules controlling the content that is available to people using search engines.

headline: Rockets Introduce Coach Ime Udoka, but Say Little About His Misconduct
abstract: The Celtics fired Udoka in February after he violated team policies. Udoka said at a news conference for his hiring as Houston’s coach that he had worked on himself and become a better person.
lead_paragraph: The Houston Rockets owner Tilman Fertitta asked fans to be forgiving on Wednesday as he introduced the team’s new head coach, Ime Udoka, who had been suspended and then fired by the Boston Celtics within the past year for violating unspecified team policies.

headline: Brazilian Judge Bans Telegram App Amid School Attacks Inquiry
abstract: The Federal Police requested the app’s suspension because it failed to provide complete user data from two group chats that the authorities said had inspired an attack.
lead_paragraph: BRASILIA — A judge in Brazil on Wednesday ordered that the messaging app Telegram be blocked throughout the country, as the authorities investigate neo-Nazi groups that they say have used the platform to incite school attacks.

headline: House Republicans Pass Debt Ceiling Bill
abstract: The Republican bill, which would raise the debt limit and cut spending, appears to have no chance of approval in the Democratic-led Senate.
lead_paragraph: The Republican bill, which would raise the debt limit and cut spending, appears to have no chance of approval in the Democratic-led Senate.

headline: When Megamergers Fall Apart
abstract: British officials blocked Microsoft’s $69 billion acquisition of Activision, raising the question how often deals fall apart?
lead_paragraph: British antitrust regulators on Wednesday blocked Microsoft’s $69 billion bid to buy the gaming giant Activision Blizzard, threatening to kill the deal entirely. The ruling raises a broader question: How often do deals fall apart after they’re signed?

headline: Fugees Rapper Pras Michel Found Guilty in Illegal Foreign Influence Scheme
abstract: Mr. Michel took orders, and millions of dollars, from a Malaysian financier who sought to gain political influence in the U.S., prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A founding member of the hip-hop group the Fugees was found guilty in federal court on Wednesday of orchestrating a sprawling international conspiracy that used millions of dollars worth of foreign money for illegal lobbying and campaign contributions, the Justice Department said.

headline: Biden’s Highest Hurdle Isn’t Age. It’s Passion.
abstract: Biden has to demonstrate more fight for more progressive policies.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden is officially running for re-election, and his candidacy will put some Democratic voters — those not only skittish about his age but also about his passion for policy — in a vise: They recognize the threat from the leading Republican candidates, but they’ve been underwhelmed by Biden, who’d be 82 at the start of a second term.

headline: Harlem Businesses Sue to Stop Cannabis Dispensary Planned for 125th Street
abstract: The lawsuit suggests more problems may be ahead for New York State’s troubled rollout of the recreational marijuana industry.
lead_paragraph: A prominent Harlem business group filed a lawsuit on Wednesday seeking to stop the state from building a recreational cannabis dispensary on the neighborhood’s main street, adding to the challenges faced by New York State in its rollout of the recreational marijuana industry.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Town Wrestles With Its Dark Past: Nazis and Soviets
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, April 27, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “If you just look at the trees and buildings, everything here looks OK, but if you know the history of this place it makes your skin crawl.”

headline: Corrections: April 27, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, April 27, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about a labor shortage threatening annual forestry targets for the Menominee Tribe misstated the name of a organization that promotes responsible forestry. It is the Forest Stewardship Council, not the Forest Steward Council.

headline: Efforts to Restrict Transgender Health Care Face Pushback in Three States
abstract: As Republicans move to limit gender-transitioning treatments, a sustained veto in Kansas, a judge’s order in Missouri and federal intervention in Tennessee have emerged as barriers.
lead_paragraph: Republican efforts to restrict gender-transitioning treatment hit roadblocks in three states on Wednesday. Kansas lawmakers failed to override the Democratic governor’s veto of a bill that would have banned the care for minors, the Justice Department sued Tennessee over its new ban and a Missouri judge temporarily blocked the enforcement of an emergency rule that would have restricted treatment for transgender children and adults.

headline: Alleviates Pain a Little
abstract: Michael Schlossberg is pushing boundaries.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: ‘New York, New York’ Review: The Big Apple, Without Bite
abstract: Based loosely on the 1977 film, a show about performers making it in the big city comes to St. James Theater with the sharper edges of its source material sanded off.
lead_paragraph: There’s a big new Broadway musical called “New York, New York,” and it’s based on the Martin Scorsese film bearing the same title.

headline: Korean Dressing, Irish Poetry and ‘American Pie’: A State Dinner of Harmony
abstract: The White House festooned the East Room with cherry blossoms, and President Biden enticed President Yoon Suk Yeol to belt out Don McLean’s iconic song about the day the music died.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Presidents traditionally invite foreign leaders visiting the White House to give a statement in front of cameras, to make a toast at a dinner, maybe even to address reporter questions. They don’t usually ask them to sing.

headline: Let Us Show You How GPT Works — Using Jane Austen
abstract: An interactive explanation of how language models learn to mimic language, from Shakespeare to Star Trek.
lead_paragraph: An interactive explanation of how language models learn to mimic language, from Shakespeare to Star Trek.

headline: Trump Can’t Stop Pence From Testifying to Jan. 6 Grand Jury, Court Rules
abstract: The ruling by an appeals court paved the way for the former vice president to appear before a federal grand jury as early as this week.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court rejected on Wednesday night an emergency attempt by former President Donald J. Trump to stop former Vice President Mike Pence from testifying in front of a grand jury investigating Mr. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election.

headline: The President Whose Birthday (Today) Is Widely Ignored
abstract: Ulysses S. Grant is finally getting his due, moving one step closer to becoming a general of the armies of the United States. His birthday is a holiday in Ohio.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Today we’ll observe the birthday of an Army general who has moved one step closer to a big promotion in the last year — even though he died in 1885. We’ll also look at Mayor Eric Adams’s decision to rescind a round of cutbacks for public libraries.

headline: ‘Baseball Size’ Hail Falls in Texas as Storms Whip Across South
abstract: Thunderstorms disrupted travel and large hail was observed in Texas and Florida. Tornado watches in the region expired early Thursday morning.
lead_paragraph: Hail as large as baseballs fell in Texas on Wednesday, officials said, as thunderstorms whipped across parts of the American South and forecasters warned of possible damage from flying debris and flash flooding in low-lying areas over the next two days.

headline: Airman Accused of Leak Has History of Racist and Violent Remarks, Filing Says
abstract: Prosecutors accused Jack Teixeira of trying to cover up his actions and described a possible propensity toward violence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jack Teixeira, the Massachusetts Air National Guardsman accused of posting classified documents online, repeatedly tried to obstruct federal investigators and has a “troubling” history of making racist and violent remarks, Justice Department lawyers said in a court filing late Wednesday.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Xi Jinping, the leader of China, spoke with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine yesterday in a one-hour telephone call, the first known contact between the two leaders since Russia invaded Ukraine last year. Zelensky had made repeated requests to talk to the Chinese leader.

headline: They Wrecked Britain, and They’re Not Going Anywhere
abstract: Obituaries for the Conservative Party are premature.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As Britain prepares for the coronation of its new king, an end-of-days feeling is sweeping the nation. In an atmosphere of social unrest, economic dysfunction and government corruption, deep political disillusionment has set in. The Conservative Party is polling 15 points behind the opposition, and the popularity of Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, the Conservatives’ fifth leader in seven years, remains obstinately low. After years of Tory misrule, the opinion of the British public seems clear: We’ve had enough.

headline: Climate Change Made East Africa’s Drought 100 Times as Likely, Study Says
abstract: The findings starkly show the misery that the burning of fossil fuels, mostly by rich countries, inflicts on societies that emit almost nothing by comparison.
lead_paragraph: Two and a half years of meager rain have shriveled crops, killed livestock and brought the Horn of Africa, one of the world’s poorest regions, to famine’s brink. Millions of people have faced food and water shortages. Hundreds of thousands have fled their homes, seeking relief. A below-normal forecast for the current rainy season means the suffering could continue.

headline: Word of the Day: phlegmatic
abstract: This word has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word phlegmatic has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 10 in “Benfica and the Great Champions League Question: What If?” by Rory Smith:

headline: U.S. Consulting Firm Is the Latest Target of a Chinese Crackdown
abstract: Bain & Company employees were questioned less than a month after Chinese police officials raided the Beijing offices of another U.S. advisory firm.
lead_paragraph: In the latest official scrutiny of a prominent American business in China, the authorities visited the Shanghai offices of the U.S. management consulting firm Bain & Company this month to question its employees.

headline: Alone and Together
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration or, tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Inside the Defamation Trial That Was ‘Over Before It Began’
abstract: Katie Robertson, a media reporter for The New York Times, was in court in Wilmington, Del., when Fox News and Dominion Voting Systems agreed to settle for a staggering $787.5 million.
lead_paragraph: The first sign that things were amiss came Sunday evening, the day before what was supposed to be the most high-profile media defamation trial in decades was set to begin.

headline: Karl and Anna, a Love Story in Clothes
abstract: Anna Wintour remembers the designer Karl Lagerfeld, and how she’s worn his clothes to the most important events in her life.
lead_paragraph: Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue and global editorial director of Condé Nast, has been the maestro of every Met Gala since 1999. But this time, it’s personal.

headline: Southern Storms Hit Florida and Texas With Large Hail
abstract: In Texas, vehicles were damaged, flights were canceled and thousands of people lost power. In Florida, a meteorologist filmed a “river of ice” floating down his street.
lead_paragraph: In Texas, vehicles were damaged, flights were canceled and thousands of people lost power. In Florida, a meteorologist filmed a “river of ice” floating down his street.

headline: Seth Meyers Speculates About Why Fox Dumped Tucker Carlson
abstract: Meyers joked that “firing Tucker for racism now after tolerating it for so long would be like canceling ‘Sesame Street’ because you just found out they were puppets.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: A Symbol of Loss in Almost Every Ukrainian Kitchen
abstract: Soledar, crushed in Russia’s long assault on Bakhmut, was only a little town. But its salt is a national staple, and a matter of pride.
lead_paragraph: “Salt gave us work and salt gave us life,” said Ruslan, a salt miner turned soldier.

headline: Lesson Plan: A Wave of Anti-Transgender Legislation
abstract: Hundreds of laws that seek to regulate the lives of transgender youths have been proposed in state legislatures across the country. In this lesson, students explore these bills and their implications.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “G.O.P. State Lawmakers Push a Growing Wave of Anti-Transgender Bills” by Maggie Astor (Note: You can also listen to this article.)

headline: N.F.L. Draft: What to Know
abstract: Who will be taken at No. 1 overall? Which teams will come out ahead? And, in a 32-team league, why are there only 31 picks in the first round?
lead_paragraph: College football stars will take their first steps toward becoming professional football stars (or flops) at the 2023 N.F.L. draft. Expect to hear “Alabama,” “Georgia” and “Ohio State” a lot, as well as “acceleration,” “physicality” and “football I.Q.”

headline: 36 Hours in Philadelphia
abstract: Spring is synonymous with street festivals, but the city’s historic charm, world-class art and passionate cheesesteak discourse are year-round.
lead_paragraph: Spring is synonymous with street festivals, but the city’s historic charm, world-class art and passionate cheesesteak discourse are year-round.

headline: How I Hold It Together: Quiet FaceTimes and More
abstract: Nicole Stock, Well's audience editor, shares her best tips for self-care.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Stock, Well's audience editor, shares her best tips for self-care.

headline: Two Americans Take a Chance in Playa del Carmen, Mexico: Which Condo Did They Buy?
abstract: Feeling restless in Portland, Ore., a couple drove south to their favorite vacation spot and looked for a two-bedroom close to the sea for less than $300,000. Here’s what they found.
lead_paragraph: Feeling restless in Portland, Ore., a couple drove south to their favorite vacation spot and looked for a two-bedroom close to the sea for less than $300,000. Here’s what they found.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Eating Candy You Find on the Street
abstract: Can one man’s trash be another’s treat?
lead_paragraph: Katrina writes: I have no problem with eating candy I find on the street: Dum-Dums, Jolly Ranchers, Tootsie Rolls. They’re always wrapped. My partner insists they might be tainted. But if the universe is sending me candy, who am I to decline? Please rule that street candy is OK to eat and order him to buy me a bag of Dum-Dums as damages.

headline: What Is Your Reaction to the Recent Wave of Anti-Transgender Legislation?
abstract: What do you wish lawmakers knew about how bills relating to transgender people affect those your age?
lead_paragraph: Please note: Our Student Opinion questions specifically invite the voices of young people. We ask that adults respect the intent of this forum and refrain from posting here.

headline: The Middle Ages Had Horses. We Have Computer Chips.
abstract: Three new books about the history of warfare have much to tell us.
lead_paragraph: Military historians have long taught that how a society fights is linked to how it produces. In most agrarian cultures, the horse was the basic unit of power. Indeed, the Mongols, the military superpower of the Middle Ages, as it is put by Stephen Morillo, the author of WAR AND CONFLICT IN THE MIDDLE AGES (Polity, 257 pp., paperback, $26.95), may have controlled more than half the horses on the planet. Then, during the industrial age, machinery became key to combat — tanks, airplanes, steel warships and locomotives. In our emerging information age, the computer chip promises to be the foundation of military power, as contemporary militaries strive to collect oceans of data, process it and act on it before the adversary does.

headline: They’re Severely Mentally Ill. Is It Ethical to Help Them Die?
abstract: A psychiatrist’s dilemma when the most extreme option is legal.
lead_paragraph: Next year, Canada’s health care system is set to undergo a controversial change, when people struggling with severe mental illness will gain the legal right to request help from a doctor in ending their lives. Until now, medical assistance in dying — or MAID, as it’s often called — has been available in North America primarily to patients with terminal physical illnesses. The introduction of psychiatric MAID will present difficult, and different, ethical questions, especially for the doctors responsible for helping patients through this choice.

headline: The Novel That Led Abraham Verghese to a Medical Career
abstract: “I’m ashamed to say I picked up W. Somerset Maugham’s ‘Of Human Bondage’ because the title seemed promising,” says the doctor and novelist, whose new novel is “The Covenant of Water.” “While it didn’t have the lascivious content I’d imagined, it turned out to have something better: It was the book that … called me to medicine.”
lead_paragraph: The stack reflects the overlapping compartments of my life: Daniel Mason’s “North Woods” (in galley form); “Images of Memorable Cases: 50 Years at the Bedside,” by Herbert L. Fred and Hendrik A. van Dijk; “The Best Strangers in the World,” by Ari Shapiro; “The Passenger,” by Cormac McCarthy; and at the bottom, the two volumes of “Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine,” a book that I’ve had a love affair with ever since I encountered the seventh edition in 1974. My ambition is always to read it cover to cover before the next edition, but for the last five editions I haven’t come close. In my defense, it’s 4,384 pages.

headline: Poem: pour la CGT
abstract: Spare, plain-spoken and true, this is a master class on poetry’s ability to confound the easy answer.
lead_paragraph: Rod Smith’s poem is a marvel. Spare, plain-spoken and true, it is also a master class on poetry’s ability to confound the easy answer, made even more cunning by the poem’s immediate impression of simplicity. The transposition of a single line works as an amplification, not a refutation. Each stanza holds equal weight, gesturing to the necessary horizon beyond the either/or.

headline: The Dramatic, Comic, Tragic, True-Life Story Behind the Death of DVD.com
abstract: Streaming is overrated.
lead_paragraph: Netflix, which has been struggling recently, announced last week that on Sept. 29 it will cease its 25-year-old DVD-by-mail delivery business to focus on its streaming service. Whereas most functioning members of 21st-century culture greeted the news with indifference or puzzlement — “People still use DVDs?” — the announcement hit me with a jolt of dread and dismay.

headline: Confederate Tributes Are Losing Their Patron Saint
abstract: The Lost Cause myth that was used to justify honoring Robert E. Lee was bankrupt from the start.
lead_paragraph: It stands to reason that Woodrow Wilson would be the president to bring us Army bases named for traitors who waged war on this country with the goal of preserving slavery. He took office in 1913 with a team of white supremacists who announced themselves by requiring separate white and colored bathrooms in federal buildings. The Wilsonians inflicted a neo-Confederate regime on the capital that was felt in far corners of the nation.

headline: Donald Trump May Have Begun Losing
abstract: Between deterrence and history lies justice.
lead_paragraph: What’s the right form of justice for the problem of Donald Trump?

headline: Should a Biographer Have Boundaries? Jeff Benedict Says Yes.
abstract: While writing about LeBron James, the veteran author chose not to probe the identity of his subject’s father. His reasons were personal.
lead_paragraph: When you read an “unauthorized” biography, you might expect tawdry revelations. You won’t find them in “LeBron,” Jeff Benedict’s exhaustively researched and thoughtful book about LeBron James, the celebrated basketball player who is the all-time leading scorer in N.B.A. history. In fact, when it came to what the author describes in the book as “one of the great mysteries of modern sports” — the identity of James’s father — Benedict made a decision not to, as he put it in a phone interview, “excavate.”

headline: Call Them Dissidents. But Don’t Call Them Feminists.
abstract: Over the last 60 years, Brazil’s women artists made work about universal rights abuses, not gender issues, a new show finds. “It was all of us, all citizens, who didn’t have rights.”
lead_paragraph: The Brazilian artist Berna Reale sits atop a horse painted scarlet, a cage-like muzzle covering her face.

headline: Elon Musk Ramps Up A.I. Efforts, Even as He Warns of Dangers
abstract: The billionaire plans to compete with OpenAI, the ChatGPT developer he helped found, while calling out the potential harms of artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: In December, Elon Musk became angry about the development of artificial intelligence and put his foot down.

headline: The Pillow Guy and the R.N.C. Chair
abstract: Conversations with Mike Lindell and Ronna McDaniel reveal the complexities of the divisions at the heart of the G.O.P.
lead_paragraph: Throughout our reporting inside the Republican Party over the past few months, one person kept showing up: Mike Lindell, MyPillow chief executive and election denier.

headline: Lawyer Up: Class-Action Suits Are Thriving in New York
abstract: If a new consumer protection bill passes in New York State, false advertising and mislabeling cases could get another boost, experts say.
lead_paragraph: On a hot summer day, a woman walked into a gas station in the Bronx and spent $1.99 on a bag of TGI Fridays Sour Cream & Onion Potato Skins chips. She tore into the snack, looking forward to the “potato skins,” as they were marketed on the packaging in 2018, according to court documents.

headline: The Microsoft-Activision Mess Is a Blow to American Sovereignty
abstract: A former S.E.C. chief and a former White House economics chief on how progressive regulators are outsourcing U.S. regulatory policy to Europe.
lead_paragraph: Congress has given federal regulators broad authority over key areas of our society, and the actions of those regulators often have profound effects on our lives and on our future. We applaud the swift and decisive actions by financial regulators to prevent the run on Silicon Valley Bank from cascading through the regional banking system. But regulatory power is not absolute; it is granted by Congress and has strict limits, and its exercise requires due process.

headline: U.S. Economy Continues to Grow, but More Slowly
abstract: Gross domestic product increased 1.1 percent in the first quarter as consumer spending remained robust despite higher interest rates.
lead_paragraph: The housing market is slowing. Businesses are pulling back on hiring and investment. But American consumers are keeping the economy out of a recession — at least for now.

headline: ‘White House Plumbers’ Revisits the Fringes of Watergate
abstract: A new HBO “slapstick tragedy” mostly avoids the Oval Office in favor of the men who actually executed the infamous burglary that brought down a president.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On June 17, 1972, five men were arrested while breaking into the Democratic National Committee offices at the Watergate office building in Washington, D.C.

headline: Couples Welcome New York’s One-Day Officiant Law
abstract: The new law, in effect in New York on March 28, was 16 years in the making. California, Massachusetts, Vermont and Rhode Island also allow individuals to become officiants for a day.
lead_paragraph: Legislation that allows any layperson to perform a marriage on a given day in New York may not seem like a top priority in Albany. And in reality, this assumption appears to be correct: It took 16 years for legislation on a one-day designation to be signed into law.

headline: The Tiny, Tight-Lipped Circle of Aides Guiding Biden 2024
abstract: They rarely give on-the-record interviews. Only two are on Twitter. But they will be the main force behind the president’s political strategy.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden announced his re-election campaign and its top two staff members this week, the names of his closest and longest-serving advisers were not included.

headline: New York Officials Failed to Address the Housing Crisis. Now What?
abstract: The state seemed poised to take the first meaningful action in decades to address its deep housing shortage. But the plans fell apart, in yet another indictment of dysfunction in Albany.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, N.Y. — It seemed like 2023 would be the year that New York would finally take the most consequential steps in decades to address the state’s dire housing shortage.

headline: The French Artist JR Brightens the Montauk Highway
abstract: His photographic installation will illuminate the exterior of the Parrish Art Museum with an image of playful innocence.
lead_paragraph: As warmer weather draws more people to the East End of Long Island, a joyful vision will beckon across the long horizontal facade of the Parrish Art Museum in Water Mill, N.Y., that will be visible from the Montauk Highway.

headline: As Regulators Block Tech Deals, They Increasingly Look to the Future
abstract: British regulators cited the newness of the cloud gaming field to block Microsoft’s $69 billion acquisition of Activision, a shift in antitrust strategy.
lead_paragraph: As companies like Google and Facebook grew into giants in the early 21st century, regulators chose largely not to interfere in the still-young market for online services.

headline: Their Reputations Precede Them. And That’s the Problem.
abstract: When an athlete breaks the rules of the game, he or she may be judged on much more than that single act. Call it the Draymond Green Effect.
lead_paragraph: Most times in basketball, a foul is just a foul. But sometimes, it can feel like so much more: a Rorschach test unearthing a person’s biases about the game, a window into a player’s thinking, a referendum on his entire career.

headline: Stolen or Original? Hear Songs From 7 Landmark Copyright Cases.
